title: MAUI (MBI Analysis User Interface)-An image processing pipeline for Multiplexed Mass Based Imaging.
main_goals: To present MAUI, a graphical user interface-based image processing pipeline for Multiplexed Mass Based Imaging (MBI) data. MAUI facilitates pre-processing steps such as removing channel crosstalk, noise, and antibody aggregates, aiming to streamline and accelerate processing via interactive parameter tuning.

title: Coordinated Cellular Neighborhoods Orchestrate Antitumoral Immunity at the Colorectal Cancer Invasive Front.
main_goals: To re-engineer CODEX for FFPE tissue microarrays and apply it to characterize the spatial organization of the immune tumor microenvironment in colorectal cancer. The study aimed to identify distinct cellular neighborhoods, analyze their spatial relationships, and correlate these spatial features with patient survival outcomes.

title: Deep cell phenotyping and spatial analysis of multiplexed imaging with TRACERx-PHLEX.
main_goals: Develop a reproducible and user-friendly computational pipeline (TRACERx-PHLEX) for deep cell phenotyping and spatial analysis of multiplexed imaging. The pipeline integrates deep learning segmentation, automated cell-type annotation, and interpretable spatial analysis modules. It aims to provide an end-to-end solution for highly multiplexed data analysis.

title: Cellpose: a generalist algorithm for cellular segmentation.
biological_context: Varied cell types and organisms from microscopy images
main_goals: Introduce Cellpose, a generalist deep learning algorithm for robust cellular segmentation from diverse microscopy images without requiring retraining. Demonstrate its performance on a large, varied dataset and present a 3D extension that reuses the 2D model. Provide software to support community data contributions for continuous model improvement.

title: A point cloud segmentation framework for image-based spatial transcriptomics.
data_modalities_used: ['image-based spatial RNA profiling', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'In Situ Hybridization, Fluorescence']
main_goals: Introduces ComSeg, a point cloud segmentation framework for image-based spatial transcriptomics. It assigns detected RNA transcripts to individual cells directly, without priors on cell shape. Evaluated on simulated and experimental datasets, showing improved performance for segmentation and in-situ cell type calling.

title: Modeling intercellular communication in tissues using spatial graphs of cells.
main_goals: The paper introduces 'node-centric expression modeling', a method based on graph neural networks, to estimate the effects of spatial niche composition on gene expression from spatial molecular profiling data. The goal is to move beyond receptor-ligand signaling to understand intercellular communication more broadly and recover signatures of molecular communication processes.

title: Semi-automated background removal limits data loss and normalizes imaging mass cytometry data.
main_goals: Investigate the impact of signal intensity fluctuations on IMC data. Explore different normalization strategies. Propose a semi-automated background removal workflow using publicly available tools to normalize IMC data, reduce data loss, and improve sample comparison.

title: SPARK-X: non-parametric modeling enables scalable and robust detection of spatial expression patterns for large spatial transcriptomic studies.
biological_context: Diverse tissues (mouse cerebellum, olfactory bulb, human ovarian neoplasms)
main_goals: Introduce SPARK-X, a non-parametric method for detecting spatially expressed genes. The method is designed for large spatial transcriptomic studies, focusing on scalability, robustness, effective type I error control, and high power while providing computational savings. The goal is to identify spatial expression patterns and derive biological insights.

title: Spatially informed clustering, integration, and deconvolution of spatial transcriptomics with GraphST.
biological_context: Multiple tissue types including brain, embryo, lymph node, and breast tumor
main_goals: Introduce GraphST, a graph self-supervised contrastive learning method for spatial transcriptomics. Improve spatial clustering, multisample integration, and cell-type deconvolution by learning informative spot representations. Demonstrate superior performance compared to existing methods across various tissue types and platforms.

title: Spatial transcriptomics at subspot resolution with BayesSpace.
biological_context: brain, melanoma, invasive ductal carcinoma, ovarian adenocarcinoma
main_goals: Introduce BayesSpace, a fully Bayesian statistical method for spatial transcriptomic data. Use spatial information for resolution enhancement and clustering analysis. Benchmark BayesSpace and demonstrate its ability to resolve tissue structure and transcriptional heterogeneity at subspot resolution.

title: Spage2vec: Unsupervised representation of localized spatial gene expression signatures.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'in situ RNA detection', 'spatial gene expression']
main_goals: Present spage2vec, an unsupervised segmentation-free method using graph representation learning to create lower dimensional representations of local spatial gene expression. Apply it to mouse brain data to show it captures meaningful biological spatial information of localized gene expression signatures.

title: Quantitative characterization of cell niches in spatially resolved omics data.
biological_context: Mouse embryonic development, Human cancers (tumor niches), Whole mouse brain
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Clustering', 'Dimension Reduction', 'Spatial Reference Mapping']
main_goals: Introduce NicheCompass, a graph deep-learning method to characterize cell niches in spatial omics data by modeling cellular communication. The method learns interpretable cell embeddings to identify and quantitatively characterize niches based on signaling events. It aims to be scalable and applicable across different tissues, disease contexts, and data modalities.

title: Explainable multiview framework for dissecting spatial relationships from highly multiplexed data.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: Introduce MISTy, a flexible, scalable, and explainable machine learning framework for analyzing spatial omics data. It uses a multiview approach to dissect spatial relationships and interactions from different contexts and can relate findings to clinical features.

title: NeST: nested hierarchical structure identification in spatial transcriptomic data.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This paper introduces NeST, a computational method for identifying nested hierarchical spatial structure in spatial transcriptomic data using coexpression hotspots. It also performs spatial analysis of cell-cell interactions de novo. The method is demonstrated on 2D and 3D ST datasets.

title: Identification of spatially associated subpopulations by combining scRNAseq and sequential fluorescence in situ hybridization data.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: Developed a method to integrate scRNAseq and spatial transcriptomics data (sequential FISH) using a hidden Markov random field model. The method distinguishes intrinsic and extrinsic effects on gene expression to identify spatially associated subpopulations and spatial domains.

title: CellPhoneDB v5: inferring cell-cell communication from single-cell multiomics data.
main_goals: This paper introduces CellPhoneDB v5, an updated bioinformatics toolkit for inferring cell-cell communication from single-cell data. It expands the interaction database, adds features for tailored queries, incorporates spatial and ATAC-seq data for prioritizing interactions, and introduces a visualization module. The goal is to enhance the precision of cell-cell communication inference.

title: Visual analysis of mass cytometry data by hierarchical stochastic neighbour embedding reveals rare cell types.
biological_context: Immune cell composition in gastrointestinal disorders and other conditions studied with mass cytometry
main_goals: Introduce Hierarchical Stochastic Neighbor Embedding (HSNE) for analyzing large, high-dimensional mass cytometry data. Overcome scalability limitations of t-SNE. Demonstrate HSNE's ability to identify rare cell populations.

title: Knowledge-graph-based cell-cell communication inference for spatially resolved transcriptomic data with SpaTalk.
main_goals: To present SpaTalk, a novel knowledge-graph-based method for inferring spatially resolved cell-cell communications from spatially resolved transcriptomic data. The tool models and scores ligand-receptor-target networks by integrating spatial mapping and cell-type deconvolution. It is benchmarked against existing methods and applied to various spatial datasets.

title: Sparcle: assigning transcripts to cells in multiplexed images.
main_goals: Introduce Sparcle, a probabilistic model to reassign transcripts to cells in multiplexed spatial images. Overcome limitations of strict segmentation-based assignment by incorporating gene covariation and spatial features. Improve per-cell transcript quantification, cell boundary delineation, and downstream analyses like clustering.

title: BIDCell: Biologically-informed self-supervised learning for segmentation of subcellular spatial transcriptomics data.
main_goals: The paper introduces BIDCell, a self-supervised deep learning framework using biologically-informed loss functions for segmenting subcellular spatial transcriptomics data. It incorporates cell-type data and morphology information. The goal is to improve cell segmentation accuracy compared to existing methods across various tissue types and platforms.

title: NaroNet: Discovery of tumor microenvironment elements from highly multiplexed images.
main_goals: To develop NaroNet, a deep learning framework for modeling the multi-scale tumor microenvironment from multiplexed images. It aims to unsupervisedly learn which cell phenotypes, neighborhoods, and interactions influence patient labels and provide interpretable predictions.

title: Mapping cellular interactions from spatially resolved transcriptomics data.
data_modalities_used: ['spatially resolved transcriptomics', 'single-cell resolution spatial transcriptomics', 'MERSCOPE', 'Vizgen', 'CosMx', 'NanoString', 'Xenium', '10x', 'Transcriptome', 'Gene Expression Profiling']
main_goals: Introduce Spacia, a multiple-instance learning framework for mapping cell-cell communication from single-cell resolution spatially resolved transcriptomics data. Highlight its advantages over existing methods, including handling multiple senders and avoiding prior databases. Evaluate Spacia's performance on MERSCOPE, CosMx, and Xenium data.

title: Unknown Title (from curated_dois.txt)
main_goals: N/A

title: An end-to-end workflow for multiplexed image processing and analysis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Image Processing', 'Image Segmentation', 'Feature Extraction', 'Spatially Resolved Single-Cell Analysis', 'Data Quality Assessment', 'Preprocessing', 'Dimensionality Reduction', 'Single-Cell Visualization', 'Phenotyping', 'Community Analysis', 'Cellular Neighborhood Detection', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This paper presents an end-to-end workflow for processing and analyzing multiplexed tissue imaging data at single-cell resolution. It integrates existing tools for tasks such as segmentation, feature extraction, and spatially resolved single-cell analysis. The workflow aims to be user-friendly and customizable, facilitating the application of various computational methods.

title: Data-Driven Phenotypic Dissection of AML Reveals Progenitor-like Cells that Correlate with Prognosis.
biological_context: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML), healthy and leukemic cells, hematopoietic progenitors
main_goals: Develop PhenoGraph, a data-driven algorithmic approach for defining cellular phenotypes in high-dimensional single-cell data (mass cytometry). Apply this method to AML to identify progenitor-like cells and correlate their phenotype with patient prognosis. Introduce new methods for large-scale single-cell heterogeneity analysis.

title: LIANA+ provides an all-in-one framework for cell-cell communication inference.
main_goals: To introduce LIANA+, a scalable framework for inferring cell-cell communication from single-cell and spatially resolved data. It unifies established methodologies, integrates a rich knowledge base, supports multi-condition datasets and multi-omics, and provides an all-in-one solution for intercellular communication analysis.

title: Compensation of Signal Spillover in Suspension and Imaging Mass Cytometry.
main_goals: Develop a novel bead-based compensation workflow and R-based software to estimate and correct for signal spillover in suspension and imaging mass cytometry. Characterize spillover properties and demonstrate the method's utility to improve data quality, simplify panel design, and allow flexibility in antibody-metal pairing.

title: Unknown Title (from curated_dois.txt)
main_goals: N/A

title: histoCAT: analysis of cell phenotypes and interactions in multiplex image cytometry data.
main_goals: Developed an open-source computational toolbox (histoCAT) for interactive, quantitative, and comprehensive analysis of multiplex image cytometry data. The tool enables exploration of individual cell phenotypes, cell-cell interactions, microenvironments, and morphological structures within intact tissues. Demonstrated the tool's abilities using highly multiplexed mass cytometry images of human breast cancer.

title: Deciphering spatial domains from spatially resolved transcriptomics with an adaptive graph attention auto-encoder.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Denoising', 'Batch Correction', 'Clustering', 'Dimension Reduction', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: Develop STAGATE, a graph attention auto-encoder framework, to identify spatial domains and denoise spatially resolved transcriptomics data. It integrates spatial information and gene expression, adaptively learns neighboring spot similarity, and can handle 3D data and batch effects.

title: Tissue schematics map the specialization of immune tissue motifs and their appropriation by tumors.
biological_context: Human lymphoid tissue and human colorectal cancer tumor microenvironment
main_goals: The paper introduces a computational approach for constructing tissue schematics (TSs) and a biological model for interpreting them from high-parameter imaging data. This method maps the spatial assembly of cellular neighborhoods into tissue motifs. It is applied to human lymphoid tissue and human colorectal cancer to understand tissue organization and its alteration in disease.

title: SpatialDM for rapid identification of spatially co-expressed ligand-receptor and revealing cell-cell communication patterns.
main_goals: To introduce SpatialDM, a statistical model and toolbox using a bivariant Moran's statistic for rapid identification of spatially co-expressed ligand-receptor pairs, local interaction spots, and communication patterns. The method aims to be scalable and robust, enabling discovery of context-specific cell cooperation and signalling.

title: SpatialDE: identification of spatially variable genes.
main_goals: Introduces SpatialDE, a statistical test for identifying genes with spatial expression patterns in spatial omics data. It also includes a spatial gene-clustering approach for expression-based tissue histology.

title: NicheNet: modeling intercellular communication by linking ligands to target genes.
main_goals: To develop a computational method, NicheNet, for modeling intercellular communication by linking ligands to target genes. The method combines expression data with prior knowledge on signaling and gene regulatory networks to predict ligand-target links between interacting cells. It aims to infer active ligands and their gene regulatory effects on interacting cells, demonstrated using tumor and immune cell data.

title: Unknown Title (from curated_dois.txt)
main_goals: N/A

title: PENGUIN: A rapid and efficient image preprocessing tool for multiplexed spatial proteomics.
main_goals: Develop PENGUIN, a rapid, efficient, and user-friendly image preprocessing tool for multiplexed spatial proteomics data. PENGUIN performs percentile normalization and denoising without manual annotation or machine learning, aiming to improve downstream tasks like cell segmentation and phenotyping.

title: Analyzing high-dimensional cytometry data using FlowSOM.
main_goals: This paper provides a detailed protocol for analyzing high-dimensional cytometry data using the FlowSOM algorithm. It offers user guidelines, parameter descriptions, troubleshooting recommendations, and R code examples. The goal is to enable scientists without a strong bioinformatics background to analyze cytometry data using FlowSOM.

title: Unknown Title (from curated_dois.txt)
main_goals: N/A

title: Cell segmentation-free inference of cell types from in situ transcriptomics data.
main_goals: Present SSAM, a segmentation-free computational framework for identifying cell types and tissue domains from in situ transcriptomics data. The method uses multidimensional mRNA density estimation and is applicable to various techniques. It is demonstrated on mouse brain datasets to identify known and discover new cell types.

title: S<sup>3</sup>-CIMA: Supervised spatial single-cell image analysis for identifying disease-associated cell-type compositions in tissue.
data_modalities_used: ['multiplexed imaging', 'high-dimensional proteomic imaging data', 'highly multiplexed fluorescence microscopy', 'imaging mass-cytometry']
main_goals: To present S3-CIMA, a weakly supervised convolutional neural network model for detecting disease-specific spatial cell-type compositions from high-dimensional proteomic imaging data. The paper demonstrates its utility in identifying disease-associated microenvironment compositions in colorectal cancer and type 1 diabetes, evaluating it as a tool for discovering novel disease-associated spatial cellular interactions.

title: ClusterMap for multi-scale clustering analysis of spatial gene expression.
biological_context: Mouse brain, placenta, gut, human cardiac organoids, complex tissues
data_modalities_used: ['in situ transcriptomic measurements', 'spatially resolved RNA profiles', 'spatial gene expression']
main_goals: Introduce ClusterMap, an unsupervised and annotation-free computational framework for multi-scale clustering analysis of spatial gene expression data. It uses point pattern analysis and density peak clustering to identify biologically meaningful structures from subcellular to tissue levels in 2D and 3D.

title: GCNG: graph convolutional networks for inferring gene interaction from spatial transcriptomics data.
main_goals: To develop a novel method, GCNG (Graph Convolutional Neural networks for Genes), for inferring gene interactions (both within and between cells) from spatial transcriptomics data. The method encodes spatial information as a graph and uses supervised training to improve upon prior methods and propose novel extracellular interacting gene pairs.

title: Identification of spatial expression trends in single-cell gene expression data.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'sequential fluorescence in situ hybridization', 'single-cell RNA-seq']
main_goals: To introduce a novel method, trendsceek, based on marked point processes for identifying genes with statistically significant spatial expression trends. The method is shown to find spatial gradients and hot spots in spatial transcriptomic, FISH, and low-dimensional scRNA-seq data.

title: MATISSE: a method for improved single cell segmentation in imaging mass cytometry.
biological_context: Tissue complexity, development, and physiology; pathologies including autoimmunity and cancer, specifically in colorectal tissue and dense cellular areas.
main_goals: To develop MATISSE, a method combining IMC and fluorescence microscopy for improved single-cell segmentation in tissue samples. The goal is to achieve better segmentation quality and quantity compared to IMC-only methods, particularly in densely packed cellular areas, enabling more accurate tissue microenvironment analysis.

title: FICTURE: scalable segmentation-free analysis of submicron-resolution spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: various challenging tissue types (vascular, fibrotic, muscular, lipid-laden)
main_goals: Introduce FICTURE, a scalable, segmentation-free spatial factorization method for high-resolution spatial transcriptomics data. Demonstrate its efficiency and ability to analyze complex tissues where previous methods failed. Highlight its compatibility with both sequencing-based and imaging-based data.

title: Whole-cell segmentation of tissue images with human-level performance using large-scale data annotation and deep learning.
biological_context: General tissue imaging, with application to human gestation
main_goals: Develop a large-scale dataset (TissueNet) and a deep-learning algorithm (Mesmer) for whole-cell segmentation in tissue images. Achieve human-level performance and generalize across diverse tissue types and platforms. Release data, code, and models as a community resource.

title: SpaGCN: Integrating gene expression, spatial location and histology to identify spatial domains and spatially variable genes by graph convolutional network.
biological_context: Diverse tissues including human brain (Dorsolateral Prefrontal Cortex, Visual Cortex), mouse brain, and pancreatic neoplasms
main_goals: To develop SpaGCN, a graph convolutional network method for SRT data integrating gene expression, spatial location, and histology. The method aims to identify spatial domains and subsequently detect spatially variable genes through domain-guided differential expression analysis. The paper demonstrates its effectiveness and efficiency on multiple SRT datasets.

title: The covariance environment defines cellular niches for spatial inference.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: Introduce COVET for representing spatial cellular niches based on gene covariance. Develop ENVI, a conditional variational autoencoder, to jointly embed spatial and single-cell RNA sequencing data. Use ENVI to impute gene expression across the spatial modality and project spatial information onto single-cell data.

title: Modeling Cell-Cell Interactions from Spatial Molecular Data with Spatial Variance Component Analysis.
main_goals: Present Spatial Variance Component Analysis (SVCA), a computational framework for spatial molecular data. SVCA quantifies spatial variation and cell-cell interaction effects on gene expression. The paper demonstrates its application on breast cancer Imaging Mass Cytometry and imaging-derived RNA data.

title: Transition to invasive breast cancer is associated with progressive changes in the structure and composition of tumor stroma.
main_goals: To understand the changes in the tumor microenvironment (TME) accompanying the transition from DCIS to IBC using MIBI-TOF and machine learning. The study aimed to delineate TME states, identify features associated with progression, and investigate factors influencing IBC relapse.

title: Identification of spatially variable genes with graph cuts.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'single-cell gene expression with positional information']
main_goals: To present scGCO, a novel method based on fast optimization of hidden Markov Random Fields with graph cuts, for identifying spatially variable genes. The paper aims to demonstrate scGCO's superior performance, accuracy, robustness, and scalability compared to existing methods.

title: Inference and analysis of cell-cell communication using CellChat.
main_goals: Develop CellChat, a tool to quantitatively infer and analyze intercellular communication networks from scRNA-seq data. It predicts signaling inputs/outputs, coordinates, classifies pathways, and delineates conserved/context-specific pathways using network analysis and pattern recognition. The goal is to discover novel communications and build cell-cell communication atlases.

title: Cell segmentation in imaging-based spatial transcriptomics.
data_modalities_used: ['in situ sequencing', 'multiplexed RNA fluorescent hybridization', 'MERFISH', 'immunostaining', 'spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: Introduce Baysor, a novel 2D/3D cell segmentation method for imaging-based spatial transcriptomics using transcriptional composition and morphology. Evaluate its performance against existing tools and demonstrate its broad applicability across different protocols.

title: Probabilistic cell typing enables fine mapping of closely related cell types in situ.
main_goals: Introduce pciSeq, a probabilistic cell typing method for in situ sequencing data. This method leverages scRNA-seq data to enable fine spatial mapping of closely related cell types. The method is applied to map inhibitory neurons in mouse hippocampal area CA1 and pyramidal cells in the neocortex.

title: Screening cell-cell communication in spatial transcriptomics via collective optimal transport.
main_goals: Present COMMOT, a collective optimal transport method to infer cell-cell communication in spatial transcriptomics, accounting for spatial distances and molecular competition. Introduce downstream tools for inferring spatial signaling directionality and gene regulation. Validate COMMOT on simulation and real spatial datasets.

title: BANKSY unifies cell typing and tissue domain segmentation for scalable spatial omics data analysis.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial omics', 'spatial RNA imaging', 'spatial RNA sequencing', 'spatial protein imaging']
main_goals: Introduce BANKSY, a novel framework unifying cell typing and tissue domain segmentation in spatial omics data through spatial feature augmentation. Demonstrate improved performance on diverse data, reveal biological insights, and highlight its scalability, speed, and applicability for quality control and batch correction.

title: CellSeg: a robust, pre-trained nucleus segmentation and pixel quantification software for highly multiplexed fluorescence images.
main_goals: Introduce CellSeg, an open-source, pre-trained software for nucleus segmentation and signal quantification in highly multiplexed fluorescence images. Demonstrate its robustness, performance compared to state-of-the-art methods, and accessibility for researchers with varying programming skills. Show its applicability in a CODEX pipeline for identifying cell populations.

title: Robust mapping of spatiotemporal trajectories and cell-cell interactions in healthy and diseased tissues.
biological_context: Healthy and diseased tissues (neurodevelopment, brain injury, microglia activation, cancer progression)
main_goals: Developed three computational-statistical algorithms (PSTS, SCTP, stSME) integrated into the stLearn software. These algorithms integrate gene expression, physical distance, and tissue morphology from spatial transcriptomics data to model spatial trajectories, study cell-cell interactions, and correct for technical noise, enabling robust analysis of healthy and diseased tissues.

title: Deep multimodal graph-based network for survival prediction from highly multiplexed images and patient variables.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Graph Analysis', 'Integration with other omics', 'Survival Analysis']
main_goals: Develop a deep multimodal graph-based network (DMGN) for survival prediction using highly multiplexed images and patient variables. The method integrates spatial phenotype information from images with clinical data via graph-based and clinical embedding modules. Demonstrate improved performance on public breast cancer datasets.

title: Podocyte YAP and TAZ hyperactivation drives glomerular epithelial proliferative diseases in mice and humans.
biological_context: Human kidney diseases (collapsing glomerulopathy, crescentic glomerulonephritis) and mouse models of podocyte dysfunction
main_goals: To identify common molecular drivers of glomerular epithelial proliferative diseases in humans using spatial transcriptomics and immunostaining. To validate the role of podocyte YAP and TAZ hyperactivation as a unifying driver in mouse models. To show that podocyte YAP/TAZ hyperactivation orchestrates profibrotic and pro-proliferative responses.

title: Multimodal transcriptomics identifies metallothionein as a novel pathway in primary sclerosing cholangitis.
biological_context: Primary sclerosing cholangitis and liver disease
main_goals: To localize potential disease pathways to specific microanatomical liver regions in primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) by combining spatial and single-nuclei transcriptomics. The study identified metallothionein as a novel pathway localized to the parenchyma-fibrosis interface in PSC livers, originating from APOE+ hepatocytes.

title: Integrative Spatial Proteomics and Single-Cell RNA Sequencing Unveil Molecular Complexity in Rheumatoid Arthritis for Novel Therapeutic Targeting.
main_goals: To understand molecular heterogeneity in Rheumatoid Arthritis synovium by applying spatial proteomics (LCM-MS) to specific histopathological niches and integrating the data with scRNA-seq to identify key proteins and potential therapeutic targets. This provides a more comprehensive view than bulk transcriptomics.

title: SMQVP: A Web Application for Spatial Metabolomics Quality Visualization and Processing.
main_goals: Introduce SMQVP, a web application for quality visualization and processing of spatial metabolomics data. Address challenges in data quality control and preprocessing to improve the reliability and robustness of spatial metabolomics findings. Demonstrate effectiveness through noise identification and removal, leading to improved clustering.

title: Patterning Defects in Mice with Defective Ventricular Wall Maturation and Cardiomyopathy.
main_goals: To investigate spatial gene expression patterns of cardiomyocyte markers in developing mouse ventricles, compare them to patterns observed in human fetal hearts, and examine how these patterns are altered in a mouse model of left ventricular non-compaction cardiomyopathy (LVNC) to understand the role of spatial organization in ventricular maturation and cardiomyopathy pathogenesis.

title: Muscle Spatial Transcriptomic Reveals Heterogeneous Profiles in Juvenile Dermatomyositis and Persistence of Abnormal Signature After Remission.
main_goals: This study aimed to investigate the spatial heterogeneity of molecular signature in the muscle of juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM) patients before and after treatment. It identified spatially distributed pathological signatures related to myofibrillar stress, muscle remodeling, and interferon signaling. The study also found persistence of these pathological signatures after two years of remission, paving the way for understanding pathophysiology and biomarker identification.

title: Spatiotemporal Adaptations-Driven Dynamic Thra Activation Simulates a Skin Wound Healing Response.
main_goals: The paper investigates the molecular coordination of spatiotemporal skin wound healing. It identifies the thyroid hormone receptor Thra as a key regulator of phase-coupled regeneration through distinct epidermal and dermal mechanisms, driving reepithelialization and angiogenic niche formation. The study uses various omics and model systems to confirm Thra's role and provides insights for clinical strategies.

title: Driving innovations in cancer research through spatial metabolomics: a bibliometric review of trends and hotspot.
main_goals: To conduct a bibliometric analysis evaluating development trends, key contributors, research hotspots, and future directions of spatial metabolomics in cancer research.

title: MYO1G promoter hypomethylation correlates with its mRNA expression, lymphocyte infiltration, and immunotherapy response in melanoma.
main_goals: This study investigates the biological and clinical significance of MYO1G DNA methylation and gene expression in melanoma and its immune microenvironment. It correlates MYO1G methylation and expression with immune cell infiltration, immune checkpoint expression, and clinical outcomes including immunotherapy response, aiming to identify MYO1G as a potential prognostic and predictive biomarker.

title: [Research advances in perineural invasion of pancreatic cancer].
main_goals: This review systematically analyzes the latest research advancements in perineural invasion (PNI) in pancreatic cancer. It covers various aspects including anatomical basis, molecular mechanisms, immune interactions, pain pathways, assessment, models, technology (like spatial transcriptomics), and surgical strategies, highlighting PNI's role in progression and prognosis.

title: From microbes to molecules: unveiling host-microbe interactions with spatial metabolomics.
main_goals: To review the application and potential of spatial metabolomics for understanding host-microbe interactions at a molecular level.

title: Rapid elemental imaging of copper-bearing critical ores using laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy coupled with PCA and PLS-DA.
main_goals: Apply Laser-Induced Breakdown Spectroscopy (LIBS) coupled with PCA and PLS-DA for rapid elemental imaging, pattern recognition, classification, and spatial analysis of copper-bearing critical ores. Visualize element spatial distribution using 2D mapping.

title: Single-cell and spatiotemporal profile of ovulation in the mouse ovary.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Single-Cell Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Gene Expression Profiling', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: To map the spatiotemporal profile of ovarian cell types across an ovulation time course using parallel single-cell RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics. The study identifies time-dependent transcriptional states, gene markers, and cell-cell interactions relevant to mouse ovulation, providing a resource for the scientific community.

title: AAnet resolves a continuum of spatially-localized cell states to unveil intratumoral heterogeneity.
main_goals: Introduce AAnet, a neural network method to learn archetypal cell states within a phenotypic continuum in single-cell and spatial data. Apply AAnet to cancer datasets to identify functionally important cell states, their spatial organization, and specific markers critical for tumor growth.

title: Spatial Transcriptomic Analysis Reveals Increased Adipogenesis and Triggering of the Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease Pathway in Pig-to-NHP Islet Recipients' livers During the Early Post-xenotransplant Period.
biological_context: Liver pathology and microenvironment changes following pig-to-NHP islet xenotransplantation, focusing on adipogenesis and NAFLD pathways
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Pathway Analysis']
main_goals: To analyze the hepatic pathology in pig-to-NHP islet recipients using spatial transcriptomics. To identify transcriptional changes in the liver, particularly near the islet implantation site. To reveal increased adipogenesis and NAFLD pathways in the liver post-transplantation.

title: CellSeg3D, Self-supervised 3D cell segmentation for fluorescence microscopy.
biological_context: Cell and nuclei segmentation in various biological samples (e.g., Platynereis, Mouse skull) for neuroscience and general biology
main_goals: Introduce novel 3D models (WNet3D, SwinUNetR) for self-supervised and supervised 3D cell segmentation. Develop the CellSeg3D Python package and napari plugin for accessibility. Address the scarcity of 3D ground truth data by creating a new dataset and demonstrating the performance of the self-supervised WNet3D model.

title: spCLUE: a contrastive learning approach to unified spatial transcriptomics analysis across single-slice and multi-slice data.
main_goals: Introduce spCLUE, a new computational framework combining multiple techniques for spatial transcriptomics analysis. The main goals are to integrate data across single and multi-slice samples and identify consistent spatial domains. The framework aims to provide accurate and interpretable results and outperform existing methods.

title: CellMemory: hierarchical interpretation of out-of-distribution cells using bottlenecked transformer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Dimension Reduction', 'Clustering', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell Type Identification']
main_goals: Introduce CellMemory, a bottlenecked Transformer for hierarchical interpretation of out-of-distribution cells. Demonstrate its performance on spatial transcriptomics data. Apply it to identify and characterize malignant cells and their founder cells.

title: Spatial metabolomics informs the use of clinical imaging for improved detection of cribriform prostate cancer.
main_goals: Identify metabolic markers for cribriform prostate cancer using spatial metabolomics. Evaluate whether clinical imaging techniques based on these markers can differentiate cribriform from noncribriform prostate cancers.

title: DNA-barcode-based Multiplex Immunofluorescence Imaging to Analyze FFPE Specimens from Genetically Reprogrammed Murine Melanoma.
biological_context: Murine melanoma model treated with nanoparticles
main_goals: Introduce a DNA-barcode-based multiplex imaging technique (Co-Detection-by-indEXing) for spatial proteomics of FFPE specimens. Present a protocol for developing antibody panels for murine FFPE. Describe an image analysis pipeline using open-source tools for annotating tissues, segmenting cells, processing data, phenotyping, and quantifying spatial metrics.

title: Single cell sequencing and spatial multiomics of diabetic kidney segmentation insights zonation-specific therapeutic metabolic pathways.
main_goals: To understand the spatial metabolic heterogeneity and compartmentalized pathway dysregulation in diabetic nephropathy using spatial multi-omics and single-cell transcriptomics. The study aims to identify zonation-specific metabolic pathways, region-enriched proteins, and contributing cell types, and evaluate a therapeutic intervention's effect on spatial metabolic perturbations.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics reveal a stress-induced EMT-like epithelial subset driving immune activation in silica-injured lung.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: To investigate epithelial dynamics in silica-induced lung injury using scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics. The study identifies a stress-induced EMT-like epithelial subset (C0) that drives immune activation and tissue remodeling through specific cell-cell interactions.

title: Entropy measures for quantifying complexity in digital pathology and spatial omics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Heterogeneity Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This review explores the use of entropy measures in digital pathology and spatial omics to quantify complexity, disorder, and heterogeneity. It synthesizes theoretical foundations, spatially-aware metrics, and applications in mapping tissue heterogeneity, profiling microenvironments, and informing biomarker discovery. It also discusses challenges and future directions for entropy-based methods.

title: Single-Cell RNA Sequencing and Spatial Transcriptomics Reveal a Novel Mechanism of Oligodendrocyte-Neuron Interaction in Cognitive Decline After High-Altitude Cerebral Edema.
biological_context: High-altitude cerebral edema (HACE) and cognitive decline in mouse hippocampus
main_goals: To investigate the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying cognitive decline after High-altitude cerebral edema (HACE) using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics in a mouse model. The study aims to reveal how transcriptomic changes and interactions between oligodendrocytes and neurons contribute to HACE-induced cognitive impairment.

title: Fusion of spatiotemporal and network models to prioritize multiscale effects in single-cell perturbations.
biological_context: Developmental and disease processes including epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition in lung cancer, CD8+ T-cell therapy effects in murine melanoma, and inflammation and tissue repair in colitis.
main_goals: To introduce Perturb-STNet, a novel framework that leverages network-based spatiotemporal models to rank spatial and temporal differentially expressed regulators due to perturbation. It identifies significant regulators, estimates dynamic regulatory networks, and provides visualizations for understanding disease progression and therapeutic responses.

title: The use of single-cell and spatial omics to study copy number variants.
biological_context: Psychiatric disorders, brain dysfunction, neurodevelopment related to Copy Number Variants (CNVs)
main_goals: Review the current progress in single-cell and spatial omics and propose a strategy for implementing these technologies in Copy Number Variant (CNV) research. The goal is to help identify driver genes and molecular mechanisms underlying brain dysfunction associated with CNVs.

title: Interferon-responsive HEVs drive tumor tertiary lymphoid structure formation and predict immunotherapy response in nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
main_goals: The paper aims to reveal characteristics of tumor tertiary lymphoid structures (TLSs) in nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell data. It identifies interferon-responsive high endothelial venules (IFN-HEVs) linked to CXCL9 and CXCR3+CD4+ T cell recruitment within TLSs. The study correlates these IFN-HEV related phenotypes with patient survival and immunotherapy response and develops a predictive scoring system (CTRscore) for ICB outcomes.

title: Laser capture microdissection-assisted gas chromatography-triple-quadruple mass spectrometry for spatial metabolic profiling of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.
main_goals: This study developed a novel analytical strategy based on laser capture microdissection-assisted gas chromatography-triple-quadruple mass spectrometry for spatial metabolic profiling. The method was optimized and validated for robustness and clinical applicability. It was applied to characterize metabolic profiles of different morphologies in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

title: Comparison of spatial transcriptomics technologies using tumor cryosections.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Data Integration', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: Compare five spatial transcriptomics technologies (RNAscope HiPlex, Molecular Cartography, Merscope, Xenium, Visium) using MBEN cryosections. Devise approaches and provide a framework to evaluate technology performance (sensitivity, specificity, attributes) for guiding method selection. Demonstrate how reimaging improves cell segmentation and enables integration of additional omic readouts.

title: The critical role of PDGFRa + Sca1 + fibroblasts in angiogenesis and vascular repair in the corpus cavernosum.
biological_context: Erectile dysfunction in corpus cavernosum of mice
main_goals: Identify specific fibroblast subsets in the corpus cavernosum associated with erectile dysfunction using scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics. Characterize PDGFRa+ Sca1+ fibroblasts and their role in angiogenesis and vascular repair, suggesting their depletion contributes to ED pathogenesis and identifying them as potential therapeutic targets.

title: Unveiling spatial domains from spatial multi-omics data using dual-graph regularized ensemble learning.
main_goals: Develop a novel ensemble learning framework (SMODEL) based on dual-graph regularized anchor concept factorization for detecting spatial domains from spatial multi-omics data. SMODEL uses an element-wise weighted ensemble strategy and leverages anchor concept factorization and dual-graph regularization. Evaluate SMODEL on diverse real and simulated datasets.

title: Field and farm-level data on agricultural land use for the European Union.
main_goals: To present field-level land-use data from the IACS system for the European Union. The paper describes the data source, pre-processing, harmonisation workflow, and exemplifies potential uses with maps.

title: Deciphering Macrophage-Fibroblast Cross Talk in Obesity-Induced Adipose Tissue Fibrosis: Insights From Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptomics.
biological_context: Obesity-Induced Adipose Tissue Fibrosis; Macrophage-Fibroblast Cross Talk
main_goals: To decipher the cross talk between macrophages and fibroblasts in the context of obesity-induced adipose tissue fibrosis. The study utilizes single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to gain insights into this biological process.

title: SGCD: High-Resolution Spatial Domain Characterization via Data Interpolation and Cell-Type Deconvolution.
biological_context: human dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, mouse brain, pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma, breast cancer
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'gene expression', 'cell type information', 'spatial location data']
main_goals: Propose SGCD, a novel method for high-resolution tissue spatial domain identification. The method integrates interpolated gene expression, deconvolved cell type information, and spatial location data. It uses graph contrastive learning to accurately delineate complex spatial domains.

title: Deciphering Cell Type Abundance in Proteomics Data Through Graph Neural Networks.
main_goals: Propose GraphDEC, a novel graph neural network method for deciphering cell type proportions in proteomic data. It uses an autoencoder and GNN to learn representations from sample relationships and proteomic data. The method aims to achieve state-of-the-art deconvolution performance and generalization by integrating multiple loss functions and handling batch effects.

title: RESIGN: Alzheimer's Disease Detection Using Hybrid Deep Learning based Res-Inception Seg Network.
main_goals: To propose a novel deep learning model, RESIGN, combining ResNet-LSTM, Inception V3, and SegNet, for detecting Alzheimer's disease from MRI images. The model aims to improve early diagnosis accuracy through hybrid feature extraction, classification, and segmentation.

title: Cellular hierarchy framework based on single-cell and bulk RNA sequencing reveals fatty acid metabolic biomarker MYDGF as a therapeutic target for ccRCC.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Functional Enrichment', 'Clustering', 'Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: Investigate fatty acid metabolism heterogeneity in ccRCC using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. Identify FAM-related genes via various computational methods and machine learning. Validate MYDGF as a key FAM-related oncogenic biomarker promoting ccRCC progression by inhibiting fatty acid oxidation.

title: Integrated spatial omics of metabolic reprogramming and the tumor microenvironment in pancreatic cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Clustering', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: To analyze metabolic reprogramming and the tumor microenvironment in pancreatic cancer by integrating single-cell transcriptomics, spatial transcriptomics, and spatial metabolomics. The study aimed to visualize spatial co-localization, uncover metabolic heterogeneity, identify metabolic shifts during progression, delineate metabolic differences between regions, and characterize aberrant cell communication.

title: Advances and challenges in cell-cell communication inference: a comprehensive review of tools, resources, and future directions.
main_goals: This paper provides a comprehensive review of over 100 bioinformatics tools and nearly 50 resources for cell-cell communication inference using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data. It discusses current challenges, limitations, and future directions in the field. The collected knowledge is consolidated into the CCC-Catalog web platform.

title: Microbiome in cancer metastasis: biological insights and emerging spatial omics methods.
main_goals: This review explores the role of the microbiome in cancer metastasis, discusses potential mechanisms and key bacteria, and examines recent advancements in spatial omics techniques for studying these interactions within the tumor microenvironment. It highlights multimodal-omics imaging approaches and addresses challenges and future directions in this research area.

title: Current status, hotspots and frontiers of ion channel-related research in glioblastoma: a bibliometric analysis from 2005 to 2024.
main_goals: To systematically examine and synthesize the knowledge structure and research focal points in the field of glioblastoma ion channels using bibliometric analysis from 2005 to 2024. The study identifies publication trends, key contributors, highly cited works, and research hotspots and frontiers.

title: First spectral reflectance dataset of a highly invasive and aggressive alien plant species, Equisetum hyemale (snakegrass), in South Africa: Towards early detection and effective eradication.
main_goals: To present the first spectral reflectance dataset of Equisetum hyemale (snakegrass) in South Africa. The dataset is intended for use in early detection and spatial distribution mapping using remote sensing.

title: Multi-omics: a bridge connecting genotype and phenotype for epilepsy?
main_goals: This review provides a comprehensive overview of omics technologies and multi-omics integration strategies. It explores their potential role in enhancing the management of epilepsy treatment and care. The goal is to offer new directions for future research in this field.

title: Vispro improves imaging analysis for Visium spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: Introduce Vispro, an end-to-end automated image processing tool for 10x Visium data. It aims to enhance histology image quality by detecting fiducial markers, restoring images, and detecting/segmenting tissue regions. By improving image quality, Vispro seeks to enhance the accuracy of downstream spatial analyses.

title: Automated Multi-grade Brain Tumor Classification Using Adaptive Hierarchical Optimized Horse Herd BiLSTM Fusion Network in MRI Images.
main_goals: To propose a Multi-Grade Hierarchical Classification Network Model (MGHCN) for hierarchical classification of brain tumor grades in MRI images. The framework uses Improved Adaptive Intensity Normalization (IAIN) for preprocessing and Dual Tree Complex Wavelet Transform with Enhanced Trigonometric Features (DTCWT-ETF) for feature extraction. Classification is performed using an Adaptive Hierarchical Optimized Horse Herd BiLSTM Fusion Network (AHOHH-BiLSTM).

title: Single-cell transcriptomic and chromatin dynamics of the human brain in PTSD.
main_goals: To characterize the cell-specific molecular regulatory mechanisms underlying the effects of traumatic stress response in the human prefrontal cortex using single-cell transcriptomics, chromatin dynamics, and spatial transcriptomics data in individuals with and without PTSD. The study aims to identify PTSD-associated gene alterations, regulatory mechanisms, and integrate genetic, transcriptomic, and epigenetic data.

title: Spatial transcriptomics of Hirschsprung disease resection margins marks differential gene expression in myenteric plexus.
main_goals: To apply spatial transcriptomics to analyze resection margins in Hirschsprung disease. The study aims to identify differential gene expression within the myenteric plexus in this specific tissue context. This approach seeks to uncover spatially resolved molecular differences related to the disease.

title: STAMP: Single-cell transcriptomics analysis and multimodal profiling through imaging.
biological_context: Peripheral blood mononuclear cells, cell lines, stem cells
data_modalities_used: ['imaging', 'transcriptomics imaging', 'proteomics imaging', 'H&E imaging', 'RNA imaging', 'protein imaging', 'multimodal imaging', 'transcriptomics', 'proteomics', 'histology images']
main_goals: Develop STAMP, a scalable, cost-efficient, imaging-based approach for single-cell transcriptomics and multimodal (RNA, protein, H&E) profiling. Overcome limitations of scRNA-seq like scalability, cost, and cell destruction while retaining cellular structure. Apply STAMP to diverse samples for large-scale studies, including rare cell identification.

title: Multi-omics reveals the polyethylene terephthalate carcinogenicity: Cancer progression and immune microenvironment.
main_goals: This study integrates multi-omics (network toxicology, machine learning, molecular docking, single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics) and experimental validation to systematically investigate the mechanistic underpinnings of PET carcinogenicity. It aims to identify PET-associated oncogenic targets, analyze their prognostic value in pan-cancer, and delineate the pathways involved in PET-driven tumorigenesis and immune microenvironment changes.

title: Unveiling Moxibustion's Impact on AD Mice Learning and Memory: Role of Mitochondrial Respiratory Chain Complex I Subunit in the Hippocampus.
main_goals: To investigate the mechanism by which moxibustion improves cognitive function in AD mice, focusing on energy metabolism. The study utilized spatial transcriptomics to identify metabolic genes affected by moxibustion, finding improvements in learning/memory, reduced pathology, enhanced mitochondrial complex I activity, and increased synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus.

title: Research advances in the study of traditional Chinese medicine formula granules on signaling pathway-mediated disease mechanisms.
biological_context: Traditional Chinese Medicine Formula Granules mechanisms in treating inflammation, tumors, metabolic disorders, fibrosis, and orthopedic conditions
main_goals: This article systematically reviews the progress of Traditional Chinese Medicine Formula Granules (TCMFG) research in signaling pathway-mediated disease mechanisms and outlines future directions to enhance its application in modern precision medicine.

title: Identification of core genes in acute kidney injury: evidence from multi-omics human transcriptomic data and in vivo models.
biological_context: Acute kidney injury in human and mouse kidney
main_goals: Identify core genes in acute kidney injury (AKI) by integrating multi-omics human transcriptomic data and validating findings in mouse models. Explore the mechanisms of these genes, focusing on SUGCT's role in proximal tubules using snRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics. Provide potential diagnostic and therapeutic targets for AKI.

title: Clonal sharing of CD8+ T-cells links skin and joint inflammation in psoriatic arthritis.
biological_context: Psoriatic arthritis (PsA), skin and joint inflammation
main_goals: Test the hypothesis that skin and joint inflammation in PsA are linked by CD8+ T-cell phenotype and clonality using scRNAseq and spatial transcriptomics. Identify shared CD8+ T-cell clones and their characteristics across skin and joint sites in PsA patients.

title: Identification of an immunomodulatory lncRNA signature associated with immune cell reprogramming in high-grade glioma.
main_goals: Identify immunomodulatory lncRNA signatures associated with the tumor immune microenvironment (TME) in high-grade gliomas. Use transcriptomics, scRNA-seq, and spatial transcriptomics to find context-dependent lncRNA expression in immune cells and their spatial distribution within the TME. Correlate specific lncRNAs with immunosuppression and immune evasion mechanisms.

title: Single-cell spatial proteomics of non-relapse small cell lung cancer identifies tumor microenvironment determinants of survival.
main_goals: This study aimed to identify factors associated with relapse-free survival in early-stage SCLC patients using single-cell spatial imaging mass cytometry. It explored tumor cell characteristics and tumor microenvironment differences between relapse and non-relapse groups. Key findings include tumor heterogeneity, association of Ki-67 expression with recurrence, and identification of M1 macrophages, stromal cells, and T cell interactions linked to better prognosis.

title: Single-Cell RNA Sequencing Delineates Renal Anti-Fibrotic Mechanisms Mediated by TRPC6 Inhibition.
biological_context: Chronic kidney disease (CKD), renal fibrosis, mouse unilateral ureteral obstruction (UUO), mouse post-ischemia-reperfusion injury (post-I/R), human kidney
main_goals: To delineate the renoprotective cell composition and cell type-specific transcriptional programs mediated by TRPC6 inhibition in mouse models of kidney injury using single-cell RNA sequencing. To explore translational aspects by analyzing human CKD samples and identify novel cell types and regulatory networks involved in renal fibrosis alleviation.

title: Editorial: New Target for Skin Cancer.
main_goals: This editorial summarizes the 29 articles included in the special issue 'New Target for Skin Cancer'. It highlights key themes such as molecular mechanisms, tumor microenvironment, biomarkers, emerging therapies, rare subtypes, and technological innovations. The goal is to provide a comprehensive update and roadmap for skin cancer research and clinical practice.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics to Study Virus-Host Interactions.
biological_context: Virus-host interactions and viral diseases in plants, animals, and humans
main_goals: Review the transformative potential of spatial transcriptomics for studying viral pathogenesis and virus-host interactions. Discuss the intricacies of corresponding technologies and how to implement them.

title: Biological and metabolomic insights into RACGAP1-mediated growth and progression of clear cell renal cell carcinoma.
main_goals: To investigate the biological function of RACGAP1 in promoting the growth and progression of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC). To reveal the regulatory mechanism of RACGAP1 in interfering with metabolic pathways using targeted and spatial metabolomics. To provide potential new targets and a theoretical basis for ccRCC treatment.

title: Quantitative Mass Spectrometry Imaging by Targeted-DESI-MSI in MRM Mode Provides Higher Sensitivity and Specificity for Fast Quantification of Chloroquine Drug in Mice Kidney.
biological_context: Mice kidney tissue, quantification of chloroquine drug distribution
main_goals: To develop and validate a targeted DESI-MSI method in MRM mode for quantitative spatial imaging (QMSI) of drugs in biological tissues. To demonstrate its application by quantifying chloroquine distribution in different regions of mice kidneys. To address challenges like sensitivity, specificity, and matrix effects for QMSI.

title: Analysis of Hyperexpanded T Cell Clones in SARS-CoV-2 Vaccine-Associated Liver Injury by Spatial Proteomics and Transcriptomics.
biological_context: SARS-CoV-2 vaccine-associated liver injury in human liver
data_modalities_used: ['T cell receptor sequencing', 'multiplex immunofluorescence (mIF)', 'RNA in situ hybridisation (RISH)', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'Xenium', 'spatial proteomics']
main_goals: This paper aims to characterize the immune infiltrate in a liver explant from a patient with severe SARS-CoV-2 vaccine-associated liver injury (SVALI). Using spatial multi-omics techniques, the study identifies and localizes hyperexpanded cytotoxic and tissue-resident CD8+ T cell clones throughout the liver, suggesting their role in SVALI pathogenesis.

title: Integrating spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing reveals epithelial cell alterations in benign prostatic hyperplasia following finasteride treatment.
biological_context: Benign prostatic hyperplasia; prostate; finasteride treatment
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: To integrate spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing data to investigate epithelial cell alterations in benign prostatic hyperplasia following finasteride treatment and understand the spatial context of these changes.

title: Integrative Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptomics Analysis Reveals ECM-remodeling Cancer-associated Fibroblast-Derived POSTN as a Key Mediator in Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma Progression.
main_goals: Integrative single-cell and spatial transcriptomics analysis was used to dissect fibroblast heterogeneity and crosstalk in PDAC. The study identified ECM-remodeling fibroblasts and the POSTN-ITGAV/ITGB5 axis as key mediators promoting tumor progression. Targeting this axis showed potential therapeutic benefits.

title: Omics-based Approach Towards Macrophages: New Perspectives of Biology and Function in the Normal and Diseased Heart.
biological_context: Macrophages in cardiovascular diseases and the heart
main_goals: This review summarizes the diverse phenotypes and functional plasticity of macrophages in cardiovascular diseases, emphasizing novel insights from multi-omics approaches like single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It aims to provide reference points for clinical macrophage-targeted strategies.

title: Role of local complement activation in kidney fibrosis and repair.
biological_context: Kidney fibrosis, Chronic kidney disease, Acute kidney injury
main_goals: Review the role of local complement activation in kidney fibrosis and repair. Highlight evidence from animal models and human data showing the pathogenic role of complement activation in kidney disease. Discuss the potential for targeting local complement activation as a therapeutic approach for CKD.

title: Biomimetic Visual System Implemented by a Two-Dimensional Plasmonic Photosensor Array for Processing Spatio-Temporal Information.
main_goals: The paper presents an in-sensor spiking neural network (SNN) based on a 2D plasmonic photosensor array (PPSA) to mimic the human visual system. Its goal is to efficiently perceive, preprocess, encode, and process spatio-temporal information, demonstrating zero energy consumption for perception and high recognition accuracy for temporal patterns.

title: Single-cell multi-omics reveals that FABP1 + renal cell carcinoma drive tumor angiogenesis through the PLG-PLAT axis under fatty acid reprogramming.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Pathway Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Visualization']
main_goals: To investigate fatty acid metabolism reprogramming in renal cell carcinoma using multi-omics. The study identifies FABP1+ tumors driving angiogenesis via the PLG-PLAT axis and suggests this axis as a potential therapeutic target.

title: Advances in molecular pathology and therapy of non-small cell lung cancer.
main_goals: This review aims to comprehensively present progress in molecular pathology (including spatial omics) and therapy of NSCLC. It highlights drugs, drug resistance mechanisms, and future treatment strategies leveraging AI to revolutionize the therapeutic landscape.

title: PRRX1 is a key regulator in the phenotypic transition between human normal dermal and keloid fibroblasts.
biological_context: Human skin (foetal, postnatal, keloid), wound healing, scarring
main_goals: To investigate the cellular and molecular characteristics underlying scarless healing by comparing human foetal skin, postnatal skin, and keloid tissue using spatial transcriptomics and histology. The study identified key differences, focusing on fibroblast heterogeneity and the role of PRRX1 in the phenotypic transition between normal and keloid fibroblasts, with the aim of finding factors for promoting scarless wound healing.

title: The role of tumor microenvironment and immune cell crosstalk in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC): Emerging therapeutic opportunities.
main_goals: This review synthesizes current research on the tumor microenvironment (TME) and immune cell crosstalk in TNBC to identify emerging therapeutic opportunities. It discusses the role of various cell types and factors in the TME, highlights insights from technologies like single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial analysis, and proposes future research directions including spatial transcriptomics for developing personalized treatments.

title: Positionally distinct interferon-stimulated dermal immune-acting fibroblasts promote neutrophil recruitment in Sweet's syndrome.
biological_context: Sweet's syndrome and pyoderma gangrenosum in human skin
main_goals: To define the cellular and molecular landscape of Sweet's syndrome skin compared to pyoderma gangrenosum and healthy controls. The study identifies an interferon signature, investigates fibroblast roles in neutrophil recruitment, and uses spatial data to map distinct fibroblast subsets.

title: Addressing the mean-variance relationship in spatially resolved transcriptomics data with spoon.
main_goals: Demonstrate the mean-variance relationship bias in spatially resolved transcriptomics (SRT) data. Propose 'spoon', a statistical framework using empirical Bayes techniques, to remove this bias. Improve the accuracy and prioritization of spatially variable genes (SVGs) identification in SRT data.

title: SpatialSNV: A novel method for identifying and analyzing spatially resolved SNVs in tumor microenvironments.
main_goals: Develop SpatialSNV, a novel framework to identify and analyze spatially resolved single-nucleotide variants (SNVs) in tumor microenvironments using spatial transcriptomics. Apply SpatialSNV to uncover insights into tumor evolution, microenvironment dynamics, tumor-immune crosstalk, and identify potential therapeutic targets based on spatial SNVs.

title: Integrating spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-seq dissects immune microenvironment in fatty liver regeneration.
biological_context: Fatty liver regeneration and immune microenvironment
main_goals: The paper aims to dissect the immune microenvironment during fatty liver regeneration by integrating spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-seq data. It focuses on using these technologies to understand the biological processes in this context.

title: Resolving spatial subclonal genomic heterogeneity of loss of heterozygosity and extrachromosomal DNA in gliomas.
main_goals: To map the spatial organization of DNA-level somatic copy number changes and extrachromosomal DNA in gliomas using an integrated framework of spatial transcriptomics and sequencing. To identify shared and distinct spatial subclonal heterogeneity characteristics and understand the role of ecDNA in tumor adaptability.

title: NeuroEmo: A neuroimaging-based fMRI dataset to extract temporal affective brain dynamics for Indian movie video clips stimuli using dynamic functional connectivity approach with graph convolution neural network (DFC-GCNN).
main_goals: Introduce a culturally relevant fMRI dataset (NeuroEmo) for identifying five emotional states in Indian participants using Bollywood movie clips. Propose and validate a supervised emotion classification model using a Dynamic Functional Connectivity (DFC) approach with a Graph Convolutional Neural Network (GCNN). Demonstrate the effectiveness of the DFC-GCNN model for emotion recognition and highlight the role of temporal connectivity dynamics.

title: High ELK3 expression is associated with the wild type IDH1 in glioma and enhances infiltration of M2 macrophages.
main_goals: This study aimed to investigate the impact of ELK3 on glioma prognosis, examine the regulatory influence of IDH1 on ELK3, and assess the role of ELK3 in tumor immune infiltration, particularly M2 macrophages.

title: Refinement of histologic subtypes and identification of biomarkers linked to unfavorable prognosis in cholangiocarcinoma: The ENSCCA registries' framework for digital twin advancement.
main_goals: To study the clinical relevance of histological heterogeneity and putative tissue biomarkers in cholangiocarcinoma (CCA). The paper describes creating a multicentric digitalized European CCA Histology Registry and using various data modalities (histology, IHC, radiomics, spatial transcriptomics, serology) to identify prognostic subtypes and their associated characteristics. They identified the PASHIGH LBD iCCA phenotype as an independent predictor of worse overall survival.

title: Gene Spatial Integration: enhancing spatial transcriptomics analysis via deep learning and batch effect mitigation.
main_goals: Develop Gene Spatial Integration (GSI), a deep learning pipeline for integrating multiple spatial transcriptomics samples. Extract spatial distribution features using an Autoencoder and integrate them with gene expression features. Mitigate batch effects and improve the performance of downstream spatial transcriptomics analysis tools, particularly clustering.

title: Leveraging deep learning to discover interpretable cellular spatial biomarkers for prognostic predictions based on hepatocellular carcinoma histology.
main_goals: Develop a computational pipeline using deep learning to quantify cellular spatial features in HCC H&E images. Identify these spatial features as novel prognostic biomarkers for HCC. Demonstrate improved prognostic stratification by combining spatial and clinical features.

title: Cell signaling characterization for spatial transcriptomics (ST) data using network analysis.
main_goals: To introduce a network analysis-based computational method for characterizing cell signaling and cell-cell communication in Spatial Transcriptomics (ST) data. The method builds a weighted network based on ligand-receptor expression and distance, using reduced rank expression values, and quantifies signaling activity via weighted in-degree centrality. It aims to capture simultaneous ligand and receptor heterogeneity and provide biologically plausible communication profiles.

title: ReSort enhances reference-based cell type deconvolution for spatial transcriptomics through regional information integration.
main_goals: Introduce ReSort, a new method for enhancing reference-based cell type deconvolution for spatial transcriptomics. ReSort integrates regional information to improve accuracy and lessen reliance on reference data. Apply ReSort to a mouse breast cancer model to demonstrate its utility.

title: Unlocking the potential of flavonoid biosynthesis through integrated metabolic engineering.
main_goals: Provide a comprehensive review of flavonoid biosynthesis, regulation, transport, and yield enhancement strategies. Highlight advances in understanding control and transport mechanisms, supported by spatial metabolomics. Explore integrated approaches like plant cell factories, genome editing, environmental optimization, and AI-driven metabolic engineering to boost flavonoid production.

title: Bridging Immune Evasion and Vascular Dynamics for Novel Therapeutic Frontiers in Hepatocellular Carcinoma.
main_goals: This review synthesizes current understanding of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), focusing on the interplay between immune evasion, vascular dynamics, and the tumor microenvironment (TME) that drives progression and therapy resistance. It details therapeutic strategies, including immunotherapy and antiangiogenic agents, and discusses emerging biomarkers. The goal is to advocate for TME-directed precision oncology in HCC.

title: A review of spatial transcriptomics in psoriasis: new insights into cellular contributions.
main_goals: This paper reviews how spatial transcriptomics has been utilized to study psoriasis. It summarizes the key insights gained regarding distinct cell populations, dysregulated pathways, tissue microenvironments, and cell-to-cell interactions in the disease. The review highlights the role of ST in shaping the understanding of prominent cell types in psoriasis.

title: From spots to cells: Cell segmentation in spatial transcriptomics with BOMS.
main_goals: Describe a new method (BOMS) for cell segmentation in imaging-based spatial transcriptomics using only spatial locations and gene labels of mRNA spots. Evaluate its performance against existing methods.

title: Multidirectional therapeutic effects of synthesized HMGB1 peptide on liver cirrhosis in mice.
main_goals: The main goal is to analyze the temporal effects of synthesized HMGB1 peptide treatment on liver cirrhosis in mice using spatial analysis. The study focuses on tracking changes in specific cell types (HSCs, macrophages, hepatocytes) over time to understand the therapeutic mechanisms related to fibrosis improvement and lipid metabolism.

title: Enrichment analysis for spatial and single-cell metabolomics accounting for molecular ambiguity.
main_goals: The paper introduces S2IsoMEr R package and a METASPACE web app to perform enrichment analysis for spatial and single-cell metabolomics data. It addresses the challenge of molecular ambiguity (isomers/isobars) in imaging MS data by using bootstrapping to propagate uncertainties into the enrichment analysis.

title: Enhanced Spatial Transcriptomics Analysis of Mouse Lung Tissues Reveals Cell-Specific Gene Expression Changes Associated with Pulmonary Hypertension.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Clustering', 'Differential Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: To present a high-resolution spatial transcriptomics protocol for fixed frozen mouse lung tissue using the 10X Genomics Xenium platform. To compare this protocol with fresh frozen tissue preparation and demonstrate its utility by analyzing pulmonary hypertension in a mouse model.

title: A spatial transcriptomic atlas of acute neonatal lung injury across development and disease severity.
biological_context: Human infant lung development and injury (neonatal, preterm birth)
main_goals: Create a spatial transcriptomic atlas of human infant lungs across development and injury using imaging-based spatial transcriptomics. Apply computational clustering to identify spatial patterns related to development and disease severity (gestational age/life span). Provide an open resource for the lung research community.

title: SMURF Reconstructs Single-Cells from Visium HD Data to Reveal Zonation of Transcriptional Programs in the Intestine.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: Introduce SMURF, a computational framework for high-resolution spatial transcriptomics (Visium HD) data. SMURF uses 'soft-segmentation' to assign transcripts to cells and can 'unroll' complex tissue structures. It is demonstrated by analyzing zonation and regional transcriptional programs in the mouse intestine.

title: Live-cell analyses with unsegmented images to study cancer cell response to modified T cell therapy.
biological_context: Cancer cell response to T cell therapy (A375 melanoma cells with modified T cells)
main_goals: Develop an unsupervised, segmentation-free analysis workflow (SF-LCBA) for live-cell imaging data of cancer cell and T cell co-cultures. The method characterizes multicellular interactions and aggregate formation in data unsuitable for cell segmentation. It aims to identify behavioral phenotypes related to cancer cell response to modified T cell therapy.

title: CD14 plays a critical role in pain and inflammation across multiple models of post-traumatic osteoarthritis.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of CD14 in pain, inflammation, and disability in post-traumatic osteoarthritis (PTOA) using pre-clinical models. It demonstrates that genetic deficiency or pharmacologic blockade of CD14 ameliorates pain and mobility impairments by influencing the synovial inflammatory landscape, including monocyte, macrophage, and fibroblast populations. The paper concludes that targeting CD14 offers a potential therapeutic approach for OA pain and disability.

title: Multiplexed Targeted Spatial Mass Spectrometry Imaging Assays to monitor lipids and NAD <sup>+</sup> metabolites in CD38 knockout mice exhibiting improved metabolism.
biological_context: Liver tissues from wild-type and CD38 knockout mice exhibiting improved metabolism
main_goals: Present a novel targeted spatial mass spectrometry imaging methodology (iprm-PASEF) combining TIMS-PASEF with MALDI. Apply this workflow to study lipids and NAD+ metabolites in CD38 knockout mouse liver. Demonstrate the method's capability for confident identification, differentiation, and quantification of analytes in spatial MSI.

title: Spatiotemporal transcriptomic analysis during cold ischemic injury to the murine kidney reveals compartment-specific changes.
biological_context: Murine kidney cold ischemic injury during transplantation
main_goals: To characterize cold ischemia injury in murine kidneys using spatial transcriptomics across different time points. The study aims to identify spatiotemporal and compartment-specific molecular changes, understand potential metabolic reprogramming, and compare findings with warm ischemia-reperfusion injury.

title: Graphical and Interactive Spatial Proteomics Image Analysis Workflow.
main_goals: Present a modular and interactive spatial proteomics imaging workflow for reproducible and customizable analysis. The workflow includes cell segmentation, clustering, validation, and visualization. It aims to provide a flexible, high-throughput, graphical, and interactive end-to-end solution for spatial proteomic analysis.

title: Spatiotemporal Single-Cell Analysis Reveals T Cell Clonal Dynamics and Phenotypic Plasticity in Human Graft-versus-Host Disease.
biological_context: Human Graft-versus-Host Disease (GVHD) after allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (alloHCT), in blood and gut
data_modalities_used: ['mixed lymphocyte reaction-based clonal "fingerprinting"', 'TCR clonotyping', 'single-cell RNA/TCR sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Clustering', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: To dissect T-cell-mediated pathology in human GVHD using integrated spatiotemporal single-cell analysis. To uncover clonal dynamics and phenotypic plasticity linked to GVHD severity. To identify spatial localization patterns of T cells in the gut.

title: Patient phenotyping for molecular profiling of neck and low back pain - Study protocol.
biological_context: Chronic neck and low back pain in humans
main_goals: To summarize the rationale and methods used to phenotype patients with chronic neck and low back pain. This phenotyping is part of a study protocol aimed at molecular profiling using multi-omics (including spatial transcriptomics) to identify phenotype-specific transcriptional signatures and underlying pain mechanisms.

title: Current concepts in the pathogenesis and clinical management of lymphangioleiomyomatosis.
main_goals: This review provides an overview of recent advancements in the pathogenesis and clinical management of Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM). It discusses improved understanding of the disease's origin, hormonal pathways, immune interactions, mTOR signaling, and the microenvironment.
