title: Deciphering the cell type-specific and zonal distribution of drug-metabolizing enzymes, transporters, and transcription factors in livers of mice using single-cell transcriptomics.
biological_context: Mouse liver cell types and zonal distribution of drug-processing genes
main_goals: To characterize the distribution of drug-processing genes (DPGs) in mouse liver using published single-cell and nuclei transcriptomic datasets, subjected to zonal deconvolution. The study aimed to identify DPG enrichment in different liver cell types and zones, providing insights into xenobiotic biotransformation.

title: DepITCM: an audio-visual method for detecting depression.
main_goals: The paper proposes DepITCM, an audio-visual method for depression detection. It introduces an Inception-Temporal-Channel Principal Component Analysis Module (ITCM Encoder) for efficient feature extraction and a multi-task learning approach to enhance prediction accuracy by incorporating a secondary regression task. The method aims to improve upon existing models by effectively extracting and fusing temporal, channel, and spatial information.

title: Spatial transcriptomics defines the cell-specific RNA landscape of equine dorsal root ganglia.
biological_context: Equine dorsal root ganglia (DRG) in healthy adult horses, with potential application to spinal neurodegenerative conditions in horses.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'histology images', 'immunohistochemistry (implied by cell markers and regions of interest)']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell Segmentation (implied by regions of interest based on markers)', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: To define the spatial transcriptomic landscape of equine dorsal root ganglia (DRG) in healthy adult horses using spatial transcriptomics. The study aimed to identify cell-specific gene expression differences in distinct DRG regions and validate the approach for future application to disease states.

title: A quantitative spatial cell-cell colocalizations framework enabling comparisons between in vitro assembloids and pathological specimens.
biological_context: Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) organoids and cancer-associated fibroblasts derived from human tumors.
main_goals: The paper proposes a quantitative framework for cataloging significant, normalized colocalizations between pairs of cell subpopulations. This framework enables comparisons of spatial features across different biological samples, including in vitro assembloids and pathological specimens.

title: Autosomal dominant SLURP1 variants cause palmoplantar keratoderma and progressive symmetric erythrokeratoderma.
biological_context: Epidermal differentiation disorders (ichthyosis and palmoplantar keratoderma (PPK)) and progressive symmetric erythrokeratoderma (PSEK) phenotypes.
data_modalities_used: ['whole-exome sequencing', 'patient keratinocytes', 'high-resolution spatial transcriptomics', 'quantitative cytokine profiling', 'mass spectrometry']
main_goals: To identify novel genetic variants that cause palmoplantar keratoderma (PPK) and progressive symmetric erythrokeratoderma (PSEK) phenotypes. The study investigated variant consequences using in silico predictions, patient keratinocyte assays, high-resolution spatial transcriptomics, and quantitative cytokine profiling. The findings expand the phenotypic spectrum of epidermal differentiation disorders due to SLURP1 variants and suggest a novel mechanism of action for dominant SLURP1 pathogenic variants.

title: Deep learning-driven bacterial cytological profiling to determine antimicrobial mechanisms in Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
main_goals: This study introduces MycoBCP, a novel adaptation of bacterial cytological profiling (BCP) using convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for analyzing morphological effects of antimicrobial compounds on Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The method overcomes challenges in traditional image analysis of M. tuberculosis, achieving high accuracy in identifying antimicrobial mechanisms of action and demonstrating utility in early drug discovery.

title: Spatial Proteomics by Parallel Accumulation-Serial Fragmentation Supported MALDI MS/MS Imaging: A First Glance Into Multiplexed and Spatial Peptide Identification.
main_goals: This study introduces and showcases a novel pipeline, iprm-PASEF, integrating TIMS-based PASEF into MALDI imaging for multiplexed and spatial peptide identification. This method enables parallel accumulation-serial fragmentation for enhanced peptide identification directly within MALDI imaging experiments, marking a step towards spatial proteomics.

title: A comprehensive spatio-cellular map of the human hypothalamus.
main_goals: The paper presents a comprehensive spatio-cellular transcriptional map of the human hypothalamus, named 'HYPOMAP', by combining single-nucleus sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies conserved and divergent cell types between humans and mice, and finds neuronal clusters enriched for body mass index (BMI) genome-wide association study genes, highlighting potential therapeutic targets for metabolic and other disorders.

title: Deep visual proteomics reveals DNA replication stress as a hallmark of signet ring cell carcinoma.
biological_context: Signet Ring Cell Carcinoma (SRCC) across bladder, prostate, seminal vesicle, and lymph node
main_goals: The paper introduces Deep Visual Proteomics (DVP), a novel method combining AI-directed cell segmentation and classification with laser microdissection and ultra-high sensitivity mass spectrometry for cell-type-specific proteomic analysis. DVP was used to analyze SRCC, revealing DNA replication stress and immune infiltration as key features. The findings suggest potential personalized therapeutic strategies for SRCC.

title: Kernel-bounded clustering for spatial transcriptomics enables scalable discovery of complex spatial domains.
main_goals: This paper introduces a new clustering algorithm called kernel-bounded clustering (KBC) for spatial transcriptomics data. KBC is designed to handle clusters with varying densities, sizes, and shapes and offers significantly improved speed compared to existing methods. The authors demonstrate its effectiveness when combined with the Weisfeiler-Lehman scheme.

title: Spatially resolved transcriptomics reveal the determinants of primary resistance to immunotherapy in NSCLC with mature tertiary lymphoid structures.
biological_context: Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) with mature tertiary lymphoid structures (mTLSs)
main_goals: To investigate the determinants of primary resistance to immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) in NSCLC patients with mature tertiary lymphoid structures (mTLSs). The study uses spatial transcriptomics and multiplex immunofluorescence to identify specific cancer-associated fibroblast (CAF) subsets that contribute to immune exclusion and T cell exhaustion, leading to resistance.

title: Learning Phenotype Associated Signature in Spatial Transcriptomics with PASSAGE.
main_goals: PASSAGE is a deep learning framework designed to characterize phenotype-associated signatures across multiple heterogeneous spatial slices in spatial transcriptomics data. It aims to identify sophisticated signatures by leveraging sample characteristics like physiological/pathological states, going beyond unsupervised methods.

title: Inferring cell trajectories of spatial transcriptomics via optimal transport analysis.
biological_context: Axolotl telencephalon regeneration and mouse midbrain development, primary tumor metastasis
main_goals: Introduces SpaTrack, a method leveraging optimal transport to integrate gene expression and spatial position for cell differentiation trajectory reconstruction. It enables detailed spatial trajectory construction, traces cell dynamics across samples and time, and models cell fate as a function of expression profiles influenced by transcription factors.

title: Spatial transcriptomics-aided localization for single-cell transcriptomics with STALocator.
biological_context: Human brain and squamous cell carcinoma
covered_analysis_steps: ['spatial localization', 'data integration', 'gene expression prediction', 'spatial gene expression analysis']
main_goals: Develop STALocator, a method to localize single cells to corresponding spatial transcriptomics data. STALocator improves upon existing methods by integrating scRNA-seq and ST data, enabling robust reconstruction of spatial organization and enhancement of gene expression patterns for various spatial technologies.

title: MALDI MSI-based spatial amine metabolomics revealing the protective effect of combination therapy against cerebral ischemia/reperfusion-induced brain injury in rats.
main_goals: This paper investigates the protective effects of Edaravone (Eda) and Ginaton injection (Gin) combination therapy against cerebral ischemia/reperfusion (I/R) injury in a rat model. It uses MALDI MSI-based spatial amine metabolomics to reveal the metabolic alterations and the regulatory effect of the combination treatment on these disorders in the cerebral cortex and striatum.

title: Targeting fibroblast-endothelial cell interactions in LAM pathogenesis using 3D spheroid models and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The study aimed to investigate fibroblast-endothelial cell interactions in LAM pathogenesis using 3D spheroid models and spatial transcriptomics. They identified elevated PDGFR and FGFR in LAMFs and demonstrated that sorafenib, a multikinase inhibitor, significantly reduced invasion in LAMF-LEC spheroids. The findings suggest VEGF-A and basic FGF as potential therapeutic targets and multikinase inhibition as a promising strategy for LAM.

title: Effects of maternal edible THC consumption on offspring lung growth and function in a rhesus macaque model.
biological_context: Offspring lung growth and function following prenatal exposure to THC
data_modalities_used: ['magnetic resonance imaging', 'pulmonary function testing', 'bulk RNAseq', 'whole genome bisulfite sequencing', 'spatial RNAseq', 'bronchial alveolar lavage']
main_goals: This study aimed to determine if in utero exposure to delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) negatively impacts offspring lung development and function in a rhesus macaque model. The researchers used MRI, pulmonary function testing, and molecular analyses to investigate these effects. Findings suggest that prenatal THC exposure may alter epigenetic regulation and adversely affect lung development and function.

title: European Society of Toxicologic Pathology-Pathology 2.0 Mass Spectrometry Imaging Special Interest Group: Mass Spectrometry Imaging in Diagnostic and Toxicologic Pathology for Label-Free Detection of Molecules-From Basics to Practical Applications.
data_modalities_used: ['Mass Spectrometry Imaging', 'MALDI', 'DESI', 'SIMS', 'spatial metabolomics', 'spatial lipidomics', 'spatial proteomics', 'histopathology images']
main_goals: This article introduces Mass Spectrometry Imaging (MSI) and its fundamentals, focusing on its application in diagnostic and toxicologic pathology. It discusses various MSI techniques, their suitability for different research questions, and showcases case examples in drug metabolism, safety assessment, and clinical diagnostics. The paper emphasizes the importance of pathologists' contributions to sample quality and data interpretation for targeted MSI experiments.

title: New Anti-Fibrotic Strategies for Keloids: Insights From Single-Cell Multi-Omics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Communication Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell Segmentation']
main_goals: This study investigates the cellular heterogeneity and molecular mechanisms of keloids using single-cell multi-omics. It identified key fibroblast subpopulations with opposing roles in fibrosis and explored endothelial cell involvement in abnormal angiogenesis and EMT. The findings provide theoretical foundations for new anti-fibrotic treatment strategies targeting specific fibroblast subpopulations.

title: Correction to: STCGAN: a novel cycle-consistent generative adversarial network for spatial transcriptomics cellular deconvolution.
main_goals: This paper is a correction to a previous publication about STCGAN, a novel cycle-consistent generative adversarial network for spatial transcriptomics cellular deconvolution. The correction addresses issues in the original method, aiming to improve its performance and accuracy in deconvolving spatial transcriptomics data.

title: Development and Validation of the Patient Experience Assessment Scale (PXAS) in Tertiary Care Hospital - Oman.
main_goals: This paper describes the development and validation of the Patient Experience Assessment Scale (PXAS) for use in tertiary care hospitals in Oman. The scale was designed to evaluate patient perspectives on healthcare quality, aiming to overcome limitations of traditional satisfaction surveys. The PXAS was found to be reliable and valid in assessing patient experience.

title: Immune microenvironment spatial landscapes of tertiary lymphoid structures in gastric cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study investigates the prognostic impact and immune microenvironment characteristics of tertiary lymphoid structures (TLS) in gastric cancer (GC). It used multispectral imaging and single-cell/spatial transcriptomics to analyze immune cell infiltration and interactions within TLS. The findings highlight the positive prognostic value of TLS and the intricate cell-cell communications they facilitate.

title: Spatial transcriptomics identifies molecular niche dysregulation associated with distal lung remodeling in pulmonary fibrosis.
main_goals: To use image-based spatial transcriptomics to analyze gene expression in the distal lung of patients with pulmonary fibrosis, characterizing spatial niches and identifying molecular changes associated with disease progression. The study aims to provide a spatially resolved view of pulmonary fibrosis and establish methods applicable to other spatial transcriptomic studies.

title: Introducing the Global Alliance for Spatial Technologies (GESTALT).
main_goals: This paper introduces the Global Alliance for Spatial Technologies (GESTALT). It is likely an announcement or foundational paper for a new organization focused on spatial technologies.

title: Enhancing urban air quality prediction using time-based-spatial forecasting framework.
main_goals: This research presents a Time-Based-Spatial (TBS) forecasting framework to enhance urban air quality prediction. The framework integrates spatial and temporal information using CNNs for spatial dependencies and ARIMA for temporal dependencies.

title: Integrating Tissue Microarray to GeoMx<sup>®</sup> Digital Spatial Profiler : Spatial Transcriptomics Assay with Bioinformatics Analysis.
main_goals: This chapter aims to delineate the NGS assay protocol for Digital Spatial Profiler (DSP) and follow bioinformatics analysis. It focuses on the integration of tissue microarrays, bioinformatics pipelines, and statistical approaches specific to GeoMx RNA assays, as well as common errors.

title: Spatial-Omics Methods and Applications.
main_goals: This chapter discusses the current state of spatial-omics, highlighting technological advances and limitations. It covers the evolution of tissue profiling from bulk to single-cell analysis and the emergence of spatial technologies for in situ analysis of biomolecules. The paper also addresses challenges such as standardization, sample compatibility, throughput, resolution, and ease of use.

title: Multiomic analysis uncovers a continuous spectrum of differentiation and Wnt-MDK-driven immune evasion in hepatoblastoma.
main_goals: To provide a comprehensive analysis of the tumor microenvironment of hepatoblastoma, unveiling its spatial architecture and key signaling mechanisms. The study identified tumor transcriptional programs, characterized the immune environment, and discovered a Wnt-MDK-driven mechanism for immune evasion. Findings suggest midkine as a potential therapeutic target.

title: Succinate supplementation alleviates liver cancer by inhibiting the FN1/SQLE axis-mediated cholesterol biosynthesis.
main_goals: This study investigated the role of exogenous succinate in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). It reports that succinate supplementation exhibits an anti-tumorigenic effect by inhibiting cell proliferation and tumor formation. The mechanism involves FN1-activated SQLE-related cholesterol biosynthesis, suggesting succinate's potential as a therapeutic agent for HCC.

title: CD8 + T cells mediate vaccination-induced lymphatic containment of latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection following immunosuppression, while B cells are dispensable.
biological_context: Latent Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection in lymphatics
main_goals: This study investigated the immunological mechanisms underlying the containment and reactivation of latent lymphatic Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection following immunosuppression. It revealed that CD8+ T cells, but not B cells, are critical for preventing reactivation induced by vaccination, despite CD4+ T cell deficiency.

title: Accessible and accurate cytometry analysis using fluorescence microscopes.
main_goals: Developed a method and Python-based tool to capture images from simple microscopes and produce flow cytometry-like data. The approach facilitates cell segmentation and quantification of fluorescent intensity, demonstrating similar speed and enhanced sensitivity compared to typical flow cytometry.

title: Accurate tiling of spatial single-cell data with Tessera.
biological_context: Healthy mouse brain and human lymph nodes, and human brain and lung cancer
main_goals: Introduces Tessera, a novel algorithm for tissue segmentation in spatial omics data. Tessera divides tissue into small multicellular tiles with edges tracking natural boundaries, overcoming limitations of existing smoothing-based methods. It identifies anatomical structures and disease-associated niches with accurate boundaries across various spatial omics technologies.

title: Golden eagle optimized CONV-LSTM and non-negativity-constrained autoencoder to support spatial and temporal features in cancer drug response prediction.
main_goals: This paper introduces a hybrid classification model, GEO-Conv-LSTM, optimized by the Golden Eagle Optimization algorithm, integrated with a Non-Negativity-Constrained Auto Encoder (NNCAE). The NNCAE addresses noise and class imbalance, while the GEO-Conv-LSTM leverages CNN and LSTM for spatial and temporal feature learning in cancer drug response prediction. The goal is to improve accuracy, reduce processing time, and lower the error rate in DRP.
data_links_mentioned: ['Genomics of Drug Sensitivity in Cancer (GDSC) repository']

title: Multi-omics analysis of core E3 ubiquitin ligase identifies prognostic biomarkers associated with immune infiltration and drug sensitivity in lung adenocarcinoma.
main_goals: This study aimed to identify key E3 ubiquitin ligases involved in LUAD progression, investigate their prognostic value, immune infiltration associations, and drug sensitivity potential. The researchers systematically analyzed their expression, localization, and functional enrichment pathways. The findings suggest these ligases could serve as molecular biomarkers for LUAD patient outcomes.

title: The future of cardiology: Integrating single-cell transcriptomics with multi-omics for enhanced cardiac disease insights.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This review highlights insights gained from single-cell transcriptome sequencing in the mammalian heart, emphasizing the integration of spatial transcriptomics and other omics technologies. It addresses research gaps in personalized medicine and rare cell population analysis for cardiovascular diseases.

title: Segment anything model-based segmentation with inception-ResNet-v2 classifier for Parkinson's disease diagnosis and metaverse visualization.
main_goals: This study introduces an automated segmentation method (Segment Anything Model - SAM) combined with an Inception-ResNet-v2 classifier for improved Parkinson's disease (PD) diagnosis. It aims to overcome limitations of traditional Voxel-Based Morphometry by enhancing brain MRI image quality through advanced preprocessing and utilizing robust feature extraction and selection techniques. The research also proposes a metaverse framework for better understanding and decision-making in PD diagnosis.

title: A single-cell and spatial wheat root atlas with cross-species annotations delineates conserved tissue-specific marker genes and regulators.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Clustering', 'Molecular Sequence Annotation', 'Gene Expression Regulation', 'Gene Regulatory Networks']
main_goals: This paper generated a single-cell and spatial transcriptomics atlas of soil-grown wheat roots. It annotated cell clusters by transferring annotations from related species and validated predictions using spatial transcriptomics. The study identified conserved tissue-specific marker genes and generated cell type-specific gene regulatory networks for wheat and other species.

title: MSC-EVs and UCB-EVs promote skin wound healing and spatial transcriptome analysis.
biological_context: skin wound healing and scar formation
data_modalities_used: ['histology images', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'electron microscopy', 'nanoparticle tracking analysis', 'western blot']
main_goals: This study investigated the effects of MSC-EVs and UCB-EVs on skin wound healing and scar formation reduction in mice. It utilized spatial transcriptomics to analyze cellular heterogeneity and molecular pathways involved in the healing process. The findings suggest these EVs are promising agents for promoting skin wound healing.

title: Spatial integration of multi-omics single-cell data with SIMO.
main_goals: The paper introduces SIMO, a computational method for spatial integration of multi-omics single-cell data. SIMO enables integration beyond spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-seq to include modalities like chromatin accessibility and DNA methylation. It aims to reveal multimodal spatial heterogeneity and topological patterns of cells and their regulatory modes.

title: INSTINCT: Multi-sample integration of spatial chromatin accessibility sequencing data via stochastic domain translation.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration of spatial chromatin accessibility sequencing data', 'Elimination of batch effects', 'Spatial domain identification', 'Spot-type annotation']
main_goals: This paper introduces INSTINCT, a novel method for the multi-sample integration of spatial chromatin accessibility sequencing data. It addresses challenges like high dimensionality and batch effects using stochastic domain translation. INSTINCT aims to improve spatial domain identification, visualization, spot-type annotation, and downstream analyses.

title: Cellular Crosstalk Promotes Hepatic Progenitor Cell Proliferation and Stellate Cell Activation in 3D Co-culture.
biological_context: Liver damage, ductular reaction, and liver fibrosis
data_modalities_used: ['fluorescently labeled progenitor cells', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'human liver explants']
main_goals: This paper reports on an in vitro co-culture system to examine the functional interaction between hepatic progenitor cells and activated hepatic stellate cells (HSCs). The study demonstrates that close contact between these cells enhances progenitor cell proliferation and HSC activation, recapitulating events observed in liver damage. The developed 3D co-culture model provides evidence for direct interactions sufficient to drive responses similar to ductular reaction and fibrosis, paving the way for further research into liver pathology.

title: Lactational high weight loss impairs follicular development by causing mitochondrial dysfunction of ovarian cells in sows and mitigated by butyrate supplement.
biological_context: Ovarian follicular development in sows and its impairment during lactational high weight loss, with mitigation by butyrate.
data_modalities_used: ['Spatial transcriptomics', 'Immunofluorescent staining', 'Transmission electron microscopy', 'Hormone detection', 'Western blot']
main_goals: To explore the mechanism by which high weight loss during lactation in sows damages follicular development and to investigate the mitigating effect of butyrate treatment. The research aims to elucidate how lactational high weight loss impacts mitochondrial function and steroidogenesis in ovarian cells, leading to impaired follicular development, and to demonstrate that butyrate can alleviate these effects.

title: Identification of TTLL8, POTEE, and PKMYT1 as immunogenic cancer-associated antigens and potential immunotherapy targets in ovarian cancer.
main_goals: This paper aims to identify potential new actionable tumor antigens in ovarian cancer by performing immunopeptidomics and assessing protein expression in patient samples. The study identifies TTLL8, POTEE, and PKMYT1 as candidate antigens and investigates their association with patient prognosis and the potential for antigen-specific T cell responses. The findings suggest these antigens as targets for immunotherapy.

title: Flexible analysis of spatial transcriptomics data (FAST): a deconvolution approach.
main_goals: The paper proposes a novel reference-free deconvolution method named Flexible Analysis of Spatial Transcriptomics (FAST) for spatial transcriptomics data. FAST utilizes regularized non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) to incorporate gene expression, spatial, and histology information. It aims to be flexible, robust, and user-friendly, outperforming existing reference-free methods in simulations and revealing tissue structures in real data.

title: TRα1 mutant suppresses KLF9 to cause endometrial metaplasia with ectopic IL-33 expression leading to uterine fibrosis and infertility.
biological_context: Uterine metaplasia and infertility in mice
main_goals: This study aimed to characterize the molecular events leading to infertility in a mouse model with a mutated TRα1 receptor. It identified endometrial metaplasia, suppressed KLF9, ectopic IL-33 expression, and uterine fibrosis as key contributors to infertility. The findings provide insights into uterine epithelial morphogenesis and the impact of thyroid dysfunction on female fertility.

title: A multi-omics spatial framework for host-microbiome dissection within the intestinal tissue microenvironment.
biological_context: Murine colitis model, intestinal tissue microenvironment
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics', 'Host Microbial Interactions']
main_goals: To introduce Microbiome Cartography (MicroCart), a framework for simultaneous in situ probing of host and microbiome across multiple spatial modalities. This enables a deep investigation of the intricate interplay between the host tissue and its microbiome with spatial multi-omics.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics Reveals Cancer and Stromal Cell Heterogeneity Between Center and Invasive Front of Pancreatic Cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Gene Expression Profiling']
main_goals: This study utilized digital spatial profiling to compare the transcriptional profiles of cancer cells and cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) between the tumor center and invasive front of human PDAC. It identified significant inter-regional heterogeneity in pathways related to cellular stress, proliferation, glycolysis, and epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT), confirmed by immunohistochemistry.

title: Decoding the blueprints of embryo development with single-cell and spatial omics.
main_goals: This review provides an in-depth exploration of the latest technical advancements in single-cell and spatial multi-omic methodologies and compiles a systematic catalog of their applications in embryonic development. It deconstructs research strategies, highlights advantages of spatial transcriptomics, and delves into current applications, data analysis algorithms, and untapped potential of these technologies.

title: Towards deciphering the bone marrow microenvironment with spatial multi-omics.
biological_context: Bone marrow microenvironment, specifically the hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) niche.
main_goals: This review summarizes the current understanding of the bone marrow microenvironment, particularly the HSC niche, highlighting insights from advanced imaging and genomic techniques. It also discusses the potential of emerging spatial multi-omics technologies to provide unprecedented detail on bone marrow architecture.

title: Enhancing online speech and language assessment: Item development for the remote adult language experiment (ReAL-E) tool.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Speech planning and production', 'Oral and written language assessment']
main_goals: The paper describes the development of the Remote Adult Language Experiment (ReAL-E) tool, designed to enhance online speech and language assessment in adults. The tool adapts speech planning, production, and language tasks for remote online administration, incorporating expert feedback and pilot testing for improvement.

title: scatterbar: an R package for visualizing proportional data across spatially resolved coordinates.
main_goals: The paper introduces 'scatterbar', an R package extending ggplot2 for visualizing proportional data across spatially resolved coordinates. It aims to address the perceptual challenges of scatter pie plots by using scatter stacked bar plots, enhancing the distinguishability of proportional trends.

title: The next generation of regenerative dentistry: From tooth development biology to periodontal tissue, dental pulp, and whole tooth reconstruction in the clinical setting.
biological_context: Tooth development, periodontal tissue regeneration, dental pulp regeneration, whole tooth reconstruction
main_goals: This review summarizes the fundamental processes of tooth development, recent findings from basic research, and current clinical applications in dental regenerative medicine, including periodontal, alveolar bone, and dental pulp regeneration. It discusses the potential of emerging approaches like organoids and xenotransplantation to achieve complete tooth and periodontal tissue regeneration.

title: Diffusion Smart-seq3 of breast cancer spheroids to explore spatial tumor biology and test evolutionary principles of tumor heterogeneity.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: The paper introduces diffusion Smart-seq3 (Smart-seq3D), a cost-efficient method combining dye diffusion, Smart-seq3xpress, and probabilistic inference for deep single-cell gene expression profiling within the core-periphery axis of spheroids. It aims to reveal spatial gene expression patterns, test evolutionary principles of tumor heterogeneity, and characterize aspects of tumor biology missing from 2D cultures.

title: Developing and validating a HEalthCare NAvigation Competency (HECNAC) Scale for refugees in the United States.
main_goals: This study developed and validated a HEalthCare NAvigation Competency (HECNAC) Scale tailored to refugees in the United States. The scale aims to measure refugees' competencies in navigating the US healthcare system, addressing challenges like unfamiliarity, limited health literacy, and language barriers. The finalized scale consists of ten domains and 35 items, intended to guide tailored interventions and training curricula.

title: Graph contrastive learning of subcellular-resolution spatial transcriptomics improves cell type annotation and reveals critical molecular pathways.
main_goals: Introduces Focus, a semi-supervised graph contrastive learning method that explicitly models RNA's subcellular distribution and community to improve cell type annotation for imaging-based spatial transcriptomics. Focus significantly improves accuracy and F1-score over state-of-the-art algorithms and provides interpretable gene importance scores for uncovering regulatory programs.

title: A high-resolution view of the immune and stromal cell response to Haemophilus ducreyi infection in human volunteers.
biological_context: Human skin infection with Haemophilus ducreyi
main_goals: To provide a high-resolution view of the immune and stromal cell response to Haemophilus ducreyi infection in human skin. The study characterizes multiple cell types within infected human skin using scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics, determining the cellular origin of differentially expressed transcripts. It identifies enriched immune cell types in pustules and highlights type I interferon stimulation in macrophages near abscesses, suggesting mechanisms for the failure of immune clearance.

title: Spatially resolved transcriptomics and graph-based deep learning improve accuracy of routine CNS tumor diagnostics.
main_goals: The paper introduces NePSTA, a spatial transcriptomic analysis pipeline enhanced with graph neural networks for automated histological and molecular diagnostics of CNS tumors. It aims to improve the accuracy of routine diagnostics by integrating morphology and molecular profiling from single tissue sections, even with limited DNA quality and quantity.

title: Spatial metabolic analysis of the regulatory effects of DL-3-n-butylphthalide in a cerebral ischemia-reperfusion mouse model.
main_goals: This study aimed to profile the metabolic alterations induced by DL-3-n-butylphthalide (NBP) during cerebral ischemia-reperfusion using spatial metabolomics. It investigated NBP's therapeutic role in improving energy supply, decreasing autophagy, and enhancing unsaturated fatty acid biosynthesis. The findings shed light on novel mechanisms of NBP efficacy in treating cerebral ischemia/reperfusion injury.

title: Mouse gut blueprint: regionality and resilience.
main_goals: To create a comprehensive blueprint of the mouse gut using spatial transcriptomics, exploring its regionality and resilience under perturbed conditions. The work highlights the adaptive capabilities of the murine gut's regionalized structure and how it functions and responds to external challenges.

title: Protocol to boost the robustness and accuracy of spatial transcriptomics algorithms using ensemble techniques.
main_goals: This paper presents a protocol, WEST (weighted ensemble method for spatial transcriptomics), which utilizes ensemble techniques to enhance the robustness and accuracy of existing spatial transcriptomics algorithms. It details steps for data preprocessing, obtaining embeddings from individual algorithms, and ensemble integration to identify spatial domains and obtain new embeddings.

title: The key role of the NUDT3 gene in lung adenocarcinoma progression and its association with the manganese ion metabolism family.
main_goals: This study aimed to systematically analyze the expression characteristics of the NUDT3 gene in lung adenocarcinoma and its association with tumor progression, integrating single-cell transcriptomic analysis and experimental validation using cell lines. The findings highlight the critical role of NUDT3 in lung adenocarcinoma progression and its potential as a therapeutic target.

title: Revisiting the female germline cell development.
biological_context: Female germline development in flowering plants (specifically Arabidopsis)
data_modalities_used: ['whole-mount single-molecule fluorescence in situ hybridization (smFISH)', 'laser-assisted microdissection (LCM)', 'chromatin immunoprecipitation/sequencing', 'CRISPR gene editing', 'single-cell transcriptome', 'spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: This review highlights recent progress in understanding female germline development in flowering plants, focusing on the roles of gene regulatory networks, epigenetic pathways, cell-cycle regulators, and phytohormones. It discusses key phases and potential distinct pathways restricting germline development.

title: TrimNN: Characterizing cellular community motifs for studying multicellular topological organization in complex tissues.
main_goals: Introduces TrimNN, a novel graph-based deep learning framework to characterize cellular community motifs in spatial omics data. It aims to identify conservative cell organization patterns as countable topological blocks, revealing relationships between spatial cell-type patterns and biological functions.

title: Comparison of imaging-based single-cell resolution spatial transcriptomics profiling platforms using formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor samples.
biological_context: Lung adenocarcinoma and pleural mesothelioma tumor samples
data_modalities_used: ['formalinfixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor samples', 'CosMx', 'MERFISH', 'Xenium', 'bulk RNA sequencing', 'multiplex immunofluorescence', 'GeoMx Digital Spatial Profiler', 'hematoxylin and eosin staining']
main_goals: This study aims to systematically evaluate and compare the performance of commercially available imaging-based spatial transcriptomics platforms (CosMx, MERFISH, Xenium) using FFPE tumor samples. It details intricate differences between platforms, highlights the importance of parameters like tissue age and probe design, and suggests reliable workflows for accurate spatial profiling and molecular discovery.

title: Vertical structure observation from spaceborne lidar ICESat-2 in East China Sea.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Preprocessing', 'Deconvolution', 'Diffuse attenuation coefficient retrieval', 'Particulate backscatter coefficient retrieval']
main_goals: The study introduces an innovative methodology to retrieve the vertical structure of subsurface optical properties in the East China Sea using ICESat-2 spaceborne LiDAR observations. The proposed method involves data preprocessing, sliding accumulation, and deconvolution to calculate the vertical profiles of the diffuse attenuation coefficient and particulate backscatter coefficient. The retrieved results are validated against MODIS and BGC-Argo data, demonstrating the efficacy of ICESat-2 for this application.

title: Three-stage training strategy phase unwrapping method for high speckle noises.
main_goals: The paper proposes a three-stage multi-task phase unwrapping method to address challenges in high speckle noise conditions. The method divides phase retrieval into wrapped phase denoising, wrap count prediction, and unwrapped phase error compensation stages, incorporating a multi-scale spatial attention module. It aims to improve measurement accuracy in noisy environments by reducing noise interference and correcting errors at each stage.

title: Trends in Research of Odontogenic Keratocyst and Ameloblastoma.
biological_context: Odontogenic Keratocyst (OKC) and Ameloblastoma (AM) jaw lesions
covered_analysis_steps: ['Tumor Microenvironment Analysis', 'Cellular Heterogeneity Analysis', 'Radiomics-based diagnosis', 'Pathomics-based prognosis']
main_goals: This review highlights recent advancements and trends in research on Odontogenic Keratocyst (OKC) and Ameloblastoma (AM). It aims to provide insights into their tumor microenvironment, cellular heterogeneity, and therapeutic targets. The paper also discusses the role of artificial intelligence and advanced preclinical models in advancing the understanding and treatment of these jaw lesions.

title: Cell-specific transcriptional signatures of vascular cells in Alzheimer's disease: perspectives, pathways, and therapeutic directions.
main_goals: This paper provides an overview of transcriptional signatures derived from single-cell transcriptomics studies of human brain vascular cells in Alzheimer's disease. It discusses implications for targeted therapy, impaired cellular crosstalk, and highlights pathways for potential therapeutic interventions by integrating multi-omic efforts.

title: Spatial metabolomics to unravel cellular metabolism.
main_goals: This paper provides an overview of spatial metabolomics as a technique to understand cellular metabolism. It discusses how spatial metabolomics can unravel complex metabolic processes within tissues and cells, highlighting its applications and potential.

title: Spatial multi-omics characterizes GPR35-relevant lipid metabolism signatures across liver zonation in MASLD.
main_goals: This study aimed to identify spatially distributed genes and metabolites regulated by GPR35 in different liver zones during MASLD progression using lipid metabolomics, spatial transcriptomics, and spatial metabolomics. The findings highlight GPR35's role in influencing lipid accumulation, inflammation, and hepatocyte damage repair in a zonal manner, thereby impacting MASLD progression.

title: Multiomics characterization of breast angiosarcoma from an Asian cohort reveals enrichment for angiogenesis signaling pathway and tumor-infiltrating macrophages.
biological_context: Breast angiosarcoma and head and neck angiosarcoma
main_goals: This paper investigates the clinical, molecular, and immune features of breast angiosarcoma (AS-B) in an Asian cohort and compares them to head and neck angiosarcoma (AS-HN). It utilized whole genome sequencing, gene expression profiling, and spatial transcriptomics to identify enriched pathways and cell types. The study suggests anti-angiogenic therapy as a potential treatment for AS-B.

title: Examining spatiotemporal dynamics of CO<sub>2</sub> emission at multiscale based on nighttime light data.
main_goals: This research explores the spatiotemporal changes of CO2 emission at different scales based on nighttime light data using a linear regression model. The study aims to provide a scientific basis for emission reduction policies by analyzing trends and spatial dynamics of CO2 emissions.

title: Computational discovery of co-expressed antigens as dual targeting candidates for cancer therapy through bulk, single-cell, and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper presents a computational pipeline to identify co-expressed antigens for bispecific antibody (bsAb) therapy. The pipeline combines bulk and single-cell RNA-seq data to overcome limitations of each method and uses spatial transcriptomics for validation. It aims to expedite the discovery of novel dual targeting candidates for cancer therapy.

title: Improving Spatial Transcriptomics with Membrane-Based Boundary Definition and Enhanced Single-Cell Resolution.
biological_context: Mouse and axolotl livers and brains, axolotl intestine
main_goals: This paper introduces a novel method for defining cell boundaries in spatial transcriptomics by labeling cell membranes with fluorescent proteins. This membrane-based approach enhances gene capture, improves consistency with single-cell RNA-seq data, and achieves higher single-cell resolution, enabling better identification of rare cell types and spatial domains. The method also accurately recognizes multinucleated and anucleated cells, making it a powerful tool for complex tissues.

title: Multiplexed spatial mapping of chromatin features, transcriptome and proteins in tissues.
biological_context: Mouse embryos and mouse brains, neuron differentiation
data_modalities_used: ['histology images', 'multiplexed imaging', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'spatial proteomics', 'histone modifications', 'chromatin accessibility', 'gene expression', 'protein levels']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial proteomics', 'Histone modifications analysis', 'Chromatin accessibility analysis', 'Cell Differentiation analysis']
main_goals: The paper introduces spatial-Mux-seq, a multimodal spatial technology that allows simultaneous profiling of five modalities: two histone modifications, chromatin accessibility, whole transcriptome, and a panel of proteins in tissues. This technology aims to provide a more complete view of cellular identity and enable the study of complex molecular interactions in a spatially resolved manner. The developed technology was applied to mouse embryos and brains to generate detailed multimodal tissue maps, uncovering spatiotemporal relationships among molecular layers during biological processes like neuron differentiation.

title: STAIG: Spatial transcriptomics analysis via image-aided graph contrastive learning for domain exploration and alignment-free integration.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Batch Correction', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: STAIG is a deep-learning model that integrates gene expression, spatial coordinates, and histological images using graph-contrastive learning. It enables alignment-free integration of tissue slices, removes batch effects, and accepts data from various platforms, even without histological images. The model can recognize spatial regions with high precision and uncover new insights into tumor microenvironments.

title: Stromal architecture and fibroblast subpopulations with opposing effects on outcomes in hepatocellular carcinoma.
data_modalities_used: ['pathological image analysis', 'spatial proteomics', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'epigenomic sequencing', 'Stereo-seq']
main_goals: This study dissects the spatial heterogeneity of cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) using pathological image analysis and spatial proteomics. It identifies two distinct stromal archetypes and corresponding fibroblast subpopulations (CAF-FAP and CAF-C7) spatially correlated with patient prognosis. The research highlights functional units and demonstrates that inhibiting CAF-FAP combined with anti-PD-1 improves tumor regression, suggesting stroma-targeted strategies for HCC.

title: Gene expression patterns of the developing human face at single cell resolution reveal cell type contributions to normal facial variation and disease risk.
main_goals: This paper presents a single-nucleus RNA sequencing atlas of human craniofacial development to understand cell type contributions to facial variation and disease risk. It resolves transcriptional dynamics of major cell types and subtypes, reveals human-biased gene expression differences, and links genetic variation to developmental processes. The findings provide insights into the origins of craniofacial disorders, the genetic basis of facial variation, and the evolutionary legacy of ancient hominins.

title: Bypassing cisplatin resistance in Nrf2 hyperactivated head and neck cancer through effective PI3Kinase targeting.
biological_context: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC)
main_goals: This study evaluates the efficacy of PI3K inhibitors (PI3Ki) in bypassing Nrf2-mediated cisplatin resistance in HNSCC. The researchers investigated transcriptomic, metabolomic, and signaling changes driven by PI3Kis in cisplatin-resistant HNSCCs in vitro and tested efficacy in vivo in various xenograft models. The findings highlight the critical role of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway in cisplatin-resistant HNSCC and the therapeutic potential of PI3K inhibitors like gedatolisib.

title: COSIME: Cooperative multi-view integration and Scalable and Interpretable Model Explainer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Dimension Reduction', 'Visualization']
main_goals: COSIME aims to address limitations in single-omics by integrating multi-omics data for improved disease phenotype prediction and interpretability. It utilizes Learnable Optimal Transport for latent feature learning and Monte Carlo sampling for Shapley value estimation, enabling assessment of feature importance and interactions. The method has been validated on simulated and real-world datasets for Alzheimer's disease.

title: MetaLigand: A database for predicting non-peptide ligand mediated cell-cell communication.
main_goals: MetaLigand is an R-based and web-accessible tool designed to infer non-peptide ligand (NPL) production and predict NPL-receptor interactions using transcriptomic data. It compiles data for 233 NPLs and integrates de novo and salvage synthesis pathways. The tool enables visualization of predicted NPL production at single-cell resolution.

title: CellSP: Module discovery and visualization for subcellular spatial transcriptomics data.
biological_context: Mouse brain myelination, axonogenesis, synapse formation; Kidney cancer vs. healthy; Mouse models of Alzheimer's Disease
main_goals: To provide a computational framework (CellSP) for identifying, visualizing, and characterizing consistent subcellular spatial patterns of mRNA. CellSP introduces 'gene-cell modules' and offers functional insights, demonstrating reliability across diverse tissues and technologies.

title: Bioinformatic and biochemical analysis uncovers novel activity in the 2-ER subfamily of OYEs.
main_goals: This paper analyzes the 2-ER subfamily of old yellow enzymes (OYEs) using bioinformatics and biochemical methods. It explores pseudo-anaerobic preparation as a method for studying oxygen-sensitive 2-ERs, identifies novel mutations in a subset of these enzymes, and reveals a new N-methyl-proline demethylation activity in OYE_Bi from Burkholderia insecticola.

title: Microfluidics for morpholomics and spatial omics applications.
main_goals: This review explores the use of microfluidic technologies for morpholomics and spatial omics, focusing on single-cell and tissue characterization. It highlights how microfluidic designs enable precise fluid manipulation for morpholomics and discusses spatial barcoding with micrometer resolutions for tissue profiling. The review also outlines how microfluidics can integrate multiple omics fields and discusses challenges in practical translation.

title: Statistical identification of cell type-specific spatially variable genes in spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Lung cancer, Kidney cancer, Alzheimer's disease
main_goals: The paper introduces Celina, a statistical method for systematically detecting cell type-specific spatially variable genes (ct-SVGs). Celina uses a spatially varying coefficient model to capture gene expression patterns in relation to cell type distribution, ensuring Type I error control and high power. It is effective for both single-cell and spot-resolution spatial transcriptomics.

title: The spatial landscape of cancer hallmarks reveals patterns of tumor ecological dynamics and drug sensitivity.
biological_context: Human primary untreated tumors across 10 cancer types, with a focus on bladder cancer for treatment sensitivity analysis.
main_goals: This paper explores the spatial distribution of cancer hallmarks across various tumor types using spatial transcriptomics. It investigates how hallmark activity is organized between cancer cells and the tumor microenvironment, how genomic distance between subclones affects hallmark specialization, and how hallmark relationships relate to drug sensitivity in bladder cancer.

title: Reverse-engineering the FLT3-PI3K/AKT axis to enhance TILs function and improve prognosis in ovarian and cervical cancers.
main_goals: This study integrated single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to explore immune regulation in ovarian and cervical cancers, focusing on the PI3K/AKT pathway and FLT3. It provides spatially resolved evidence of FLT3's immune-modulatory role and suggests it as a promising immunotherapeutic target.

title: DeepExtremeCubes: Earth system spatio-temporal data for assessing compound heatwave and drought impacts.
data_modalities_used: ['Sentinel-2 L2A images', 'ERA5-Land variables', 'land cover maps', 'topography maps']
main_goals: Introduce the DeepExtremeCubes database to facilitate the analysis of compound heatwave and drought extreme impacts on terrestrial ecosystems. The database aims to streamline data accessibility and pre-processing for machine learning models, enabling biosphere dynamics forecasting.

title: Tertiary lymphoid structures as a biomarker in immunotherapy and beyond: Advancing towards clinical application.
main_goals: This review discusses recent advances in TLS assessment, including gene expression signatures, histological analysis, artificial intelligence, and spatial omics. It explores the structure, formation, and role of TLS in disease prognosis, particularly in immunotherapy effectiveness in cancer. The paper highlights the need for novel techniques for precise characterization of TLS and their significance as predictive biomarkers.

title: HemaScope: A Tool for Analyzing Single-cell and Spatial Transcriptomics Data of Hematopoietic Cells.
biological_context: Hematopoietic cells, human bone marrow, acute myeloid leukemia, angioimmunoblastic T cell lymphoma, primary central nervous system lymphoma
covered_analysis_steps: ['Quality Control', 'Basic Analysis', 'Cell Atlas Construction', 'Cellular Heterogeneity Exploration', 'Dynamical Examination', 'Spatial Analysis', 'Microenvironment Analysis', 'Lineage Affiliation Evaluation', 'Cell Cycle Prediction', 'Marker Gene Collection']
main_goals: HemaScope is a specialized bioinformatics toolkit for analyzing single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data of hematopoietic cells. It offers modular designs for quality control, analysis, cell atlas construction, heterogeneity exploration, spatial and microenvironment analysis, and includes hematopoietic cell-specific features. The toolkit is available in R, web server, Docker, and Shiny graphical interface forms to enhance user experience.

title: A 2D cell segmentation protocol for monitoring multiple STAT signaling pathways by fluorescence microscopy.
main_goals: This paper describes a protocol for high-fidelity segmentation of the nucleus and cytoplasm in cell culture, applicable to monitoring signaling pathways by fluorescence microscopy. The approach is presented as an improvement over previous methods and an alternative to neural-network-based segmentation, using conventional techniques. It enables simultaneous monitoring of multiple STAT isoforms.

title: Enhancing waste classification accuracy with Channel and Spatial Attention-Based Multiblock Convolutional Network.
main_goals: This research proposes a novel Channel and Spatial Attention-Based Multiblock Convolutional Network for accurately classifying municipal waste. The method aims to enhance feature learning and classification accuracy by utilizing a unique attention mechanism, data augmentation, and image patching to overcome challenges in computational complexity, time consumption, and appearance variability in waste materials. The experimental validation demonstrates higher accuracy and lower error rates compared to existing strategies, making it suitable for real-time municipal waste classification.

title: Time-Series Change Detection Using KOMPSAT-5 Data with Statistical Homogeneous Pixel Selection Algorithm.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Preprocessing', 'Co-registration', 'Radiometric terrain correction', 'Normalization', 'Speckle filtering', 'Homogeneous pixel selection', 'Coherence-based analysis', 'Adaptive thresholding', 'Morphological operations', 'Small-segment removal']
main_goals: This study presents a robust change detection methodology for urban changes using KOMPSAT-5 time-series data. It details a comprehensive preprocessing framework and a statistical homogeneous pixel selection algorithm combined with coherence-based analysis to quantify temporal decorrelation and detect changes. The method achieved high reliability with 92% accuracy.

title: Gesture Recognition with Residual LSTM Attention Using Millimeter-Wave Radar.
main_goals: This paper proposes a gesture recognition algorithm based on ResNet Long Short-Term Memory with an Attention Mechanism (RLA) for non-contact scenarios using millimeter-wave radar. It addresses challenges in multi-feature input complexity and single-feature recognition performance by combining residual networks with attention modules and using LSTMs for temporal feature processing.

title: Application of Spatial Transcriptomics in Digestive System Tumors.
main_goals: This review provides a concise introduction to spatial transcriptomics and summarizes recent advances, application prospects, and technical challenges of these technologies in digestive system tumor research. It also discusses the importance of combining spatial transcriptomics with single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq), artificial intelligence, and machine learning in digestive system cancer research.

title: From Genes to Clinical Practice: Exploring the Genomic Underpinnings of Endometrial Cancer.
main_goals: This review explores the genomic underpinnings of endometrial cancer (EC), from genes to clinical practice. It highlights the ongoing need for multidisciplinary research and collaboration to address the complexities of EC and improve diagnosis, treatment, and patient outcomes.

title: Proximity Labeling: Precise Proteomics Technology for Mapping Receptor Protein Neighborhoods at the Cancer Cell Surface.
main_goals: This review explores the fundamental principles, technologies, advantages, limitations, and applications of proximity labeling in cancer biology, focusing on mapping receptor microenvironments. By advancing mechanistic insights into cancer cell receptor signaling mechanisms, proximity labeling is poised to transform cancer research, improve targeted therapies, and illuminate avenues to overcome drug resistance.

title: Natural killer cells occupy unique spatial neighborhoods in HER2<sup>-</sup> and HER2<sup>+</sup> human breast cancers.
biological_context: HER2- and HER2+ human breast cancers
main_goals: This study aims to evaluate NK cells at the single-cell spatial proteomics level and illustrates how spatial characteristics of NK cell neighborhoods vary within the context of HER2- and HER2+ breast cancers. It utilizes multiplex immunohistochemistry to quantitatively interrogate leukocyte lineages, focusing on NK cells and their phenotypes, in breast cancer patient cohorts.

title: Author Correction: Resolving tissue complexity by multimodal spatial omics modeling with MISO.
main_goals: The paper introduces MISO, a multimodal spatial omics modeling pipeline for resolving tissue complexity.

title: High-resolution spatially resolved proteomics of complex tissues based on microfluidics and transfer learning.
biological_context: Mouse cerebellum, rat villus, human breast cancer
main_goals: The paper presents PLATO, an integrated framework combining microfluidics with deep learning to enable high-resolution mapping of thousands of proteins in whole tissue sections. It validates the framework by profiling the spatial proteome of the mouse cerebellum and then applies it to rat villus and human breast cancer samples to uncover proteomic dynamics associated with disease states.

title: FL-W3S: Cross-domain federated learning for weakly supervised semantic segmentation of white blood cells.
biological_context: White blood cells in microscopic images
main_goals: The paper proposes a cross-domain federated learning method for weakly supervised semantic segmentation of white blood cells. It uses a multi-class token transformer model to learn relationships between patch tokens and class tokens. The method aims to improve segmentation performance on different datasets.

title: Resolving spatiotemporal dynamics in bacterial multicellular populations: approaches and challenges.
data_modalities_used: ['microscopy', 'mass spectrometry imaging', 'flow cytometry', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'single-bacteria RNA sequencing']
main_goals: This review discusses technologies for studying bacterial multicellularity at the single-cell level, focusing on microscopic techniques, mass spectrometry imaging, flow cytometry, spatial transcriptomics, and single-bacteria RNA sequencing. It encourages exploring the synergistic potential of new technologies in the study of bacterial multicellularity and highlights how resolving population structures at the single-cell level can elucidate the overarching functions of bacterial multicellular populations.

title: Detection of Cancer Stem Cells from Patient Samples.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'spatial proteomics', 'multiplexed imaging', 'liquid biopsy', 'in vivo imaging', 'single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq)']
main_goals: This review summarizes various techniques for detecting cancer stem cells (CSCs) from patient samples, highlighting their benefits and limitations. It also covers methods designed to detect CSCs based on secreted and niche-associated signaling factors. Spatial and single-cell methods for analyzing patient tumor tissues and noninvasive techniques such as liquid biopsy and in vivo imaging are discussed.

title: Advancing precision cancer immunotherapy drug development, administration, and response prediction with AI-enabled Raman spectroscopy.
main_goals: This paper explores the application of Raman spectroscopy as a tumor profiling tool for precision immunotherapy. It examines how Raman spectroscopy's non-invasive, label-free approach can deepen our understanding of intricate inter- and intra-cellular interactions within the tumor-immune microenvironment. Lastly, it highlights the translational potential of Raman for its integration in clinical practice for safe and precise patient-centric immunotherapy.

title: Exploring the role of metabolic pathways in TNBC immunotherapy: insights from single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This review article provides an overview of the interplay between metabolic pathways and immune function in the context of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). It highlights recent advancements in single-cell and spatial transcriptomics technologies and explores the implications of metabolic-immune interactions for the efficacy of immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) therapies in TNBC. The review also outlines future directions and the potential for combination therapies that integrate metabolic modulation with immunotherapeutic approaches.

title: Energy consumption prediction using modified deep CNN-Bi LSTM with attention mechanism.
main_goals: The paper proposes a modified Deep CNN-Bi-LSTM with attention mechanism for energy consumption prediction. The goal is to improve prediction accuracy by extracting temporal and spatial complex features from household energy consumption data. The model's performance is evaluated using MSE, MAPE, and RMSE metrics.

title: Mapping the topography of spatial gene expression with interpretable deep learning.
main_goals: The paper develops GASTON, an unsupervised and interpretable deep learning algorithm for spatial transcriptomics data. GASTON learns the isodepth, spatial gradients, and piecewise linear expression functions to model gene expression. It accurately identifies spatial domains and marker genes in various tissues and gradients of neuronal differentiation and metabolism.

title: ETSpy: A HyperSpy extension package for electron tomography data processing and reconstruction.
biological_context: Materials characterization at the nano- and atomic-scales
main_goals: The paper describes the capabilities of ETSpy, a new, open-source software package built upon HyperSpy for electron tomography data processing and reconstruction. It presents the basic usage of the software and some specific applications. The software aids in pre-processing steps like spatial binning, image registration, and tilt-axis alignment.

title: Highly multiplexed spatial transcriptomics in bacteria.
biological_context: Escherichia coli and Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron in mammalian colon
main_goals: The paper introduces bacterial-MERFISH, a method combining volumetric expansion with multiplexed error-robust fluorescence in situ hybridization (MERFISH). This method enables high-throughput, spatially resolved profiling of thousands of operons within individual bacteria. The method is then used to dissect the response of Escherichia coli to carbon starvation, map subcellular RNA organization, and chart the adaptation of a gut commensal Bacteroides thetaiotaomicron to micrometer-scale niches in the mammalian colon.

title: Spatially resolved transcriptomics of benign and malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors.
main_goals: The study aimed to determine the spatial and biological heterogeneity of PNSTs using spatial transcriptomics on diseased peripheral nerve tissue. They identified distinct transcriptional signatures differentiating PNSTs and provided a spatial cellular differentiation map for MPNST. The study integrates morphological and high-dimensional molecular data to improve PNSTs classification.

title: Novel Integration of Spatial and Single-Cell Omics Data Sets Enables Deeper Insights into IPF Pathogenesis.
main_goals: The study integrates spatial multi-omics with scRNA-seq data to identify disease-associated cell types and potential targets for novel therapies in IPF intervention. It uses published spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing data and adopts the Query method and the Overlap method to determine cell type enrichments in histopathological regions. The approach aims to be applicable to other disease areas characterized by spatial heterogeneity.

title: Organizational Principles of the Primate Cerebral Cortex at the Single-Cell Level.
main_goals: The study aims to understand the organizational principles of neurons in the macaque cerebral cortex. By analyzing single-cell spatial transcriptomes, the researchers discover non-random neuronal distribution and the presence of neuronal clusters with specific cell-type combinations. The study suggests conserved organizational principles across cortical regions.

title: Assessing spatial sequencing and imaging approaches to capture the molecular and pathological heterogeneity of archived cancer tissues.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: The study aims to assess and optimize spatial transcriptomics (ST) protocols and imaging methods (RNAScope, CODEX) for analyzing archived cancer tissues. It evaluates the performance of these methods on formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tissues, considering RNA quality and tissue storage duration. The ultimate goal is to quantify tumor heterogeneity by integrating gene expression profiles with pathological information.

title: Novel photocrosslinking chemical probes utilized for high-resolution spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper introduces CrossSeq, a novel method employing photocrosslinking fluorescent probes and confocal microscopy for multiplexed spatial transcriptomic analysis. It defines photoactivity profiles of phenyl azide and diazirine crosslinking scaffolds and applies CrossSeq to investigate gene expression changes in a metastatic cancer migration model. The goal is to provide a valuable tool for spatial transcriptomic analysis using conventional microscopy and analysis techniques.

title: APOE Christchurch enhances a disease-associated microglial response to plaque but suppresses response to tau pathology.
main_goals: The study investigates the effect of the ApoeCh variant on the development of AD-related pathology using the 5xFAD model of amyloidosis and the PS19 model of tauopathy. It explores the impact of the ApoeCh variant on AD pathological development and the brain's response to plaques and tau using immunohistochemical, biochemical analysis, single-cell spatial omics, and bulk proteomics. The findings highlight the ability of the ApoeCh variant to modulate microglial responses based on the type of pathology.

title: Tissue-resident memory CD8 T cell diversity is spatiotemporally imprinted.
main_goals: The study aims to understand the origins of T<sub>RM</sub> cell diversity in the small intestine by investigating the spatiotemporal distribution of T<sub>RM</sub> cell differentiation. The goal is to determine how distinct tissue niches drive phenotypic heterogeneity of T<sub>RM</sub> cells. The study reveals that the regionalized signaling of the intestinal architecture supports two distinct T<sub>RM</sub> cell states.

title: A novel multiple directional shearing interferometry system with synchronous polarization phase shifting.
main_goals: This paper introduces a novel multi-directional shearing synchronous polarization phase-shifting interferometer utilizing a birefringent crystal displacer. The system aims to mitigate nonlinear issues and environmental influences. It reconstructs the wavefront by fitting coefficients obtained from multi-directional differential wavefront data.

title: Molecular and cellular morphology of placenta unveils new mechanisms of reproductive immunology.
main_goals: The study aims to investigate the cellular and molecular characteristics of early and late phase placentas to understand the immune regulation of human reproductive process. It seeks to trace the fetal and maternal origin of cells and understand the immune interactions between the fetus and the mother. The findings suggest a fetus-driven mechanism of immune balance involving cellular and humoral immunity in human reproduction.

title: Mass Spectrometry-Based Spatial Multiomics Revealed Bioaccumulation Preference and Region-Specific Responses of PFOS in Mice Cardiac Tissue.
data_modalities_used: ['Mass Spectrometry', 'Mass spectrometry imaging', 'spatial proteomics', 'liquid chromatography MS analysis']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Proteomics Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: The paper develops a mass-spectrometry (MS)-based spatial multiomics workflow, integrating matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization MS imaging, laser microdissection, and liquid chromatography MS analysis. This integrated workflow elucidates the spatial distribution of PFOS in mouse cardiac tissue, highlighting its preferential accumulation in the pericardium over the myocardium. The approach demonstrates significant potential for revealing complex molecular mechanisms underlying the health impacts of environmental pollutants.

title: The XCL1-XCR1 axis supports intestinal tissue residency and antitumor immunity.
main_goals: The main goal was to investigate the role of the XCL1-XCR1 axis in intestinal tissue-resident memory T cell (TRM) formation and antitumor immunity. The study found that XCL1 is critical for TRM formation and that cDC1 supports the positioning of intestinal CD8+ T cells. Enforced Xcl1 expression promoted intratumoral cDC1 accumulation and T cell persistence, leading to improved survival.

title: MDD-SSTNet: detecting major depressive disorder by exploring spectral-spatial-temporal information on resting-state electroencephalography data based on deep neural network.
main_goals: The paper proposes a novel model, MDD-SSTNet, for detecting major depressive disorder by exploring spectral-spatial-temporal information from resting-state EEG with a deep convolutional neural network. The model uses a Sinc filter for frequency band features and parallel branches for temporal and spatial feature extraction. It outperforms baseline models on two datasets in terms of classification accuracy.

title: Single-cell transcriptomics reveals the heterogeneity and function of mast cells in human ccRCC.
main_goals: This study investigates the heterogeneity and effects of mast cells (MCs) in clear cell renal carcinoma (ccRCC) using single-cell transcriptomics, spatial transcriptomics and multiplex immunohistochemistry. The study revealed increased MC density in ccRCC and a shift in the MC phenotype from CTSG<sup>high</sup>MCs to more activated VEGFA+MCs, providing a potential therapeutic target for inhibiting ccRCC progression.

title: Targeting immune cellular populations and transcription factors: unraveling the therapeutic potential of JQF for NAFLD.
biological_context: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in mice
main_goals: The main goal was to investigate the mechanism of action of Jiangtang Qingre Formula (JQF) in treating NAFLD. The study used a high-fat diet-induced NAFLD mouse model and employed single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to understand JQF's treatment mechanisms by analyzing immune cell populations and transcription factors.

title: Comprehensive single-cell atlas of colorectal neuroendocrine tumors with liver metastases: unraveling tumor microenvironment heterogeneity between primary lesions and metastases.
biological_context: Colorectal neuroendocrine tumors with liver metastases
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'bulk RNA sequencing', 'multiplex immunohistochemistry', 'multiplex immunofluorescence']
main_goals: The study aims to elucidate the variations in the tumor microenvironment (TME) between primary lesions (PL) and liver metastases (LM) in colorectal neuroendocrine tumors with liver metastases (CRNELM) patients using single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, bulk RNA sequencing, and multiplex immunohistochemistry/immunofluorescence. The research identified distinct cell subsets and receptor-ligand interactions that may drive TME discrepancies and support metastatic tumor growth, highlighting potential therapeutic targets.

title: Techniques and analytic workflow for spatial transcriptomics and its application to allergy and inflammation.
main_goals: This review summarizes recent developments in spatial transcriptomics, its application to allergy and inflammation, and recent single-cell resolution platforms designed for spatial transcriptomics with a focus on data processing and analyses for efficient biologic interpretation of data. It highlights the critical insights into tissue architecture and cellular interactions that are unattainable with traditional transcriptomics methods.

title: Spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing revealed dendritic cell-mediated inflammation in keratoconus.
main_goals: This study investigates molecular and cellular variations in keratoconus (KC) using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing. It identifies inflammatory responses in the cornea, particularly the role of dendritic cells (DCs) and the IL-1β pathway in KC pathogenesis. The findings highlight the importance of inflammation in KC and suggest anti-inflammatory treatments as potential adjuvant therapy.

title: Finding and Profiling Renal Cells with Spatial Transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper aims to identify and profile renal cells using spatial transcriptomics.

title: Single-cell and Spatial Transcriptomics Illuminate Bat Immunity and Barrier Tissue Evolution.
biological_context: Egyptian fruit bat gut, lung, and blood cells
main_goals: To investigate transcriptional patterns in Egyptian fruit bat tissues using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics of gut, lung, and blood cells. The study compares gene expression between bat, mouse, and human to identify unique transcriptional divergences, particularly in the complement system, that may be linked to bat resistance to pathogens. The study highlights the intricate evolutionary landscape of bat immunity.

title: Optimizing Prescribing for Individuals With Type 2 Diabetes and Chronic Kidney Disease Through the Development and Validation of Algorithms for Community Pharmacists.
biological_context: Type 2 Diabetes and Chronic Kidney Disease
main_goals: The main goal of this study was to develop and validate algorithms for community pharmacists to identify and manage type 2 diabetes (T2D) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) in primary care. The algorithms were designed to assist in prescribing kidney-protective medications for individuals with an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 30 to 60 mL/min/1.73 m².

title: Benchmarking cell type annotation methods for 10x Xenium spatial transcriptomics data.
main_goals: The paper compares the performance of five reference-based cell type annotation methods (SingleR, Azimuth, RCTD, scPred and scmapCell) with a marker-gene-based manual annotation method on imaging-based Xenium data of human breast cancer. It demonstrates a practical workflow for preparing a high-quality single-cell RNA reference, evaluating accuracy, and estimating the running time for reference-based cell type annotation tools. The study identifies SingleR as the best-performing tool.

title: A practical guide for choosing an optimal spatial transcriptomics technology from seven major commercially available options.
main_goals: The paper aims to analyze and compare seven major commercially available spatial platforms to guide researchers in choosing the most suitable option for their needs.

title: Spatiotemporal transcriptome and metabolome landscapes of cotton somatic embryos.
main_goals: To investigate the spatial and single-cell expression profiles of key genes and the metabolic patterns of key metabolites during cotton somatic embryogenesis by integrated scRNA-seq, ST, and SM. To functionally characterize the potential roles of two representative marker genes, AATP1 and DOX2, in the regulation of cotton somatic embryo development. To provide a publicly available web-based resource database for future studies.

title: Genomic and transcriptomic signatures of sequential carcinogenesis from papillary neoplasm to biliary tract cancer.
main_goals: The study aims to provide a comprehensive mutational and spatial transcriptomic landscape of papillary neoplasms of the bile duct and gallbladder. It offers insights into the mechanism of sequential carcinogenesis in papillary biliary tract tumors, pathology-genomic correlations, and potential therapeutic targets.

title: Parenchymal and inflammatory responses to ozone exposure in the aging healthy and surfactant protein C mutant lung.
biological_context: Aging wild-type and mutant mouse lung exposed to ozone
main_goals: The study examines structural, mechanical, and immunological responses to single acute ozone exposure in young, middle-aged, and old mice with and without a mutation in surfactant protein C. It uses spatial transcriptomics to highlight age-dependent shifts in inflammatory and extracellular matrix organization signaling. The results illustrate the structural and immunological impact of ozone in the aging wild-type and mutant lung.

title: The Dyson equalizer: adaptive noise stabilization for low-rank signal detection and recovery.
biological_context: single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics data
main_goals: The paper develops an adaptive normalization procedure to equalize noise variance in heteroskedastic data matrices. The approach leverages random matrix theory to infer noise levels and enforce the Marchenko-Pastur law. The method aims to improve signal detection and recovery in heteroskedastic settings, and is applied to single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics data.

title: EPISeg: Automated segmentation of the spinal cord on echo planar images using open-access multi-center data.
main_goals: This paper presents a deep learning-based model, EPISeg, for the automatic segmentation of the spinal cord on gradient-echo EPI data. The model demonstrates improved segmentation quality compared to other available models and is resilient to different acquisition protocols and common artifacts in fMRI data. The training code is available, and the model is integrated into the Spinal Cord Toolbox as a command-line tool.
