title: Identifying spatially variable genes by projecting to morphologically relevant curves.
main_goals: The paper introduces a methodology based on spectral graph theory to identify spatially variable genes by projecting to morphologically relevant curves. It uses a generalized additive model (GAM) to detect genes with variable expression in a new coordinate system that reflects tissue morphology. The approach aims to improve performance in identifying spatial loci and estimating gene expression patterns.

title: Spatial Transcriptomic Analysis Identifies a SERPINA3-Expressing Astrocytic State Associated with the Human Neuritic Plaque Microenvironment.
main_goals: This paper uses spatial transcriptomics to analyze the microenvironment of neuritic amyloid plaques in Alzheimer's disease. It identifies a SERPINA3-expressing astrocytic state (Ast.5) associated with the plaques, and validates findings via immunofluorescence.

title: Generalized cell phenotyping for spatial proteomics with language-informed vision models.
main_goals: The paper introduces a novel approach to cell phenotyping for spatial proteomics using a language-informed vision model. It aims to address the challenge of generalization across different datasets with varying marker panels. The method demonstrates superior accuracy and generalizability compared to existing methods.

title: Integration of Imaging-based and Sequencing-based Spatial Omics Mapping on the Same Tissue Section via DBiTplus.
biological_context: Mouse embryos, normal human lymph nodes, human lymphoma FFPE tissue
main_goals: DBiTplus introduces an integrative multi-modality spatial omics approach that combines sequencing-based spatial transcriptomics and image-based spatial protein profiling on the same tissue section. This enables single-cell resolution cell typing and genome-scale interrogation of biological pathways. The pipeline offers a unified workflow for spatially resolved single-cell atlasing and exploration of biological pathways.

title: Spatially Resolved in vivo CRISPR Screen Sequencing via Perturb-DBiT.
biological_context: Human cancer metastatic colonization model, immune-competent syngeneic model
main_goals: The paper introduces Perturb-DBiT, a platform for simultaneous co-sequencing of spatial transcriptomes and guide RNAs (gRNAs) for in vivo CRISPR screens. This allows for the comprehensive understanding of how genetic modifications affect cellular behavior and tissue architecture across various cancer models. The method enables the evaluation of the impact of each knockout on tumor initiation, development, metastasis, histopathology, and immune landscape.

title: Single-cell spatial mapping reveals alteration of cell type composition and tissue microenvironment during early colorectal cancer formation.
main_goals: The paper aims to analyze the pre-cancer and tumor microenvironment in colorectal cancer using single-cell multiplexed imaging. It investigates changes in cell type composition and spatial organization during the progression from normal mucosa to FAP polyps and adenocarcinoma, as well as sporadic colorectal cancer.

title: Single-cell spatial transcriptomics of fixed, paraffin-embedded biopsies reveals colitis-associated cell networks.
main_goals: The study aimed to apply imaging-based, single-cell spatial transcriptomics (iSCST) to archived clinical FFPE mucosal biopsies from patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). They developed a robust framework for analyzing these samples and identified colitis-associated cell networks and signatures associated with Vedolizumab responsiveness. The results could help in risk-stratifying patients.

title: Accurate Spatial Heterogeneity Dissection and Gene Regulation Interpretation for Spatial Transcriptomics using Dual Graph Contrastive Learning.
main_goals: The paper introduces stDCL, a dual graph contrastive learning method, to identify spatial domains and interpret gene regulation in spatial transcriptomics data. The method preserves critical information within the latent embedding representations and ensures that the latent embedding representation closely resembles the actual spatial distribution. stDCL is demonstrated to be effective in identifying spatial domains and interpreting gene regulation, as well as in reconstructing spatial hierarchical structures and refining differential expression assessment.

title: Childhood-onset lupus nephritis is characterized by complex interactions between kidney stroma and infiltrating immune cells.
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to analyze kidney tissue from children with lupus nephritis. The research aims to understand the interactions between kidney stromal cells and infiltrating immune cells and how these interactions contribute to the disease. The study also aims to identify gene expression patterns that correlate with disease activity.

title: An optimal deep learning approach for breast cancer detection and classification with pre-trained CNN-based feature learning mechanism.
main_goals: This paper proposes a deep learning-based system for breast cancer detection and classification. The system uses a DCUNet for segmentation, SCADN-121 for feature learning, ECSO for feature selection, and ECSO-LSTM for classification to achieve high accuracy in breast cancer classification.

title: Tumor microenvironment and cancer metastasis: molecular mechanisms and therapeutic implications.
main_goals: This review summarizes the current research on how the tumor microenvironment (TME) promotes metastasis through molecular pathways. It highlights the roles of TGF-β and VEGF signaling and explores metabolic reprogramming of tumor and stromal cells. The study also evaluates therapeutic strategies targeting these interactions to disrupt metastasis.

title: Single-Nucleus and Spatial Transcriptomics Revealing Host Response Differences Triggered by Mutated Virus in Severe Dengue.
biological_context: Dengue virus infection in murine models
main_goals: This study investigates the host response differences triggered by a mutated Dengue virus in murine models using single-nucleus and spatial RNA sequencing. The research identifies the host factor Nrg4 and its role in the NRG/ErbB pathway in severe dengue symptoms. The findings aim to provide a framework for understanding disturbed host responses in severe dengue.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics and Single-Nucleus Multi-Omics Analysis Revealing the Impact of High Maternal Folic Acid Supplementation on Offspring Brain Development.
main_goals: This study investigates the impact of high maternal folic acid supplementation on offspring brain development using spatial transcriptomics and single-nucleus multi-omics approaches. The findings reveal specific brain regions, cell types, gene expressions, and pathways affected by the supplementation.

title: Integration of Machine Learning and Experimental Validation to Identify Anoikis-Related Prognostic Signature for Predicting the Breast Cancer Tumor Microenvironment and Treatment Response.
main_goals: The paper aims to identify an anoikis-related prognostic signature (ANRS) for breast cancer patients using machine learning methods. It investigates the correlation between ANRS and the tumor microenvironment, drug sensitivity, and immunotherapy response. Furthermore, the study validates the expression of prognostic ANRGs and identifies potential inhibitors for specific genes.

title: Molecular Mechanisms of Heterosis and Its Applications in Tree Breeding: Progress and Perspectives.
main_goals: This review summarizes the genetic, molecular, and epigenetic mechanisms underlying heterosis and its applications in tree breeding. It also discusses recent advances in predictive methods for heterosis and explores the potential of integrating multi-omics approaches and emerging gene-editing tools to revolutionize tree hybrid breeding.

title: Deep-Learning-Based Segmentation of Cells and Analysis (DL-SCAN).
main_goals: The paper introduces DL-SCAN, a deep-learning-based tool for automated segmentation and analysis of fluorescence microscopy images. It aims to overcome the limitations of manual image analysis, particularly in scenarios with low signal-to-noise ratios, to improve reproducibility and efficiency. The tool's application to ion dynamics in neurons and astrocytes is demonstrated.

title: Unveiling Tumorigenesis Mechanisms and Drug Therapy in Neuroblastoma by Mass Spectrometry Based Proteomics.
main_goals: This review focuses on the application of mass spectrometry-based proteomics in neuroblastoma research, covering areas like tumorigenesis, drug treatment, and drug resistance. It highlights potential protein signatures and signaling pathways with translational values, and discusses emerging proteomic techniques like single-cell and spatial proteomics for studying intratumor heterogeneity.

title: Decoding senescence of aging single cells at the nexus of biomaterials, microfluidics, and spatial omics.
main_goals: This perspective paper highlights the key aspects of how biomaterials provide non-cellular cues to cell aging, microfluidics recapitulate flow-induced and multi-cellular dynamics, and spatial omics analyses dissect the coordination of several biomarkers of senescence as a function of cell interactions in distinct tissue environments. It also includes an overview of how senescence and immune dysregulation play a role in organ aging, cancer, wound healing, Alzheimer's, and osteoporosis, and discusses the societal impact of aging and anti-aging interventions.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals substantial heterogeneity in triple-negative breast cancer with potential clinical implications.
main_goals: This paper investigates the tumor architecture and microenvironment of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) using spatial transcriptomics. It identifies nine spatial archetypes of TNBC and associates them with disease outcome and response to immunotherapy. The work aims to provide insights into the complexity of TNBC and potential clinical applications.

title: Visium spatial transcriptomics and proteomics identifies novel hepatic cell populations and transcriptomic signatures of alcohol-associated hepatitis.
main_goals: This study used spatial transcriptomics and proteomics to identify cell populations and their associated transcriptomic and proteomic changes in alcohol-associated hepatitis. It identified global cell type alterations and transcriptomic changes between AH and non-ALD controls. These findings contribute to identifying novel therapeutics.

title: Tau Accumulation Induces Microglial State Alterations in Alzheimer's Disease Model Mice.
main_goals: The study investigates the relationship between tau pathology and microglial states in an Alzheimer's disease model. It aims to determine how tau propagation and accumulation affect microglial phenotypes using spatial transcriptomics and single-nucleus RNA sequencing. The researchers showed that tau accumulation induces a disease-associated microglial phenotype in AD model mice.

title: Identification of Spatial Specific Lipid Metabolic Signatures in Long-Standing Diabetic Kidney Disease.
main_goals: This study investigates lipid metabolism profiles in long-standing diabetic kidney disease (LDKD) using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial metabolomics. The research identifies two injured cell types and their metabolic differences, revealing injury-associated cellular processes and potential molecular mechanisms.

title: Spatial Omics: Navigating Neuroscience Research into the New Era.
main_goals: This paper provides a comprehensive overview of spatial omics technologies, particularly focusing on their application in neuroscience research. It discusses various methods, including FISH-based, in situ sequencing-based (ISS), and NGS-based methods, highlighting their capabilities and limitations in the context of brain tissue analysis. The review aims to offer insights into the advancements and future directions of spatial omics for studying the brain.

title: Comprehensive single-cell aging atlas of healthy mammary tissues reveals shared epigenomic and transcriptomic signatures of aging and cancer.
biological_context: Mouse mammary glands aging and breast cancer
main_goals: This study investigates how aging affects mouse mammary glands at single-cell resolution using transcriptomic and epigenomic approaches. It aims to uncover the impact of age-related cellular and molecular changes on breast cancer initiation. The study identifies shifts in cell proportions and identities within epithelial, immune, and stromal cells, suggesting implications for cell plasticity and neoplasia risk.

title: The lives of cells, recorded.
main_goals: This Perspective explores the rationale and technical basis of DNA recording in cells, discussing what aspects of cellular biology might be recorded and how, and the types of discovery this paradigm will enable.

title: A composite scaling network of EfficientNet for improving spatial domain identification performance.
main_goals: The paper introduces EfNST, a novel method based on an efficient composite scaling network of EfficientNet, to improve spatial domain identification performance in spatial transcriptomics data. EfNST aims to learn multi-scale image features and exhibits high accuracy in discerning fine tissue structures. The study highlights the algorithm's scalability and operational efficiency.

title: Spatial and temporal patterns of brain neural activity mediating human thermal sensations.
main_goals: This study aimed to elucidate the spatial and temporal patterns of brain neural activity associated with cold and hot sensations. EEG data was analyzed using independent component analysis to identify patterns of brain neural activity. The results suggested that cold and hot sensations are processed through different temporal brain neural activity patterns in overlapping brain regions.

title: IoT based healthcare system using fractional dung beetle optimization enabled deep learning for breast cancer classification.
main_goals: This paper introduces an IoT-based healthcare system for breast cancer detection. It utilizes a novel method called SqueezeNet_Fractional Dung Beetle Optimization (Squeeze_FDBO) for image processing and classification. The method aims to improve accuracy in breast cancer diagnosis by combining deep learning with optimization techniques.

title: Spatial differences in gene expression across the dorsal raphe nucleus in a model of early Alzheimer's disease.
main_goals: This study uses Visium Spatial Gene Expression to analyze transcriptomic changes in the dorsal raphe nucleus (DRN) of a preclinical Alzheimer's disease model (htau mice). The goal is to identify genes associated with the susceptibility or resistance of 5-HT neurons to AD pathology and to understand spatial differences in gene expression within the DRN.

title: A novel adjunctive diagnostic method for bone cancer: Osteosarcoma cell segmentation based on Twin Swin Transformer with multi-scale feature fusion.
main_goals: The paper introduces a novel Twin Swin Transformer with multi-scale feature fusion method for osteosarcoma cell segmentation. It aims to improve the accuracy and efficiency of cell segmentation compared to existing techniques, thus facilitating better diagnosis and treatment planning.

title: Non-coding RNAs in oral cancer: Emerging biomarkers and therapeutic frontier.
main_goals: This article explores the potential of ncRNAs as diagnostic and therapeutic tools for oral cancer. It highlights the use of spatial transcriptomics, spatial metabolomics, and single-cell RNA sequencing to enhance diagnostic and therapeutic precision for OC. The study also explores the role of salivary biomarkers as a non-invasive diagnostic avenue.

title: Development of mutated β-catenin gene signature to identify CTNNB1 mutations from whole and spatial transcriptomic data in patients with HCC.
main_goals: The paper aims to derive the Mutated β-catenin Gene Signature (MBGS) to predict CTNNB1-mutational status in patients with HCC, to aid in patient stratification for precision medicine. It uses bulk RNA-seq, whole-exome-sequencing, and spatial transcriptomic data to identify the MBGS and assess its performance.

title: Soft tissue sarcomas at the single-cell and spatial resolution: new markers and targets.
main_goals: This review summarizes the findings from single-cell and spatial analyses of soft tissue sarcomas. It discusses tumor cell populations, interactions with the microenvironment, new prognostic markers, and potential therapeutic targets. The paper highlights the challenges and future perspectives in this field.

title: VGAE-CCI: variational graph autoencoder-based construction of 3D spatial cell-cell communication network.
main_goals: The paper proposes VGAE-CCI, a deep learning framework based on the Variational Graph Autoencoder, to identify cell-cell communication across multiple tissue layers. The model addresses the challenges of incomplete data and systematic biases in spatial transcriptomics data. The method allows for more accurate inference of cell-cell communication and cell clustering at single-cell resolution.

title: Spatial dissection of tumour microenvironments in gastric cancers reveals the immunosuppressive crosstalk between CCL2+ fibroblasts and STAT3-activated macrophages.
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to analyze the tumor microenvironment of gastric cancers. The aim is to delineate cellular interactions and their functional impacts, particularly focusing on crosstalk between CCL2+ fibroblasts and STAT3-activated macrophages.

title: Local ablation disrupts immune evasion in pancreatic cancer.
main_goals: This paper investigates the impact of local ablation on the immune microenvironment in pancreatic cancer. It aims to understand how local ablation influences tumor progression, immune cell infiltration, and the effectiveness of immunotherapy. The study integrates multiple techniques to analyze the tumor microenvironment and identify potential therapeutic strategies.

title: CelloType: a unified model for segmentation and classification of tissue images.
main_goals: The paper introduces CelloType, an end-to-end model for cell segmentation and classification in image-based spatial omics data. It utilizes a multitask learning strategy integrating segmentation and classification to improve performance. The model leverages transformer-based deep learning techniques and demonstrates superior performance over existing methods and state-of-the-art models.

title: KanCell: dissecting cellular heterogeneity in biological tissues through integrated single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: human lymph nodes, hearts, melanoma, breast cancer, dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, and mouse embryo brains
main_goals: KanCell is a deep learning model that integrates single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics data to enhance cellular heterogeneity analysis. It outperforms existing methods across various metrics, providing an accurate and efficient tool for spatial transcriptomics. KanCell aims to reveal cellular heterogeneity, clarify disease microenvironments, and identify therapeutic targets.

title: Convolution spatial-temporal attention network for EEG emotion recognition.
main_goals: The paper introduces a novel method for emotion recognition using EEG signals. It transforms EEG signals into spatio-temporal representations and leverages a convolutional neural network with attention mechanisms for feature extraction and dependency learning. The method achieves high accuracy in emotion recognition tasks.

title: MCGAE: unraveling tumor invasion through integrated multimodal spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper introduces MCGAE, a novel deep computational framework for analyzing spatial transcriptomics data. It integrates gene expression, spatial coordinates, and morphological information to identify tumor invasion regions and characterize cellular molecular regulation. MCGAE demonstrates superior performance in spatial domain detection, data denoising, and trajectory inference, outperforming existing methods.

title: Integrated analysis of single-cell, spatial and bulk RNA-sequencing identifies a cell-death signature for predicting the outcomes of head and neck cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: The study aims to identify a cell-death signature for predicting outcomes in head and neck cancer (HNC) by integrating single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq), bulk RNA-seq, and spatial transcriptomics (ST) data. They establish a risk score model (CDRscore) to assess prognosis and explore the biological functions associated with high and low-risk groups, validating their findings with external datasets.

title: Scale Selection and Machine Learning-based Cell Segmentation and Tracking in Time Lapse Microscopy.
main_goals: This paper introduces a comprehensive cell segmentation and tracking methodology. It employs multi-scale space-time interest point detection and characterization for automatic scale selection and cell segmentation. Additionally, it uses a neural network for cell region detection and a graph-based framework for track generation.

title: Addressing the mean-variance relationship in spatially resolved transcriptomics data with spoon.
main_goals: The paper introduces spoon, a statistical framework that employs Empirical Bayes techniques to address the mean-variance relationship bias in spatial transcriptomics data. The primary goal is to improve the accuracy of identifying spatially variable genes (SVGs). The method's performance is demonstrated on both simulated and real spatial transcriptomics datasets.

title: xIV-LDDMM Toolkit: A Suite of Image-Varifold Based Technologies for Representing and Mapping 3D Imaging and Spatial-omics Data Simultaneously Across Scales.
main_goals: This paper introduces the xIV-LDDMM toolkit, a collection of technologies for cross-modality 3D mapping. These technologies address challenges in integrating data across different imaging and omics modalities and scales, from the nano to millimeter scales. The toolkit offers methods for data representation and efficient mapping, including censored data representation, image-varifold measure norms, and multi-scale optimization.

title: Single-Cell and Spatial Multi-omics Reveal Interferon Signaling in the Pathogenesis of Perianal Fistulizing Crohn's Disease.
main_goals: The study investigated the cellular and molecular landscape of perianal fistulizing Crohn's disease (PCD) using multi-omics approaches. It aimed to identify key pathogenic pathways, particularly interferon (IFN)G signaling, and to explore potential therapeutic targets for PCD.

title: The MRAP2 accessory protein directly interacts with melanocortin-3 receptor to enhance signaling.
main_goals: The paper investigates the interaction between MRAP2 and MC3R in regulating energy homeostasis. It uses single-molecule pull-down, spatial transcriptomics and functional analyses to understand the role of MRAP2 in enhancing MC3R signaling. The study also explores the effects of genetic variants in MRAP2 on MC3R function.

title: Molecular Signatures of Resilience to Alzheimer's Disease in Neocortical Layer 4 Neurons.
main_goals: This paper investigates molecular signatures of resilience to Alzheimer's disease in neocortical layer 4 neurons. The study utilizes single-nucleus and spatial transcriptomics to compare neocortical regions affected by Alzheimer's disease. The research identifies genes and pathways associated with neuronal resilience and provides insights into the mechanisms of neurodegeneration.

title: Multifunctional GAN-based optimization for X-ray tomography under different conditions.
main_goals: This paper introduces a multifunctional GAN-based X-ray tomographic protocol for artifact correction, noise suppression, and super-resolution of reconstruction. It aims to remove ring artifacts, improve the contrast-to-noise ratio and spatial resolution, and achieve higher processing speed and minimal information loss. This protocol provides a robust optimization tool for large fields of view and high-resolution X-ray tomography.

title: Multimodal single cell-resolved spatial proteomics reveal pancreatic tumor heterogeneity.
main_goals: The paper introduces Spatial and Cell-type Proteomics (SCPro), a multimodal spatial proteomics approach that combines multiplexed imaging and flow cytometry with protein aggregation capture technology. The SCPro aims to characterize spatial proteome heterogeneity with single-cell resolution in pancreatic tumor microenvironments. The method allows for spatial distribution analysis of immune cell subtypes and discovery of regulatory T cell subtypes.

title: Development and evaluation of a caregiver checklist for primary care.
main_goals: The study developed and evaluated a checklist to help identify and discuss caregivers' concerns in primary care. The checklist's content validity, utility, and ease of use were assessed by subject matter experts. Minor revisions were made to enhance the checklist's applicability.

title: Visualizing the Submolecular Organization of αβ-Tubulin Subunits on the Microtubule Inner Surface Using Atomic Force Microscopy.
main_goals: The paper introduces a method using FM-AFM and simulations to visualize the submolecular arrangement of tubulin subunits on the inner surface of microtubules. It aims to identify structural defects and understand the interactions of MTs, MT-associated proteins, and other molecules.

title: IgG autoantibodies in bullous pemphigoid directly induce a pathogenic MyD88-dependent pro-inflammatory response in keratinocytes.
main_goals: This paper investigates the direct effect of IgG autoantibodies in bullous pemphigoid (BP) on keratinocytes and the role of MyD88-dependent signaling. It identifies a pro-inflammatory response in keratinocytes treated with BP-IgG, validates the response using spatial transcriptomics and scRNA-seq, and demonstrates the role of MyD88 in regulating inflammatory markers.

title: Gut microbiota in health and disease: advances and future prospects.
biological_context: Gut microbiota in health and disease
main_goals: This review consolidates recent findings on the impact of gut microbiota in immune-mediated and inflammation-associated conditions. It identifies gaps in current research and explores the potential of advanced technologies for deepening our understanding. Emerging tools, including single-bacterium omics and spatial metabolomics, are discussed for their promise in elucidating the microbiota's role in disease development.

title: A multi-omic atlas of human embryonic skeletal development.
main_goals: The study established a multi-omic atlas of human embryonic joint and cranium development. It characterized osteoprogenitor trajectories and regulatory networks. It also introduced a tool (SNP2Cell) and revealed progenitor zonation mechanisms.

title: A spatial human thymus cell atlas mapped to a continuous tissue axis.
main_goals: This paper uses a spatial framework to analyze human thymus development, mapping the microanatomical aspects of the process. It establishes the lobular cytokine network, thymocyte trajectories, and epithelial cell distributions. A toolkit for cross-platform imaging data analysis and annotation (TissueTag) is provided.

title: A temporal cortex cell atlas highlights gene expression dynamics during human brain maturation.
main_goals: This study builds a joint pediatric and adult atlas of 75 cell subtypes in the human temporal lobe using single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. The study explores the differences between pediatric and adult cell subtypes, revealing genes and pathways that change during brain maturation. The research aims to improve understanding of brain development and contribute to a global brain cell map.

title: A developmental biliary lineage program cooperates with Wnt activation to promote cell proliferation in hepatoblastoma.
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of developmental biliary lineage programs and Wnt activation in promoting cell proliferation in hepatoblastoma. It uses histology-guided and spatial transcriptomics to characterize the tumor and explores the relationship between gene expression, cell phenotype, and growth factor signaling.

title: HOX gene expression in the developing human spine.
main_goals: The study analyzes HOX gene expression across cell types during human spine development. It investigates the HOX gene code in neural-crest cell derivatives and explores distinct patterns in the spinal cord's ventral and dorsal domains. The goal is to provide insights into motor pool organization and the loss of collinearity in HOXB genes.

title: Divergent WNT signaling and drug sensitivity profiles within hepatoblastoma tumors and organoids.
main_goals: The study aims to characterize the molecular heterogeneity of hepatoblastoma and identify novel targeted therapies. They employed single-cell RNA-seq/ATAC-seq, spatial transcriptomics, and drug profiling to identify distinct tumor epithelial signatures and drug sensitivities.

title: Understanding isoform expression by pairing long-read sequencing with single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This review provides an overview of single-cell and spatial long-read sequencing technologies, discussing their challenges and opportunities. It aims to highlight how these technologies can be used to understand the relationships between transcript molecules and their roles in development and pathology. Single-nucleus long-read sequencing is also discussed.

title: The critical role of endoplasmic reticulum stress and the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) pathway in kidney fibrosis.
main_goals: The study investigates the role of endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and the stimulator of interferon genes (STING) pathway in kidney fibrosis. It uses transcriptomics analysis, mouse models, and human kidney spatial transcriptomics to demonstrate STING's role as an upstream regulator of ER stress during kidney fibrosis development.

title: Repurposing large-format microarrays for scalable spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper introduces Array-seq, a method to repurpose microarrays for spatial transcriptomics. It aims to provide a cost-effective and scalable platform for spatiomolecular studies of small-to-large specimens. The method yields spatial transcriptomes with high detection sensitivity and localization specificity.

title: Clustering-independent estimation of cell abundances in bulk tissues using single-cell RNA-seq data.
main_goals: The paper introduces ConDecon, a clustering-independent method for inferring the likelihood of single cells in a bulk tissue. It aims to improve phenotypic resolution and functionality compared to regression-based methods. The method is applied to study the implication of neurodegenerative microglia in ependymoma.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics in Inflammatory Skin Diseases Using GeoMx Digital Spatial Profiling: A Practical Guide for Applications in Dermatology.
main_goals: This paper provides a technical guide for using GeoMx Digital Spatial Profiler to analyze the transcriptome in inflammatory skin diseases. It aims to illustrate the potential of digital spatial profiling to dissect skin disease pathogenesis and offer a framework for other investigators.

title: Novel integrated multiomics analysis reveals a key role for integrin beta-like 1 in wound scarring.
main_goals: This paper uses a novel spatial multiomics method to study the molecular and spatial organization of the wound repair process. They identified Integrin beta-like 1 (Itgbl1) as a key gene in inflammation-related scarring and determined its role in granulation tissue formation and fibrogenesis during skin repair.

title: Probe set selection for targeted spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper introduces Spapros, an end-to-end pipeline for selecting an optimal set of genes for targeted spatial transcriptomics experiments. It aims to optimize gene set specificity for cell type identification and resolve spatially distinct populations by considering prior knowledge and probe design constraints. The study demonstrates the pipeline's effectiveness in cell type recovery and detecting spatial variation using SCRINSHOT experiments in adult lung tissue.

title: Cutaneous T cell lymphoma atlas reveals malignant T<sub>H</sub>2 cells supported by a B cell-rich tumor microenvironment.
main_goals: This paper investigates the tumor microenvironment of cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL) using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies malignant T cells co-opting immune programs and highlights the role of B cells in the tumor microenvironment, potentially aiding in diagnosis, staging, and treatment.

title: TET3 regulates terminal cell differentiation at the metabolic level.
main_goals: The paper investigates the role of TET3 in regulating terminal cell differentiation in the intestinal epithelium. It uses single-cell analysis and spatial metabolomics to study enterocytes in wild-type and Tet3 knockout mice. The findings suggest that TET3 regulates mitochondrial function and, thus, terminal cell differentiation at the metabolic level.

title: Using GeoMx DSP Spatial Proteomics to Investigate Immune Infiltration of NOD Mouse Islet and Exocrine Compartments.
biological_context: Non-Obese Diabetic (NOD) mice pancreatic islets and exocrine tissue
main_goals: To investigate immune infiltration heterogeneity in NOD mouse pancreatic islets and exocrine tissue using spatial proteomics, aiming to identify markers elucidating Type 1 Diabetes pathogenesis.

title: An effective classification approach for EEG-based motor imagery tasks combined with attention mechanisms.
main_goals: The paper develops a hybrid structure combining convolutional neural networks and bidirectional long short-term memory (BLSTM) model (CBLSTM) and an attention mechanism (AM) model for decoding MI-EEG signals. The goal is to improve the decoding performance for MI tasks. The model achieves high accuracy on a public dataset.

title: The urban footprint of rural forced displacement.
main_goals: This interdisciplinary study merges concepts from human geography and urban theory with computational methods in remote sensing and exploratory spatial data analysis to analyze the housing needs of internally displaced persons. It aims to identify distinct patterns within urban IDP settlements and advocate for culturally sensitive housing policies.

title: Mapping intratumoral myeloid-T cell interactomes at single-cell resolution reveals targets for overcoming checkpoint inhibitor resistance.
main_goals: The paper investigates how agonistic CD40 alters immune cell crosstalk in tumor models, and in combination with immune checkpoint blockade (ICB). It aims to identify targets for overcoming ICB resistance by analyzing single-cell RNA-sequencing data to determine cell-cell interactomes, and validate these findings using spatial transcriptomics and immunofluorescence.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics Reveals the Temporal Architecture of the Seminiferous Epithelial Cycle and Precise Sertoli-Germ Synchronization.
main_goals: This paper uses spatial transcriptomics to study the seminiferous epithelial cycle in mouse testis. It aims to identify transcriptional changes across the cycle, define correlations between germ and somatic cells, and elucidate regulatory mechanisms in spermatogenesis, specifically focusing on Sertoli cell synchronization.

title: Spatial Expression of Long Non-Coding RNAs in Human Brains of Alzheimer's Disease.
main_goals: This study analyzes the spatial expression of lncRNAs in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex of aged human brains using spatial transcriptomics. It aims to identify differentially expressed lncRNAs in Alzheimer's disease and explore their potential roles in the disease pathogenesis by analyzing interactions with proteins and their association with pathological features.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics of IPMN Reveals Divergent Indolent and Malignant Lineages.
biological_context: Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMN) of the pancreas
main_goals: The paper uses spatial transcriptomics to analyze intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMN). It aims to identify transcriptomic states associated with cancer risk and distinguish between indolent and malignant lineages. The findings could improve IPMN risk stratification models.

title: VAPOR: Variational autoencoder with transport operators decouples co-occurring biological processes in development.
main_goals: The paper introduces VAPOR, a variational autoencoder with transport operators, to decouple dynamic patterns from developmental gene expression data. It learns a latent space for gene expression dynamics and decomposes it into multiple subspaces governed by ordinary differential equations. The method infers process-specific pseudotimes to reveal multifaceted timescales of distinct processes during development.

title: CytoSpatio: Learning cell type spatial relationships using multirange, multitype point process models.
main_goals: The paper introduces CytoSpatio, an open-source software for constructing generative, multirange, and multitype point process models. It aims to capture interactions among multiple cell types at various distances simultaneously using multiplexed fluorescence imaging data. The software also enables the generation of synthetic tissue structures.

title: DNA methylation memory of pancreatic acinar-ductal metaplasia transition state altering Kras-downstream PI3K and Rho GTPase signaling in the absence of Kras mutation.
main_goals: The study investigates epigenetic memory of the acinar-to-ductal metaplasia (ADM) transition state in pancreatic cancer. It examines differential DNA methylation in Kras-downstream pathways during ADM and its persistence, linking this memory to cancer cell plasticity even without oncogene mutation. Single-cell spatial transcriptomics is used to link epigenetic memory to specific cellular pathways.

title: Considerations on Image Preprocessing Techniques Required by Deep Learning Models. The Case of the Knee MRIs.
main_goals: This paper introduces preprocessing steps for knee MRI images to detect meniscal lesions using deep learning models. It highlights the practical implications of these techniques in diagnosing knee conditions, such as meniscal injuries. The goal is to streamline the preparation of standardized formats for deep learning model training and benefit radiologists and orthopedic surgeons.

title: BFAST: joint dimension reduction and spatial clustering with Bayesian factor analysis for zero-inflated spatial transcriptomics data.
main_goals: The paper introduces BFAST, a novel method that performs dimension reduction and spatial clustering for zero-inflated spatial transcriptomics data. It aims to enhance the accuracy and precision of clustering by extracting more biologically informative features. The method's performance is validated using simulation and real datasets.

title: CMTT-JTracker: a fully test-time adaptive framework serving automated cell lineage construction.
main_goals: This paper introduces CMTT-JTracker, a fully test-time adaptive framework for automated cell lineage construction. It focuses on improving cell segmentation and tracking accuracy using a CMTT mechanism and a multi-task learning network with spatial attention. The framework is shown to outperform existing methods in biological and tracking performance.

title: Advanced single-cell and spatial analysis with high-multiplex characterization of circulating tumor cells and tumor tissue in prostate cancer: Unveiling resistance mechanisms with the CoDuCo in situ assay.
main_goals: The paper introduces the CoDuCo assay, a novel combinatorial dual-color in situ mRNA detection method with enhanced multiplexing for analyzing circulating tumor cells and tumor tissue. It aims to visualize diverse resistance mechanisms in prostate cancer and identify druggable targets and predictive markers. The method uses machine learning for CTC classification and provides single-cell and spatial gene expression analysis.

title: Chrysalis: decoding tissue compartments in spatial transcriptomics with archetypal analysis.
main_goals: Chrysalis is a computational method designed to rapidly uncover tissue compartments in spatial transcriptomics data. It utilizes spatially variable gene detection and archetypal analysis, avoiding the need for external reference data. It aims to enable swift tissue characterization and identification of distinct cellular niches through gene expression signatures.

title: Single cell and spatial transcriptomics highlight the interaction of club-like cells with immunosuppressive myeloid cells in prostate cancer.
main_goals: This paper investigates the tumor microenvironment in prostate cancer using single-cell RNA-sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. The study identifies club-like cells as a key epithelial cell subtype interacting with immunosuppressive myeloid cells. The findings link club-like cells to myeloid inflammation and androgen deprivation therapy resistance, suggesting potential therapeutic targets.

title: Impact of aerobic exercise on brain metabolism: Insights from spatial metabolomic analysis.
main_goals: This study aimed to explore aerobic exercise-induced metabolic alterations in the brain of young male mice. Spatial metabolomic analysis was used to compare the metabolomic profiles across different brain regions. The study investigated the effects of exercise on lipid metabolism, epinephrine levels, and the vitamin B6 metabolic pathway.

title: Exploring the Impact of Variability in Cell Segmentation and Tracking Approaches.
main_goals: This paper compares the intra- and inter-user variability in manual cell segmentation and tracking. It also compares the performance of different automated segmentation software for a ptychographic cell image. The goal is to highlight the importance of careful consideration of segmentation and tracking methods for result reproducibility.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics identify COL6A3 as a prognostic biomarker in undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma.
biological_context: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS) and related tumors
main_goals: The study aims to characterize undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma (UPS) and related tumors by using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. The research identifies COL6A3 as a prognostic biomarker for UPS, predicting overall survival and metastasis-free survival.

title: Comprehensive mapping of somatotroph pituitary neuroendocrine tumour heterogeneity using spatial and single-cell transcriptomics.
main_goals: This study investigates the inter- and intra-tumoral heterogeneity of somatotroph PitNETs using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing. It aims to visualize cellular distributions and identify protumor factors and signaling pathways to improve treatment strategies.

title: Single cell-spatial transcriptomics and bulk multi-omics analysis of heterogeneity and ecosystems in hepatocellular carcinoma.
main_goals: This study investigates the heterogeneity and ecosystems of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) using single-cell spatial transcriptomics and bulk multi-omics analysis. The researchers aim to understand the driving forces behind tumor growth, the role of tumor-associated macrophages, and the spatial and temporal traits related to tumor recurrence. The data aims to provide insights into clinical scenarios of HCC.

title: Differentiation signals induce APOBEC3A expression via GRHL3 in squamous epithelia and squamous cell carcinoma.
biological_context: squamous epithelia and squamous cell carcinoma
main_goals: The study investigates the expression of APOBEC3A and APOBEC3B in healthy and malignant mucosal epithelia. It identifies that APOBEC3A expression is linked to GRHL3 activity in differentiating cells and extends to proliferating cells in squamous cell carcinoma. The findings suggest a functional role for APOBEC3A during keratinocyte differentiation and provide a mechanism for its mutagenic activity in tumors.

title: Pericancerous cross-presentation to cytotoxic T lymphocytes impairs immunotherapeutic efficacy in hepatocellular carcinoma.
main_goals: The study investigates how cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) interact with macrophages in the tumor microenvironment of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). It reveals that pericancerous macrophages cross-present antigens to CD103+ CTLs, which activates the NLRP3 inflammasome and promotes tumor progression. The research aims to identify therapeutic strategies that can disrupt this interaction and enhance the efficacy of immune checkpoint blockade (ICB) treatment against HCC.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals molecular cues underlying the site specificity of the adult mouse oral mucosa and its stem cell niches.
main_goals: The paper investigates the molecular cues that maintain oral mucosal sites in adult mice using spatial transcriptomics. It identifies molecular markers for unique and shared cellular niches and differentiation programs, and validates FGF ligands as site-specific niche factors.

title: SPathDB: a comprehensive database of spatial pathway activity atlas.
biological_context: Human and mouse tissues, including cancer
main_goals: The paper introduces SPathDB, a database designed to analyze pathway-mediated multidimensional spatial heterogeneity using spatial transcriptomics data. It provides interactive analysis and visualization tools for pathway functional activities across spatial spots in various tissues and diseases. The database aims to identify functional features and elucidate underlying mechanisms of spatial heterogeneity.

title: A signal-diffusion-based unsupervised contrastive representation learning for spatial transcriptomics analysis.
main_goals: The paper introduces SDUCL, a signal-diffusion-based unsupervised contrast learning method for spatial transcriptomics analysis. It integrates image features, spatial relationships, and gene expression information to learn low-dimensional latent embeddings. The method aims to improve understanding of tissue structure and tumor microenvironments by performing well in downstream tasks.

title: Spatially resolved transcriptomic signatures of hippocampal subregions and Arc-expressing ensembles in active place avoidance memory.
biological_context: Rodent hippocampus; active place avoidance memory
main_goals: The study investigates gene expression changes in the dorsal hippocampus following active place avoidance memory recall. It aims to identify regionalized transcriptomic profiles in the CA1, CA3, and DG subregions, and spatially distinct immediate early gene (IEG) expressing spots. The research seeks to understand the biological processes, especially synaptic plasticity, that support memory recall.

title: Brain-wide alterations revealed by spatial transcriptomics and proteomics in COVID-19 infection.
main_goals: The study investigated the impact of COVID-19 on the brain using spatial transcriptomics, proteomics, and bulk gene expression. It aimed to identify brain-wide alterations and potential therapeutic targets related to neurological symptoms observed after infection. The research revealed multi-regional antiviral responses and dysregulation of mitochondrial and synaptic pathways, overlapping with changes in neurodegenerative diseases.

title: Hierarchical Analysis of Protein Structures: From Secondary Structures to Protein Units and Domains.
main_goals: This paper introduces Protein Units (PUs) as an intermediate organizational level in protein structure analysis, bridging the gap between secondary structures and domains. The main goals are to provide a refined understanding of protein architecture and propose alternative structural partitioning solutions for improved domain identification.

title: Integration of Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptomic Data Reveals Spatial Architecture and Potential Biomarkers in Alzheimer's Disease.
main_goals: This study investigates the cellular atlas and spatial architecture of the human prefrontal cortex in Alzheimer's disease using scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies molecular signatures linked to disease progression, specifically focusing on the role of oligodendrocytes and their subtypes, and also proposes PLXDC2 as a potential blood biomarker.

title: MVCLST: A spatial transcriptome data analysis pipeline for cell type classification based on multi-view comparative learning.
biological_context: human dorsolateral prefrontal cortex data and the mouse brain tissue data; mouse olfactory bulbdata
main_goals: The paper proposes MVCLST, a multi-view comparative learning method for accurate cell type classification from spatial transcriptomics data. MVCLST integrates gene expression, spatial location, and image features. The model utilizes contrastive learning and Leiden algorithm for cell type identification and clustering.

title: SpaInGNN: Enhanced clustering and integration of spatial transcriptomics based on refined graph neural networks.
biological_context: mouse olfactory bulb and human lateral prefrontal cortex
main_goals: The paper introduces SpaInGNN, a GNN framework for spatial domain identification by integrating spatial location, histological information, and gene expression data into low-dimensional embeddings. It refines spatial graphs using both tissue image and Euclidean distances. The method mitigates batch effects and demonstrates improved accuracy in spatial domain recognition in mouse and human samples.

title: Gene regulatory networks in abiotic stress responses via single-cell sequencing and spatial technologies: Advances and opportunities.
main_goals: This paper reviews the application of single-cell sequencing and spatial technologies to understand gene regulatory networks in plants under abiotic stress. It highlights the progress, challenges, and opportunities of using these technologies to study cellular responses and cell-to-cell interactions. The goal is to identify regulatory factors for enhancing stress resilience in crop plants.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics Brings New Challenges and Opportunities for Trajectory Inference.
main_goals: This review examines the challenges of using trajectory inference methods on spatial transcriptomics data, focusing on spatial batch effects and measurement granularity. It explores how current methods address these issues and highlights opportunities for future development.

title: SpaGIC: graph-informed clustering in spatial transcriptomics via self-supervised contrastive learning.
main_goals: The paper introduces SpaGIC, a graph-based deep learning framework for spatial transcriptomics analysis. It aims to identify spatial domains, denoise data, visualize results, and infer trajectories by leveraging graph convolutional networks and self-supervised contrastive learning. The method's effectiveness is demonstrated through evaluations on multiple spatial transcriptomics datasets.

title: Chemokine expression profile of an innate granuloma.
biological_context: Liver granuloma in mice infected with Chromobacterium violaceum
main_goals: The study characterizes the chemokine expression profile within an innate granuloma formed in the liver of mice infected with Chromobacterium violaceum. It uses spatial transcriptomics to investigate the spatial and temporal expression of chemokines and their receptors. The research also investigates the role of CCR2 and monocyte-derived macrophages in the granuloma formation and bacterial containment.

title: Aberrant Activation of Wound-Healing Programs within the Metastatic Niche Facilitates Lung Colonization by Osteosarcoma Cells.
main_goals: This study aimed to identify therapeutic vulnerabilities in osteosarcoma lung metastasis by characterizing the cellular and molecular mechanisms of niche formation. The research utilized single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and immunofluorescence to analyze the lung microenvironment.  Nintedanib, a kinase inhibitor, was evaluated for its ability to impair metastasis progression.

title: Clearance of p21 highly expressing senescent cells accelerates cutaneous wound healing.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of p21 highly expressing senescent cells in cutaneous wound healing. Using spatial transcriptomics (Xenium), the authors identify a pro-inflammatory p21 expressing cell population. They find that clearing these cells accelerates wound closure, mediated by NF-κB inhibition.

title: Protocol for Xenium spatial transcriptomics studies using fixed frozen mouse brain sections.
main_goals: This paper presents a protocol for Xenium spatial transcriptomics studies using fixed frozen mouse brain sections. The protocol describes steps for intracardiac perfusion, cryosectioning, and section mounting. The study demonstrates compatibility of fixed frozen brain sections with the Xenium platform.

title: Application and prospects of single-cell and spatial omics technologies in woody plants.
main_goals: This review provides an overview of single-cell and spatial omics technologies in woody plants. It focuses on the development of these technologies, their applications, and the challenges they present. The paper also discusses potential solutions and future research directions.

title: Spatial metabolomics highlights metabolic reprogramming in acute myeloid leukemia mice through creatine pathway.
main_goals: This study applied spatial metabolomics to identify metabolites in liver metastases of AML mice. It aimed to understand metabolic reprogramming, specifically focusing on the creatine pathway, and exploring the potential of inhibiting Slc6a8 as a treatment strategy for AML.

title: Molecular dynamics study of the microstamping of TiAl6V4 alloy.
main_goals: This paper develops a molecular dynamics simulation to study the microstamping process of the TiAl6V4 alloy. It investigates the damage mechanism and the influence of overlap ratios on the depth of the damaged layer and dislocation density. The aim is to determine an optimal overlap ratio to enhance surface strength and reduce processing time.

title: Zr-NMOF tagged with heterobifunctionalized aptamers for highly sensitive, multiplexed and rapid imaging mass cytometry.
main_goals: This paper introduces Zr-NMOF_Aptamer probes for imaging mass cytometry (IMC) to enhance sensitivity, multiplicity, and acquisition speed. The probes enable specific molecular recognition and signal amplification, and are compatible with existing probes for multiplexed analysis. The study aims to advance spatial proteomics through improved molecular probes.

title: Combined LinkNet-MBi-LSTM for brain activity recognition with new Stockwell transform features.
main_goals: This paper introduces a novel hybrid framework for brain activity detection using the enhanced Stockwell transform and an EEG signal called LinkNet and modified bidirectional-long short-term memory (LN-MBi-LSTM) model. The framework aims to improve brain activity recognition by using feature extraction techniques and processing the features with LinkNet and MBi-LSTM. The study demonstrates a strong model for brain activity recognition and achieving a high precision.

title: Sainsc: A Computational Tool for Segmentation-Free Analysis of In Situ Capture Data.
main_goals: Sainsc is a computational tool designed for segmentation-free analysis of in situ capture data. It generates cell-type maps with accurate cell-type assignment at the nanometre scale, along with corresponding assignment scores. The tool requires lower computational resources and has scalable performance, enabling interactive data exploration.

title: Integrating gene expression and imaging data across Visium capture areas with visiumStitched.
main_goals: The paper introduces visiumStitched, an R/Bioconductor package designed to stitch together Visium capture areas, handling overlapping and adjacent images. It constructs an artificial hexagonal array grid to facilitate downstream spatial analyses, such as spatially-aware clustering, without discarding data from overlapping spots. The tool expands possibilities for multi-capture area study designs.

title: Spatiotemporal modeling of molecular holograms.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Visualization']
main_goals: The paper introduces Spateo, a 3D spatiotemporal modeling framework for analyzing embryogenesis data. It enables scalable alignment, refinement, and correction to create molecular holograms, digitizing multi-level biological information and modeling interactions in 3D structures. The framework aims to study organ ecology at a molecular level in 3D space over time.

title: Data augmentation via warping transforms for modeling natural variability in the corneal endothelium enhances semi-supervised segmentation.
main_goals: This paper proposes a data augmentation technique using warping transforms to improve the performance of semi-supervised training for corneal endothelium segmentation. The method aims to capture the natural variability of the endothelium, enriching the dataset with realistic and diverse images. The proposed approach achieved increased mIoU and Dice coefficient metrics in segmentation tasks.

title: 12-Lipoxygenase inhibition delays onset of autoimmune diabetes in human gene replacement mice.
main_goals: The study investigated the therapeutic potential of targeting 12-lipoxygenase (12-LOX) using a mouse model for autoimmune diabetes. The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 12-LOX inhibitor, VLX-1005, on the onset of autoimmune diabetes. The study employed spatial proteomics and RNA sequencing analysis to understand the changes in immune cell infiltration and inflammatory pathways.

title: Psychological correlates of the good old days bias in mild traumatic brain injury.
main_goals: The study examines the psychological correlates of the "good old days" bias in individuals with mild traumatic brain injury (MTBI). It investigates the relationship between this bias and other psychological factors associated with post-concussive symptoms, such as illness perception beliefs, intolerance of uncertainty, suggestibility, and domain identification. The aim is to understand the potential mechanisms of persistent symptoms following MTBI and to inform clinical assessment and treatment.

title: Spatial transcriptomics analysis identifies therapeutic targets in diffuse high-grade gliomas.
main_goals: This study applies spatial transcriptomics to analyze the gene expression profiles in diffuse high-grade gliomas. It aims to identify differentially expressed genes and their spatial distribution to reveal potential therapeutic targets for glioma treatment.

title: Detection of breast cancer using machine learning on time-series diffuse optical transillumination data.
main_goals: To evaluate the classification of cancer-positive versus cancer-negative patients using machine learning methods on raw transmission time series data from bilateral breast scans.  The authors aimed to explore data preprocessing and feature-generation strategies using SVM and AutoML.  They sought to demonstrate the viability of ML for breast cancer diagnosis using diffuse-optical transmission measurements.

title: Development of a Mobile Laser Measurement System for Subway Tunnel Deformation Detection.
main_goals: Develop a mobile laser measurement system for detecting deformation in metro tunnels. Integrate multiple sensors and propose a pre-processing algorithm for point cloud data analysis, including denoising, centerline calculation, and deformation assessment.

title: IAMSAM: image-based analysis of molecular signatures using the Segment Anything Model.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Region of Interest Selection', 'Differential Gene Expression Analysis', 'Enrichment Analysis', 'Cell Type Prediction', 'Image Processing']
main_goals: Present IAMSAM, a web-based tool for spatial transcriptomics analysis. It uses the Segment Anything Model for accurate tissue image segmentation, enables semi-automatic selection of morphological regions of interest, and provides downstream analysis like DEG identification, enrichment, and cell type prediction. The tool aims to empower researchers to explore heterogeneous tissues.

title: SpottedPy quantifies relationships between spatial transcriptomic hotspots and uncovers environmental cues of epithelial-mesenchymal plasticity in breast cancer.
main_goals: The paper introduces SpottedPy, a Python package designed to identify tumor hotspots and map spatial interactions in the cancer ecosystem using spatial transcriptomics data. It applies the tool to analyze epithelial-mesenchymal plasticity in breast cancer.

title: Cell Segmentation With Globally Optimized Boundaries (CSGO): A Deep Learning Pipeline for Whole-Cell Segmentation in Hematoxylin-and-Eosin-Stained Tissues.
biological_context: Cancer tumor microenvironment studies in liver, lung, and oral tissues
main_goals: Develop a deep learning pipeline (CSGO) for accurate whole-cell segmentation in H&E-stained tissues. Evaluate its performance against state-of-the-art methods. Provide a user-friendly tool for researchers studying the tumor microenvironment.

title: Homebuilt Imaging-Based Spatial Transcriptomics: Tertiary Lymphoid Structures as a Case Example.
main_goals: To provide a comprehensive do-it-yourself (DIY) guide for performing homebuilt, imaging-based spatial transcriptomics experiments at reduced costs leveraging open-source approaches. The guide covers the entire project lifecycle, including experimental choices, wet lab approaches, instrumentation, and analysis, using tertiary lymphoid structures as a case example.

title: Measuring Cell Dimensions in Fission Yeast Using Machine Learning.
biological_context: Schizosaccharomyces pombe (Fission yeast) cell cycle, aging, genomic instability, replication stress
main_goals: Introduce PhotoPhenosizer (PP), a machine learning-based tool for automated cell segmentation and dimensional analysis of fission yeast from brightfield microscopy images. Provide a protocol for its use. Demonstrate its application by measuring cell size dynamics in a yeast chronological lifespan assay to study the effect of genomic instability.

title: scProAtlas: an atlas of multiplexed single-cell spatial proteomics imaging in human tissues.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Neighborhood Analysis', 'Cell Proximity Analysis', 'Spatial Cell Mapping', 'Multimodal Integration', 'Spatial Variable Feature Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Pathway Analysis']
main_goals: To construct a comprehensive spatial proteomics functional annotation knowledgebase, scProAtlas, to help users understand spatial context in human tissues. It provides detailed spatial functional annotation and offers insights into tissue spatial structure. The platform integrates data from multiple spatial protein imaging techniques across various human tissues.

title: An interpretable hybrid framework combining convolution latent vectors with transformer based attention mechanism for rolling element fault detection and classification.
main_goals: Develop a novel hybrid framework combining CNN and Transformer for rolling element fault detection and classification. Validate the framework using the CWRU and MFPT datasets. Achieve high accuracy and efficient detection time for industrial asset condition monitoring.

title: Machine and Deep Learning in Hyperspectral Fluorescence-Guided Brain Tumor Surgery.
main_goals: Develop a pipeline combining classical, machine learning, and deep learning methods to analyze hyperspectral fluorescence images from brain tumor surgery. Use the pipeline to classify tissue types, tumor grade, and IDH mutation status, aiming to improve discrimination at tumor margins and overall classification performance.

title: Spatiotemporal Cellular Dynamics of Germinal Center Reaction in Coronavirus Disease 2019 Lung-Draining Lymph Node Based on Imaging-Based Spatial Transcriptomics.
biological_context: COVID-19 immune response and lymphoid structural recovery in lymph nodes of nonhuman primates
main_goals: This study utilized imaging-based spatial transcriptomics to delineate immune cell composition and tissue architecture formation in lung-draining lymph nodes during primary SARS-CoV-2 infection, convalescence, and reinfection in nonhuman primates. The goal was to elucidate lymphoid structural recovery and its implications for immunologic memory by observing germinal center formation, cell differentiation, and transcriptome dynamics in spatial context. Findings aim to inform vaccine strategies and therapies.

title: Profiling immune cell tissue niches in the spatial -omics era.
biological_context: Tissue immunity and immune cell niches
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Cell Distribution Analysis', 'Immune Repertoire Analysis']
main_goals: To review recent technological and analytical advances in spatial omics for profiling immune cell tissue niches. To propose a framework for defining immune niches using spatial profiling methodologies. To summarize approaches for spatially resolved adaptive immune repertoire analysis.

title: HistoSPACE: Histology-inspired spatial transcriptome prediction and characterization engine.
main_goals: Develop HistoSPACE, a lightweight deep learning model to predict spatial transcriptomes from histological images. Extract molecular insights from tissue images and link predicted expression with disease pathology. Demonstrate efficiency and robustness.

title: A Novel Non-Contact Multi-User Online Indoor Positioning Strategy Based on Channel State Information.
main_goals: Propose a novel non-contact multi-user online indoor positioning strategy based on WiFi Channel State Information (CSI). Introduce the NKCK method combining neighborhood component analysis (NCA), K-means clustering, and K-nearest neighbor (KNN) classification. Demonstrate the performance improvement of the NKCK method compared to traditional methods for indoor positioning accuracy.

title: scDOT: optimal transport for mapping senescent cells in spatial transcriptomics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Deconvolution', 'Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: To develop scDOT, a method integrating optimal transport and expression deconvolution to map single cells in spatial transcriptomics data. The method aims to improve spatial cell mapping, identify senescent cells and their neighbors, and uncover associated gene interactions, demonstrating its utility on lung spatial transcriptomics data.

title: From bioinformatics to anti-inflammation and immune regulation: ACT001 in lipopolysaccharide-induced lung injury.
main_goals: Investigate the role of NLRP3-dependent pyroptosis in acute lung injury (ALI) using single cell and spatial transcriptomics. Evaluate the therapeutic effect of ACT001 on LPS-induced ALI, focusing on pyroptosis and mitochondrial dynamics. Determine the relationship between ACT001 and NLRP3.

title: The involvement and possible targeting of cardiolipins degradation and disturbed linoleic acid metabolism in cardiac atrophy under cancer cachexia.
biological_context: Cardiac atrophy under cancer cachexia in mice and H9c2 cardiomyocytes
main_goals: To study the mechanisms of cardiac atrophy in cancer cachexia focusing on glycerophospholipid and fatty acid metabolism (cardiolipins, linoleic acid). To search for possible drug targets, evaluating the peptide SS-31.

title: Lamination-based organoid spatially resolved transcriptomics technique for primary lung and liver organoid characterization.
main_goals: This paper introduces Lamination-based Organoid Spatially Resolved Transcriptomics (LOSRT), a novel technique for enabling spatial transcriptomics on primary tissue-derived organoids. It demonstrates the method on mouse lung and liver organoids, showing preservation of structure and successful characterization of cell types and their spatial distribution. The goal is to provide a standardized method for spatially resolving gene expression in primary organoids.

title: IL1RAP Blockade With a Monoclonal Antibody Reduces Cardiac Inflammation and Preserves Heart Function in Viral and Autoimmune Myocarditis.
main_goals: The study aimed to evaluate IL1RAP blockade as a therapeutic strategy for viral and autoimmune myocarditis using mouse models. They found that IL1RAP blockade reduced disease severity, preserved cardiac function in the autoimmune model, and modulated immune infiltration and spatial gene expression in the heart. The findings suggest IL1RAP blockade is a potential therapy.

title: Spatial transcriptome analysis reveals de novo regeneration of poplar roots.
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to analyze the regeneration of poplar roots. It aims to map gene expression changes over time and space, identify distinct spatial domains/clusters, analyze cell differentiation trajectories, and discover potential biomarkers for root regeneration.

title: GraphPCA: a fast and interpretable dimension reduction algorithm for spatial transcriptomics data.
main_goals: Develop GraphPCA, a fast and interpretable dimension reduction algorithm for spatial transcriptomics data. Demonstrate its effectiveness in enhancing downstream analyses like spatial domain detection, denoising, and trajectory inference.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals strong association between SFRP4 and extracellular matrix remodeling in prostate cancer.
main_goals: To understand how SFRP4 relates to prostate cancer heterogeneity using comprehensive spatial and multiomics analysis. The study found SFRP4 mRNA is predominantly in cancer stroma produced by fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells and associated with extracellular matrix components and cancer aggressiveness. Interestingly, high mRNA levels did not reflect SFRP4 protein levels.

title: [Molecular pathology of skin fragility].
main_goals: This review paper discusses the molecular pathology of skin fragility disorders, focusing on the role of cutaneous adhesion structures and dermal connective tissue components. It highlights the molecular composition of these structures and the specific diseases associated with deficiencies in these components. The review also briefly mentions modern techniques like single-cell and spatial transcriptomics used in the field.

title: SpaDiT: diffusion transformer for spatial gene expression prediction using scRNA-seq.
main_goals: Develop SpaDiT, a deep learning framework using a diffusion transformer for spatial gene expression prediction in ST data. It uses scRNA-seq data as input condition. The goal is to improve prediction accuracy compared to baseline methods.

title: New perspective on central nervous system disorders: focus on mass spectrometry imaging.
biological_context: Central Nervous System Diseases (Alzheimer's disease, CNS tumors, stroke, depression, Huntington's disease, Parkinson's disease)
main_goals: This review provides an overview of mass spectrometry imaging (MSI), covering its processes, applications, advantages, disadvantages, and mechanisms. It summarizes the main applications of MSI in studying various central nervous system diseases. The review also discusses synergistic applications with other imaging modalities, use in organoid models, integration with spatial omics, and future potential.

title: Spatial domains identification in spatial transcriptomics using modality-aware and subspace-enhanced graph contrastive learning.
main_goals: This paper proposes GRAS4T, a graph contrastive learning framework enhanced with subspace analysis for spatial domain identification in spatial transcriptomics data. GRAS4T utilizes tissue microenvironment and morphological priors through graph augmentation based on histological images. It aims to improve accuracy and unveil more detailed spatial domains compared to existing methods.

title: Comprehensive single-cell and bulk transcriptomic analyses to develop an NK cell-derived gene signature for prognostic assessment and precision medicine in breast cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Gene Signature Development', 'Prognostic Modeling', 'Survival Analysis', 'Network Analysis', 'Tumor Microenvironment Analysis', 'Immunotherapy Response Prediction', 'Chemotherapeutic Sensitivity Prediction']
main_goals: Develop a prognostic and therapeutic prediction model for breast cancer by identifying NK cell-related genes and constructing a risk scoring system (NKRS). Validate the predictive power of NKRS for prognosis, TME, immune function, and therapy response, and confirm key gene expression via spatial transcriptomics and IHC.

title: Expanding Spatial Metabolomics Coverage with Lithium-Doped Nanospray Desorption Electrospray Ionization Mass Spectrometry Imaging.
main_goals: Introduce lithium-doped nano-DESI as a simple and robust method to increase spatial metabolomics coverage in mass spectrometry imaging. The method enhances ionization efficiencies for compounds lacking basic moieties and improves structurally diagnostic tandem mass spectra. It is demonstrated on an ovarian tumor section to visualize metabolites and lipids.

title: Emerging Techniques in Spatial Multiomics: Fundamental Principles and Applications to Dermatology.
main_goals: This paper reviews emerging spatial multi-omic technologies. It outlines their fundamental principles, advantages, and limitations. The review focuses on their potential applications to advance dermatologic research by enabling spatially-resolved visualization of multiple molecular channels.

title: Choroid Plexus as a Mediator of CNS Inflammation in Multiple Sclerosis.
main_goals: This perspective review discusses the current understanding of the choroid plexus's role as a conductor of immune responses. It explores how the choroid plexus may contribute to propagating neuroinflammation associated with multiple sclerosis via the cerebrospinal fluid.

title: Biosynthesis-Based Spatial Metabolome of Condensed Tannin Reveals Its Role in Salt Tolerance of Non-Salt-Secretor Mangrove Kandelia obovata.
biological_context: Non-salt-secretor mangrove Kandelia obovata salt tolerance
main_goals: Identify the composition of autofluorescent inclusions (AFIs) in mangrove mesophyll cells as condensed tannin (CT). Analyze the spatial distribution and biosynthesis of CT using spatial metabolomics under salt stress. Demonstrate that CT synthesis and transport facilitate Na+ sequestration into vacuoles, conferring salt tolerance to Kandelia obovata.

title: Adding Highly Variable Genes to Spatially Variable Genes Can Improve Cell Type Clustering Performance in Spatial Transcriptomics Data.
main_goals: Investigate whether adding highly variable genes to spatially variable genes improves cell type clustering performance in spatial transcriptomics data. Test this by comparing performance using HV genes, SV genes, and their union on multiple real datasets.

title: Cell type mapping reveals tissue niches and interactions in subcortical multiple sclerosis lesions.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell type mapping', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: The paper uses single-nucleus and spatial transcriptomics to characterize cell types, tissue niches, and cell-cell communication in subcortical multiple sclerosis lesions. It identifies specific niches like the inflamed rim and lesion core, linking them to distinct cell compositions and interactions. This provides insight into the cellular dynamics underlying lesion progression.

title: Mapping out multiple sclerosis with spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper aims to use spatial transcriptomics technology to investigate and characterize multiple sclerosis.

title: Spatial transcriptomic landscape unveils immunoglobin-associated senescence as a hallmark of aging.
biological_context: Aging in mice and humans, tissue integrity and organ dysfunction
main_goals: To characterize aging via spatial transcriptomics in mice and humans. The study identified immunoglobulin-associated senescence as a hallmark of aging, showing IgG accumulation and its pro-senescent effect, and demonstrated that reducing IgG mitigates aging.

title: Increased BMP-Responsive Transcription Factors in Distinct Endothelial and Mesenchymal Cells in PAH.
main_goals: To investigate the increase in BMP-responsive transcription factors in distinct endothelial and mesenchymal cells within the context of Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) using spatial transcriptomics.

title: Spatiotemporal transcriptomic map of glial cell response in a mouse model of acute brain ischemia.
biological_context: Acute brain ischemia in a mouse model
main_goals: To decode key molecular and cellular processes after acute brain ischemia using spatial and single-cell transcriptomic profiling. The study provides a spatiotemporal map of glial cell response and identifies processes like inflammation, glial scar formation, and specific signaling pathways in the postischemic mouse brain.

title: Leveraging deep single-soma RNA sequencing to explore the neural basis of human somatosensation.
biological_context: Human somatosensation, dorsal root ganglion (DRG) neurons
main_goals: The study isolated somata from individual human DRG neurons and performed deep RNA sequencing to create a transcriptomic atlas with 16 neuronal types. The results were validated using spatial transcriptomics and RNAscope. The research aimed to explore the neural basis of human somatosensation and identify human-specific neuronal types.

title: Molecular Lineages and Spatial Distributions of Subplate Neurons in the Human Fetal Cerebral Cortex.
biological_context: Human fetal cerebral cortex development / neurogenesis
main_goals: This study investigates the molecular origin, lineage specification, and spatial distribution of subplate neurons (SPNs) in the human fetal cerebral cortex (GW 10-25). It uses spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing to create spatial landscapes and molecular trajectories of SPNs, highlighting enriched ECM gene expression in a region-specific manner.

title: Pairpot: a database with real-time lasso-based analysis tailored for paired single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: Develop Pairpot, a database and analysis platform tailored for paired single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data. Curate high-quality paired datasets and provide real-time heuristic analysis using lasso-based methods for tasks like spatial domain identification and cell proportion inference.

title: eMCI: An Explainable Multimodal Correlation Integration Model for Unveiling Spatial Transcriptomics and Intercellular Signaling.
biological_context: zebrafish melanomas, soybean nodule maturation, human embryonic lung
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Deconvolution', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: Introduce eMCI, an explainable deep learning framework integrating scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics data.
