main_goals: The paper proposes UnDRground Tubes (UT), a visualization idiom for analyzing multivariate spatial data. UT combines set visualization and multidimensional projections to address challenges in analyzing latent components from methods like Spatial Blind Source Separation (SBSS). The approach is integrated into an interactive multiple-view system and validated through expert interviews and evaluations.

title: Multiomics analyses decipher intricate changes in the cellular and metabolic landscape of steatotic livers upon dietary restriction and sleeve gastrectomy.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell transcriptome analysis', 'single-nuclei transcriptome analysis', 'spatial metabolomics', 'immunohistochemistry', 'circulating biomarkers', 'serum samples', 'AI-assisted image analysis']
main_goals: This study aimed to elucidate the intricate hepatic changes following dietary restriction (DR), sleeve gastrectomy (SG), or sham surgery in rats with diet-induced obesity-related MASLD, comparing them to a clinical cohort. It sought to understand the distinct metabolic or immunological changes induced by these interventions in MASLD livers. The findings highlight the role of PPARα, gut-liver axis, and metabolically active myeloid cells in SG's therapeutic effects on MASLD.

title: HMGB2 drives tumor progression and shapes the immunosuppressive microenvironment in hepatocellular carcinoma: insights from multi-omics analysis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study aimed to identify key factors influencing the immunosuppressive microenvironment in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and investigate the role of HMGB2 in HCC progression and immune evasion. The research used multi-omics approaches, including spatial transcriptomics and multiplex immunohistochemistry, to validate findings in clinical samples.

title: Comparing Deep Learning Performance for Chronic Lymphocytic Leukaemia Cell Segmentation in Brightfield Microscopy Images.
main_goals: This paper compares the performance of eight state-of-the-art neural network architectures for segmenting chronic lymphocytic leukaemia cells in brightfield microscopy images. The goal is to identify the optimal segmentation method by evaluating cell characteristics and agreement with ground truth. The study found that while overall agreement with ground truth was similar, different methods preferred different morphological features, highlighting the importance of application-specific method selection.

title: Intracellular spatial transcriptomic analysis toolkit (InSTAnT).
main_goals: Develops Intracellular Spatial Transcriptomic Analysis Toolkit (InSTAnT) for extracting molecular relationships from spatial transcriptomics data at single molecule resolution. Uses specialized statistical tests to detect gene co-localization patterns within cells and across the cellular landscape. Showcases the toolkit on diverse datasets and identifies cell type and region-specific gene co-localizations in the brain.

title: ST-GEARS: Advancing 3D downstream research through accurate spatial information recovery.
main_goals: To address discrepancies in 3D spatial transcriptomics reconstructions by proposing ST-GEARS, a system for accurate spatial information recovery. ST-GEARS employs distributive constraints and elastic fields to precisely align sections and counteract distortions, ultimately recovering the original spatial profile for reliable downstream analysis.

title: Matrisomics: Beyond the extracellular matrix for unveiling tumor microenvironment.
main_goals: This paper reviews the growing field of cancer matrisomics, which utilizes diverse -omics approaches to study the matrisome (proteins constituting or interacting with the extracellular matrix) in the tumor microenvironment. It explores patterns of matrisomal populations across different cancers, investigates dysregulation by cell type and spatial location, and highlights the potential of matrisome genes as biomarkers for cancer progression and treatment efficacy.

title: Evaluation of tumor budding with virtual panCK stains generated by novel multi-model CNN framework.
main_goals: To address the goal of producing virtual panCK stains capable of replacing chemical panCK, this paper proposes an innovative multi-model framework combining Mask-RCNN and GAN models. This framework is used to evaluate tumor budding in breast cancer samples, demonstrating superior accuracy compared to existing single cycleGAN models.

title: Spatial transcriptomics defines injury specific microenvironments and cellular interactions in kidney regeneration and disease.
biological_context: Mouse ischemia-reperfusion injury in the kidney
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: To apply single-cell spatial transcriptomics to examine ischemia-reperfusion injury in the mouse kidney. The study aims to reveal injury-specific and spatially-dependent gene expression patterns and predict molecular interplay between kidney cells and fibroblasts. It also seeks to identify cellular microenvironments resembling tertiary lymphoid structures and associated molecular pathways.

title: Unraveling the spatial organization and development of human thymocytes through integration of spatial transcriptomics and single-cell multi-omics profiling.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Visualization']
main_goals: Develops the TSO-his tool for integrating multimodal single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data to decipher human thymus structure. Characterizes dynamic changes in cell types and markers, identifies ELOVL4's role in CD4+ T cell positive selection, reconstructs thymic architecture, and delineates intermediate thymocyte states. Enhances understanding of thymic biology and informs potential therapeutic interventions.

title: The G protein-coupled receptor ADGRG6 maintains mouse growth plate homeostasis through IHH signaling.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of ADGRG6 in maintaining mouse growth plate homeostasis. It demonstrates that ADGRG6 is essential for regulating chondrocyte proliferation, differentiation, and signaling pathways like IHH and PTHrP. The findings elucidate the mechanisms by which this receptor contributes to skeletal growth.

title: MVST: Identifying spatial domains of spatial transcriptomes from multiple views using multi-view graph convolutional networks.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'histology images', 'gene expression information', 'spatial location information']
main_goals: MVST proposes an unsupervised clustering framework based on multiview graph convolutional networks to identify spatial domains in spatial transcriptomes by leveraging gene expression, spatial location, and histopathological image information. It aims to achieve more accurate spatial domain recognition by comprehensively utilizing data from multiple views. The method was validated on real and simulated datasets, demonstrating improved accuracy compared to existing methods.

title: Spatial Transcriptomic Study Reveals Heterogeneous Metabolic Adaptation and a Role of Pericentral PPARα/CAR/Ces2a Axis During Fasting in Mouse Liver.
biological_context: Mouse liver adaptation to fasting and refeeding states
main_goals: To elucidate dynamic temporal-spatial gene cascades and liver zonation adaptation to nutritional shifts using spatial transcriptomics. The study identifies pericentral CAR as a regulator of triglyceride metabolism during fasting, influenced by Pparα activation and enhancing lipolysis via Ces2a.

title: Spatial Transcriptomic Approach to Understanding Coronary Atherosclerotic Plaque Stability.
main_goals: To investigate the vascular microenvironment in patients with stable and unstable coronary atherosclerotic plaques using spatial transcriptomics. The study aimed to map the vascular transcriptome and characterize cell-specific and regional transcriptional alterations associated with plaque instability. It seeks to identify novel mediators of acute coronary syndrome and inform preventative/therapeutic strategies.

title: CellContrast: Reconstructing spatial relationships in single-cell RNA sequencing data via deep contrastive learning.
biological_context: Mouse embryo and human breast cells
main_goals: CellContrast is a computational method for reconstructing spatial relationships among single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) cells using spatial transcriptomics (ST) reference data. It employs a deep contrastive learning framework to project gene expressions into a hidden space, enabling proximate cells to share similar representations. The method aims to facilitate accurate spatial reconstruction and enable downstream analyses like cell-type co-localization and cell-cell communication.

title: Reliable imputation of spatial transcriptomes with uncertainty estimation and spatial regularization.
main_goals: The paper introduces TransImpute, a computational model for imputing missing features in spatial transcriptomics. It uniquely provides uncertainty estimation and uses spatial regularization to improve accuracy and reliability of imputation. This enhances downstream analyses like detecting spatial variable genes and ligand-receptor pairs.

title: An aberrant immune-epithelial progenitor niche drives viral lung sequelae.
biological_context: Post-acute sequelae of SARS-CoV-2 (PASC) and viral lung disease
main_goals: The study identified an aberrant immune-epithelial progenitor niche in fibroproliferation in respiratory PASC using patient cohorts and a mouse model. It highlights CD8+ T cell-macrophage interactions driving fibrosis and proposes therapeutic strategies targeting IFNγ+TNF or IL-1β.

title: Optimized Spatial Transformer for Segmenting Pancreas Abnormalities.
main_goals: This paper introduces a novel approach called the Spatial Horned Lizard Attention Approach (SHLAM) for segmenting pancreas abnormalities. The method includes preprocessing to remove noise, feature identification for forecasting impacted regions, and segmentation. The SHLAM method demonstrated high accuracy compared to existing models.

title: Graspot: a graph attention network for spatial transcriptomics data integration with optimal transport.
main_goals: Graspot is a graph attention network designed for spatial transcriptomics data integration with unbalanced optimal transport. It aims to remove batch effects while preserving biological structure by aligning common structures across multiple ST datasets and embedding them into a unified latent space. The method excels in partial alignment and accurately reconstructs human heart developmental processes.

title: Predicting spatially resolved gene expression via tissue morphology using adaptive spatial GNNs.
main_goals: The paper presents a graph neural network based framework (adaptive spatial GNNs) to predict spatial gene expression from tissue histological images. The method aims to provide a scalable alternative to expensive spatial transcriptomics technologies. Experiments show improved prediction performance and better delineation of spatial domains.

title: Morphogenic, molecular, and cellular adaptations for unidirectional airflow in the chicken lung.
biological_context: Chicken lung development and adaptation to unidirectional airflow
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell Segmentation', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study delineates the morphogenic, molecular, and cellular features that enable unidirectional airflow in the chicken lung. It identifies key developmental processes, including parabronchi formation and alveologenesis, and characterizes a novel luminal cell type. The research aims to explore evolutionary lung diversification and lay the foundation for functional genetic analysis.

title: Spatial Immunophenotyping from Whole-Slide Multiplexed Tissue Imaging Using Convolutional Neural Networks.
main_goals: The paper introduces CellGate, a deep-learning computational pipeline for streamlined, end-to-end whole-slide multiplexed immunofluorescence (mIF) image analysis. It aims to automate nuclei detection, cell segmentation, cell classification, and immuno-phenotyping from mIF images, addressing the labor-intensive nature of current analyses. The goal is to enable high-throughput whole-slide mIF tissue image analysis for large-scale clinical and research applications with improved consistency.

title: Recon8D: A metabolic regulome network from oct-omics and machine learning.
main_goals: Recon8D predicts metabolomic variation from multi-omics data using machine learning. It reconstructs multiomic interaction subnetworks and prioritizes predictive features for single-cell and spatial metabolomics. The study highlights YAP1 signaling as a global predictor and identifies predictive features enriched for synthetic-lethal interactions.

title: SPACE: Spatially variable gene clustering adjusting for cell type effect for improved spatial domain detection.
main_goals: SPACE is a framework that classifies spatially variable genes (SVGs) based on their spatial patterns, adjusting for confounding effects caused by shared cell types. This aims to improve spatial domain detection by grouping SVGs and using these groups in downstream analysis, without requiring prior knowledge of gene cluster numbers or cell types. The method has demonstrated efficiency and promise in simulations and real data analyses.

title: Endogenous adenine is a potential driver of the cardiovascular-kidney-metabolic syndrome.
biological_context: Cardiovascular-kidney-metabolic (CKM) syndrome, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, heart failure with preserved ejection fraction, myocardial infarction
data_modalities_used: ['spatial metabolomics', 'bulk metabolomics', 'single nucleus gene expression', 'urine adenine/creatinine ratio', 'snRNA-seq', 'heart adenine and MTAP gene expression']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Metabolomics Analysis', 'Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: This study investigates the role of endogenous adenine in the cardiovascular-kidney-metabolic (CKM) syndrome. It identifies adenine as upregulated in the hearts of patients with diabetes and left ventricular hypertrophy and demonstrates that adenine accumulation causes heart dysfunction and ischemic heart damage in preclinical models. The findings suggest adenine is a potential driver and therapeutic target for CKM syndrome-related heart diseases.

title: ST-SCSR: identifying spatial domains in spatial transcriptomics data via structure correlation and self-representation.
main_goals: This paper introduces ST-SCSR, a novel algorithm for identifying spatial domains in spatial transcriptomics data. It integrates local and global information, and similarity of spatial domains by utilizing matrix tri-factorization and learning an affinity graph of spots.

title: Spatially resolved analysis of pancreatic cancer identifies therapy-associated remodeling of the tumor microenvironment.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell spatial transcriptomics', 'histology images', 'ex vivo tumoroid coculture system']
main_goals: The study introduces SCOTIA, a novel optimal transport model for analyzing cell-cell interactions based on spatial distance and ligand-receptor gene expression. It demonstrates the method's ability to identify therapy-associated remodeling of the tumor microenvironment and molecular interactions conferring therapeutic resistance in pancreatic cancer.

title: Clinical Implications of Basic Research: Exploring the Transformative Potential of Spatial 'Omics in Uro-oncology.
covered_analysis_steps: ['spatial molecular architecture mapping', 'tracking clonal phylogenetics in situ', 'immune-cell interactions in the tumour microenvironment']
main_goals: This paper reviews the transformative potential of spatial molecular technologies (spatial 'omics) in uro-oncology. It highlights how these platforms can uncover tumor heterogeneity, provide insights into disease development and progression, and aid in diagnosis and treatment strategies, particularly for risk stratification and precision medicine. Current challenges and future directions driven by evolving technologies and machine learning are also discussed.

title: The effect of Proteinase K treatment on GeoMx digital spatial profiling data quality from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue.
main_goals: This study investigates the impact of Proteinase K (ProtK) treatment on spatial transcriptomic data quality from FFPE tissues using GeoMx DSP and Illumina NextSeq 2000. The aim is to understand how ProtK affects metrics like total reads, signal-to-noise ratio, and gene detection, across different tissue types and ProtK concentrations. The findings highlight the need for careful optimization of sample processing workflows for spatial transcriptomics.

title: Immunobiology of primary sclerosing cholangitis.
main_goals: To provide a comprehensive overview of recent immunobiology insights in Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC), with a particular emphasis on immunological concepts like tissue residency and knowledge gained from novel technologies such as single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. The review covers major and newly described immune cell types in PSC-diseased livers and highlights the importance of time and space in PSC heterogeneity.

title: The immune microenvironment of steatotic hepatocellular carcinoma: Current findings and future prospects.
main_goals: To present a timely summary of the immune microenvironment of MASH-HCC, discussing the use of cutting-edge technologies like single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and mass cytometry imaging. It also covers novel therapeutic innovations in preclinical models for MASH-HCC.

title: A best practices framework for spatial biology studies in drug discovery and development: enabling successful cohort studies using digital spatial profiling.
biological_context: drug discovery and development, biomarker analysis in solid tissue specimens
main_goals: To provide a best practices framework for spatial biology studies in drug discovery and development, enabling successful cohort studies using digital spatial profiling. The framework aims to improve tissue analysis by offering practical guidelines for designing spatial studies and utilizing spatial biology platforms.

title: Type 1 innate lymphoid cells: a biomarker and therapeutic candidate in sarcoidosis.
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of type 1 innate lymphoid cells (ILC1s) in sarcoidosis. It identifies an accumulation of ILC1s and a CXCL12/CXCR4 axis in sarcoidosis skin samples, and demonstrates their contribution to granuloma formation in a mouse model. The findings suggest ILC1s as potential diagnostic biomarkers and therapeutic targets for sarcoidosis.

title: Single-cell spatial transcriptomics in cardiovascular development, disease, and medicine.
main_goals: This paper introduces the main methods of RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics analysis and highlights the latest advances in cardiovascular research. It discusses how single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics improve the understanding of cardiovascular phylogeny and diseases. The aim is to facilitate precise individualized treatment of CVDs by combining spatial and temporal characterization with multidisciplinary techniques.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics Reveals the Transcriptomic Signatures in a Mouse Model of Pediatric Metabolic Dysfunction-Associated Steatohepatitis.
biological_context: Pediatric metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH) in mice
main_goals: To develop and characterize a mouse model of pediatric MASH using spatial transcriptomics. The study aimed to identify transcriptomic signatures associated with the disease and explore potential links to disease pathogenesis, such as the role of cytochrome P450 2E1.

title: Reconstruction residual network with a fused spatial-channel attention mechanism for automatically classifying diabetic foot ulcer.
main_goals: The paper proposes a reconstruction residual network with a fused spatial-channel attention mechanism (FARRNet) for automatically classifying diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs). The model aims to improve feature extraction and classification accuracy, especially in data-imbalanced scenarios, making it suitable for medical diagnosis environments with limited resources.

title: Feasibility of using electrodermal activity responses to assess level of crowdedness of pedestrian paths.
main_goals: This study explores the feasibility of assessing the crowdedness levels of pedestrian paths by measuring subjects' physiological responses (electrodermal activity) to visual stimuli of different pedestrian traffic flows. The findings suggest that EDA data can differentiate crowdedness levels, contributing to a novel, quantitative method for gauging pedestrian path crowdedness.

title: Gut Analysis Toolbox - automating quantitative analysis of enteric neurons.
main_goals: This paper introduces the Gut Analysis Toolbox (GAT), a user-friendly image analysis tool developed in Fiji for the quantitative analysis of enteric neurons and their neurochemical coding in GI wholemount preparations. GAT utilizes custom deep learning models for rapid and accurate segmentation and enables proximal neighbor-based spatial analysis. It aims to streamline routine image analysis tasks in ENS research, enhancing throughput and allowing unbiased analysis of larger tissue areas.

title: Microglia LILRB4 upregulation reduces brain damage after acute ischemic stroke by limiting CD8<sup>+</sup> T cell recruitment.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of LILRB4 in modulating the immune response and its potential protective effects against ischemic brain injury in mice. It demonstrates that LILRB4 in microglia plays a crucial role in moderating the post-stroke immune response by controlling CD8+ T cell infiltration and activation. The findings highlight the therapeutic potential of targeting LILRB4 for mitigating immune-mediated damage in ischemic stroke.

title: Making Multiplexed Imaging Flexible: Combining Essential Markers With Established Antibody Panels.
main_goals: This paper demonstrates a protocol for combining manual indirect immunofluorescence with commercially pre-conjugated antibody panels on the PhenoCycler platform. The workflow is detailed for both fresh frozen and FFPE tissue sections, including image coregistration. The goal is to make multiplexed imaging more flexible by integrating essential markers with established antibody panels.

title: Re-analysis of single cell and spatial transcriptomics data reveals B cell landscape in gastric cancer microenvironment and its potential crosstalk with tumor cells for clinical prognosis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This study aimed to explore the B cell landscape in the gastric cancer microenvironment and its potential crosstalk with tumor cells for clinical prognosis. It identified B cell subpopulations, differentiation trajectories, and co-localization patterns with tumor cells. The research also highlighted the CCL28-CCR10 signaling axis as a key player in tumor cell-B cell communication and the LAMA/CD44 axis as a potential prognostic marker for immunotherapy.

title: Combining spatial metabolomics and proteomics profiling of single cells.
main_goals: This paper reviews the emerging field of combining spatial metabolomics and proteomics profiling of single cells. It discusses the technical advancements and potential applications of these integrated approaches for gaining deeper biological insights.

title: STIE: Single-cell level deconvolution, convolution, and clustering in in situ capturing-based spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper presents STIE, an Expectation Maximization algorithm to achieve single-cell level deconvolution, convolution, and clustering for in situ capturing-based spatial transcriptomics. STIE aligns spatial transcriptomic data with histology images to recover missing cells and characterizes cell-type-specific gene expression.

title: Eganelisib combined with immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy and chemotherapy in frontline metastatic triple-negative breast cancer triggers macrophage reprogramming, immune activation and extracellular matrix reorganization in the tumor microenvironment.
data_modalities_used: ['multiplex immunofluorescence', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'PD-L1 immunohistochemistry', 'flow cytometry', 'multiplex cytokine analysis']
main_goals: This paper presents translational analyses from a phase 2 clinical trial (MARIO-3) evaluating eganelisib combined with atezolizumab and nab-paclitaxel in frontline metastatic triple-negative breast cancer. The study aimed to understand the mechanisms of action, focusing on macrophage reprogramming, immune activation, and extracellular matrix reorganization within the tumor microenvironment. The findings support the therapeutic rationale for combining eganelisib with immunotherapy and chemotherapy.

title: Distinct clinical outcomes and biological features of specific KRAS mutants in human pancreatic cancer.
main_goals: This study examines the distinct clinical outcomes and biological features associated with specific KRAS mutations in human pancreatic cancer. It identifies that KRAS²G12R mutations are linked to earlier stage disease and improved survival compared to KRAS²G12D, exploring underlying biological mechanisms through spatial profiling and RNA-sequencing.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics of vulvar lichen sclerosus reveal multi-compartmental alterations in gene expression and signaling cross-talk.
main_goals: This study utilizes single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to analyze vulvar lichen sclerosus (VLS) lesions and controls. It reveals molecular and cellular heterogeneities and identifies unifying gene expression changes across cell types in VLS, highlighting cellular stress, T cell activation, aberrant signaling, and increased activation of IFN, JAK/STAT, and p53 pathways. The findings offer insights into VLS pathogenesis and potential therapeutic targets.

title: A comparison of super-resolution microscopy techniques for imaging tightly packed microcolonies of an obligate intracellular bacterium.
biological_context: Imaging of obligate intracellular bacteria (Orientia tsutsugamushi) within host cells.
data_modalities_used: ['fluorescence microscopy', 'confocal microscopy', 'Airyscan confocal microscopy', 'instant Structured Illumination Microscopy (iSIM)', '3D Structured Illumination Microscopy (3D-SIM)', 'Stimulated Emission Depletion Microscopy (STED)']
main_goals: This study compares five fluorescence microscopy techniques (confocal, Airyscan, iSIM, 3D-SIM, STED) for imaging tightly packed intracellular bacteria. The comparison focuses on resolving bacterial cells in both lateral and axial dimensions, and detecting external vesicles. The most successful combination (3D-STED with Cellpose segmentation and Imaris analysis) was used to reveal differences in bacterial shape when grown in different cell lines.

title: Characteristics of blood-brain barrier heterogeneity between brain regions revealed by profiling vascular and perivascular cells.
biological_context: Blood-brain barrier heterogeneity between brain regions in mice
main_goals: The study investigated the molecular and anatomical specializations contributing to blood-brain barrier (BBB) heterogeneity between different brain regions. It identified molecular differences in vascular and perivascular cells and distinct interaction patterns, highlighting the role of both in BBB functional variation. The platform developed can aid in future BBB research and the development of targeted CNS therapeutics.

title: Integration of mass cytometry and mass spectrometry imaging for spatially resolved single-cell metabolic profiling.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: This paper describes the integration of mass spectrometry imaging-based metabolomics and imaging mass cytometry-based immunophenotyping on a single tissue section. The goal is to reveal metabolic heterogeneity at single-cell resolution and its association with specific cell populations, providing insights into tissue-level interplay between metabolic processes and cellular components.

title: A targetable type III immune response with increase of IL-17A expressing CD4<sup>+</sup> T cells is associated with immunotherapy-induced toxicity in melanoma.
data_modalities_used: ['serum proteomic analyses', 'multiplex cytokine and chemokine assays', 'flow cytometry', 'multiplex immunohistochemistry', 'spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: This study investigates the molecular mechanisms behind immunotherapy-induced adverse events in melanoma. It identifies a link between type III immune responses, specifically IL-17A expressing CD4+ T cells, and these toxicities. The findings suggest anti-IL-17A as a potential therapeutic target for managing these adverse events.

title: Graph Fourier transform for spatial omics representation and analyses of complex organs.
biological_context: Human and mouse organs (lymph nodes, tonsil)
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell Type Annotation', 'Subcellular feature inference']
main_goals: Introduces Spatial Graph Fourier Transform (SpaGFT) for interpretable representation of spatial omics data. It improves spatially variable gene identification and gene expression imputation. SpaGFT enhances accuracy in various spatial omics analyses and can detect rare subcellular organelles.

title: CHAI: consensus clustering through similarity matrix integration for cell-type identification.
main_goals: CHAI (consensus Clustering tHrough similArIty matrix integratIon) is presented as a wisdom of crowds approach for single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNAseq) clustering. It integrates results from multiple state-of-the-art clustering methods to improve cell-type identification. The R package offers flexibility for users to customize the aggregation framework.

title: Meningeal solitary fibrous tumor cell states phenocopy cerebral vascular development and homeostasis.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial RNA sequencing', 'bulk RNA sequencing', 'immunofluorescence', 'immunohistochemistry']
covered_analysis_steps: ['single-cell analysis', 'spatial transcriptomic analysis', 'cell-cell communication analysis', 'trajectory analysis', 'pseudotemporal ordering']
main_goals: This paper aims to define the cell states and spatial transcriptomic architecture of meningeal SFTs across histological grades and patient-matched samples. The study investigates the underlying pathways and cell-cell interactions in SFTs by comparing them to cerebral vascular development and homeostasis, and to meningiomas. The findings provide insights into the unique clinical behavior of meningeal SFTs and a framework for integrating multi-omics data.

title: Hypoxic Upregulation of IER2 Increases Paracrine GMFG Signaling of Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress-CAF to Promote Chordoma Progression via Targeting ITGB1.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'GeoMx Digital Spatial Profiler', 'data-independent acquisition proteomics', 'bulk RNA-seq', 'multiplexed quantitative immunofluorescence']
main_goals: This study investigates the oncogenic mechanism of the endoplasmic reticulum stress-CAF (ERS-CAF) subpopulation in chordoma. It reveals that hypoxia reprograms CAFs into ERS-CAFs via IER2 upregulation, leading to paracrine GMFG signaling that promotes chordoma progression by targeting ITGB1 on tumor cells. The findings highlight the IER2/GMFG/ITGB1 axis as a potential therapeutic target.

title: Unveiling Molecular Diversity in Cerebral Thrombi via Spatial Transcriptomics.
biological_context: Intracranial thrombosis, specifically in the middle cerebral artery related to atherosclerosis and stroke.
main_goals: This study aims to unveil the molecular diversity within cerebral thrombi using spatial transcriptomics. It investigates the cellular and molecular landscape of thrombi from patients undergoing thrombectomy for middle cerebral artery occlusion, providing insights into the biological processes underlying stroke.

title: Integration of Bioinformatics and Machine Learning to Identify CD8+ T Cell-Related Prognostic Signature to Predict Clinical Outcomes and Treatment Response in Breast Cancer Patients.
main_goals: This study aimed to identify a CD8+ T cell-related prognostic signature to predict clinical outcomes and treatment response in breast cancer patients. It leveraged bioinformatics and machine learning to construct a prognostic score (CTR score) from CD8+ T cell-related genes. The signature's relationship with the tumor microenvironment, immunotherapy response, and drug sensitivity was analyzed, and its expression heterogeneity was investigated.

title: Disturbance of Immune Microenvironment in Androgenetic Alopecia through Spatial Transcriptomics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Deconvolution', 'Clustering', 'Differential Expression Analysis', 'Protein-Protein Interaction Networks']
main_goals: This study investigated immune cells around the infundibulum of hair follicles in androgenetic alopecia (AGA) using spatial transcriptome profiling. The aim was to understand the immunological disruptions and identify cell types and molecular dysregulation in the peri-infundibular immune infiltration (PII) region. The findings revealed distinct immune landscapes and a bias towards a Th2 response in AGA patients compared to controls.

title: Heavy Metal Exposure-Mediated Dysregulation of Sphingolipid Metabolism.
biological_context: Respiratory diseases, particularly asthma, and the effects of heavy metal exposure on pulmonary cells.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'quantitative real-time PCR', 'in vitro model system', 'ex vivo human tissue models']
main_goals: This study investigates the impact of local high concentrations of specific heavy metals (NaAsO2, MnCl2, and CdCl2) on sphingolipid homeostasis and oxidative stress in pulmonary cells. It evaluates the expression of enzymatic regulators of sphingolipid metabolism and observed differential modulation. The study also identified heavy metal exposure-induced transcriptomic signatures of oxidative stress in epithelial cells and human lung tissues.

title: Comprehensive pan-cancer analysis reveals EPHB2 is a novel predictive biomarker for prognosis and immunotherapy response.
data_modalities_used: ['bulk transcriptomic datasets', 'single-cell transcriptomic datasets', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'multi-fluorescence staining']
main_goals: This study investigates the role of EPHB2 in various cancer types, focusing on its prognostic value, association with immune infiltration (specifically M2 macrophages), and response to immunotherapy. The research uses bioinformatics tools and transcriptomic/staining data to explore these associations and validates findings in LUAD cell lines. The aim is to establish EPHB2 as a potential biomarker for cancer prognosis and immunotherapy.

title: An integrated single-cell reference atlas of the human endometrium.
main_goals: To create a high-resolution reference atlas of the human endometrium (HECA) by integrating multiple single-cell transcriptomics datasets. This atlas identifies cell types, characterizes stromal-epithelial cell coordination via TGFβ signaling, and defines signaling between fibroblasts and progenitor cells in the basalis. HECA is also used to identify dysregulated cell types in endometriosis by integrating with GWAS data.

title: Spatially clustered type I interferon responses at injury borderzones.
main_goals: This study investigates the spatial distribution and cellular origin of Type I interferon responses at the borderzones of myocardial infarction. It identifies cardiomyocytes as the dominant initiators of this response, leading to the formation of interferon-induced cell colonies that contribute to pathological remodeling and increased risk of ventricular rupture. The findings suggest targeting IRF3 activation in non-immune cells as a therapeutic strategy.

title: CNTools: A computational toolbox for cellular neighborhood analysis from multiplexed images.
main_goals: Develop CNTools, a computational toolbox for end-to-end cellular neighborhood analysis from annotated cell images. The toolbox includes identification and analysis steps, featuring novel methods like Cellular Neighbor Embedding (CNE) and Naive Smoothing, along with established downstream approaches. CNTools aims to accurately and efficiently identify cellular neighborhoods from multiplexed imaging data and provides guidance on method selection.

title: ConvFormer-KDE: A Long-Term Point-Interval Prediction Framework for PM<sub>2.5</sub> Based on Multi-Source Spatial and Temporal Data.
main_goals: This study proposes a novel long-term point and interval prediction framework, ConvFormer-KDE, for urban air quality (PM2.5) using multi-source spatial and temporal data. The framework integrates CNN and Transformer models for capturing local and long-term dependencies, and uses KDE for uncertainty quantification. It aims to outperform existing models in long-term prediction and provide early warnings for PM2.5 changes.

title: circRNAs as Epigenetic Regulators of Integrity in Blood-Brain Barrier Architecture: Mechanisms and Therapeutic Strategies in Multiple Sclerosis.
biological_context: Multiple Sclerosis and Blood-Brain Barrier Integrity
main_goals: To provide an overview of the role of circRNAs in maintaining Blood-Brain Barrier (BBB) integrity in Multiple Sclerosis (MS). The review discusses the mechanisms by which circRNAs regulate BBB permeability and cytoskeletal stability, and explores potential therapeutic strategies targeting BBB damage in MS.

title: Chronic Rejection After Kidney Transplantation.
main_goals: This paper discusses chronic rejection after kidney transplantation, focusing on the role of natural killer (NK) cells and antibody-mediated rejection (AMR). It highlights unmet needs in therapy and presents felzartamab, a CD38-targeting monoclonal antibody, as a promising treatment option, particularly for late AMR.

title: Transcriptomics in the Study of Antiviral Innate Immunity.
main_goals: This chapter describes the application, significance, and experimental procedures of a variety of transcriptomic technologies in antiviral natural immunity. It highlights the importance of transcriptomics in studying all RNA molecules and the expanded scope provided by recent advances like single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.

title: Spatiotemporal transcriptomic mapping of regenerative inflammation in skeletal muscle reveals a dynamic multilayered tissue architecture.
biological_context: Skeletal muscle regeneration following acute injury and in dystrophic muscle
main_goals: This study reconstructs the dynamic trajectories of myeloid cells in injured and dystrophic muscles to understand how macrophages spatially adapt and diversify their functions. It identifies distinct macrophage and DC subsets and their organized distribution in regenerative inflammation zones (RIZs) around damaged myofibers, revealing a multilayered tissue architecture that supports regeneration. The study also shows that glucocorticoid treatment disrupts these RIZs.

title: The heterogeneity of cellular metabolism in the tumour microenvironment of hepatocellular carcinoma with portal vein tumour thrombus.
biological_context: Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with portal vein tumour thrombus (PVTT)
covered_analysis_steps: ['Clustering', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study comprehensively analyzed the metabolic heterogeneity of HCC, PVTT, and normal liver samples using multi-omics combinations. It identified optimal subtypes that interpret PVTT formation and development, and developed a combined index for predicting prognosis and immunotherapy responses. The study also highlighted the metabolism of polyamines, particularly ODC1, as a key metabolic pathway involved in the conversion of metabolic heterogeneity.

title: Personalized composite scaffolds for accelerated cell- and growth factor-free craniofacial bone regeneration.
main_goals: This paper describes a material-centric 3D-printed composite scaffold system (CSS) for accelerated cell- and growth factor-free craniofacial bone regeneration. The CSS integrates a porous ceramic scaffold with a thermoresponsive hydrogel composite. It stimulates osteogenesis in vitro and in vivo, accelerating ECM deposition and mineralized osteoid formation.

title: The co-location of CD14+APOE+ cells and MMP7+ tumour cells contributed to worse immunotherapy response in non-small cell lung cancer.
main_goals: This study investigated intra-tumour immune infiltration patterns and their spatial structures in NSCLC to understand their impact on immunotherapy response. It identified immune exclusion and activation patterns, with CD14+APOE+ cells and MMP7+ tumour cells co-locating and negatively impacting T-cell infiltration and immunotherapy outcomes.

title: Potential of land degradation index for soil salinity mapping in irrigated agricultural land in a semi-arid region using Landsat-OLI and Sentinel-MSI data.
biological_context: Soil salinity mapping in irrigated agricultural land in a semi-arid region.
main_goals: This study evaluated the potential of the land degradation index (LDI) for soil salinity mapping in irrigated agricultural land using Landsat-OLI and Sentinel-MSI data. It compared LDI with soil salinity indices that only use VNIR wavelengths, integrating both VNIR and SWIR bands. The study aimed to determine if LDI can effectively identify soil salinity and if high-resolution Sentinel-MSI data improves prediction accuracy.

title: Inferring pattern-driving intercellular flows from single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Cortical organoid development, pancreatic islets, COVID-19 severity, mouse embryogenesis
main_goals: The paper presents FlowSig, a novel method for inferring communication-driven intercellular flows from single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data. It uses graphical causal modeling and conditional independence to capture directed information flow mediated by intracellular gene modules. FlowSig is benchmarked on organoid and synthetic data and applied to diverse biological contexts to demonstrate its utility.

title: A multidimensional analysis reveals distinct immune phenotypes and the composition of immune aggregates in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia.
biological_context: Pediatric acute myeloid leukemia (AML) bone marrow
main_goals: This study conducts a multidimensional analysis of the tumor immune microenvironment in pediatric AML and non-leukemic controls. It demonstrates that nearly one-third of pediatric AML cases have an immune-infiltrated bone marrow with altered macrophage ratios. The study also detects T cell networks and analyzes their composition using spatial transcriptomics.

title: Precision fMRI and cluster-failure in the individual brain.
main_goals: The paper introduces Adaptive-Weight Smoothing with Optimized Metrics (AWSOM), a novel smoothing filter designed to improve BOLD sensitivity in fMRI while preserving spatial accuracy in single-subject analyses. It aims to address challenges posed by ultrahigh spatial and temporal resolution fMRI, which can reduce temporal signal-to-noise ratio (tSNR) and impact sensitivity. AWSOM is presented as a solution that is as sensitive as conventional smoothing methods but better preserves spatial details and suppresses false positives.

title: Uncovering the hidden effects of repetitive subconcussive head impact exposure: A mega-analytic approach characterizing seasonal brain microstructural changes in contact and collision sports athletes.
biological_context: Brain microstructural changes in contact and collision sports athletes due to repetitive subconcussive head impacts
main_goals: This study explores patterns of longitudinal brain white matter changes across sports with repetitive subconcussive head impact exposure using a mega-analytic approach. It characterizes seasonal brain microstructural changes in contact and collision sports athletes by analyzing diffusion magnetic resonance imaging data.

title: Advances in spatial multi-omics in tumors.
main_goals: This paper reviews emerging spatial omics techniques in cancer research and their therapeutic applications. It discusses how these technologies reveal cellular interactions and microenvironment characteristics within the tumor ecosystem. The authors also propose future development prospects for these spatial omics approaches.

title: Utilizing convolutional neural networks for discriminating cancer and stromal cells in three-dimensional cell culture images with nuclei counterstain.
biological_context: 3D cell culture, specifically spheroids containing tumor cells and fibroblasts
main_goals: To develop a non-invasive, toxicity-free approach using CNNs for classifying cancer and stromal cells in 3D cell cultures based on reflectance, transmittance, and nuclei counterstain images. The study aims to enable accurate cell segmentation and classification within live heterogeneous cell populations for studying cell behavior and drug responses.

title: Environmental community transcriptomics: strategies and struggles.
covered_analysis_steps: ['RNA extraction', 'mapping reads to reference genome', 'de novo assembly of reads']
main_goals: This review covers advances in transcriptomic techniques and assesses their viability for community transcriptomics. It aims to better understand interactions between members of environmental communities by studying their RNA transcripts. The paper highlights challenges in RNA extraction and analysis steps for community transcriptomics.

title: UBL3 overexpression enhances EV-mediated Achilles protein secretion in conditioned media of MDA-MB-231 cells.
main_goals: This study investigated the effect of UBL3 overexpression on EV-mediated Achilles protein secretion in MDA-MB-231 cells using a dual-reporter system. The findings demonstrated that UBL3 overexpression enhances this secretion, suggesting UBL3 as a potential therapeutic target for cancer metastasis.

title: METI: deep profiling of tumor ecosystems by integrating cell morphology and spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Tumor microenvironment (TME) in gastric, lung, and bladder cancers, as well as premalignant tissues.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Deconvolution', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: METI is an end-to-end framework for deep profiling of tumor ecosystems. It integrates cell morphology and spatial transcriptomics to map cancer cells and TME components, stratify cell types and states, and analyze cell co-localization. METI enhances understanding of the molecular landscape and cellular interactions within tissues.

title: Integrated multi-omics analyses reveal the pro-inflammatory and pro-fibrotic pulmonary macrophage subcluster in silicosis.
data_modalities_used: ['Bronchoalveolar lavage fluid analysis', 'Multiplex cytokine analysis', 'Single-cell RNA sequencing', 'Spatial transcriptomics', 'Histology', 'Hydroxyproline assay', 'Immunohistochemical staining', 'Quantitative polymerase chain reaction']
main_goals: This study aimed to investigate the phenotypic and functional heterogeneity of pulmonary macrophages in silicosis using integrated multi-omics analyses. The researchers identified a specific subcluster of Mmp12hi macrophages that are pro-inflammatory and pro-fibrotic, contributing to the progression of fibrosis. The findings suggest that this macrophage subset could be a potential therapeutic target for silicosis.

title: Spatial transcriptomics elucidates medulla niche supporting germinal center response in myasthenia gravis-associated thymoma.
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptome analysis to investigate the pathology of thymoma and thymic hyperplasia in patients with myasthenia gravis. It identifies the enlarged medullary region in seropositive thymomas as containing MG-specific germinal center structures and enriched immune cells, linking it to MG pathology.

title: Computational methods and biomarker discovery strategies for spatial proteomics: a review in immuno-oncology.
main_goals: This review aims to bridge the divide between computational methods and spatial proteomics in immuno-oncology. It consolidates prevailing computational methods and outlines a roadmap from image processing to data-driven biomarker discovery. The paper also explores future perspectives for precision care.

title: Toward a foundation model of causal cell and tissue biology with a Perturbation Cell and Tissue Atlas.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: The paper proposes a generative causal foundation model for unifying human cell biology, termed a Perturbation Cell Atlas. This model leverages pooled CRISPR-based perturbation screens with high-content readouts and AI/ML to map and decipher genetically causal circuits, enabling prediction and generation of experimental information. The goal is to create a comprehensive understanding of cellular phenotypic space.

title: Spatiotemporal omics for biology and medicine.
biological_context: Human life, organ functionality, embryogenesis, species evolution, disease pathogenesis
main_goals: To provide an updated overview of how spatial omics has advanced the understanding of biological processes. It emphasizes the discovery of various biological phenomena related to organ functionality, embryogenesis, species evolution, and disease pathogenesis. The review highlights the translation of genetic information into cellular heterogeneity and tissue structural organization and their dynamic changes over time.

title: Exploring the Sociodemographic and Health-Related Determinants of Telehealth Use Among a Cohort of Older Australians During the COVID-19 Pandemic: Repeated Cross-Sectional Study.
biological_context: Telehealth use among older Australians during the COVID-19 pandemic
main_goals: This study aimed to identify and describe the sociodemographic and health-related determinants of telehealth adoption and use among older Australians during the COVID-19 pandemic. The research utilized data from the Sax Institute's 45 and Up COVID Insights study to understand patterns of telehealth use. The findings contribute to tailoring telehealth services to the needs of older adults.

title: How Can Spatial Transcriptomic Profiling Advance Our Understanding of Skin Diseases?
biological_context: Skin biology in health and disease, specifically cutaneous aging, tumorigenesis, and psoriasis.
main_goals: This paper reviews the field of spatial transcriptomic (ST) profiling and discusses its application to dermatology. It highlights the potential of ST to advance the understanding of skin biology in health and disease through illustrative examples in cutaneous aging, tumorigenesis, and psoriasis.

title: Spatial diversity of in vivo tissue immunity.
biological_context: In vivo tissue immunity, liver, kidney, intestine, lung
main_goals: This paper reviews the spatial diversity of immune cells within tissues. It highlights how advanced technologies like intravital imaging and spatial transcriptomics reveal immune cell distribution and function. The review emphasizes the importance of understanding spatial communication between immune cells, the environment, and surrounding non-immune cells for managing inflammatory diseases.

title: da_Tracker: Automated workflow for high throughput single cell and single phagosome tracking in infected cells.
biological_context: Infectious diseases, host-pathogen interactions, particularly within macrophages infected with intracellular pathogens.
main_goals: To develop a near-fully automated workflow ('da_tracker') for high-throughput, low-bias tracking of single cells and single phagosomes in infected cells using time-lapse confocal microscopy. The workflow integrates Cellpose for deep-learning segmentation with Trackmate algorithms via PyImageJ for quantitative analysis of cellular and sub-cellular parameters.

title: Automatic Tumor Cellularity Measurement: AI-Based Pipeline for Multi-Organ Pathology Imaging.
main_goals: This paper proposes an AI-based pipeline for automatic tumor cellularity measurement in multi-organ pathology imaging. The pipeline addresses challenges like cross-organ data adaptation and clustered cell segmentation using channel normalization, a specialized segmentation model (CacoX) with attention gates, and a watershed algorithm.

title: Multi-transcriptomics analysis of microvascular invasion-related malignant cells and development of a machine learning-based prognostic model in hepatocellular carcinoma.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference']
main_goals: This study aimed to identify and characterize microvascular invasion (MVI)-related malignant cells in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and develop a machine learning-based prognostic model. The research delineated MVI-related malignant cell subtypes using multi-transcriptomics data, exploring their biological functions and interactions. The developed prognostic model demonstrated high sensitivity and specificity for predicting patient outcomes.

title: Spatial transcriptomic validation of a biomimetic model of fibrosis enables re-evaluation of a therapeutic antibody targeting LOXL2.
main_goals: This study aims to validate a biomimetic model of fibrosis using spatial transcriptomics by comparing it to active human lung fibrogenesis sites. The research evaluates a therapeutic antibody targeting LOXL2 within this model, revealing its anti-angiogenic but not anti-fibrotic activity, which has implications for previous clinical trial interpretations.

title: Intra-patient spatial comparison of non-metastatic and metastatic lymph nodes reveals the reduction of CD169<sup>+</sup> macrophages by metastatic breast cancers.
biological_context: Breast cancer metastasis to lymph nodes
main_goals: This study aimed to comprehensively characterize the effects of breast cancers on immune cells in lymph nodes by comparing non-metastatic and metastatic lymph nodes. It revealed a significant reduction in CD169+ macrophages in metastatic lymph nodes, suggesting a detrimental impact on anti-cancer immunity.

title: Acute ocular hypertension in the living human eye: Model description and initial cellular responses to elevated intraocular pressure.
biological_context: Acute ocular hypertension in the living human eye
main_goals: This study presents the initial development of a model for acute ocular hypertension in living human eyes using brain-dead organ donors. It describes initial immunohistochemical and transcriptomic changes in the optic nerve head and retina following elevated intraocular pressure, laying the groundwork for future studies on mechanotranscriptomic responses.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals profound subclonal heterogeneity and T-cell dysfunction in extramedullary myeloma.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'RNA tomography', 'tomo-seq', '10x Visium', 'single-cell RNA sequencing', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial heterogeneity analysis', 'Clustering']
main_goals: This study aims to dissect the 3-dimensional architecture of extramedullary myeloma (EMD) and its microenvironment using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing. It reveals profound subclonal heterogeneity, T-cell dysfunction, and spatial differences in antigen expression, highlighting potential new therapeutic avenues.

title: Leveraging 3D convolutional neural network and 3D visible-near-infrared multimodal imaging for enhanced contactless oximetry.
main_goals: The paper aims to develop and validate a contactless SpO2 measurement approach using 3D CNN and 3D VIS-NIR multimodal imaging. The proposed approach utilizes a 3D VIS-NIR multimodal camera system to capture facial videos and estimates SpO2 through 3D CNN by extracting spatial and temporal features. The goal is to offer a convenient, accurate, and robust alternative for SpO2 monitoring.

title: Profiling cell identity and tissue architecture with single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['sample processing', 'data integration', 'identification of subtle cell states', 'trajectory modelling', 'deconvolution', 'spatial analysis', 'deep learning', 'foundation models']
main_goals: This review discusses recent advancements, ongoing challenges, and prospects in identifying and characterizing cell states and multicellular neighbourhoods using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. It covers progress in sample processing, data integration, cell state identification, trajectory modelling, deconvolution, and spatial analysis, as well as the increasing application of deep learning. The review also highlights applications in stem cell biology, immunology, and tumour biology, and the future translation to clinical settings.

title: An Active-Matrix Synaptic Phototransistor Array for In-Sensor Spectral Processing.
main_goals: The paper introduces an active-matrix synaptic phototransistor array (AMSPA) based on organic/inorganic semiconductor heterostructures. The AMSPA enables wavelength-dependent, bidirectional photoresponses for dynamic imaging and in-sensor spectral preprocessing. It aims to construct artificial vision systems by demonstrating spatial chromatic enhancement and temporal trajectory imaging.

title: Multiplex spatial omics reveals changes in immune-epithelial crosstalk during inflammation and dysplasia development in chronic IBD patients.
biological_context: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and colitis-associated cancer (CAC)
data_modalities_used: ['digital spatial RNA profiling', 'RNAscope', 'imaging mass cytometry', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'multiplexed imaging']
main_goals: This study investigates the molecular changes contributing to colitis-associated cancer (CAC) development in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Using spatial omics techniques, it reveals distinct inflammatory patterns, including activated IL-17 pathways, engaged STAT3 signaling, and diminished cytotoxic T cell infiltration, which are associated with disease progression.

title: A single-cell and spatially resolved atlas of human osteosarcomas.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: The study aims to provide a comprehensive single-cell and spatially resolved transcriptomics atlas of human osteosarcomas. It seeks to characterize cellular composition, functional states, and the impact of chemotherapy, as well as identify spatial niches associated with resistance and inter-cellular crosstalk.

title: Spatial transcriptomics profiling of gallbladder adenocarcinoma: a detailed two-case study of progression from precursor lesions to cancer.
biological_context: Gallbladder adenocarcinoma and its precursor lesions (Biliary intraepithelial neoplasia)
main_goals: To characterize the spatial transcriptomics of gallbladder cancer tumourigenesis in individual patients using GeoMx digital spatial profiling. The study investigated the progression from precursor lesions to cancer within two patients and identified the role of Semaphorin 4A (SEMA4A) repression in promoting tumour progression.

title: Multimodal analysis unveils tumor microenvironment heterogeneity linked to immune activity and evasion.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This paper introduces a systems biology approach to derive a signature of tumor microenvironment heterogeneity, termed 'iHet', from lung cancer transcriptomics. The study demonstrates its conservation across different cancers and association with antitumor immunity. Furthermore, it shows how iHet can predict cancer immunotherapy response, with potential improvement by disentangling immune activity, infiltration/exclusion, and cancer-cell foreignness.

title: Host-pathogen interactions in the Plasmodium-infected mouse liver at spatial and single-cell resolution.
main_goals: To delineate host-pathogen interactions across Plasmodium berghei-infected mouse liver tissues at spatial and single-cell resolution. The study reveals changes in spatial gene expression, lipid metabolism, and distinct inflammation programs. It serves as a benchmark for investigating transcriptome changes during host-parasite interactions in tissues.

title: Spatial transcriptomic revealed intratumor heterogeneity and cancer stem cell enrichment in colorectal cancer metastasis.
biological_context: Colorectal cancer metastasis to the liver
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study applied spatial transcriptomics to investigate intratumor heterogeneity and cancer stem cell enrichment in colorectal cancer liver metastasis. It identified FOXD1 as a potential metastatic CSC marker and revealed distinct evolutionary trajectories during metastasis, providing insights into the cellular mechanisms underlying CRC metastasis.

title: Spatial transcriptomics of fetal membrane-Decidual interface reveals unique contributions by cell types in term and preterm births.
biological_context: Fetal membrane-decidual interface during pregnancy, including term and preterm births.
main_goals: This study used single-cell transcriptomics to unravel the transcriptomics network at spatial levels within the fetal membrane-decidual interface. The goal was to discern the contributions of each layer (amnion epithelium, amnion mesenchyme, chorion, and decidua) to term and preterm birth outcomes. The findings identified spatially recognized differentially expressed genes and associated pathways, aiming to provide insights for targeted interventions against preterm birth.

title: Beyond the Heartbeat: Single-Cell Omics Redefining Cardiovascular Research.
main_goals: This review explores recent advances in single-cell omics techniques applied to the human heart, detailing their contributions to understanding cellular diversity, regulatory networks, and disease mechanisms. It highlights applications in cardiac regeneration, disease modeling, and precision medicine.

title: In Vivo Calcium Imaging of Granule Cells in the Dentate Gyrus of Hippocampus in Mice.
biological_context: Dentate gyrus of the hippocampus in mice
main_goals: This paper presents a detailed protocol for in vivo calcium imaging of granule cells in the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus in mice. It describes the procedures for viral injection, GRIN lens implantation, base plate attachment, and data preprocessing using MATLAB, enabling the study of neuronal activity in deep brain regions.

title: Combining single-cell spatial transcriptomics and molecular simulation to develop in vivo probes targeting the perineural invasion region of adenoid cystic carcinoma.
biological_context: Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) with perineural invasion (PNI)
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'single-cell transcriptomic sequencing', 'in vivo experiments', 'in vitro experiments']
main_goals: To develop in vivo probes targeting the perineural invasion (PNI) region of adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) by combining spatial transcriptomics and single-cell sequencing. The study identified peptide probes targeting Major Histocompatibility Complex II (MHC-II) molecules on Schwann cells within the PNI region and validated their efficacy in labeling viable Schwann cells. These probes serve as a tool for dynamic in vivo marking of tumor invasion into nerves.

title: Advancing precision medicine in gliomas through single-cell sequencing: unveiling the complex tumor microenvironment.
main_goals: This paper aims to advance precision medicine in gliomas by leveraging single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to understand the complex tumor microenvironment. It examines the interactions of various cell types, including microglia, macrophages, endothelial cells, and T cells, and their impact on glioblastoma growth and therapeutic response. The ultimate goal is to identify novel therapeutic strategies targeting these interactions.

title: Deciphering cell-cell communication at single-cell resolution for spatial transcriptomics with subgraph-based graph attention network.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-type identification', 'Deconvolution', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: This paper presents DeepTalk, a method for inferring spatial cell-cell communication (CCC) at single-cell resolution by integrating scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics data. DeepTalk utilizes a subgraph-based graph attention network (GAT) to enable accurate cell-type identification and deconvolution, and to capture multi-level cellular connections for spatially resolved CCC inference. It demonstrates strong performance across multiple datasets for dissecting cellular behavior.

title: A systematic evaluation of computational methods for cell segmentation.
biological_context: Cell nuclei and whole cell segmentation using light microscopy and fluorescence staining images.
main_goals: This paper systematically evaluates the performance of 18 computational methods for cell segmentation using light and fluorescence microscopy images. It identifies factors influencing performance and provides guidelines for choosing optimal methods. The authors also developed Seggal, an online resource for pre-trained segmentation models.

title: Breaking barriers: improving time and space resolution of arbuscular mycorrhizal symbiosis with single-cell sequencing approaches.
biological_context: Arbuscular mycorrhizal symbiosis, plant-fungal interaction for nutrient acquisition
main_goals: To highlight the potential of single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) approaches to improve the time and space resolution of arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) symbiosis research. The paper discusses the challenges and benefits of scRNA-seq and suggests integration with spatial transcriptomics for a comprehensive understanding of AM symbiosis.

title: Utilizing spontaneous plants for sustainable development in residential green spaces: Insights from environmental drivers and niche analysis in Fuzhou City, China.
biological_context: Spontaneous plants in residential green spaces
main_goals: To explore low-maintenance, high-diversity, and sustainable greening strategies for residential areas by analyzing spontaneous plants in Fuzhou City. The study investigated environmental drivers and niche characteristics of these plants, proposing sustainable management measures.

title: SpatialOne: end-to-end analysis of visium data at scale.
main_goals: SpatialOne is an end-to-end pipeline designed to simplify the analysis of 10x Visium data. It combines multiple state-of-the-art computational methods to segment, deconvolve, and quantify spatial information, aiming to streamline reproducible spatial-data analysis at scale.

title: Exploring new frontiers in type 1 diabetes through advanced mass-spectrometry-based molecular measurements.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Biomarker identification', 'Mechanistic studies', 'Spatial heterogeneity analysis', 'Environmental factor analysis']
main_goals: This review explores recent advancements in mass spectrometry (MS)-based molecular measurements and their role in understanding Type 1 Diabetes (T1D). It discusses how MS methods, integrated with machine learning and advanced techniques like ion-mobility separations and single-cell/spatial omics, can identify new biomarkers, elucidate disease mechanisms, and uncover therapeutic targets, while also highlighting remaining challenges.

title: Fruit surface temperature data at different ripeness stages and ambient temperature provided as temperature-annotated 3D point clouds of apple trees.
biological_context: Apple trees (Malus x domestica 'Gala') at different ripeness stages
main_goals: The paper presents a dataset of fruit surface temperature (FST) at different ripeness stages and ambient temperatures, provided as temperature-annotated 3D point clouds of apple trees. The data aims to facilitate the development of methodologies for 3D point cloud processing and can be reused in ecophysiological studies.

title: ResSAT: Enhancing Spatial Transcriptomics Prediction from H&E- Stained Histology Images with Interactive Spot Transformer.
main_goals: This paper introduces ResSAT, a framework that enhances the prediction of spatial gene expression from H&E-stained histology images. It captures tissue structures and uses a self-attention transformer to improve prediction accuracy. ResSAT aims to reduce the cost and acquisition time of spatial transcriptomics profiling.

title: Integrating gene expression and imaging data across Visium capture areas with visiumStitched.
main_goals: The paper introduces visiumStitched, an R/Bioconductor package designed to integrate gene expression and imaging data across multiple, potentially overlapping Visium capture areas. It facilitates stitching images using Fiji and constructing SpatialExperiment objects, enabling downstream analyses like spatially-aware clustering without discarding data from overlapping regions. The tool provides a flexible framework for multi-capture area study designs, expanding possibilities for spatial transcriptomics research.

title: Get to know your neighbors with a SNAQ<sup>™</sup>: A framework for single cell spatial neighborhood analysis in immunohistochemical images.
main_goals: This paper introduces SNAQ™, an R Markdown script for single-cell spatial neighborhood analysis in immunohistochemical images. It enables quantification of cell prevalence and distances in the vicinity of other cell types without extensive coding knowledge. The framework aims to reveal insights into tumor-immune dynamics and spatial interactions.

title: Scalable imaging-free spatial genomics through computational reconstruction.
main_goals: Developed an imaging-free spatial transcriptomics method that uses molecular diffusion patterns to computationally reconstruct spatial data. This method utilizes a simple experimental protocol on 2D barcode arrays and the UMAP algorithm to reconstruct spatial locations. It is compatible with existing spatial transcriptomics methods and scales to large tissue areas.

title: Optics-free Spatial Genomics for Mapping Mouse Brain Aging.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: Introduce IRISeq, an optics-free spatial transcriptomics platform for rapid and cost-effective tissue processing. IRISeq enables mapping of gene expression and cellular dynamics without predefined capture arrays or extensive imaging, allowing for studies without size constraints and across varied resolutions.

title: Exploit Spatially Resolved Transcriptomic Data to Infer Cellular Features from Pathology Imaging Data.
data_modalities_used: ['HE-stained images', 'pathology imaging data', 'spatially resolved transcriptomic data']
main_goals: The paper proposes an innovative approach to annotate pathology images using paired spatially resolved transcriptomic data. It introduces a novel transfer-learning neural network model, STpath, to predict cell type proportions or classify tumor microenvironments. The model demonstrates promising performance in breast cancer datasets, especially with variable cell type proportions and high-resolution images.

title: Characterisation of HBV and co-infection with HDV and HIV through spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Chronic Hepatitis B (CHB) with co-infection of Hepatitis Delta Virus (HDV) or Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
main_goals: To evaluate spatial transcriptomics (NanoString GeoMx) for characterising the intrahepatic transcriptional landscape, cellular composition, and biological pathways in liver biopsy samples from patients with HBV and HDV or HIV co-infection. The study aims to provide insights into complex intrahepatic processes guiding personalized treatments.

title: Distinct tumor-TAM interactions in IDH-stratified glioma microenvironments unveiled by single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This study delineates the phenotypic heterogeneity of tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) across IDH-stratified gliomas. It identifies distinct tumor-TAM crosstalk in IDH-WT gliomas, proposing SLAMF9 as a therapeutic target and revealing ANXA1-FPR1/3, FN1-ITGAVB1, VEGFA-NRP1, and TNFSF12-TNFRSF12A as key communication pathways. The findings offer insights into TAM roles and vulnerabilities in IDH-WT GBM.

title: A Hands-on Guide to AmoePy - a Python-Based Software Package to Analyze Cell Migration Data.
main_goals: This paper introduces AmoePy, a Python-based software package for analyzing cell migration data. It provides tools for cell segmentation, contour detection, and analysis of contour dynamics, enabling the characterization of phenotypic differences in cell locomotion. The software facilitates the creation of kymographs and videos from microscopy recordings.

title: Automated spatial omics landscape analysis approach reveals novel tissue architectures in ulcerative colitis.
main_goals: The paper introduces an automated spatial omics landscape analysis approach that matches spatial pattern detection to cell annotation. This method was applied to ulcerative colitis patient colonic biopsies to identify novel tissue architectures and rare cell types within germinal-center B cell follicles. The approach aims to deepen understanding of disease pathogenesis and inform precision diagnosis and therapies.

title: Conserved B cell signaling, activation, and differentiation in porcine jejunal and ileal Peyer's patches despite distinct immune landscapes.
biological_context: Porcine jejunal and ileal Peyer's patches
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell transcriptomics', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'ex vivo staining', 'in situ staining']
main_goals: This study aimed to define B cell signaling, activation, and differentiation in porcine jejunal and ileal Peyer's patches using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. Despite distinct immune landscapes between intestinal locations, the research identified conserved B cell dynamics and deduced activation/differentiation routes. The findings establish a benchmark for understanding intestinal immune induction.

title: Protocol for preparing mammalian skin samples encompassing hair follicles for spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Mammalian skin, specifically focusing on hair follicles.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Tissue Preparation', 'Embedding', 'Frozen Slice Acquisition', 'RNA Quality Control', 'Tissue Mounting', 'Fixation', 'Staining', 'Imaging', 'Permeabilization', 'Reverse Transcription', 'cDNA Collection']
main_goals: This paper presents a detailed protocol for preparing mammalian skin samples, including hair follicles, for spatial transcriptomics. The protocol covers sample preparation, embedding, sectioning, RNA quality control, fixation, staining, imaging, and cDNA preparation, enabling single-cell resolution gene expression analysis in skin.

title: Human genetics and epigenetics of alcohol use disorder.
main_goals: This paper reviews progress in understanding the genetics and epigenetics of Alcohol Use Disorder (AUD). It summarizes key findings from candidate gene studies to genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and epigenome-wide association studies (EWAS). The authors also discuss limitations and future directions for research in AUD.

title: LIM domain only 7: a novel driver of immune evasion through regulatory T cell differentiation and chemotaxis in pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial proteomics', 'in vitro experiments', 'in vivo experiments', 'histology images']
main_goals: This study aimed to uncover PDAC's immune microenvironment heterogeneity and identify molecular mechanisms driving immune evasion, specifically focusing on the role of LIM domain only 7 (LMO7) in promoting regulatory T cell (Treg) differentiation and chemotaxis, leading to immune evasion in PDAC. It also investigates targeting the LMO7-Foxp1-TGF-β/CCL5 axis as a therapeutic strategy.

title: Origin, structure, and composition of the spider major ampullate silk fiber revealed by genomics, proteomics, and single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper aims to understand the bioprocessing and composition of spider silk fibers by identifying the proteins involved and mapping their production within the gland. It reveals the cellular and zonal organization of the major ampullate silk gland and the layered structure of the fiber. The study provides significant advancements in understanding the spider silk gland and the resulting fiber's architecture and composition.

title: Spatial multiomics reveals a subpopulation of fibroblasts associated with cancer stemness in human hepatocellular carcinoma.
data_modalities_used: ['multi-region proteomics', '10X Genomics Visium spatial transcriptomics', 'multiplexed imaging', 'bulk transcriptome']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Colocalization']
main_goals: This study aimed to decipher the expression heterogeneity, functional diversity, spatial distribution, colocalization, and interaction of fibroblasts in the liver tumor microenvironment. The researchers identified a novel subpopulation of cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), termed F5-CAF, associated with cancer stemness and unfavorable prognosis in hepatocellular carcinoma.

title: The spatial distribution of intermediate fibroblasts and myeloid-derived cells dictate lymph node metastasis dynamics in oral cancer.
biological_context: Oral cancer (gingivo-buccal oral squamous cell carcinoma)
covered_analysis_steps: ['Gene expression profiling', 'Differential gene expression', 'Deconvolution', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: To investigate the localization of genes and cell types within the invasive margins of oral cancer that could lead to nodal metastasis. The study identified the tumor-stromal interface as a critical region for disease progression and pinpointed specific genes and cell types contributing to metastasis.

title: An isotopically-labelled temporal mass spectrometry imaging data analysis workflow to reveal glucose spatial metabolism patterns in bovine lens tissue.
