It infers spatial relationships among cells via transcriptome-to-space projection, defining neighborhoods and enhancing cell-cell communication analyses. The method facilitates quantitative assessments of spatial cell neighborhoods, interactions, and tumor-immune microenvironments in both human and mouse datasets.

title: Unveiling Spatial Immune Cell Profile in Kidney Allograft Rejections Using 36-plex Immunofluorescence Imaging.
main_goals: To unveil novel spatial indices associated with transplant rejection using a spatial bioinformatic approach on 36-plex immunofluorescence data. The study aimed to characterize immune cell profiles in kidney allograft rejections and identify spatial features related to different rejection types and patient outcomes.

title: The Effect of Exposure to Neighborhood Violence on Glucocorticoid Receptor Signaling in Lung Tumors.
biological_context: Lung cancer in Black men in Chicago
main_goals: This study investigates the relationship between exposure to neighborhood violence and glucocorticoid receptor (GR) signaling in lung tumors. The authors aimed to understand how social stress influences tumor biology by examining GR binding and gene expression in relation to violent crime rates in Chicago neighborhoods. The findings suggest that social stress, through GR reprogramming, may contribute to lung cancer disparities.

title: Historic obstacles and emerging opportunities in the field of developmental metabolism - lessons from Heidelberg.
biological_context: Developmental metabolism, interorgan metabolic communication, gene-by-metabolite interactions
main_goals: This paper summarizes key discussions from a 2023 EMBO workshop on developmental metabolism. It highlights historical obstacles and emerging opportunities driven by technological advancements like metabolomics, sensors, single-cell sequencing, and computational modeling. The authors emphasize how these advances enable new inquiries into cell-specific metabolic networks, interorgan communication, and gene-metabolite interactions, offering opportunities for young scientists.

title: DDIT3 is associated with breast cancer prognosis and immune microenvironment: an integrative bioinformatic and immunohistochemical analysis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study investigates the role of DDIT3 in breast cancer prognosis and its interaction with the immune microenvironment. It utilizes a multi-omics integration strategy to identify a prognostic signature and explore spatial expression patterns, aiming to provide insights for personalized treatment.

title: Multi-omic profiling of breast tumor microenvironment uncovers a role of mitochondrial calcium gatekeepers.
main_goals: This study elucidates the role of mitochondrial calcium uptake 1/2 (MiCU1/2) in breast cancer using multi-omics. It establishes MiCU1/2 as a diagnostic biomarker and therapeutic target by correlating its expression with clinical status, patient survival, and immune infiltration, and identifies potential drugs targeting MiCU1/2-high cells.

title: Spatial and Single-Cell Investigations Illuminate Theragnostic value and Immune Landscape of Mitochondrial Dynamin-Like GTPase in Breast Cancer.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of OPA1/3 in breast cancer and its interplay with the immune microenvironment. It reveals that OPA1/3 is upregulated in breast cancer and correlates with poor prognosis, suggesting its potential as a diagnostic, prognostic, and survival biomarker.

title: Synthesizing 4D Magnetic Resonance Angiography From 3D Time-of-Flight Using Deep Learning: A Feasibility Study.
main_goals: To develop a deep convolutional neural network (DCNN) model capable of generating synthetic 4D MRA from 3D TOF images, enabling the estimation of temporal changes in arterial flow. The model aims to extract latent dynamic information from TOF signals, overcoming the limitations of static TOF MRA.

title: Spatial Proteomics of Single Hepatocytes with Multiplexed Data-Independent Acquisition (mDIA).
main_goals: The paper describes a protocol for spatial proteomics of single hepatocytes using multiplexed data-independent acquisition (mDIA) with dimethyl labeling. The aim is to enhance proteome depth, accuracy, and throughput while minimizing costs, enabling high-quality single-cell proteome analysis.

title: Deciphering spatial domains from spatial multi-omics with SpatialGlue.
main_goals: SpatialGlue is a graph neural network model with a dual-attention mechanism for integrating spatial multi-omics data. It deciphers spatial domains by intra-omics and cross-omics integration, demonstrating improved anatomical detail and domain resolution compared to other methods. The method also identifies cell types not present in original annotations and scales well with data size.

title: A versatile tissue-rolling technique for spatial-omics analyses of the entire murine gastrointestinal tract.
data_modalities_used: ['Histological staining', 'Immunohistochemistry', 'In situ hybridization', 'Multiplexed antibody staining', 'Spatial transcriptomics', 'Spatial proteomics', 'Visium', 'ChipCytometry', 'CODEX-PhenoCycler']
main_goals: This paper reports a simple mounting technique to maximize the analyzed area of the murine gastrointestinal tract, enabling comprehensive spatial omics analyses on a single slide. The method integrates tissue rolling with transcriptomics (Visium) and proteomics (ChipCytometry, CODEX-PhenoCycler) for a systematic approach to generating gene and protein expression profiles of the entire GI tract.

title: Multiomics integration-based immunological characterizations of adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma in relation to keratinization.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: To perform an integrative analysis of single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics on ACP specimens to characterize the immunological microenvironment and intercellular network. The study aimed to identify potential therapeutic targets by understanding the cellular composition and interactions within the tumor microenvironment, particularly focusing on TAMs and keratinization.

title: Unveiling contact-mediated cellular crosstalk.
main_goals: This review explores cutting-edge approaches, including single-cell sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, bioengineering, and molecular tools, to understand cell-cell interactions. It highlights how spatial transcriptomics reveals gene expression changes based on cell proximity and discusses computational methods for deciphering cell contact-governed cellular responses.

title: IRF4 requires ARID1A to establish plasma cell identity in multiple myeloma.
data_modalities_used: ['functional genomics screening', 'spatial proteomics', 'global chromatin mapping', 'immunohistochemistry', 'mass spectrometry', 'CRISPR screening', 'in vivo studies in mice']
main_goals: This study investigates the role of ARID1A in establishing plasma cell identity in multiple myeloma, identifying ARID1A as a requirement for IRF4 expression and function. It demonstrates that targeting SWI/SNF activity is toxic to MM cells and shows potential as a therapeutic strategy for relapsed/refractory disease, especially in combination with MEK inhibitors.

title: SEraster: a rasterization preprocessing framework for scalable spatial omics data analysis.
main_goals: To enhance the scalability of spatial omics data analysis by developing a rasterization preprocessing framework called SEraster that aggregates cellular information into spatial pixels. SEraster reduces computational resource requirements while maintaining high performance for spatial variable gene expression analysis and cell-type spatial co-enrichment characterization. It enables analysis of large spatial omics datasets with millions of cells.

title: Advances in spatial transcriptomics and its applications in cancer research.
main_goals: This paper summarizes the development of spatial transcriptomics technologies and tools, and their applications in cancer research. It also discusses the limitations and challenges of current approaches, as well as future development and prospects.

title: Automatic classification of normal and abnormal cell division using deep learning.
biological_context: Cell division in response to genotoxic stress (radiation)
main_goals: Develop an automatic mitosis classifier to categorize cell division sequences as 'Normal' or 'Abnormal'. The classifier uses deep learning, specifically a ResNet50 backbone with an LSTM layer, achieving a mean F1-score of 0.93. The goal is to integrate this with cell segmentation and tracking for phylogenetic analysis after genomic stress.

title: Artificial intelligence-driven assessment of salt caverns for underground hydrogen storage in Poland.
main_goals: This study introduces an artificial intelligence framework for assessing the suitability of salt caverns for underground hydrogen storage in Poland. The framework integrates multi-criteria decision-making and spatial data analysis with eight machine-learning algorithms to create suitability maps. The goal is to aid stakeholders in identifying optimal locations for hydrogen storage.

title: An improved approach for automated cervical cell segmentation with PointRend.
biological_context: Cervical cancer screening and cytological analysis
main_goals: This paper proposes a new convolutional neural network based on Mask RCNN and PointRend module to segment overlapping cervical cells. The method aims to fine-tune candidate boundary pixels of cell cytoplasm for precise segmentation. The proposed model achieves improved performance on cervical cell segmentation tasks.

title: Challenges and opportunities in cancer immunotherapy: a Society for Immunotherapy of Cancer (SITC) strategic vision.
main_goals: This paper presents a strategic vision for cancer immunotherapy, identifying high-priority areas of opportunity and cross-cutting tools for optimization. It outlines three key guiding principles to accelerate progress in the field over the next decade.

title: Spatial metabolomics in tissue injury and regeneration.
main_goals: This review focuses on mass spectrometry imaging as an advanced platform to understand metabolic adaptation in tissue homeostasis, injury, and repair. It highlights how this technology deciphers metabolic networks that govern cellular behavior and tissue resilience, aiming to advance fundamental understanding and inform therapeutic interventions by targeting metabolic pathways.

title: Spatial proteomics of skeletal muscle using thin cryosections reveals metabolic adaptation at the muscle-tendon transition zone.
biological_context: Skeletal muscle and the muscle-tendon transition zone
main_goals: This study performs a spatial proteomics analysis of mouse soleus muscle, including the muscle-tendon transition zone, using thin cryosections and LC-MS. The analysis reveals proteins related to neuronal activity, fatty acid biosynthesis, and the renin-angiotensin system (RAS) that increase from muscle to tendon. It also demonstrates that the RAS regulates ECM synthesis in tenocytes, acting as an additional regulator of the matrix within muscle-tendon junctions.

title: Large-scale neurophysiology and single-cell profiling in human neuroscience.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'ex vivo tissue culture', 'single-unit neurophysiology']
main_goals: This perspective describes the development of large-scale single-unit human neurophysiology and single-cell profiling techniques. It discusses how their convergence will advance investigations into the cellular underpinnings of network-level activity in the human brain. The paper also explores the impact of these advances on clinical practice and societal/ethical implications.

title: Multiscale topology classifies cells in subcellular spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Human kidney tissue and mouse model of lupus nephritis
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: The paper proposes a multiscale approach to automatically classify cell types at the subcellular level using transcriptomic information and spatial context. It leverages multiparameter persistent homology to identify cell spatial relationships. The framework aims to bridge different levels of biological organization from genes to tissues and generalize to new platforms.

title: Microenvironment shapes small-cell lung cancer neuroendocrine states and presents therapeutic opportunities.
data_modalities_used: ['spatially resolved transcriptomics', 'quantitative mass spectrometry-based proteomics', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study maps the Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC) tumor microenvironment (TME) using spatial transcriptomics and proteomics. It identifies cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) as crucial for immune exclusion and poor prognosis, suggesting TME-driven reprogramming of neuroendocrine cell states. The research aims to highlight the TME's role in SCLC adaptability and open avenues for therapeutic interventions.

title: Spatial Transcriptome-Wide Profiling of Small Cell Lung Cancer Reveals Intra-Tumoral Molecular and Subtype Heterogeneity.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study analyzes the spatial transcriptome-wide profiling of small cell lung cancer (SCLC) to understand intra-tumoral molecular and subtype heterogeneity. It identifies distinct molecular profiles, biological functions, immune features, and molecular subtypes within spatially localized histological regions and establishes connections to patient survival and therapeutic response. A gene signature, ITHtyper, is developed for patient risk stratification from bulk RNA-seq profiles.

title: Development of a nanoparticle-based tendon-targeting drug delivery system to pharmacologically modulate tendon healing.
main_goals: To develop a nanoparticle-based drug delivery system that targets the healing tendon to deliver therapeutic agents and improve functional and mechanical recovery following acute tendon injury.

title: Inhibition of the Eukaryotic Initiation Factor-2-α Kinase PERK Decreases Risk of Autoimmune Diabetes in Mice.
biological_context: Autoimmune type 1 diabetes (T1D) in mice and human islets
main_goals: This paper investigates whether inhibiting the eIF2α kinase PERK can reduce the risk of autoimmune diabetes in mice. The study shows that PERK inhibition delays diabetes onset, reduces islet inflammation, and preserves beta cell mass. It also identifies molecular mechanisms, including increased PD-L1 expression in beta cells, mediated by PERK activity.

title: APOE Christchurch enhances a disease-associated microglial response to plaque but suppresses response to tau pathology.
main_goals: This study investigated the effect of the APOE Christchurch (APOECh) variant on Alzheimer's disease pathology using mouse models. The research explored how APOECh impacts microglial responses to amyloid and tau pathologies, aiming to understand its protective mechanisms.

title: Spatial Deconvolution of Cell Types and Cell States at Scale Utilizing TACIT.
main_goals: The paper introduces TACIT, an unsupervised algorithm for cell annotation in spatial biology. TACIT operates without training data, using unbiased thresholding and focusing on relevant markers to identify cells. It aims to overcome the generalization difficulties of deep learning methods by being robust to variations in cells, neighborhoods, and niches.

title: SpotSweeper: spatially-aware quality control for spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: SpotSweeper introduces spatially-aware quality control methods for spatial transcriptomics data. It identifies local outliers and regional artifacts by evaluating spots relative to their neighborhoods and using multiscale methods. This leads to improved downstream clustering and marker gene detection.

title: Ablation of Vitamin D Signaling in Cardiomyocytes Leads to Functional Impairment and Stimulation of Pro-Inflammatory and Pro-Fibrotic Gene Regulatory Networks in a Left Ventricular Hypertrophy Model in Mice.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of vitamin D signaling in cardiomyocytes during left ventricular hypertrophy by ablating the vitamin D receptor (VDR) specifically in these cells. The researchers used transverse aortic constriction (TAC) to induce hypertrophy and spatial transcriptomics to analyze gene expression changes in cardiac tissue. Their findings suggest that vitamin D signaling in cardiomyocytes offers a protective role under stress.

title: Longitudinal Neuropathological Consequences of Extracranial Radiation Therapy in Mice.
biological_context: Cancer-related cognitive impairment (CRCI) induced by extracranial radiation therapy (ECRT)
data_modalities_used: ['spatial proteomics', 'immunohistochemistry', 'Nanostring nCounter® glial profiling', 'neuroinflammation gene panels', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Protein Analysis', 'Histology Image Analysis', 'Gene Expression Profiling']
main_goals: To investigate the longitudinal neuropathological consequences of ECRT in mice and identify signaling pathways involved in ECRT-related CRCI. The study aimed to understand the role of neuroinflammation and glial cell activation in the pathogenesis of CRCI by analyzing brain tissue, spinal cord, and skin following radiation treatment.

title: Traumatic brain injury promotes neurogenesis at the cost of astrogliogenesis in the adult hippocampus of male mice.
biological_context: Traumatic brain injury (TBI) effects on the adult hippocampus of male mice
main_goals: To investigate how traumatic brain injury (TBI) affects hippocampal neurogenesis and astrogliogenesis in adult male mice. The study uses single cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to assess changes in neural stem cells and their derivatives. It aims to identify cellular targets to counteract TBI-induced cellular changes in the hippocampus.

title: DNA-PAINT adaptors make for efficient multiplexing.
main_goals: This paper highlights advances in DNA-PAINT adaptors that improve the efficiency of multiplexed super-resolution imaging. The described methods, SUM-PAINT and FLASH-PAINT, leverage DNA strand design to increase the speed of label exchange, facilitating time-efficient mapping of multiple protein species for spatial proteomics.

title: Inhibition of the eukaryotic initiation factor-2α kinase PERK decreases risk of autoimmune diabetes in mice.
data_modalities_used: ['insulin-producing β cells', 'human islets', 'T1D-susceptible mice', 'Single-cell RNA-Seq', 'spatial proteomics', 'EndoC-βH1 human β cells']
main_goals: This study investigates the inhibition of the eukaryotic initiation factor-2α kinase PERK as a strategy to prevent autoimmune diabetes. The authors found that PERK inhibition reduced islet inflammation, preserved beta cell mass, and altered antigen presentation pathways in beta cells. They identified PD-L1 stabilization as a mechanism by which PERK inhibition may reduce beta cell immunogenicity.

title: The crosstalk role of CDKN2A between tumor progression and cuproptosis resistance in colorectal cancer.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'pathological image analysis', 'TCGA multi-omics analysis', 'in vitro experimental validation']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study investigates the role of CDKN2A in cuproptosis resistance and tumor progression in colorectal cancer. It explores CDKN2A's distribution, expression, epigenetic modification, regulation, and genomic features. The findings associate CDKN2A with cuproptosis resistance, malignant phenotype, and a pro-tumor niche, suggesting therapeutic potential for radiation and chemotherapy in high-CDKN2A tumors.

title: Spatial metabolomics reveals key features of hippocampal lipid changes in rats with postoperative cognitive dysfunction.
biological_context: Postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) after cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) in rats
main_goals: This study aimed to elucidate the role of lipid metabolism in postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) in rats following cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). It utilized spatial metabolomics and imaging techniques to identify lipid changes in the hippocampus and investigated the impact of modulating specific lipid metabolism pathways on POCD.

title: Prediction of Tumor-Associated Macrophages and Immunotherapy Benefits Using Weakly Supervised Contrastive Learning in Breast Cancer Pathology Images.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This paper develops a weakly supervised contrastive learning model to infer tumor-associated macrophages and potential immunotherapy benefits from H&E stained pathology images. The method extracts features from whole slide images, aggregates them, and fine-tunes an encoder for downstream tasks. Experiments demonstrate accurate prediction of immune cell infiltration, immune subtypes, and immunotherapy benefit.

title: HCCDB v2.0: Decompose Expression Variations by Single-cell RNA-seq and Spatial Transcriptomics in HCC.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Visualization', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: HCCDB v2.0 is an updated version of the database integrating bulk, single-cell, and spatial transcriptomic data of HCC clinical samples. It expands the data size and introduces a novel single-cell level and 2-dimension (sc-2D) metric to summarize cell type-specific and dysregulated gene expression patterns. The database allows for graphical visualization and user-friendly data retrieval.

title: Morphological profiling for drug discovery in the era of deep learning.
main_goals: This review provides a comprehensive overview of recent advances in morphological profiling for drug discovery, focusing on the integration of high-throughput imaging and deep learning. It summarizes image profiling analysis workflows, surveys feature engineering- and deep learning-based approaches, and highlights applications in drug discovery, while also identifying challenges and opportunities.

title: Spatial transcriptomics at the brain-electrode interface in rat motor cortex and the relationship to recording quality.
biological_context: Brain tissue response to implanted electrodes in rat motor cortex
main_goals: To study the foreign body reaction to implanted electrodes in the brain using spatial transcriptomics. The study aims to identify changes in gene expression related to electrode implantation and correlate these changes with glial reactivity, neuronal loss, and electrophysiological recording quality, seeking potential biomarkers.

title: Transcriptional switches in melanoma T Cells: Facilitating polarizing into regulatory T cells.
main_goals: This paper elucidates mechanisms of Treg self-maintenance and communication in melanoma, identifies novel functional molecules (SPOCK2, SH2D2A, ITGB2, LTA, CLEC2C, CLEC2D) and a melanoma Treg-specific regulatory tag set (Mel TregS). It also introduces SERS technology for clinical disease monitoring.

title: Spatial transcriptomics in embryonic mouse diaphragm muscle reveals regional gradients and subdomains of developmental gene expression.
main_goals: This paper provides spatially resolved gene expression data for embryonic mouse diaphragms. It reveals gene signatures for specific muscle regions, neuromuscular junctions, and myotendinous junctions. The data also helps in understanding the effects of genetic mutations on muscle development and gene expression.

title: Intrinsic Gata4 expression sensitizes the aortic root to dilation in a Loeys-Dietz syndrome mouse model.
biological_context: Loeys-Dietz syndrome (LDS) mouse model and human aortic VSMCs
main_goals: To identify molecular determinants of aortic root vulnerability in Loeys-Dietz syndrome (LDS) by investigating vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) heterogeneity. The study found that Gata4-expressing VSMCs, predominantly in the aortic root, have a less differentiated, proinflammatory profile and contribute to aortic root dilation in LDS mice. Postnatal Gata4 deletion reduced dilation, indicating its sensitizing role.

title: Advances and applications of biomimetic biomaterials for endogenous skin regeneration.
main_goals: This review outlines recent advances in biomimetic materials for endogenous skin regeneration, focusing on structural and functional mimicry, physiological process regulation, and biophysical property design. It highlights novel techniques such as in situ reprogramming, flexible electronic skin, AI, single-cell sequencing, and spatial transcriptomics that can contribute to biomimetic biomaterial development. The paper aims to address clinical problems of rapid and high-quality skin regeneration.

title: Do negative stereotypes and domain identification moderate novice participants' performance on a soccer-dribbling task ?
main_goals: The research explored whether negative stereotypes and domain identification moderate novice participants' performance on a soccer-dribbling task. Using a novel statistical procedure for within-subjects moderation, the study found that neither inducing a negative stereotype nor domain identification moderated performance in a stereotype threat situation. Therefore, novice participants' performance did not depend on these factors, but further research is needed.

title: Tissue gene expression profiles and communication networks inform candidate blood biomarker identification in psoriasis and atopic dermatitis.
main_goals: This study aims to identify transcriptional signatures and communication networks in keratinocytes and T lymphocytes from patients with psoriasis and atopic dermatitis using spatial transcriptomics. The goal is to advance biomarker development and identify potential therapeutic targets.

title: Identifying proteomic risk factors for overall, aggressive, and early onset prostate cancer using Mendelian Randomisation and tumour spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Prostate cancer (overall, aggressive, and early onset)
main_goals: This study investigates the association of genetically predicted circulating protein levels with prostate cancer risk using Mendelian Randomization and colocalization. It also utilizes spatial transcriptomic data to assess the role of identified proteins in tumour aggressiveness. The aim is to identify proteomic risk factors for prostate cancer and potential therapeutic targets.

title: Predicting the odds of chronic wasting disease with Habitat Risk software.
biological_context: Chronic Wasting Disease (CWD) in cervid populations, specifically white-tailed deer, across various geographical regions.
main_goals: To introduce the Habitat Risk software, which links an epidemiological model with environmental and disease testing data. The software enables localized, data-driven predictions of Chronic Wasting Disease (CWD) detection odds after an outbreak. It aims to facilitate wider use of technical scientific methods by wildlife agencies through semi-automation.

title: SCIMAP: A Python Toolkit for Integrated Spatial Analysis of Multiplexed Imaging Data.
main_goals: To introduce SCIMAP, a Python package designed for integrated spatial analysis of multiplexed imaging data. It aims to address the need for tools that seamlessly integrate image visualization with data analysis and exploration for large-scale tissue profiling.

title: Visualising Neutrophil Actin Dynamics in Zebrafish in Response to Laser Wounding Using Two-Photon Microscopy.
main_goals: This paper describes a laser-wound assay protocol for zebrafish larvae to visualize neutrophil actin dynamics in response to acute injury using two-photon microscopy. The assay allows for monitoring cellular behavior and cytoskeletal changes immediately after focused injury, offering high resolution and precision.

title: Library size normalization affects spatial domain identification.
main_goals: This paper investigates how library size normalization methods impact the identification of spatial domains in spatial transcriptomics data. It demonstrates that different normalization strategies can lead to variations in the identified spatial structures, highlighting the importance of considering normalization choices when analyzing spatial omics datasets.

title: STPDA: Leveraging spatial-temporal patterns for downstream analysis in spatial transcriptomic data.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell type classification', 'Ligand-receptor interactions']
main_goals: The paper introduces STPDA, a computational framework that leverages spatial-temporal patterns for downstream analysis of spatial transcriptomic data. It utilizes ARMA and LSTM models to decipher spatio-temporal dynamics and excels in tasks like ligand-receptor interaction identification and cell type classification, outperforming existing methods.

title: Feasibility of MALDI-MSI-Based Proteomics Using Bouin-Fixed Pathology Samples: Untapping the Goldmine of Nephropathology Archives.
biological_context: Nephropathology, specifically focusing on renal tissue and kidney diseases.
main_goals: This paper explores the feasibility of using MALDI-MSI on Bouin-fixed paraffin-embedded (BFPE) renal tissue, a common but challenging fixative in nephropathology. It evaluates the impact of preanalytical conditions and compares BFPE with formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) samples. The study demonstrates that BFPE samples can effectively distinguish parenchyma regions and substructures, supporting their utility in spatial proteomics research.

title: Editorial: Spatiotemporal heterogeneity in CNS tumors.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'multiplex spatial 3D mapping', 'single cell spatial analysis']
main_goals: This editorial discusses the spatiotemporal heterogeneity observed in central nervous system (CNS) tumors, such as glioblastoma. It highlights the importance of understanding this heterogeneity through advanced techniques like multiplex spatial 3D mapping and single-cell spatial analysis. The aim is to underscore how these approaches can shed light on tumor biology and therapeutic resistance.

title: Picosecond laser capture microdissection based on edge catapulting combined with dielectrophoretic force.
main_goals: The paper proposes a novel picosecond laser capture microdissection system (ps-LMED) that utilizes edge catapulting and dielectrophoretic force. This system aims to enable fast, non-invasive acquisition of uncontaminated cells and cell populations for downstream molecular assays. The method allows for the collection of samples ranging from single cells to larger tissues without further operations.

title: Multi-branch attention Raman network and surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy for the classification of neurological disorders.
biological_context: Neurological disorders (healthy controls, mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer's disease, Non-Alzheimer's dementia, elderly depression, elderly anxiety)
main_goals: This paper proposes a Multi-branch Attention Raman Network (MBA-RamanNet) to improve the classification of neurological disorders using SERS data. The network incorporates a multi-branch attention module to extract both global and local information from characteristic Raman peaks. It aims to optimize feature extraction for more accurate disease identification.

title: Gene count normalization in single-cell imaging-based spatially resolved transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper investigates the impact of different gene count normalization methods on imaging-based spatially resolved transcriptomics (im-SRT) data. It demonstrates how normalization methods can differentially affect gene expression magnitudes in a region- or cell type-specific manner, potentially reducing the reliability of downstream analyses. The study recommends using non-gene count-based normalization approaches and evaluating gene panel representativeness.

title: Progress of single-cell RNA sequencing combined with spatial transcriptomics in tumour microenvironment and treatment of pancreatic cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Tumor Microenvironment Analysis']
main_goals: This review explains the research progress on the tumor microenvironment and treatment of pancreatic cancer by detailing the methods of single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) combined with spatial transcriptomics (ST). It highlights how these techniques improve understanding of tumor heterogeneity and treatment development.

title: Spatial transcriptomics analysis identifies a tumor-promoting function of the meningeal stroma in melanoma leptomeningeal disease.
main_goals: This paper characterizes the tumor microenvironment of melanoma leptomeningeal disease (LMD) using spatial transcriptomics. It identifies a tumor-promoting function of the meningeal stroma, mediated by SERPINA3, and demonstrates a mechanism to overcome associated drug resistance.

title: Single-cell multi-ome and immune profiles of the Inspiration4 crew reveal conserved, cell-type, and sex-specific responses to spaceflight.
biological_context: Spaceflight effects on astronaut immune system
main_goals: This study aimed to characterize the immune response to spaceflight by generating multi-omic data from the Inspiration4 crew. The researchers identified a conserved 'spaceflight signature' in gene expression and observed specific changes in T cells and MHC class I genes, linking immune disruption to microbiome shifts. The findings provide a roadmap for countermeasures to maintain astronaut health.

title: Sopa: a technology-invariant pipeline for analyses of image-based spatial omics.
main_goals: Sopa is a technology-invariant, memory-efficient pipeline with a unified visualizer for all image-based spatial omics. It optimizes tasks like segmentation, transcript/channel aggregation, annotation, and geometric/spatial analysis, providing user-friendly web reports and comprehensive data files.

title: Spatially resolved multiomics on the neuronal effects induced by spaceflight in mice.
biological_context: The study investigates the impact of spaceflight on the mouse brain, specifically focusing on neurogenesis, synaptogenesis, synaptic transmission, astrocyte activation, and immune dysfunction.
main_goals: To elucidate the impact of spaceflight on the mouse brain using an integrated approach of single-cell multiomics and spatial transcriptomics. The study aims to identify alterations in brain processes and pathways affected by spaceflight and to provide a basis for future research.
data_links_mentioned: ['National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) Open Science Data Repository (OSDR)']

title: DOT: a flexible multi-objective optimization framework for transferring features across single-cell and spatial omics.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell transcriptomics', 'spatially-resolved imaging/sequencing', 'high-resolution spatially-resolved data', 'low-resolution spatially-resolved data']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: DOT is a multi-objective optimization framework designed to transfer cellular features across single-cell transcriptomics and spatially-resolved omics data. It integrates complementary information by leveraging genes beyond common ones, utilizing local spatial context, transferring spatial features beyond cell-type information, and inferring cell population abundance. This framework bridges single-cell data with both high- and low-resolution spatial data, addressing practical aspects of cell composition, heterogeneity, and prior knowledge integration.

title: A greedy regularized block Kaczmarz method for accelerating reconstruction in magnetic particle imaging.
main_goals: This paper proposes a greedy regularized block Kaczmarz method (GRBK) to accelerate reconstruction in Magnetic Particle Imaging (MPI). GRBK aims to improve reconstruction speed and image quality for real-time MPI applications by partitioning the system matrix and using a regularized block Kaczmarz algorithm.

title: Integration of Clinical Trial Spatial Multiomics Analysis and Virtual Clinical Trials Enables Immunotherapy Response Prediction and Biomarker Discovery.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Biomarker Discovery', 'Immunotherapy Response Prediction']
main_goals: The study developed a novel computational model for spatial quantitative systems pharmacology to track tumor progression and capture spatial heterogeneity in HCC. This model aims to simulate the effects of combination immunotherapy, facilitating dosing regimen design and biomarker discovery. The model was validated against clinical trial spatial multiomics data, demonstrating its utility for patient outcome prediction and biomarker identification.

title: A comprehensive survey of dimensionality reduction and clustering methods for single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data.
main_goals: This review systematically summarizes widely recognized algorithms for dimensionality reduction and clustering analysis of single-cell and spatial transcriptomic data. It aims to provide valuable insights for the development of novel tools in this rapidly evolving field.

title: ExMove: An open-source toolkit for processing and exploring animal-tracking data in R.
main_goals: This paper presents ExMove, an open-source toolkit in R for processing raw animal-tracking data. It aims to standardize data cleaning, improve reproducibility, and facilitate data sharing. The toolkit includes flexible code, an overview website, and a Shiny app for visualization and parameter determination.

title: Fine-Scale Spatial Prediction on the Risk of Plasmodium vivax Infection in the Republic of Korea.
biological_context: Malaria risk prediction in the Republic of Korea
data_modalities_used: ['spatial data of patient locations', 'environmental data', 'sociodemographic data', 'meteorological data']
main_goals: To develop and evaluate machine learning models for fine-scale spatial prediction of Plasmodium vivax infection risk in the Republic of Korea. The study aimed to identify high-risk areas by incorporating various predictor variables and testing the performance of four machine learning algorithms.

title: DNA-Programmed Four-Bit Quaternary Fluorescence Encoding (FLUCO) Enables 51-Colored Bioimaging Analysis.
main_goals: This paper introduces Fluorescence Encoding (FLUCO), a multibit DNA self-assembly system that enables accurate, target-responsive, amplified color encoding at the molecular level. It demonstrates a quaternary FLUCO system encoding 51 colors, facilitating simultaneous imaging of multiple targets and integrating computer science for molecular encoding and decoding. This approach aims to advance spatial omics analysis and high-throughput liquid biopsy.

title: Remotely sensed estimates of long-term biochemical oxygen demand over Hong Kong marine waters using machine learning enhanced by imbalanced label optimisation.
main_goals: This study estimated the Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) concentration of Hong Kong's marine waters using remote sensing and an improved machine learning (ML) method. The scheme was derived from four ML algorithms calibrated using in-situ BOD5 data. The study highlights the potential of label distribution smoothing (LDS) to improve BOD5 estimates by dealing with imbalanced training datasets and reveals a downward trend in BOD5 concentration over two decades.

title: TrueTH: A user-friendly deep learning approach for robust dopaminergic neuron detection.
main_goals: This paper introduces TrueTH, a user-friendly and robust deep learning pipeline for accurate quantification of dopaminergic (DA) neurons. It addresses the limitations of existing tools by offering an open-sourced solution with remarkable resilience to staining variations and image quality issues. TrueTH aims to provide a practical tool for Parkinson's disease research by simplifying DA neuron assessment.

title: A Bibliometric Analysis of the Spatial Transcriptomics Literature from 2006 to 2023.
main_goals: This paper presents a bibliometric analysis of the spatial transcriptomics literature from 2006 to 2023. The study aims to identify frontiers and trends in this medical research field. It highlights rapid publication growth, key journals and countries, influential authors, and emerging hot topics like tissue recognition, cancer, and immunotherapy.

title: Deciphering lung granulomas in HIV & TB co-infection: unveiling macrophages aggregation with IL6R/STAT3 activation.
biological_context: HIV and Tuberculosis co-infection in the lung
main_goals: To elucidate histopathological features and inflammation regulation in HIV & TB co-infection by comparing it to TB alone. The study revealed distinct immune responses, particularly macrophage aggregation and IL6R/STAT3 activation in HIV & TB granulomas, suggesting potential therapeutic targets.

title: Energy competition remodels the metabolic glucose landscape of psoriatic epidermal cells.
data_modalities_used: ['bulk RNA-sequencing', 'single-cell RNA-sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'glucose uptake experiments', 'histology images']
main_goals: This study explored the role of metabolic competition in epidermal cell proliferation and differentiation in psoriatic skin. It identified that highly proliferative basal cells in psoriasis win glucose competition, upregulate OXPHOS via COX7B, increase ROS, and activate glutathione metabolism for antioxidant capacity. The study also noted glucose starvation and high SLC7A11 expression in suprabasal cells leading to disulfide stress and impaired differentiation.

title: diaTracer enables spectrum-centric analysis of diaPASEF proteomics data.
main_goals: This paper introduces diaTracer, a spectrum-centric computational tool for diaPASEF data analysis. It enables 3D peak tracing and feature detection to generate pseudo-MS/MS spectra for peptide identification and quantification. diaTracer is integrated into FragPipe and demonstrates performance across various sample types and experimental conditions.

title: Integrated spatial metabolomics and network pharmacology to explore the pharmacodynamic substances and mechanism of Radix ginseng-Schisandra chinensis Herb Couple on Alzheimer's disease.
main_goals: This study uses integrated spatial metabolomics and network pharmacology to explore the pharmacodynamic substances and mechanism of the Radix ginseng-Schisandra chinensis herbal couple on Alzheimer's disease in a rodent model. It identifies biomarkers linked to AD pathology and elucidates potential therapeutic targets and mechanisms of the herbal combination.

title: Spatial transcriptomics in cancer research and potential clinical impact: a narrative review.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'gene expression profiling', 'RNA profiling', 'HE-stained images', 'histology images']
main_goals: This review summarizes precision oncology and tumor sequencing in the clinic. It reviews available spatial transcriptomics research methods and their literature, focusing on solid tumors. The paper concludes by addressing the ultimate impact of spatial transcriptomics on cancer patients.

title: Spatiotemporal transcriptomic landscape of rice embryonic cells during seed germination.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Gene Expression Profiling', 'Single-Cell Analysis']
main_goals: The study characterizes the spatiotemporal transcriptomic landscape of rice embryonic cells during seed germination using Stereo-seq and scRNA-seq. It identifies novel cell types, delineates gene expression dynamics, and highlights key genes involved in germination processes. The research aims to provide a detailed understanding of cellular functions regulating seed vigor and seedling establishment.

title: Plasmodium infection induces phenotypic, clonal, and spatial diversity among differentiating CD4<sup>+</sup> T cells.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell Differentiation']
main_goals: This study investigates the phenotypic, clonal, and spatial diversity of CD4+ T cells during Plasmodium infection. It characterizes T cell differentiation states, spatial organization within the spleen, and molecular interactions with other immune cells. The research also explores the role of CCR5 in promoting T cell expansion and differentiation.

title: iIMPACT: integrating image and molecular profiles for spatial transcriptomics analysis.
main_goals: Develops iIMPACT, a multi-stage statistical method to integrate image and molecular profiles for spatial transcriptomics analysis. It identifies histology-based spatial domains using AI-reconstructed histology images and spatial context of gene expression, and detects domain-specific differentially expressed genes. The method aims to improve accuracy and interpretability compared to existing approaches.

title: Deconwolf enables high-performance deconvolution of widefield fluorescence microscopy images.
biological_context: DNA and RNA fluorescence in situ hybridization images, in situ spatial transcriptomics images, fluorescence in situ sequencing of barcoded Oligopaint probes
data_modalities_used: ['widefield fluorescence microscopy', 'fluorescence in situ hybridization', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'fluorescence in situ sequencing']
main_goals: Deconwolf is an open-source, user-friendly software for high-performance deconvolution of widefield fluorescence microscopy images. It enables accurate quantification of crowded diffraction limited fluorescence dots and robust detection of individual transcripts, improving chromosome tracing and transcript identification.

title: Accurate and efficient integrative reference-informed spatial domain detection for spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Brain structures, tumor microenvironment, diabetes-affected testis
main_goals: IRIS is presented as a computational method for accurately and efficiently detecting spatial domains in spatial transcriptomics studies. It leverages single-cell RNA sequencing data for reference-informed detection of biologically interpretable spatial domains and integrates multiple spatial transcriptomics slices. The method demonstrates substantial accuracy and speed improvements across diverse datasets.

title: Shared and unique transcriptomic signatures of antidepressant and probiotics action in the mammalian brain.
biological_context: Mammalian brain responses to antidepressant and probiotic treatments
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Differential Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: To examine the transcriptomic effects of antidepressants (bupropion, desipramine, fluoxetine) and a probiotic formulation (Lacidofil®) across 10 regions of the mammalian brain. The study aims to understand shared and divergent mechanisms by intersecting gene expression data with neuropsychiatric GWAS loci, MDD transcriptomic portraits, and mouse models of stress and depression, revealing region-specific and treatment-specific molecular responses.

title: A single-cell and spatial RNA-seq database for Alzheimer's disease (ssREAD).
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell clustering', 'Identification of differentially expressed genes', 'Identification of spatially variable genes', 'Cell-type-specific marker genes', 'Cell-type-specific regulons', 'Spot deconvolution']
main_goals: To address the surge in Alzheimer's Disease single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data by creating a comprehensive, user-friendly repository named ssREAD. It integrates a broad spectrum of AD-related datasets with an optimized analytical pipeline and improved usability for researchers.

title: Granuloma Annulare Exhibits Mixed Immune and Macrophage Polarization Profiles with Spatial Transcriptomics.
biological_context: Granuloma annulare (GA) is an idiopathic condition characterized by granulomatous inflammation in the skin.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Transcriptomics']
main_goals: To improve the understanding of spatially localized gene expression patterns underlying Granuloma Annulare (GA) by profiling the spatial gene expression landscape. The study aimed to reveal mixed T helper 1 and T helper 2 signals and spatially distinct M1 and M2 macrophage polarization characteristics within the GA microenvironment. It sought to identify key regulators of granulomatous inflammation, such as IFN-γ, TNF, and IL-32.

title: Spatiotemporal evolution and key driver analysis of ozone pollution from the perspectives of spatial spillover and path-dependence effects in China.
main_goals: This study investigates the spatiotemporal evolution and key drivers of ozone pollution in China, focusing on spatial spillover and path-dependence effects. It uses exploratory spatial data analysis (ESDA) and the dynamic spatial Durbin model (SDM) to analyze panel data from 30 Chinese provinces (2013-2020). The research aims to provide scientific guidance for regional synergy and long-term ozone control policies.

title: Revisiting Cardiac Biology in the Era of Single Cell and Spatial Omics.
biological_context: Cardiac biology and function in health and disease
main_goals: To provide a comprehensive overview of the cellular landscape of the heart by integrating insights from single-cell and spatial omics. It aims to bridge the gap between different omics approaches, discuss experimental and computational challenges, and contextualize cardiac cells within their niches. The ultimate goal is to pave the way for novel diagnostic tools and therapeutic interventions for cardiovascular diseases.

title: PIK3CA inhibition in models of proliferative glomerulonephritis and lupus nephritis.
biological_context: Proliferative glomerulonephritis and lupus nephritis in mice and humans
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'genetically engineered mouse models']
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of the PIK3CA pathway in proliferative glomerulonephritis and lupus nephritis. It demonstrates that PIK3CA inhibition, specifically by alpelisib, improves kidney function and lesions in mouse models. The study also reveals that PIK3CA inhibition impacts immune cells in lupus nephritis, reducing proinflammatory cytokines and autoantibodies.

title: Multi-omic profiling reveals potential biomarkers of hepatocellular carcinoma prognosis and therapy response among mitochondria-associated cell death genes in the context of 3P medicine.
main_goals: The study developed a novel predictive model, MCDI, for LIHC prognosis and therapy response. It leveraged machine learning and multi-omic data to identify key mitochondrial cell death genes. The model integrates into the PPPM framework to improve clinical decision-making for LIHC patients.

title: Classic genetic and hormonal switches during fetal sex development and beyond.
main_goals: This paper reviews the critical genetic and hormonal switches that regulate fetal sex development in humans. It discusses how these switches, initially thought to be a simple binary system, can act variably due to mutations, leading to a spectrum of differences in sex development (DSD). The review highlights key genes (SRY, SOX9, RSPO1, WNT4, FOXL2) and hormones (testosterone, DHT, AMH) involved in gonadal and phenotypic sex differentiation.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics reveal a high glycolysis B cell and tumor-associated macrophages cluster correlated with poor prognosis and exhausted immune microenvironment in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This study utilized multiple omics technologies to identify metabolic features of highly malignant DLBCL cells and tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs), along with their associated tumor microenvironment. It found that high-glycolysis malignant DLBCL tissues exhibit an immunosuppressive microenvironment and identified glycolysis genes and IFN_TAMs as potential prognostic markers and therapeutic targets in DLBCL.

title: HyperGCN: an effective deep representation learning framework for the integrative analysis of spatial transcriptomics data.
main_goals: This paper proposes HyperGCN, a deep representation learning framework for the integrative analysis of gene expression and spatial information from spatial transcriptomics data. HyperGCN uses a hypergraph induced graph convolutional network to model high-order interactions and noise, enabling data visualization, clustering, domain segmentation, and downstream biological analysis. It demonstrates superior performance across various datasets and technologies.

title: A spatial portrait of the human sebaceous gland transcriptional program.
biological_context: Human sebaceous gland differentiation and sebum production
main_goals: To map the landscape of sebaceous gland differentiation by characterizing the progressive transcriptional changes of sebocytes. The study aims to provide a high-resolution spatial portrait of the sebaceous gland transcriptional landscape and identify candidate molecules for regulating sebaceous gland homeostasis.
code_availability.link_in_abstract_or_ti: freely available and browsable online tool

title: Interferon-γ induces combined pyroptotic angiopathy and APOL1 expression in human kidney disease.
biological_context: Human kidney disease, including COVID-19, HIV, and APOL1 nephropathy
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'immunoblotting', 'quantitative fluorescence-based assays', 'multiomic analyses', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of Interferon-gamma (IFN-γ) in kidney diseases. It demonstrates that IFN-γ induces pyroptotic angiopathy and APOL1 expression in human kidney organoids and patient samples. The study suggests that targeting IFN-γ signaling could be a therapeutic strategy for APOL1-mediated collapsing glomerulopathy.

title: Single-Cell Spatial Transcriptomics Unveils Platelet-Fueled Cycling Macrophages for Kidney Fibrosis.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of platelets in kidney injury and repair, identifying platelet-modulated cycling M2 macrophages as key mediators of fibrosis. It highlights thrombospondin 1 (THBS1) as a target for mitigating kidney fibrosis by reducing the profibrotic M2 macrophage subset.

title: Hidden invasiveness of non-native Schlegel's Japanese gecko (Reptilia: Squamata: Gekkonidae) and three-way competition among natives and non-natives in Japan.
biological_context: Invasiveness and interspecific competition among gecko species in Japan.
main_goals: This study investigates the hidden invasiveness of the non-native Schlegel's Japanese gecko (Gekko japonicus) by examining its competitive interactions with native endemic gecko species and G. hokouensis in Japan. The research uses niche analysis and population genetics to assess the historical impact of G. japonicus invasions and their tripartite competitive relationship with other gecko species.

title: HE2Gene: image-to-RNA translation via multi-task learning for spatial transcriptomics data.
main_goals: Propose HE2Gene, a multi-task learning method to predict spot-level gene expressions and pathological annotations from H&E-stained images. HE2Gene is capable of predicting tens of thousands of genes and generalizes well to external datasets without re-training.

title: Resting State Functional Networks in Gliomas: Validation With Direct Electric Stimulation Using a New Tool for Planning Brain Resections.
main_goals: This study introduces an updated version of the ReStNeuMap software for rs-fMRI data preprocessing and automatic detection of resting-state networks. The updated tool demonstrates strong concordance with intraoperative direct electric stimulation mapping, highlighting its utility for personalized presurgical planning in brain tumor patients.

title: Cell type mapping of inflammatory muscle diseases highlights selective myofiber vulnerability in inclusion body myositis.
biological_context: Inflammatory muscle diseases (Inclusion Body Myositis and Immune-mediated Necrotizing Myopathy)
main_goals: To map cell-type-specific drivers underlying IBM pathogenesis by pairing single-nucleus RNA sequencing with spatial transcriptomics. The study aimed to compare these drivers with those in IMNM and non-inflammatory skeletal muscle. The findings highlight selective myofiber vulnerability and potential mechanisms of degeneration in IBM.

title: Specialized Tfh cell subsets driving type-1 and type-2 humoral responses in lymphoid tissue.
biological_context: Humoral immunity and T follicular helper cell specialization under type-1 and type-2 immune responses
main_goals: This paper investigates the specialization of T follicular helper (Tfh) cells under type-1 and type-2 immune responses. Using machine learning, they established gene expression signatures for Tfh1 and Tfh2 cells and validated these signatures. They further dissected Tfh cell heterogeneity using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics, identifying a Gzmk+ Tfh cell population specific for type-1 conditions.

title: GJA4 expressed on cancer associated fibroblasts (CAFs)-A 'promoter' of the mesenchymal phenotype.
data_modalities_used: ['HE-stained images', 'immunohistochemistry', 'single-cell analysis', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'immunofluorescence staining', 'Sirius red staining', 'wound healing assays', 'transwell assays', 'western blotting', 'CCK8 assay', 'in vivo experiments']
main_goals: This study investigates the role of GJA4 expressed on cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) in promoting the mesenchymal phenotype in colorectal cancer. It explores the mechanisms by which GJA4 promotes fibroblast activation and EMT, and its synergistic effects with M2 macrophages on the tumor immune microenvironment. The findings suggest that GJA4+ fibroblasts and M2 macrophages are potential targets for enhancing tumor immunotherapy.

title: Spatial recovery of the murine gut microbiota after antibiotics perturbation.
biological_context: Murine gut microbiota recovery after antibiotic perturbation
main_goals: The study investigates the spatial organization and recovery of the murine gut microbiota after antibiotic treatment using a high-phylogenetic-resolution microbiota mapping technique. It employs a novel analytical framework to characterize spatial changes and identify species involved in recovery.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics reveal alterations in trophoblasts at invasion sites and disturbed myometrial immune microenvironment in placenta accreta spectrum disorders.
main_goals: This study aimed to reveal alterations in trophoblasts at invasion sites and disturbed myometrial immune microenvironment in placenta accreta spectrum disorders using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing. It identified specific trophoblast subpopulations invading the myometrium and characterized immune and inflammation-associated pathways in PAS tissues. The findings elucidate the interplay between immune escape in trophoblasts and immune tolerance in myometrial smooth muscle cells during invasion in PAS.

title: Integrated spatial and multimodal single-cell transcriptomics reveal patient-dependent cell heterogeneity in splenic marginal zone lymphoma.
data_modalities_used: ["3'-single-cell RNA-sequencing", 'Cellular Indexing of Transcriptomes and Epitopes by sequencing (CITE-seq)', "5'-V(D)J single-cell RNA-sequencing", 'spatial transcriptomics', 'imaging mass cytometry', 'paired blood/spleen samples']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'B-cell receptor and T-cell receptor repertoires']
main_goals: To perform in-depth characterization of splenic marginal zone lymphoma (SMZL) through integrated spatial and multimodal single-cell analyses. The study aimed to characterize SMZL transcriptome profiles, including B-cell receptor and T-cell receptor repertoires, and to investigate patient-dependent cell heterogeneity. Findings provide a comprehensive high-resolution description of SMZL biological hallmarks, including inter- and intra-patient heterogeneity at transcriptomic and protein levels.

title: PCP auto count: a novel Fiji/ImageJ plug-in for automated quantification of planar cell polarity and cell counting.
biological_context: Inner ear sensory epithelia (cochleae and utricles) from mice, and other tissues such as Drosophila ommatidia, mouse ependymal cells, and mouse radial progenitors.
main_goals: To automate the measurement of cell orientations and cell counting for planar cell polarity (PCP) studies. The developed Fiji/ImageJ plug-in, PCP Auto Count (PCPA), analyzes binary images to quantify PCP and cell counts, aiming to reduce the time-consuming manual processes.

title: Uncover spatially informed variations for single-cell spatial transcriptomics with STew.
biological_context: Human dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and mouse main olfactory bulb data, psoriatic skins
main_goals: Introduces STew, a Spatial Transcriptomic multi-viEW representation learning method to jointly analyze spatial information and gene expression scalably. It measures model fit with a data-driven statistical framework and achieves superior performance in clustering accuracy and spatial domain continuity compared to other methods. STew is robust, insensitive to parameters, and applicable to large datasets.

title: CoCo-ST: Comparing and Contrasting Spatial Transcriptomics data sets using graph contrastive learning.
main_goals: This paper presents CoCo-ST, a graph contrastive feature representation method for spatial transcriptomics data. It aims to enhance the identification of interesting patterns in target data (e.g., precancerous tissue) by incorporating background data (e.g., normal tissue) and mitigating the influence of common patterns. This approach enables the discernment of biologically relevant, tissue-specific features.

title: Single-cell and spatiotemporal profile of ovulation in the mouse ovary.
main_goals: To detail the precise window of ovulation at single-cell resolution in mouse ovaries. The study mapped the spatiotemporal profile of ovarian cell types using parallel single-cell RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics, identified ovulation-dependent gene markers, and performed cell-cell interaction analyses to understand ovulation drivers.

title: Integrated analysis of multiple transcriptomic approaches and machine learning integration algorithms reveals high endothelial venules as a prognostic immune-related biomarker in bladder cancer.
main_goals: This study integrates multiple transcriptomic approaches and machine learning algorithms to identify high endothelial venules (HEVs) as a prognostic immune-related biomarker in bladder cancer. It reveals a correlation between higher HEV levels and improved immune response and prognosis, identifying HEV-related genes for patient stratification. LDLRAD3 is proposed as a potential target for enhancing immunotherapy efficacy.

title: Tissue module discovery in single-cell-resolution spatial transcriptomics data via cell-cell interaction-aware cell embedding.
main_goals: SPACE is a deep-learning method for cell-type identification and tissue module discovery from single-cell-resolution spatial transcriptomics data. It learns cell representations that capture gene expression and spatial neighbor interactions to identify spatially informed cell subtypes and discover 'cell communities' (tissue modules) with characteristic proximal cell-cell interaction networks.

title: Multi-model analysis of gallbladder cancer reveals the role of OxLDL-absorbing neutrophils in promoting liver invasion.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'proteomics', 'multiplexed immunohistochemistry', 'in vitro assays']
main_goals: This study analyzed the tumor microenvironment of gallbladder cancer (GBC) with a focus on liver invasion. It identified a subset of neutrophils that absorb oxidized low-density lipoprotein (oxLDL) via OLR1, which promotes tumor invasion. The research also elucidated the cellular interactions and niche components that foster these pro-tumoral neutrophils.

title: Age-related Differences in Spatially Resolved Transcriptomic Profiles of Patients With Hormone Receptor-positive Breast Carcinoma.
main_goals: To compare spatially resolved transcriptomic profiles between younger (<=50 years) and older (>50 years) patients with hormone receptor (HR)-positive breast carcinoma. The study identified age-related differences in gene expression and transcriptional pathways, highlighting the need for age-specific treatment strategies.

title: High-Resolution Raman Imaging of >300 Patient-Derived Cells from Nine Different Leukemia Subtypes: A Global Clustering Approach.
main_goals: The study introduces a global clustering approach for Raman hyperspectral maps of leukemia cells to characterize different subtypes. This method enables unsupervised creation of pseudostained images and semiquantitative analysis of cellular components, highlighting the potential of Raman imaging in leukemia research.

title: Colorectal cancer-associated fibroblasts inhibit effector T cells via NECTIN2 signaling.
covered_analysis_steps: ['scRNA-seq analysis', 'spatial proteomics analysis', 'co-culture experiments', 'in vivo functional assays', 'clinical data analysis']
main_goals: This paper aimed to characterize fibroblast heterogeneity in colorectal cancer (CRC) using scRNA-seq and spatial proteomics. The researchers identified a novel cluster of cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs), termed TinCAFs, that inhibit effector T cells via NECTIN2 signaling. The study demonstrates that NECTIN2 is a poor prognostic factor and suggests TinCAFs as a potential target for immunotherapy.

title: Microglia-astrocyte crosstalk in the amyloid plaque niche of an Alzheimer's disease mouse model, as revealed by spatial transcriptomics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics (CosMx and Stereo-seq) to characterize transcriptomic alterations, cellular compositions, and signaling perturbations in the amyloid plaque niche of an Alzheimer's disease mouse model. It reveals heterogeneity in plaque niche cellular composition and differential glial responses, highlighting how microglia accumulation disrupts astrocytic signaling, leading to neuronal synaptic imbalance.

title: Comparative Methods for Demystifying Spatial Transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper breaks down the spatial transcriptomics analysis pipeline into four essential steps: image analysis, read alignment, gene quantification, and spot clustering. It compares the results obtained when using reads from different subsets of spots and/or employing alternative genome or transcriptome references, demonstrating the impact of these choices on analysis outcomes.

title: Multi-modal domain adaptation for revealing spatial functional landscape from spatially resolved transcriptomics.
main_goals: This study proposes stMDA, a multi-modal unsupervised domain adaptation method to integrate gene expression with other modalities (e.g., histological images and spatial locations) in spatially resolved transcriptomics (SRT) datasets. It aims to reveal the spatial functional landscape by learning modality-specific representations and aligning their spatial distributions. The method demonstrates improved performance in identifying spatial domains and spatially variable genes across diverse platforms and species.

title: Next-Generation Sequencing-Based Spatial Transcriptomics: A Perspective from Barcoding Chemistry.
main_goals: This perspective focuses on next-generation sequencing-based spatial transcriptomic methods, particularly highlighting spatial barcoding chemistry. It delves into optically manipulated spatial indexing methods and DNA array-barcoded spatial indexing methods by exploring current advances, challenges, and future development directions in this nascent field.

title: Interactions between LAMP3+ dendritic cells and T-cell subpopulations promote immune evasion in papillary thyroid carcinoma.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq)', 'spatial transcriptomics RNA sequencing', 'immunohistochemistry', 'multiplex immunohistochemistry', 'bulk RNA-seq']
main_goals: This study investigates the interactions between LAMP3+ dendritic cells and T-cell subpopulations to understand immune evasion in papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC). It identifies LAMP3+ DCs as key players promoting CD8+ T cell exhaustion and regulatory T cell infiltration, contributing to an immune-suppressive microenvironment. The findings offer new strategies for PTC immunotherapy.

title: Quantum Dot-Fab' Conjugates as Compact Immunolabels for Microtubule Imaging and Cell Classification.
biological_context: Microtubule imaging and cell classification in fixed cells and fixed brain specimens
main_goals: The paper develops and evaluates quantum dot-Fab' conjugates as compact immunolabels for improved microtubule imaging and cell classification. These conjugates offer advantages over traditional QD-antibody conjugates, including smaller size, homogeneous composition, and site-specific orientation of the antigen-binding domain.

title: Dissecting Spatiotemporal Structures in Spatial Transcriptomics via Diffusion-Based Adversarial Learning.
main_goals: Introduces PearlST, a computational framework using a PDE-enhanced adversarial graph autoencoder for inferring spatiotemporal structures from spatial transcriptomics data. It integrates contrastive learning, a PDE-based diffusion model, and Wasserstein adversarial regularized graph autoencoders. PearlST outperforms existing methods in spatial clustering, trajectory inference, and pseudotime analysis, and elucidates functional regulations.

title: Diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder by Dynamic Local Graph-Theory Indicators Based on Electroencephalogram.
main_goals: To identify biomarkers for Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) diagnosis by developing a method that integrates dynamic functional connectivity, local graph-theory indicators, and a feature-selection approach applied to electroencephalogram (EEG) data. The study aimed to overcome limitations of previous static analyses by incorporating temporal dynamics and spatial interactions.

title: The enhanced energy metabolism in the tumor margin mediated by RRAD promotes the progression of oral squamous cell carcinoma.
main_goals: This study investigated the enhanced energy metabolism in the tumor margin of OSCC and identified RRAD as a mediator of this process. It found that downregulation of RRAD enhances glucose uptake and malignant behaviors by activating the CAMKIV-CREB1 axis, leading to GLUT3 transcription. The research suggests GLUT3 as a potential therapeutic target for OSCC.

title: SpaNCMG: improving spatial domains identification of spatial transcriptomics using neighborhood-complementary mixed-view graph convolutional network.
biological_context: The paper applies its method to various tissues including human dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, mouse somatosensory cortex, and mouse olfactory bulb, as well as mouse embryos to understand tissue structure and gene expression patterns.
main_goals: The paper proposes a novel algorithm, SpaNCMG, for improving spatial domain identification in spatial transcriptomics data. It utilizes a neighborhood-complementary mixed-view graph convolutional network to integrate local and global spatial information, adaptively fuse reconstructed expressions, and reduce dimensionality, outperforming existing methods on multiple datasets.

title: Early Injury Landscape in Vein Harvest by Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptomics.
biological_context: Vein graft injury following cardiovascular bypass surgery
main_goals: To elucidate the response of the vein conduit wall during harvest and following implantation to identify maladaptive pathways driving graft failure and potential therapeutic targets. The study employed single-nuclei RNA-sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to analyze vein grafts from a canine model. The findings highlight the genomic response to vein conduit harvest and distension, and its exacerbation after implantation, suggesting potential early targets for therapies.

title: Impeller: a path-based heterogeneous graph learning method for spatial transcriptomic data imputation.
main_goals: This paper introduces Impeller, a path-based heterogeneous graph learning method for spatial transcriptomic data imputation. It addresses limitations of existing methods by simultaneously modeling spatial proximity and expression similarity, and incorporating both short- and long-range cell-to-cell interactions. The method utilizes a learnable path operator to mitigate over-smoothing issues, demonstrating superiority over state-of-the-art methods on diverse datasets.

title: Distinctive multicellular immunosuppressive hubs confer different intervention strategies for left- and right-sided colon cancers.
main_goals: This study leverages single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to investigate the heterogeneity between left- and right-sided colon cancers. It identifies distinct multicellular immunosuppressive hubs associated with each side and proposes different intervention strategies based on these findings.

title: Cascade spatial and channel-wise multifusion network with criss cross augmentation for corneal segmentation and reconstruction.
main_goals: The paper proposes CSCM-CCA-Net, a novel network for accurate corneal segmentation and 3D reconstruction from AS-OCT images. It addresses challenges with low-contrast regions and the lack of reconstruction methods for 180-degree scanning sequences. The network utilizes cascade spatial and channel-wise multifusion (CSCM) and criss cross augmentation (CCA) for improved accuracy and feature extraction.

title: Spatial analysis of recurrent glioblastoma reveals perivascular niche organization.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: This paper analyzes matched primary and recurrent glioblastoma tissues to understand the relationships between genetic and tumor microenvironment diversity. It investigates how extracellular matrix texture predicts genetic traits and reveals structured organization of the perivascular niche in recurrent GBM, enriched in immunosuppressive macrophages. The study highlights the importance of tissue organization in GBM evolution and genetic/spatial dependencies.

title: Non-coding genome contribution to ALS.
data_modalities_used: ['non-coding genome', 'genetic variation', 'gene expression', 'single-cell epigenetic profiling', 'spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: This review summarizes current discoveries of ALS-associated genetic drivers within the non-coding genome. It argues that improved cell-specific annotation of genomic function, particularly via single-cell epigenetic profiling and spatial transcriptomics, is required to advance the field. The paper proposes that cell-specific functional annotation of ALS-associated genetic variants will accelerate discovery of the genetic architecture underpinning disease.

title: A multi-view graph contrastive learning framework for deciphering spatially resolved transcriptomics data.
main_goals: The paper proposes MuCoST, a multi-view graph contrastive learning framework for deciphering complex spatially resolved transcriptomic architectures. MuCoST models nonlocal spatial co-expression dependency and spatially adjacent dependency by fusing gene expression correlation and spatial location proximity. It demonstrates high accuracy in spatial domain identification and deciphers subtle biological textures and functional patterns.

title: Role of ferroptosis in neuroimmunity and neurodegeneration in multiple sclerosis revealed by multi-omics data.
main_goals: This study explores the role of ferroptosis in multiple sclerosis by integrating multi-omics data. It defines a ferroptosis scoring metric, identifies ferroptosis hotspots in active lesions, and associates ferroptosis with neurodegeneration and microglia activation. The paper also establishes a diagnostic model for multiple sclerosis based on ferroptosis-related genes.

title: Computational modeling for deciphering tissue microenvironment heterogeneity from spatially resolved transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper categorizes and discusses computational methods for analyzing spatial transcriptomics data, focusing on spatial domain detection and spatial deconvolution. It reviews machine learning-based, probabilistic model-based, and deep learning-based methods, outlining their advantages and disadvantages. The authors also describe datasets and evaluation metrics used to assess these methods and provide future directions for computational method development.

title: MUSTANG: Multi-sample spatial transcriptomics data analysis with cross-sample transcriptional similarity guidance.
main_goals: MUSTANG is a framework for multi-sample spatial transcriptomics spot cellular deconvolution. It enables sharing of cross-sample expression-based similarity information and incorporates spatial correlation in gene expression patterns within samples. Experiments demonstrate its effectiveness in revealing biological insights from tissue samples.

title: A generative benchmark for evaluating the performance of fluorescent cell image segmentation.
main_goals: Developed a generative framework using StyleGAN2 and Pix2PixHD to create diverse, graded-density fluorescent cell images. This framework addresses limitations in existing evaluation methods for cell segmentation. The study used this dataset to evaluate three leading cell segmentation methods.

title: Enhanced Complement Expression in the Tumor Microenvironment Following Neoadjuvant Therapy: Implications for Immunomodulation and Survival in Pancreatic Ductal Adenocarcinoma.
main_goals: This study investigates the effects of neoadjuvant therapy (NAT) on pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) carcinoma cells and the tumor microenvironment (TME). It found that NAT remodels the TME by upregulating complement genes, which is associated with improved survival and reduced immunosuppression. The findings suggest complement dynamics as a potential biomarker for NAT-treated PDAC.
