title: Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptome Profiling Identifies the Transcription Factor BHLHE40 as a Driver of EMT in Metastatic Colorectal Cancer.
main_goals: This study aimed to elucidate the cellular mechanisms driving EMT in colorectal cancer. It identified BHLHE40 as a key transcription factor promoting EMT and liver metastasis by analyzing single-cell and spatial transcriptomic data. The findings provide insights for improving diagnosis and treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer.

title: Batf3<sup>+</sup> DCs and the 4-1BB/4-1BBL axis are required at the effector phase in the tumor microenvironment for PD-1/PD-L1 blockade efficacy.
biological_context: Tumor microenvironment (TME) in the context of cancer immunotherapy
data_modalities_used: ['flow cytometric analysis', 'gene-targeted mice', 'blocking antibody studies', 'immunofluorescence', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'human tumor samples']
main_goals: This paper investigates the cellular source of positive signals that reinvigorate T cells within the tumor microenvironment (TME) for PD-1/PD-L1 blockade efficacy. It identifies Batf3-lineage dendritic cells (DCs) and the 4-1BB/4-1BBL axis as essential for this process. The study highlights the importance of Batf3+ DCs and their proximity to CD8+ T cells for anti-PD-1 efficacy in human tumor samples.

title: Skin in the game: a review of single-cell and spatial transcriptomics in dermatological research.
biological_context: Healthy skin and dermatologic pathophysiologies (atopic dermatitis, psoriasis, cutaneous malignancies)
main_goals: This paper reviews the application of single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and spatial transcriptomics (ST) in dermatological research. It highlights how these technologies characterize gene expression microenvironments in healthy skin and various skin diseases, aiming to reshape disease characterization and clinical practice.

title: Spatial Proteomics Reveals Alcohol-Induced Damages to the Crypts and Villi of the Mouse Small Intestine.
biological_context: Alcohol-induced damage to the mouse small intestine
main_goals: This study employed laser capture microdissection and label-free proteomics to investigate the proteomic changes in the crypts and villi of the mouse small intestine following alcohol exposure. It aimed to understand how immune-related cells in the gut are perturbed during this process. The findings reveal alcohol-induced changes in alcohol metabolism, defensin levels, lipid metabolism, and apoptosis.

title: Integrated spatial metabolomics and transcriptomics decipher the hepatoprotection mechanisms of wedelolactone and demethylwedelolactone on non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
biological_context: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) induced by thioacetamide (TAA) in zebrafish
main_goals: This study investigated the impacts and mechanisms of wedelolactone (WEL) and demethylwedelolactone (DWEL) on non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) using a zebrafish model. The research utilized integrated spatial metabolomics with liver-specific transcriptomics to identify distinct hepatoprotective mechanisms of WEL and DWEL.

title: Integrating spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing reveals the alterations in epithelial cells during nodular formation in benign prostatic hyperplasia.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: To integrate spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing to elucidate epithelial cell alterations during nodular formation in benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The study identified a specific basal epithelial cell subgroup (BE5) crucial for BPH progression through hypoxia-induced EMT and validated the role of c-Fos.

title: Co-ordinate-based positional embedding that captures resolution to enhance transformer's performance in medical image analysis.
biological_context: Infarct segmentation on MRI dataset with AxTrace and AxADC contrasts
main_goals: This paper proposes a co-ordinate-based embedding for Vision Transformers to capture physical co-ordinate and resolution information in medical images. This method enhances the performance of models like UNETR and SwinUNETR for infarct segmentation without requiring resampling, leading to substantial improvements in Dice score.

title: Integrative spatial analysis reveals a multi-layered organization of glioblastoma.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This paper defines glioma cellular states and uncovers their multi-layered organization using spatial transcriptomics and proteomics. It identifies three modes of organization: local environments enriched with single states, preferential pairing of specific states, and a global architecture composed of five layers. Hypoxia is highlighted as a key driver of this long-range organization.

title: Recent contributions of single-cell and spatial profiling to the understanding of bladder cancer.
main_goals: This review summarizes recent advancements in single-cell and spatial omics methodologies for understanding bladder cancer biology and their potential impact on the development of novel therapeutic strategies. It highlights how these techniques provide insights into tumor microenvironment, heterogeneity, cancer stemness, cellular plasticity, and immune cell composition in bladder cancer. The review also discusses challenges in translating research findings into clinical practice.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals segregation of tumor cell states in glioblastoma and marked immunosuppression within the perinecrotic niche.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This paper investigates the spatial organization of tumor cell states within the glioblastoma microenvironment using spatial transcriptomics. It reveals patterns of segregation between different tumor cell states and highlights the immunosuppressive nature of perinecrotic regions.

title: Integrated single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics analysis reveals the tumour microenvironment in patients with endometrial cancer responding to anti-PD-1 treatment.
main_goals: This study integrates single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to analyze the tumor microenvironment in patients with endometrial cancer responding to anti-PD-1 treatment. It aims to reveal the cellular composition and spatial organization that contribute to treatment response.

title: A robust genetic algorithm-based optimal feature predictor model for brain tumour classification from MRI data.
biological_context: Brain tumour classification from MRI data
main_goals: This paper proposes a transform- and windowing-based optimization strategy for exposing and segmenting brain tumours from MRI data. It utilizes Gabor transform for multi-resolution conversion, Genetic Algorithm for feature optimization, and Neuro Fuzzy System for classification. The approach aims for effective detection and classification with high sensitivity, specificity, and accuracy.

title: High-density generation of spatial transcriptomics with STAGE.
main_goals: STAGE is developed for generating high-density spatial transcriptomics by learning continuous patterns of gene expression in space using a supervised auto-encoder. It aims to improve data quality, smooth gene expression manifolds, and enable robust identification of spatially informative genes. It can also be extended to 3D stacked spatial transcriptomics data.

title: DeepSeeded: Volumetric Segmentation of Dense Cell Populations with a Cascade of Deep Neural Networks in Bacterial Biofilm Applications.
main_goals: Propose DeepSeeded, a novel 3D cell segmentation approach for dense bacterial biofilms. DeepSeeded utilizes a cascade of deep neural networks to estimate seeds for seeded watershed segmentation, enhancing interior and border information. The method demonstrates superior segmentation results compared to state-of-the-art methods on synthetic and real biofilm datasets.

title: The neuroendocrine transition in prostate cancer is dynamic and dependent on ASCL1.
biological_context: Prostate cancer progression and neuroendocrine differentiation
main_goals: This study describes an in vivo platform to study the neuroendocrine transition in prostate cancer. It reveals that ASCL1+ cells arise from KRT8+ luminal epithelial cells and highlights the dynamic nature of this lineage plasticity, emphasizing the importance of therapeutic timing. The work provides a platform for identifying further drivers of lineage plasticity.

title: Multi-pronged analysis of pediatric low-grade glioma reveals a unique tumor microenvironment associated with BRAF alterations.
data_modalities_used: ['single cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq)', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'cytokine analyses', 'bulk analyses']
main_goals: To characterize and understand tumor and immune cell heterogeneity across pediatric low-grade gliomas (pLGG) using a multi-pronged approach including scRNA-seq, spatial transcriptomics, and cytokine analyses. The study aimed to reveal differences in the tumor microenvironment associated with genetic drivers, particularly BRAF alterations, and to inform potential therapeutic strategies.

title: CSsingle: A Unified Tool for Robust Decomposition of Bulk and Spatial Transcriptomic Data Across Diverse Single-Cell References.
main_goals: Introduces CSsingle, a unified tool for robust decomposition of bulk and spatial transcriptomic data. It enhances deconvolution by applying cell size correction using ERCC spike-in controls and enables fine-scale analysis for spatial transcriptomics. CSsingle outperforms existing methods in accuracy and robustness.

title: da_Tracker: Automated workflow for high throughput single cell and single phagosome tracking in infected cells.
main_goals: Developed a near-fully automated workflow (da_Tracker) for high-throughput single cell and single phagosome tracking in infected cells. It utilizes PyImageJ, Cellpose, and Trackmate to quantify signals at single-cell and single-phagosome levels. The workflow aims to provide insights into pathogen-host cell interactions and virulence mechanisms.

title: Chronic hyperactivation of midbrain dopamine neurons causes preferential dopamine neuron degeneration.
main_goals: This study developed a chemogenetic mouse model to investigate the effects of chronic hyperactivation of midbrain dopamine neurons on their degeneration. The findings reveal that SNc dopamine neurons are preferentially vulnerable to increased neural activity, potentially contributing to Parkinson's disease pathogenesis.

title: Spatial motifs reveal patterns in cellular architecture of complex tissues.
biological_context: Mouse retinal bipolar cells and hypothalamic preoptic region
main_goals: This paper introduces a novel method for detecting spatial motifs in cellular neighborhood graphs. The method identifies spatial arrangements of cell types that occur more frequently than expected by chance. Applied to real data, it reveals previously unrecognized patterns in cell type arrangements and their potential functional significance.

title: Spatial enrichment and genomic analyses reveal the link of NOMO1 with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.
biological_context: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) in the human motor cortex
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Burden analyses']
main_goals: This study aimed to investigate the spatial enrichment of ALS-associated genes in the human motor cortex and identify novel genes linked to ALS risk. It developed a tool called SpatialE for spatial enrichment analysis and used it to analyze human motor cortex and prefrontal cortex tissues. The study identified NOMO1 as a novel ALS-associated gene, down-regulated in ALS, consistent with a loss-of-function mechanism.

title: spVC for the detection and interpretation of spatial gene expression variation.
main_goals: Introduce spVC, a statistical method based on a generalized Poisson model for the detection and interpretation of spatial gene expression variation. It integrates constant and spatially varying effects of covariates, enhancing interpretability and capturing continuous expression patterns.

title: Single Cell Atlas: a single-cell multi-omics human cell encyclopedia.
main_goals: This paper describes the construction of a single-cell multi-omics map of human tissues by characterizing datasets from five single-cell omics, spatial transcriptomics, and two bulk omics across 125 tissues. It also presents a web-based platform, the Single Cell Atlas (SCA), for interactive data exploration. The goal is to provide a comprehensive resource for omics studies.

title: Identification of hypoxic macrophages in glioblastoma with therapeutic potential for vasculature normalization.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell transcriptomics', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'xenograft model antitumor assays', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This paper identifies a subset of tumor-associated macrophages (Hypoxia-TAMs) in glioblastoma localized to the peri-necrotic niche. These macrophages acquire a hypoxia response signature, destabilize tumor vasculature via adrenomedullin signaling, leading to hyperpermeability. Targeting Hypoxia-TAMs and adrenomedullin shows therapeutic potential for vasculature normalization and improved drug delivery.

title: CellSNAP: a fast, accurate algorithm for 3D cell segmentation in quantitative phase imaging.
main_goals: The paper introduces the CellSNAP algorithm for fast and accurate 3D cell segmentation in quantitative phase imaging (QPI). It aims to address the under-developed analysis pipeline for QPI tomograms and facilitate broader adoption of QPI for high-throughput analysis.

title: Library size confounds biology in spatial transcriptomics data.
main_goals: This paper demonstrates that library size in spatial transcriptomics data is associated with tissue structure. It highlights that normalizing out these effects using common single-cell RNA-sequencing normalization methods negatively affects spatial domain identification. The study recommends against specific library size correction prior to analysis and cautions against the adoption of scRNA-seq algorithms for spatial data.

title: Improving the power of drug toxicity measurements by quantitative nuclei imaging.
biological_context: Anticancer drug toxicity measurements in cancer cell lines
data_modalities_used: ['XTT assay', 'quantitative nuclei imaging', 'trypan blue dye exclusion assay', 'fluorescent microscopy']
main_goals: This paper compares drug toxicity measurements obtained by XTT assay, quantitative nuclei imaging, and trypan blue dye exclusion assay using cancer cell lines and various drugs. It shows that imaging-based approaches are highly accurate and highlights issues with the XTT assay for certain drug classes due to induced cell size growth and increased mitochondrial activity. The study also demonstrates the benefits of image-based analysis for monitoring cell number dynamics, dissecting mitochondrial activity from proliferation, and identifying chromatin remodeling drugs.

title: Identification of signaling pathways that specify a subset of migrating enteric neural crest cells at the wavefront in mouse embryos.
biological_context: Mouse embryo enteric nervous system development
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', "human Hirschsprung's disease gut tissue"]
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study identifies signaling pathways governing wavefront enteric neural crest cell specification and niche interaction during mouse embryonic development. It uses single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to map these dynamics and links pathway disruptions to human Hirschsprung's disease. The research also highlights the role of these cells in shaping the gut microenvironment.

title: Tools and methods for high-throughput single-cell imaging with the mother machine.
biological_context: Microbial cells, specifically E. coli, under controlled growth conditions using the mother machine microfluidic device.
main_goals: The primary purpose of this work is to introduce napari-MM3, a complete and modular image analysis pipeline for mother machine data, which leverages the interactivity of napari. It also provides information for researchers wanting to implement mother machine-based high-throughput imaging and analysis methods.

title: Brain tumor segmentation using neuro-technology enabled intelligence-cascaded U-Net model.
main_goals: This paper proposes a novel model called Intelligence Cascade U-Net (ICU-Net) for brain tumor segmentation. ICU-Net is built on dynamic convolution and a non-local attention mechanism, featuring a two-stage cascade of 3DU-Net to reconstruct detailed spatial information. The goal is to identify optimal learnable parameters to maximize data likelihood and leverage contextual information more effectively.

title: Spatial Transcriptomic Analysis of Pituitary Corticotroph Tumors.
main_goals: This study presents the first spatial transcriptomic analysis of pituitary corticotroph tumors (PitNETs) using formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissues. The analysis aimed to uncover spatial interactions and identify intratumor heterogeneity by comparing gene expression profiles with immunohistochemistry results. The findings provide insights into the spatial cell profile of PitNETs and reveal potential cell variability within tumors.

title: Research on the spatial allocation of national fitness resources at the street scale-taking Fuzhou city as an example.
main_goals: To explore the spatial allocation of national fitness resources at different spatial scales in Fuzhou city to provide useful references for optimizing and enhancing the spatial allocation of national fitness resources and urban planning. Analyzes equity, spatial distribution characteristics, accessibility, and supply-demand balance of national fitness resources using the two-step mobile search method, Gini coefficient, and exploratory spatial data analysis. The paper identifies imbalances and suggests improvements for urban planning and resource allocation.

title: Co-expression of immune checkpoints in glioblastoma revealed by single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This study aimed to understand the pattern of immune checkpoint expression in glioblastoma using single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It identified major cell types, analyzed interactions between specific malignant cells and immune cells, and proposed potential therapeutic targets based on immune checkpoint expression patterns.

title: Spatial and single-cell explorations uncover prognostic significance and immunological functions of mitochondrial calcium uniporter in breast cancer.
main_goals: This study investigates the prognostic significance and immunological functions of the mitochondrial calcium uniporter (MCU) in breast cancer (BRCA). It employs a multi-omics approach, including spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-sequencing, to analyze MCU's role in the tumor microenvironment, immune cell infiltration, and clinical pathology. The findings suggest MCU alterations have diagnostic and prognostic implications for BRCA and could be a target for precision medicine.

title: SPADE: spatial deconvolution for domain specific cell-type estimation.
main_goals: SPADE integrates spatial patterns into cell type composition analysis using single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and histological data. It accurately estimates cell type proportions in different locations and discerns cell type-specific spatial patterns. The method provides insights into cellular dynamics and tumor tissue composition.

title: Cross-link assisted spatial proteomics to map sub-organelle proteomes and membrane protein topologies.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Proteomics', 'Sub-organelle Proteome Profiling', 'Membrane Protein Topology Characterization']
main_goals: The paper introduces a novel cross-link assisted spatial proteomics (CLASP) strategy. CLASP aims to overcome limitations of existing methods in resolving sub-organelle compartments and characterizing membrane-associated proteomes. The study demonstrates its capability to map sub-organelle proteomes and membrane protein topologies using human mitochondria and synaptic vesicles as model systems.

title: Structural, Functional, and Genetic Changes Surrounding Electrodes Implanted in the Brain.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: To investigate the structural, functional, and genetic changes occurring in brain tissue surrounding implanted electrodes. The study aims to inform improved designs of implantable neurotechnology by linking biological responses to device characteristics. New biomarkers for benchmarking electrode effects are also a key outcome.

title: stDiff: a diffusion model for imputing spatial transcriptomics through single-cell transcriptomics.
main_goals: stDiff introduces a conditional diffusion model to impute spatial transcriptomics data using single-cell RNA sequencing data. It leverages gene expression abundance relationships captured by Markov processes to enhance spatial transcriptomics data, preserving topological structures and accurately reconstructing spatial expression patterns.

title: Attention-guided variational graph autoencoders reveal heterogeneity in spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: Introduce AttentionVGAE (AVGN), a method integrating slice images, spatial information, and gene expression using a variational graph autoencoder with multi-head attention. AVGN captures spatial relationships, adaptively focuses on key features, and alleviates the need for prior knowledge of cluster numbers, outperforming existing methods in elucidating tissue anatomy and interpreting tumor heterogeneity.

title: Nextflow pipeline for Visium and H&E data from patient-derived xenograft samples.
main_goals: The paper introduces the Spatial Transcriptomics Quantification (STQ) pipeline, a Nextflow DSL2-based tool for processing Visium spatial transcriptomics data alongside matched H&E whole-slide images from PDX samples. It enables species classification, transcript mapping, H&E image alignment to spatial layout, and generation of imaging and quantitative morphology features for each spot. The pipeline supports flexible analysis workflows and demonstrates similar biological patterns revealed by both data modalities.

title: Edge-relational window-attentional graph neural network for gene expression prediction in spatial transcriptomics analysis.
main_goals: This paper proposes ErwaNet, a novel graph neural network for predicting gene expression from standard tissue images, eliminating the need for costly specialized equipment. It enhances gene prediction by capturing local interactions and global structural information from tissue images using heterogeneous graphs and an attention mechanism. ErwaNet is a prior-free and easy-to-implement method that outperforms state-of-the-art methods on public breast cancer datasets.

title: Lung Tissue Multilayer Network Analysis Uncovers the Molecular Heterogeneity of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease.
biological_context: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) lung tissue
main_goals: To unravel mechanisms associated with clinical characteristics of COPD by integrating different omics data using a novel multilayer network approach. The study identified five distinct patient communities and characterized molecular differences between patients with similar clinical presentations (low FEV1 and emphysema) using spatial transcriptomics.

title: Peripheral HMGB1 is linked to O<sub>3</sub> pathology of disease-associated astrocytes and amyloid.
biological_context: Alzheimer's disease pathobiology associated with ozone exposure
main_goals: This study investigated the role of disease-associated astrocytes (DAAs) and peripheral myeloid cell high mobility group box 1 (HMGB1) in ozone-induced Alzheimer's disease pathology. It characterized the O3-induced astrocyte phenotype in 5xFAD mice using spatial transcriptomics and proteomics, revealing impacts on DAA transcriptional fingerprints and astrocyte-microglia interactions. The research demonstrated that peripheral myeloid cell HMGB1 is crucial in regulating the O3-induced DAA phenotype, suggesting a potential intervention target for air pollution-induced AD.

title: Microenvironmental reorganization in brain tumors following radiotherapy and recurrence revealed by hyperplexed immunofluorescence imaging.
main_goals: This study introduces Hyperplexed Immunofluorescence Imaging (HIFI), a spatial proteomic workflow for simultaneous analysis of >45 markers in fragile tissue sections. HIFI integrates with machine learning and graph-based analysis to study microenvironmental reorganization in brain tumors following radiotherapy and recurrence. The research demonstrates HIFI's utility in revealing divergent treatment responses between glioblastomas and brain metastases.

title: Spot-Based Global Registration for Subpixel Stitching of Single-Molecule Resolution Images for Tissue-Scale Spatial Transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper introduces Spot-Based Global Registration (SBGR), a novel strategy for subpixel stitching of single-molecule resolution images for tissue-scale spatial transcriptomics. SBGR focuses on identified molecular spots rather than raw images to achieve robust and accurate image alignment, outperforming existing methods with subpixel accuracy. It also incorporates a mechanism to remove duplicate spots in overlapping regions to maximize information recovery.

title: Seq-Scope Protocol: Repurposing Illumina Sequencing Flow Cells for High-Resolution Spatial Transcriptomics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['histological imaging', 'sequencing library preparation', 'integration of histological and transcriptomic data', 'spatial analysis']
main_goals: The paper provides a detailed protocol to implement Seq-Scope, a novel technology that repurposes Illumina sequencing flow cells for high-resolution spatial transcriptome analysis. It enables the profiling of multiple tissue sections on large areas and includes instructions for data integration and a computational pipeline for high-resolution spatial analysis.

title: Spatial and single-cell colocalisation analysis reveals MDK-mediated immunosuppressive environment with regulatory T cells in colorectal carcinogenesis.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Single-Cell Analysis', 'Spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: This study investigates cell-cell interactions in the tumor microenvironment of early colorectal cancer using spatial transcriptomics. It identifies MDK as a key signaling molecule mediating an immunosuppressive environment with regulatory T cells and assesses its clinical significance.

title: The p21<sup>+</sup> perinecrotic hepatocytes produce the chemokine CXCL14 after a severe acetaminophen overdose promoting hepatocyte injury and delaying regeneration.
main_goals: This study investigated the role of p21+ perinecrotic hepatocytes in acetaminophen-induced liver injury. It identified CXCL14 as a key secreted factor from these hepatocytes that promotes injury and delays regeneration. The findings suggest that targeting CXCL14 can improve liver recovery.

title: Machine Learning-Based Characterization and Identification of Tertiary Lymphoid Structures Using Spatial Transcriptomics Data.
main_goals: This research aims to develop a machine learning-based approach to characterize and identify Tertiary Lymphoid Structures (TLSs) using spatial transcriptomic data. It involves identifying TLS markers through bioinformatics and machine learning, and then building predictive models for TLS location. The study contributes to better detection of TLS and may impact cancer treatment strategies.

title: scRNAseq and High-Throughput Spatial Analysis of Tumor and Normal Microenvironment in Solid Tumors Reveal a Possible Origin of Circulating Tumor Hybrid Cells.
biological_context: Solid tumors, specifically breast and colon cancers
main_goals: This study aimed to identify the tissue origin of circulating hybrid cells (CHCs) implicated in metastatic spread. Utilizing scRNA-seq and high-throughput spatial transcriptomics, they identified tumor hybrid cells (THCs) co-expressing epithelial and macrophage markers in breast and colon cancers, and characterized their transcriptomes. The findings provide evidence for THC tissue residence and offer insights into their invasive capabilities.

title: LIRRN: Location-Independent Relative Radiometric Normalization of Bitemporal Remote-Sensing Images.
main_goals: The paper introduces LIRRN, a location-independent relative radiometric normalization method for bitemporal remote-sensing images. It addresses challenges with misaligned land cover and introduces a coregistration-free approach using nearest-distance-based image content matching. LIRRN aims for improved accuracy and efficiency compared to existing methods, especially for unregistered datasets.

title: Spatial analysis toolkits for RNA in situ sequencing.
covered_analysis_steps: ['image analysis', 'cell segmentation', 'clustering', 'functional enrichment', 'detection of spatially variable genes and cell clusters', 'spatial cell-cell interactions', 'trajectory inference']
main_goals: This review presents the state-of-the-art bioinformatic toolkits for In Situ Sequencing (ISS) data analysis. It covers upstream and downstream analysis workflows, including compatibility with ISS data. The paper discusses future perspectives and challenges for integrating these tools into user-friendly pipelines.

title: The implications of single-cell RNA-seq analysis in prostate cancer: unraveling tumor heterogeneity, therapeutic implications and pathways towards personalized therapy.
main_goals: This review outlines the significance of single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) in prostate cancer research, from preclinical to clinical applications. It summarizes scRNA-seq findings in mouse and human prostate cancer, highlights key molecular targets for diagnosis and treatment, and explores potential clinical applications of other single-cell technologies for personalized medicine.

title: Spatiotemporal immune atlas of a clinical-grade gene-edited pig-to-human kidney xenotransplant.
main_goals: To study the human immune response to a gene-edited pig kidney xenograft in a brain-dead human recipient using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing. The study aimed to characterize the immune cell infiltration and phenotype to inform immunomodulatory strategies for xenotransplantation.

title: A systematic evaluation of state-of-the-art deconvolution methods in spatial transcriptomics: insights from cardiovascular disease and chronic kidney disease.
biological_context: Cardiovascular disease (CVD) and chronic kidney disease (CKD)
main_goals: This study systematically evaluates and compares the performance of three state-of-the-art deconvolution methods (Cell2location, RCTD, and spatialDWLS) on human spatial transcriptomics data from cardiovascular disease (CVD) and chronic kidney disease (CKD) samples. The goal is to identify the best performing methods for these specific tissue types and pathological states, considering accuracy, computational efficiency, and workflow simplicity. The findings highlight that while all methods perform comparably for verifiable cell types, RCTD shows the best accuracy in CVD samples, and Cell2location has the highest average performance across all experiments.

title: U-NTCA: nnUNet and nested transformer with channel attention for corneal cell segmentation.
main_goals: This paper proposes a novel network, U-NTCA, for automatic segmentation of corneal stromal cells. U-NTCA integrates nnUNet with a nested Transformer and dual high-order channel attention to improve accuracy in challenging image conditions like uneven illumination and vascular occlusion. The method aims to provide a cost-effective and high-precision segmentation solution for clinical applications.

title: Challenges and Opportunities for the Clinical Translation of Spatial Transcriptomics Technologies.
main_goals: This paper reviews the challenges and opportunities for the clinical translation of spatial transcriptomics technologies, focusing on the GeoMx and Visium platforms. It highlights how these technologies provide novel insights into kidney disease by revealing spatial heterogeneity, affected cell types, and molecular pathways predictive of disease and therapeutic response. The ultimate goal is to advance personalized treatments for kidney diseases.

title: The discovery of regional neurotoxicity-associated metabolic alterations induced by carbon quantum dots in brain of mice using a spatial metabolomics analysis.
biological_context: Mouse brain neurotoxicity induced by carbon quantum dots
main_goals: This study investigated the regional neurotoxicity-associated metabolic alterations induced by carbon quantum dots (CQDs) in the brains of mice using spatial metabolomics. The findings identified specific metabolites and pathways affected by CQDs, contributing to understanding their neurotoxic mechanisms and guiding future safety evaluations.

title: DAIS: a method for identifying spatial domains based on density clustering of spatial omics data.
main_goals: This paper introduces DAIS, a novel method for identifying spatial domains in spatial omics data. DAIS utilizes density clustering to group spatially proximate cells, enabling the characterization of distinct tissue microenvironments. The method aims to provide a robust computational approach for understanding spatial organization in biological tissues.

title: Spatiotemporal transcriptomic changes of human ovarian aging and the regulatory role of FOXP1.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study systematically characterizes human ovarian aging using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies spatiotemporal molecular signatures of ovarian cells and reveals DNA damage response as a key pathway in oocyte aging. The study also identifies FOXP1 as a regulator of ovarian aging, declining with age and inhibiting CDKN1A.

title: Isoporous Membrane Mediated Imprinting Mass Spectrometry Imaging for Spatially-Resolved Metabolomics and Rapid Histopathological Diagnosis.
biological_context: Liver cancer tumor margins, Kidney tissue
main_goals: This paper proposes a membrane-mediated imprinting mass spectrometry imaging (MMI-MSI) strategy using isoporous nuclepore track-etched membranes. This method aims to improve spatial resolution and reduce sample preparation time for metabolomics and histopathological diagnosis by preventing lateral diffusion of biomolecules.

title: Responses of Three Pedicularis Species to Geological and Climatic Changes in the Qinling Mountains and Adjacent Areas in East Asia.
biological_context: Responses of three Pedicularis species to geological and climatic changes in the Qinling Mountains and adjacent areas in East Asia.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Ecological niche modeling', 'Distribution patterns of climate fluctuations', 'Niche dynamics framework', 'Niche breadth analysis']
main_goals: This study investigated the evolutionary origins and phylogenetic relationships of three Pedicularis species in the Qinling Mountains and adjacent areas. It used ecological niche modeling to predict species distributions across different time periods and assessed niche equivalence among them. The findings provide insights into divergence, origins, and responses to climate and geological changes.

title: Spatial co-transcriptomics reveals discrete stages of the arbuscular mycorrhizal symbiosis.
biological_context: Arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) symbiosis in Medicago truncatula and Rhizophagus irregularis
main_goals: This study utilized single-nucleus and spatial RNA sequencing to investigate the arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) symbiosis in Medicago truncatula and Rhizophagus irregularis. The researchers aimed to reveal distinct stages of the symbiotic interaction at cellular and spatial resolution. The findings demonstrate dynamic interplay between plant and fungal cells during symbiosis establishment.

title: Single-cell multiomics reveals the interplay of clonal evolution and cellular plasticity in hepatoblastoma.
data_modalities_used: ['spatial transcriptomics', 'single-cell multiomics', 'chromatin accessibility landscapes', 'single-cell mapping of somatic alterations']
main_goals: This study uses a single-cell multiomic strategy to reveal the molecular determinants of cellular plasticity in hepatoblastoma. It identifies a continuum of cell states and describes the gene regulatory networks and transcription factor activations underlying cell state transitions. The research highlights the interplay of clonal evolution and epigenetic plasticity in shaping the response of hepatoblastoma subclones to chemotherapy.

title: Mgp High-Expressing MSCs Orchestrate the Osteoimmune Microenvironment of Collagen/Nanohydroxyapatite-Mediated Bone Regeneration.
biological_context: Bone regeneration mediated by collagen/nanohydroxyapatite biomaterials
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification']
main_goals: This study depicts the osteoimmune microenvironment around collagen/nanohydroxyapatite biomaterials using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies Mgp high-expressing MSCs as a pioneer subpopulation orchestrating bone repair by modulating macrophage polarization and osteoclastogenesis via the Mdk/Lrp1 pathway. The research also highlights crosstalk between immune cells and Mgp⁹rMSCs through the SPP1 signaling pathway, aiming to advance biomaterial design strategies for osteoimmune modulation.

title: Insights and Opportunity Costs in Applying Spatial Biology to Study the Tumor Microenvironment.
main_goals: This paper discusses practical factors to consider when designing a spatial biology cohort for studying the tumor microenvironment. It also offers perspectives on the future of spatial biology research in this area.

title: PreTSA: computationally efficient modeling of temporal and spatial gene expression patterns.
main_goals: To present PreTSA, a computationally efficient method for modeling temporal and spatial gene expression patterns in large-scale single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data. PreTSA matches state-of-the-art results while significantly reducing computational time, enabling the study of gene expression in extremely large datasets.

title: Coordination analysis of flood-sediment transportation, eco-environment, and socio-economy coupling in the governance of the Yellow River Basin system.
main_goals: This paper aims to build a comprehensive evaluation model for flood-sediment transportation, eco-environment, and socio-economy (FES) and explore their complex interactions in the Yellow River Basin (YRB) from 2000 to 2020. It investigates the trends in FES indices, their positive and negative effects, coupling coordination degree, and spatial distribution patterns. The goal is to provide a scientific framework for the governance, protection, and management of the YRB system.

title: Identification of cells of leukemic stem cell origin with non-canonical regenerative properties.
biological_context: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) regeneration and relapse
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Single-cell transcriptomics analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: This study identifies a new cell population in AML, termed Regeneration Enriched Cells (RECs), which are derived from leukemic stem cells but lack stem/progenitor capacity. RECs influence leukemic regeneration and prognosis by interacting with CD34-expressing cells. The findings contribute to understanding the non-canonical framework of AML regeneration and relapse.

title: Correction to: Adjustment of scRNA-seq data to improve cell-type decomposition of spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper provides a correction to a previous publication regarding the adjustment of scRNA-seq data to improve cell-type decomposition of spatial transcriptomics. The correction aims to enhance the accuracy and reliability of cell-type assignment in spatial transcriptomics data by refining the preprocessing and adjustment steps.

title: Intestinal Stromal Cells in the Turmoil of Inflammation and Defective Connective Tissue Remodeling in Inflammatory Bowel Disease.
main_goals: This review discusses the roles of intestinal stromal cells, particularly myofibroblasts, in the pathogenesis of Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD). It highlights their activation during inflammation, their interactions with immune cells, and their contribution to extracellular matrix remodeling, which can lead to complications like fibrostenosis and fistulas. The paper aims to identify potential pharmacologic targets related to disrupted extracellular matrix homeostasis for treating complicated IBD.

title: Single-cell approaches define two groups of mammalian oligodendrocyte precursor cells and their evolution over developmental time.
biological_context: Murine cortical OPCs throughout postnatal life
main_goals: This paper characterizes murine cortical OPCs throughout postnatal life using single-cell RNA sequencing, ATAC sequencing, and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies two distinct groups of OPCs, termed active (actOPCs) and homeostatic (hOPCs), with differential localization and epigenetic states. The study also investigates the differences in oligodendrogenesis between neonatal and adult OPCs.

title: A hybrid 1D CNN-BiLSTM model for epileptic seizure detection using multichannel EEG feature fusion.
main_goals: To present a novel hybrid 1D CNN-BiLSTM feature fusion model for automatically detecting epileptic seizures using multichannel EEG data. The model aims to leverage spatial features from CNN and temporal features from Bi-LSTM to enhance classification accuracy. It also aims to reduce complexity and enhance efficiency for clinical use.

title: Regional analysis to delineate intrasample heterogeneity with RegionalST.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell type mixture quantification', 'Cell interactions identification', 'Sub-region identification', 'Cross-region cell type-specific differential analysis', 'Visualization']
main_goals: This paper introduces RegionalST, an efficient computational method to quantify cell type mixture and interactions, identify sub-regions, and perform cross-region differential analysis for spatial transcriptomics data. It addresses challenges related to exploiting cross-regional information and limited spatial resolution. RegionalST enables accurate and flexible exploration of tissue heterogeneity.

title: Cellular atlas of the human ovary using morphologically guided spatial transcriptomics and single-cell sequencing.
biological_context: Human ovary function and follicle development
main_goals: To create a cellular atlas of the human ovary using morphologically guided spatial transcriptomics and single-cell sequencing. The study aims to characterize the functional attributes of ovarian cells, identify specific gene activities for key cell types (oocytes, theca, granulosa), and uncover variations in cellular activities across ovarian regions, ultimately serving as a resource for future ovarian research.

title: Spatial omics reveals molecular changes in focal cortical dysplasia type II.
biological_context: Focal cortical dysplasia type II (FCD II) in a mouse model and human samples.
data_modalities_used: ['Mass Spectrometry Imaging (MSI)', 'fluorescence imaging', 'label free proteomics', 'bulk transcriptomics', 'laser capture microdissection (LMD)']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Proteomic Analysis', 'Spatial Lipidomic Analysis']
main_goals: This study aims to characterize the proteomic and lipidomic changes in a mouse model of FCD type II using spatial omics techniques. It also investigates the interplay between genetic mutations and molecular changes in human FCD type IIb by analyzing bulk transcriptomics. The goal is to understand the functional consequences of somatic mutations and identify potential therapeutic targets.

title: In situ profiling reveals spatially metabolic injury in the initiation of polystyrene nanoplastic-derived intestinal epithelial injury in mice.
biological_context: Polystyrene nanoplastic-derived intestinal epithelial injury in mice
data_modalities_used: ['mass spectrometry imaging', 'spatial metabolomics', 'spatial metallomics', 'histopathological damage', 'microstructural changes']
main_goals: This study investigates the mechanisms underlying polystyrene nanoplastic-derived intestinal toxicity in mice. It reveals that while direct inflammation or histopathological damage is not induced, nanoplastic accumulation leads to enterocyte microstructural changes, gut microbiota dysbiosis, and host metabolic reprogramming, ultimately initiating intestinal injury. The findings highlight the critical role of gut microbial-host metabolic remodeling in nanoplastic-induced intestinal damage.

title: Emerging Roles of Spatial Transcriptomics in Liver Research.
biological_context: Liver research, liver diseases, liver cancer
main_goals: To provide an overview of the emerging roles of spatial transcriptomics in liver research. It highlights how spatial transcriptomics aids in understanding cellular heterogeneity, cell-cell interactions, zonated liver functions, and the pathogenesis of liver diseases like steatosis and cancer.

title: Niche analyses and the potential distribution of four invasive bumblebees worldwide.
main_goals: The paper applies environmental niche and potential distribution analyses to four invasive bumblebee species to evaluate similarities and differences between their native and invaded ranges. It found that these species can adapt to changes in temperature and humidity, allowing them to expand their ranges into new climatic conditions. The models agreed with known distributions and indicated niche shifts from native to invaded areas.

title: Macrophage diversity in human cancers: New insight provided by single-cell resolution and spatial context.
main_goals: This paper summarizes recent studies on macrophage diversity in human cancers, focusing on insights gained from single-cell resolution and spatial context technologies. It highlights novel functional subsets of tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) and their clinical significance, as well as the role of spatial transcriptomics in understanding TAM-environment interactions and immunotherapy response.

title: Artifact-suppressing reconstruction of strongly interacting objects in X-ray near-field holography without a spatial support constraint.
main_goals: Proposes a projected gradient descent (PGD) based reconstruction scheme combined with preprocessing and regularization to reduce artifacts in refractive reconstructions from single holograms without a spatial support constraint. This method is demonstrated to be feasible and robust for time-sensitive in situ and operando measurements in X-ray near-field holography.

title: Immune microniches shape intestinal T<sub>reg</sub> function.
data_modalities_used: ['in vivo live imaging', 'photo-activation-guided single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'RNA sequencing']
main_goals: This study investigates the spatial mechanisms of T regulatory cell function in the intestine. It identifies the lamina propria as a key microniche supporting effector T regulatory cell function and reveals a tolerogenic interaction between CD206+ macrophages and eTreg cells. The findings offer insights into spatial tolerance and potential therapeutic strategies.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals discrete tumour microenvironments and autocrine loops within ovarian cancer subclones.
data_modalities_used: ['Visium spatial transcriptomics', 'CosMx single molecule imaging', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'gene expression profiling']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to identify HGSOC subclones and analyze their association with the tumor microenvironment. It reveals subclone-specific ligand and receptor expression patterns that modulate interactions with stromal and immune cells, identifying autocrine loops within subclones.

title: Progression from ductal carcinoma in situ to invasive breast cancer: molecular features and clinical significance.
biological_context: Breast cancer progression from ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) to invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC)
main_goals: To review the molecular features and clinical significance of progression from DCIS to IDC. The paper aims to shed light on the DCIS-IDC transition by exploring molecular features, tumor microenvironment alterations, and research tools, and to facilitate personalized treatment strategies.

title: Lost in space: what single-cell RNA sequencing cannot tell you.
data_modalities_used: ['RNA in situ hybridization', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'single-cell RNA sequencing']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: This review highlights how current single-cell analysis pipelines cannot completely recover spatial information, which confounds biological interpretation. It discusses strategies to identify RNA location and utilize spatial information to supervise single-cell analyses, advocating for an integrative approach to maximize the potential of each technology.

title: Digital Spatial Profiling Identifies Distinct Molecular Signatures of Vascular Lesions in Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension.
biological_context: Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH) and vascular lesions
main_goals: To test the hypothesis that microscopic IPAH vascular lesions express unique molecular profiles. The study used digital spatial transcriptomics to profile the transcriptomic signature of key pathological lesions in IPAH lungs and compared them with control pulmonary arteries. The findings provide a molecular-structural framework for IPAH vascular lesions that can inform novel biomarkers and therapeutic targets.

title: Voxel-Wise Fusion of 3T and 7T Diffusion MRI Data to Extract more Accurate Fiber Orientations.
main_goals: The study explores the feasibility of fusing 3T and 7T dMRI data to extract voxel-wise quantitative parameters at higher spatial resolution. Novel algorithms are proposed to fuse intra-subject 3T and 7T dMRI data for more detailed information of voxel-wise quantitative parameters. The goal is to build more accurate structural brain networks.

title: Bento: a toolkit for subcellular analysis of spatial transcriptomics data.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: Bento is a Python toolkit for subcellular analysis of spatial transcriptomics data. It utilizes single-molecule information to enable analysis at the subcellular scale, focusing on defining subcellular domains, annotating localization patterns, and quantifying gene-gene colocalization. Bento integrates with the Scverse ecosystem for broader compatibility.

title: Glioblastoma-instructed microglia transition to heterogeneous phenotypic states with phagocytic and dendritic cell-like features in patient tumors and patient-derived orthotopic xenografts.
biological_context: Glioblastoma tumor microenvironment in patients and patient-derived orthotopic xenografts (PDOXs)
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'multicolor flow cytometry', 'immunohistochemistry', 'functional studies', 'histology images']
covered_analysis_steps: ['single-cell analysis', 'spatial analysis', 'flow cytometry analysis', 'immunohistochemistry analysis', 'functional studies']
main_goals: To characterize the heterogeneous tumor microenvironment (TME) in glioblastoma (GBM) patient tumors and patient-derived orthotopic xenografts (PDOXs) at single-cell and spatial levels. The study aims to understand how GBM cells instruct myeloid cells, particularly microglia, to adopt diverse phenotypic states and to assess the relevance of PDOXs as models for studying the GBM ecosystem and treatment responses.

title: Overcoming barriers to single-cell RNA sequencing adoption in low- and middle-income countries.
main_goals: This perspective discusses the current landscape of ancestral inclusivity in genomic and single-cell transcriptomic studies. It highlights the need for greater inclusion of researchers and donors from low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) to realize the full potential of these technologies equitably. The paper outlines collaborative efforts required to overcome barriers to establishing, expanding, and adopting single-cell sequencing research in LMICs.

title: Pianno: a probabilistic framework automating semantic annotation for spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Human neocortex, tumor microenvironments, diverse anatomical structures
main_goals: Pianno is a Bayesian framework that automates structural semantics annotation for spatial transcriptomics data using marker genes. It accurately annotates anatomical structures, tumor microenvironments, and estimates cell type distributions across various platforms. It also aids in discovering new cell subtypes, as demonstrated by the identification of an excitatory neuron subtype in the human neocortex.

title: Imbalance in Glucose Metabolism Regulates the Transition of Microglia from Homeostasis to Disease-Associated Microglia Stage 1.
main_goals: Investigate the role of glucose metabolism and PKM2 in the transition of microglia from homeostasis to disease-associated microglia (DAM) stage 1 in the context of Alzheimer's disease. The study aims to understand the molecular mechanisms regulating this transition, particularly focusing on metabolic dysregulation.

title: Symbiotic symphony: Understanding host-microbiota dialogues in a spatial context.
biological_context: Host-microbiota interactions in humans, particularly in early life.
main_goals: This review addresses lacunae in host-microbiome research by highlighting the importance of profiling hosts and microbiota together while preserving their spatial context. It emphasizes how spatial transcriptomics can overcome limitations in low biomass samples and has potential clinical implications for understanding localized infections and inflammation.

title: Single-Cell Multi-Omics Map of Cell Type-Specific Mechanistic Drivers of Multiple Sclerosis Lesions.
biological_context: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) brain white matter lesions
main_goals: To provide a single-cell multi-omics map of cell type-specific mechanistic drivers of multiple sclerosis (MS) lesions, uncovering specific genetic signatures, cellular endophenotypes, and B-cell coexpression networks within MS brain white matter. The study aims to offer detailed insights into cellular dynamics and interactions in MS pathogenesis.

title: The society for craniofacial genetics and developmental biology 46th annual meeting.
main_goals: This paper reports on the 46th Annual Meeting of the Society for Craniofacial Genetics and Developmental Biology (SCGDB). It highlights the awards given to Drs. Sally Moody and Justin Cotney and summarizes the sessions focused on signaling and genomic mechanisms, human genetics, translational and regenerative approaches, and clinical management of craniofacial differences. The meeting fostered interactions among attendees through workshops and a poster session.

title: Interpretable Spatial Gradient Analysis for Spatial Transcriptomics Data.
biological_context: Glioblastoma and 87 tumor spatial transcriptomic datasets
main_goals: LSGI is a computational framework to identify prominent, interpretable spatial transcriptomic gradients (STGs) from spatial transcriptomic data. It utilizes non-negative matrix factorization (NMF) combined with linear regression to analyze sliding windows. The framework aims to reveal insights into tumor biology by identifying gradated gene expression patterns.

title: Molecular architecture of primate specific neural circuit formation.
biological_context: Primate brain development, specifically neural circuit formation in the marmoset cortex
main_goals: To understand the molecular mechanisms of primate-specific neural circuit formation by assessing gene expression dynamics in the marmoset cortex using spatial transcriptomics. The study identified differentially expressed genes, particularly axon guidance molecules in the prefrontal cortex, and investigated the role of PRSS12 in circuit formation.

title: Dysregulation of cell state dynamics during early stages of serous endometrial carcinogenesis.
biological_context: Serous endometrial carcinogenesis in a mouse model
main_goals: This study provides a comprehensive census of cell types and their states during the early stages of serous endometrial carcinogenesis in a mouse model. It identifies molecular and cellular dynamics associated with pre-dysplastic changes and highlights aberrant cell-cell interactions. The paper also proposes a panel of 44 genes as potential early diagnostic and prognostic markers for human serous endometrial carcinoma.

title: Chemotherapy induces myeloid-driven spatial T-cell exhaustion in ovarian cancer.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell analysis', 'spatial analysis', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'histology images', 'in vitro immuno-oncology platform']
main_goals: This paper investigates the spatiotemporal remodeling of the tumor microenvironment induced by chemotherapy in ovarian cancer. It identifies chemotherapy-triggered spatial redistribution and exhaustion of CD8+ T cells, driven by macrophages, and proposes novel immunotherapeutic strategies.

title: Integrative spatial omics reveals distinct tumor-promoting multicellular niches and immunosuppressive mechanisms in Black American and White American patients with TNBC.
main_goals: This study aimed to investigate racial disparities in TNBC by characterizing the tumor microenvironment (TME) in Black American (BA) and White American (WA) patients using imaging mass cytometry and spatial transcriptomics. It revealed distinct TME profiles associated with survival differences and immunosuppressive mechanisms, suggesting potential race-inclusive therapeutic targets.

title: CHAI: Consensus Clustering Through Similarity Matrix Integration for Cell-Type Identification.
main_goals: CHAI is a consensus clustering approach for single-cell RNA sequencing data that aggregates clustering results from multiple state-of-the-art methods. It aims to improve cell-type identification performance and provides a platform for multiomic integration, demonstrating improved performance with spatial transcriptomics data.

title: Updates in Skin Cancer in Transplant Recipients and Immunosuppressed Patients: Review of the 2022-2023 Scientific Symposium of the International Immunosuppression and Transplant Skin Cancer Collaborative.
biological_context: Skin cancer in transplant recipients and immunosuppressed patients
main_goals: To summarize the most impactful scientific updates presented at the 2022 ITSCC symposium regarding cutaneous malignancies in solid organ transplant recipients (SOTR) and immunosuppressed patients. The symposium focused on chemoprevention, immunosuppression regimens, immunotherapy, spatial transcriptomics, and tumor registries.

title: Integrating Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptomics Reveals Heterogeneity of Early Pig Skin Development and a Subpopulation with Hair Placode Formation.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Cell Differentiation', 'Gene Expression Profiling']
main_goals: This study integrates single-cell and spatial transcriptomics on fetal pig skin across four developmental periods to understand heterogeneity and hair follicle formation. It identifies conserved genes with human skin diseases and pinpoints progenitor cells (OGN+/UCHL1+) for hair placode development, providing a resource for studying human skin diseases using porcine models.

title: Creating a universal cell segmentation algorithm.
main_goals: The paper aims to create a universal cell segmentation algorithm. This algorithm is intended to be broadly applicable across different imaging modalities and biological samples.

title: Spatial-temporal graph neural ODE networks for skeleton-based action recognition.
main_goals: The paper proposes STG-NODE, a novel model for skeleton-based action recognition that addresses challenges like intra-individual action differences and long-term temporal dependencies. It utilizes dynamic time warping for data normalization and custom ODE integrators to improve temporal modeling and recognition accuracy.

title: Deciphering the spatial landscape and plasticity of immunosuppressive fibroblasts in breast cancer.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Trajectory Inference', 'Deconvolution', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: This paper aims to decipher the spatial landscape and plasticity of immunosuppressive fibroblasts (FAP+ CAFs) in breast cancer. It identifies spatially organized cellular niches and investigates the mechanisms driving CAF transitions and their impact on the tumor microenvironment, linking CAF subpopulations to invasive recurrence risk.

title: Artifact removal and motor imagery classification in EEG using advanced algorithms and modified DNN.
main_goals: This paper presents an advanced approach for EEG artifact removal and motor imagery classification using Four Class Iterative Filtering and Filter Bank Common Spatial Pattern Algorithm with a Modified Deep Neural Network (DNN) classifier. The goal is to enhance the accuracy and reliability of BCI systems by addressing EEG artifacts and complex motor imagery tasks.

title: Automated Spatial Omics Landscape Analysis Approach Reveals Novel Tissue Architectures in Ulcerative Colitis.
main_goals: The paper introduces an automated spatial context-dependent approach that matches spatial pattern detection to cell annotation. This approach is designed to identify architectural complexities and rare cell types in spatial omics data, specifically demonstrating its utility in ulcerative colitis germinal-center B cell follicles.

title: Cell Marker Accordion: interpretable single-cell and spatial omics annotation in health and disease.
main_goals: The Cell Marker Accordion is a user-friendly platform that provides automatic annotation and biological interpretation of single-cell populations using consistency-weighted markers. It aims to improve annotation accuracy and identify disease-critical cells and pathological processes, extracting potential biomarkers.

title: 3DCellComposer - A Versatile Pipeline Utilizing 2D Cell Segmentation Methods for 3D Cell Segmentation.
main_goals: This paper introduces 3DCellComposer, a versatile pipeline that leverages existing 2D cell segmentation methods for accurate 3D cell segmentation. It addresses challenges like limited training data and complexity in 3D segmentation by allowing users to choose any suitable 2D segmentation model without retraining. The package also includes an enhanced quality evaluation tool for 3D images, enabling performance assessment without human annotations.

title: A Spatial Omnibus Test (SPOT) for Spatial Proteomic Data.
main_goals: The paper proposes the Spatial Omnibus Test (SPOT) to analyze spatial clustering of cells in spatial omics data across a range of radii. SPOT addresses the challenge of pre-specifying an optimal radius by aggregating results across multiple radii using the Cauchy combination test. This method aims to control type I error rates and improve power compared to existing approaches, with demonstrated application in ovarian cancer.

title: SpatialcoGCN: deconvolution and spatial information-aware simulation of spatial transcriptomics data via deep graph co-embedding.
biological_context: Human ductal carcinoma in situ, developing human heart, mouse brain
covered_analysis_steps: ['Deconvolution', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Spatial transcriptomics data simulation']
main_goals: The paper proposes a deep graph co-embedding framework called SpatialcoGCN to improve spatial transcriptomics data analysis. It aims to deconvolve cell mixtures in spatial data using single-cell data and recover spatial transcript distributions. Additionally, it introduces a simulation method, SpatialcoGCN-Sim, for generating realistic ST data.

title: Redefining clinical practice through spatial profiling: a revolution in tissue analysis.
main_goals: This paper discusses the recent evolution of spatial biology and its potential for improving tissue-level understanding and treatment of disease. It aims to advance precision and effectiveness in healthcare interventions by highlighting spatial omics' capabilities in biomarker discovery, disease stratification, and personalized treatments.

title: Protocol for preparing formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded musculoskeletal tissue samples from mice for spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Mouse musculoskeletal system (femora with adjacent muscle)
covered_analysis_steps: ['Tissue harvesting', 'Sample preparation', 'Paraffin embedding', 'FFPE sample selection', 'Sectioning', 'Placement on spatial slides', 'Imaging', 'Decrosslinking', 'Library preparation', 'Sequencing data analysis']
main_goals: This paper presents a protocol for preparing formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded (FFPE) musculoskeletal tissue samples from mice for spatial transcriptomics. It details the steps from tissue harvesting and sample preparation to library preparation and data analysis. The protocol aims to enable spatial transcriptomics on mineralized tissues, with a significant portion dedicated to decalcification.

title: Identification of spatially-resolved markers of malignant transformation in Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasms.
biological_context: Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasms (IPMN) and pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) progression
main_goals: This paper identifies subtype-specific spatially-resolved gene expression markers for Intraductal Papillary Mucinous Neoplasms (IPMN) across two independent cohorts and two Spatial Transcriptomics (ST) technologies. It aims to improve risk stratification and guide therapeutic options by revealing the role of specific gene activations in IPMN progression and its relation to pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC).

title: Development and content validation of a financial and functional outcomes tool for diabetes-related foot disease in patients undergoing major lower limb amputation: a prospective observational study from Pakistan.
biological_context: Diabetes-related foot disease and major lower limb amputation
main_goals: To develop and content validate a questionnaire to assess the financial and functional impact of major lower limb amputation in patients with diabetes-related foot disease. A 37-item multidimensional questionnaire was developed and rigorously content-validated.

title: Spatial proteomics in neurons at single-protein resolution.
main_goals: The paper introduces SUM-PAINT, a high-throughput imaging method for virtually unlimited multiplexing at better than 15 nm resolution. It allows for the generation of 30-plex single-molecule resolved datasets in neurons. The work also provides an integrated acquisition and analysis workflow for comprehensive spatial proteomics at single-protein resolution.

title: Unraveling cellular complexity with transient adapters in highly multiplexed super-resolution imaging.
biological_context: Mammalian cells, primary cilia, Golgi stacks
main_goals: This paper presents FLASH-PAINT, a method for rapid multiplexed super-resolution microscopy using fluorogenic labeling and transient adapter-mediated switching. It allows for the imaging of a nearly unlimited number of molecular targets. The method's versatility is demonstrated through mapping multiple proteins in mammalian cells, analyzing primary cilia, studying Golgi stacks, and investigating inter-organelle contacts.

title: Using clustering as pre-processing in the framework of signal unmixing for exhaustive exploration of archaeological artefacts in Raman imaging.
biological_context: Archaeological mosaic fragment from the oppidum period unearthed near Perpignan, France.
main_goals: This paper introduces an innovative threshold-based clustering algorithm combined with multiple Orthogonal Projection Approaches (OPA) to enhance the initial estimation step within the Multivariate Curve Resolution and Alternating Least-Squares (MCR-ALS) algorithm for Raman imaging data. The aim is to improve matrix rank investigation and thus optimize MCR-ALS analysis, particularly for complex archaeological samples.

title: Single-Nucleus Multiomic Analyses Identifies Gene Regulatory Dynamics of Phenotypic Modulation in Human Aneurysmal Aortic Root.
biological_context: Human aortic root aneurysm, specifically in the context of Marfan syndrome (MFS)
data_modalities_used: ['single-nucleus multiomic (gene expression)', 'single-nucleus multiomic (chromatin accessibility)', 'spatial transcriptomic sequencing']
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Gene Expression Profiling', 'Chromatin Accessibility']
main_goals: To perform the first integrative analysis of single-nucleus multiomic and spatial transcriptomic sequencing data of human aortic root tissue under healthy and Marfan syndrome conditions. The study aims to identify cell-type-specific transcriptomic and cis-regulatory profiles, delineate regulatory and spatial dynamics during vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) phenotypic modulation, and identify key regulators of this process, such as FOXN3.

title: Maturity Classification of Rapeseed Using Hyperspectral Image Combined with Machine Learning.
main_goals: To establish a nondestructive classification model for rapeseed maturity using hyperspectral imaging combined with machine learning. The study aimed to compare various preprocessing methods, feature wavelength selection algorithms, and classification models to identify the optimal combination for accurate maturity prediction. The D2nd-IVISSA-SPA-SVM model demonstrated the highest performance.

title: SpiDe-Sr: blind super-resolution network for precise cell segmentation and clustering in spatial proteomics imaging.
biological_context: Human and mouse tissues, breast cancer microenvironment
main_goals: SpiDe-Sr is proposed as a super-resolution network with a denoising module to enhance spatial resolution in Imaging Mass Cytometry (IMC). It aims to improve imaging quality by 4 times, resisting noise and increasing cell extraction accuracy, enabling better analysis of spatial proteomics data.

title: Expanding Sparse Radar Depth Based on Joint Bilateral Filter for Radar-Guided Monocular Depth Estimation.
main_goals: This paper presents a novel radar expansion technique inspired by the joint bilateral filter for radar-guided monocular depth estimation. The proposed method effectively increases the number of radar points and exhibits fewer intrinsic errors compared to raw radar and previous methodologies. The approach is validated on the nuScenes dataset, demonstrating state-of-the-art performance.

title: Point Cloud Denoising and Feature Preservation: An Adaptive Kernel Approach Based on Local Density and Global Statistics.
main_goals: This paper proposes an adaptive kernel approach based on local density and global statistics (AKA-LDGS) for point cloud denoising. The method uses Bayesian estimation theory to dynamically set prior probabilities for real and noise points, employing a multivariate Gaussian distribution for real points and a non-parametric adaptive kernel density estimation (KDE) for noise points. The goal is to effectively remove noise from real-world outdoor point clouds while preserving structural features.

title: SPINK1 Overexpression Correlates with Hepatocellular Carcinoma Treatment Resistance Revealed by Single Cell RNA-Sequencing and Spatial Transcriptomics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'single cell RNA-sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics']
main_goals: This study aims to elucidate the functions of SPINK1 on HCC therapy resistance using single cell RNA-sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It reveals that high SPINK1 expression is associated with drug resistance and identifies SPINK1 as a potential therapeutic target for refractory HCC.

title: The Sympatric Coexistence Mechanism: A Case Study of Two Penahia Species in the Beibu Gulf, South China Sea.
biological_context: Fish feeding habits and coexistence mechanisms
data_modalities_used: ['stomach content analysis', 'carbon and nitrogen stable isotope analysis']
main_goals: This study investigates the sympatric coexistence mechanisms between two congeneric fish species, Pennahia pawak and Pennahia anea, in the Beibu Gulf. It compares their feeding habits and trophic niches using stomach content and stable isotope analyses, alongside spatial niche analysis. The research aims to understand how niche differentiation contributes to their coexistence in a resource-limited environment.

title: Unique Spatial Transcriptomic Profiling of the Murine Femoral Fracture Callus: A Preliminary Report.
biological_context: Murine femoral fracture callus formation with metastatic breast cancer impairment
main_goals: To provide the first spatially intact characterization of genetic expression changes within an orthopedic model of impaired fracture healing using the Visium CytAssist platform. The study aimed to identify spatially localized gene expression changes in the fracture callus and investigate the impact of metastatic breast cancer on these patterns. The findings suggest that spatial transcriptomics is a valuable tool for orthopedic research by providing temporal and spatial context.

title: Gene networks and systems biology in Alzheimer's disease: Insights from multi-omics approaches.
main_goals: This review delves into techniques employed in Alzheimer's disease research, explores discoveries made using these techniques, and provides insights into the future of the field, particularly focusing on gene networks and systems biology in AD.

title: The multimodality cell segmentation challenge: toward universal solutions.
main_goals: This paper presents a multimodality cell segmentation benchmark comprising over 1,500 labeled images from diverse biological experiments. The top-performing method is a Transformer-based deep-learning algorithm that achieves high accuracy across various microscopy images and imaging platforms without manual parameter tuning. This benchmark and algorithm aim to enable more accurate and versatile cell analysis in microscopy.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals molecular dysfunction associated with cortical Lewy pathology.
biological_context: Parkinson's disease and related dementia, specifically cortical Lewy pathology
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics to identify specific classes of excitatory neurons vulnerable to Lewy pathology in the cortex of Parkinson's disease patients and a mouse model. It also describes a conserved signature of molecular dysfunction, termed LAMDA, characterized by downregulated synaptic, mitochondrial, and protein degradation genes, and upregulated DNA repair and immune genes in aggregate-bearing neurons.

title: Pharmacological suppression of the OTUD4/CD73 proteolytic axis revives antitumor immunity against immune-suppressive breast cancers.
main_goals: This paper identifies and pharmacologically targets the OTUD4/CD73 proteolytic axis in immune-suppressive breast cancers, specifically TNBC. It demonstrates that inhibiting this axis with a new compound, ST80, can revive antitumor immunity and sensitize tumors to immunotherapy. The study highlights the role of TGF-β signaling and uses spatial transcriptomics to understand immune cell interactions.

title: EHMT2 Inactivation in Pancreatic Epithelial Cells Shapes the Transcriptional Landscape and Inflammation Response of the Whole Pancreas.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of EHMT2 inactivation in exocrine pancreatic epithelial cells in shaping the transcriptional landscape and inflammation response of the whole pancreas. It reveals that EHMT2 inactivation enhances the injury-inflammation-repair response by reprogramming the local environment to recruit mesenchymal and immunological cells, contributing to the suppression of pancreatic cancer initiation and modulation of inflammatory pancreatic diseases.

title: Democratizing Pathological Image Segmentation with Lay Annotators via Molecular-empowered Learning.
biological_context: Pathological image segmentation, specifically cell segmentation in whole slide images (WSIs) of kidney tissue (implied by podocyte and mesangial cells).
main_goals: This paper proposes a molecular-empowered learning scheme for multi-class cell segmentation in pathological images using lay annotators. It integrates Giga-pixel level molecular-morphology cross-modality registration, molecular-informed annotation, and molecular-oriented segmentation. The method aims to democratize pathological AI deployment by enabling efficient and accurate segmentation with partial labels from lay annotators, outperforming traditional methods.

title: Navigating the landscapes of spatial transcriptomics: How computational methods guide the way.
main_goals: This review provides an overview and discussion of the current computational approaches for mining spatial transcriptomics data. It aims to propose future directions and perspectives of methodology design to stimulate further discussions and advances in new analytical models and algorithms.

title: Imaging Mass Cytometry for In Situ Immune Profiling.
biological_context: Host-pathogen interactions, tumor microenvironments, and inflammatory conditions
main_goals: Presents an optimized staining protocol for imaging mass cytometry with modifications for RNAscope integration. This allows for combined protein and single-molecule RNA detection, enabling comprehensive immune profiling within tissue contexture.

title: Fetal liver macrophages contribute to the hematopoietic stem cell niche by controlling granulopoiesis.
main_goals: This study investigates the heterogeneity of fetal liver macrophage populations in mice and their roles in hematopoiesis. It found that specific fetal liver macrophages interact preferentially with long-term HSCs and are crucial for controlling granulopoiesis and supporting erythropoiesis.

title: Tree parameter extraction in Fokienia hodginsii plantation based on airborne LiDAR data.
