title: Spatial Omics Reveals that Cancer-Associated Glycan Changes Occur Early in Liver Disease Development in a Western Diet Mouse Model of MASLD.
biological_context: Mouse model of Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD)
main_goals: The study aims to elucidate the N-glycome profile during the progression of MASLD to liver cancer using MALDI-IMS. They identified specific N-glycan structures, including fucosylated and highly branched N-linked glycans, at very early stages of liver injury. They propose these findings as promising biomarkers for the early diagnosis of liver injury in MASLD.

title: Estimation of Biochemical Pigment Content in Poplar Leaves Using Proximal Multispectral Imaging and Regression Modeling Combined with Feature Selection.
main_goals: This study evaluates the field application of proximal multispectral imaging combined with feature selection and regressive analysis to estimate the biochemical pigment contents of poplar leaves. It explores three variable selection algorithms and compares Partial Least Square Regression (PLSR) and nonlinear Support Vector Machine Regression (SVR) for estimation accuracy.

title: PGGait: Gait Recognition Based on Millimeter-Wave Radar Spatio-Temporal Sensing of Multidimensional Point Clouds.
main_goals: The paper proposes a gait recognition system called PGGait that utilizes millimeter-wave radar to extract high-quality point clouds and a neural network to extract spatial and temporal features for user identification. The system aims to provide an efficient and feasible solution for user gait recognition. Experimental results demonstrate high accuracy in recognizing single and two-person radial paths.

title: Biomarkers in Cancer Detection, Diagnosis, and Prognosis.
main_goals: This review paper describes a variety of biomarkers applicable for cancer detection and diagnosis, including imaging-based diagnosis, blood-based biomarkers, cell imaging-based diagnosis, tissue imaging-based diagnosis, and genetic-based biomarkers.

title: Semi-Supervised Clustering-Based DANA Algorithm for Data Gathering and Disease Detection in Healthcare Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN).
main_goals: This paper introduces a semi-supervised clustering-based DANA algorithm for data gathering and disease detection in healthcare wireless sensor networks (WSN). The DANA algorithm optimizes energy consumption and prolongs sensor node lifetimes. The semi-supervised clustering model utilizes both labeled and unlabeled data to create a more robust and adaptable clustering technique.

title: Profiling the heterogeneity of colorectal cancer consensus molecular subtypes using spatial transcriptomics.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Clustering']
main_goals: The study aims to decipher the spatially resolved cellular and molecular composition of colorectal cancer (CRC) using Spatial Transcriptomics (ST) and single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq). It focuses on mapping the intratumoral heterogeneity of consensus molecular subtypes (CMS) and their microenvironment, and identifying cell communication events in the tumor-stroma interface. The research intends to advance personalized therapy by resolving CRC molecular heterogeneity.

title: Single-cell, single-nucleus, and spatial transcriptomics characterization of the immunological landscape in the healthy and PSC human liver.
biological_context: Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and healthy human liver
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'single-nucleus RNA sequencing', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'Visium', 'Nanostring GeoMx DSP', 'flow cytometry']
main_goals: To generate a comprehensive atlas of the PSC liver using multi-omic modalities and protein-based functional validation. The study aimed to understand the cellular composition of the affected liver and how it underlies disease pathogenesis. The atlas expands our understanding of the cellular complexity of PSC and has potential to guide the development of novel treatments.

title: Comparison of holotomographic microscopy and coherence-controlled holographic microscopy.
main_goals: The paper compares two quantitative phase imaging (QPI) microscopes, the Telight Q-Phase microscope and the Nanolive 3D Cell Explorer-fluo microscope, focusing on their ability to generate images suitable for single-cell segmentation and quantitative data. It discusses the strengths and limitations of both microscopes when examining two cell lines. The study concludes that the choice between them depends on the specific requirements and goals of the user.

title: Spatial proteomics reveals phenotypic and functional differences in T cell and macrophage subsets during villitis of unknown etiology.
main_goals: To evaluate the phenotypic and functional differences between T cells and macrophages associated with villitis of unknown etiology (VUE). The study uses GeoMx Digital Spatial Profiling to analyze placental tissue from VUE cases and controls. The goal is to gain a deeper understanding of the immuno-pathogenesis of VUE.

title: Single-cell and spatial profiling identify three response trajectories to pembrolizumab and radiation therapy in triple negative breast cancer.
main_goals: The study aims to identify patient groups that respond differently to pembrolizumab and radiation therapy in triple negative breast cancer using single-cell transcriptomics and spatial proteomics. The analysis revealed three response trajectories: non-responders, responders with pre-existing anti-tumor immunity, and responders who mount a maximal immune response after combination therapy.

title: Unique macrophage phenotypes activated by BMP signaling in breast cancer bone metastases.
main_goals: This study aimed to identify unique macrophage phenotypes activated by BMP signaling in breast cancer bone metastases and to investigate the role of BMP inhibition in restricting metastasis progression.

title: Unsupervised and supervised discovery of tissue cellular neighborhoods from cell phenotypes.
main_goals: The paper introduces CytoCommunity, an algorithm for identifying tissue cellular neighborhoods (TCNs) based on cell phenotypes and their spatial distributions. It learns a mapping from cell phenotype space to TCN space using a graph neural network without intermediate clustering. The algorithm identifies condition-specific and predictive TCNs under the supervision of sample labels and enables the discovery of condition-specific cell-cell communication patterns across spatial scales.

title: Generating Contextual Variables From Web-Based Data for Health Research: Tutorial on Web Scraping, Text Mining, and Spatial Overlay Analysis.
main_goals: The paper describes and implements an 8-step method that combines web scraping, text mining, and spatial overlay analysis (WeTMS) to transform extensive text data from government websites into analyzable data sets containing contextual data for jurisdictional areas. It aims to provide a tutorial and resources for health and social researchers to apply this method.

title: stAA: adversarial graph autoencoder for spatial clustering task of spatially resolved transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper proposes stAA, an adversarial variational graph autoencoder, to identify spatial domains in spatial transcriptomics data. stAA leverages gene expression and spatial information using graph neural networks and enforces the distribution of cell embeddings to a prior distribution. The adversarial training process can make cell embeddings better capture spatial domain information and more robust.

title: Deep learning segmentation of endothelial cell images using an active learning paradigm with guided label corrections.
main_goals: The paper introduces Guided Correction Software for manual editing of automatically generated corneal endothelial cell segmentations. This software is then applied in an active learning paradigm to analyze a diverse set of post-keratoplasty EC images, improving deep learning performance and reducing segmentation time.

title: New perspectives on biology, disease progression, and therapy response of head and neck cancer gained from single cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC)
main_goals: This review provides an overview of scRNAseq, spatial transcriptomics, and associated bioinformatics methods in the context of HNSCC. It summarizes how these technologies have promoted our understanding of the emergence, composition, progression, and therapy responsiveness of, and intercellular signaling within, HNSCC.

title: Human disease-specific cell signatures in non-lesional tissue in Multiple Sclerosis detected by single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The study aimed to identify cell type-specific differences in non-lesional brain tissue from individuals with MS compared to controls using single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. The researchers identified region- and cell type-specific differences in non-lesional samples from individuals diagnosed with MS and/or exhibiting secondary demyelination with other neurological conditions, including differences in oligodendrocytes and microglia.

title: scResolve: Recovering single cell expression profiles from multi-cellular spatial transcriptomics.
biological_context: Human breast cancer data, human lung disease data
main_goals: The paper introduces scResolve, a method for recovering single-cell expression profiles from spatial transcriptomics measurements at multi-cellular resolution. scResolve restores expression profiles of individual cells at their locations, enabling cell type-specific differential gene expression analysis and accurate identification of rare cell populations. The method facilitates more flexible and precise spatial analysis that complements raw multi-cellular level analysis.

title: Spatial transcriptomics analysis identifies a unique tumor-promoting function of the meningeal stroma in melanoma leptomeningeal disease.
main_goals: The main goal of this paper is to characterize the tumor microenvironment of the leptomeningeal tissues and patient-matched extra-cranial metastatic sites in melanoma LMD using spatial transcriptomic analyses. They identify a tumor-promoting role of meningeal stroma mediated through upregulation of SERPINA3. They demonstrate a mechanism for overcoming microenvironment-mediated drug resistance unique to this metastatic site.

title: Single-cell level deconvolution, convolution, and clustering in spatial transcriptomics by aligning spot level transcriptome to nuclear morphology.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Deconvolution', 'Clustering', 'Cell Segmentation', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Integration with other omics']
main_goals: The paper presents STIE, an EM algorithm that aligns spatial transcriptomics data to histology images to achieve single-cell level deconvolution/convolution and clustering. It addresses the issue of spots covering multiple cells in spot-based spatial transcriptomics. The method recovers missing cells and enables novel insights into cell-type specific gene expression, spot resolution, cell typing, cell type colocalization, and cell-cell interactions.

title: Spatial profiling of the interplay between cell type- and vision-dependent transcriptomic programs in the visual cortex.
main_goals: The study aims to characterize the spatial organization of L2/3 cell types in the mouse primary visual cortex with and without visual experience using spatial transcriptomics. It investigates how visual deprivation affects transcriptomic changes and cell type identity. The study integrates spatial transcriptomic measurements with single-nucleus RNA-seq data to understand how vision patterns L2/3 cortical cell types during the postnatal critical period.

title: STEM enables mapping of single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data with transfer learning.
biological_context: Human squamous cell carcinoma, hepatic lobule
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering', 'Dimension Reduction', 'Deconvolution']
main_goals: The paper develops a method called STEM (SpaTially aware EMbedding) for integrating spatial transcriptomics (ST) and single-cell RNA-sequencing (SC) data. STEM uses deep transfer learning to encode both ST and SC data into a unified spatially aware embedding space. It then uses the embeddings to infer SC-ST mapping and predict pseudo-spatial adjacency between cells in SC data.

title: A new prediction method for sodium aluminate solution evaporation integrating process knowledge and data-driven spatial-temporal adaptive model.
biological_context: Sodium aluminate solution evaporation in alumina production
main_goals: The paper proposes a new prediction method for sodium aluminate solution evaporation by integrating process knowledge and a data-driven spatial-temporal adaptive model. The method aims to improve prediction accuracy and reduce energy consumption in alumina production. It involves data reconciliation, mechanism modeling based on material and heat transfer, and an error compensation method using double locally weighted kernel PLS.

title: Single-cell RNA-seq reveals the metabolic status of immune cells response to immunotherapy in triple-negative breast cancer.
main_goals: This study identifies metabolic 'sub-subtypes' associated with ICB non-response in TNBC by developing an analytic pipeline to reveal metabolic heterogeneity within immune cell subtypes. The study uncovers the mechanisms of regulation for these sub-subtypes, particularly the role of pDCs and macrophages. The proposed analytical pipeline can be used to examine metabolic heterogeneity within cell types that correlate with diverse phenotypes.

title: Single-cell spatial multi-omics and deep learning dissect enhancer-driven gene regulatory networks in liver zonation.
main_goals: The study maps enhancer-gene regulatory networks across mouse liver cell types using single-cell multiomics, spatial omics, massively parallel reporter assays, and deep learning. They trained a hierarchical deep learning model called DeepLiver to examine the architecture of enhancers driving cell states. The study aims to provide a multimodal understanding of the regulatory code underlying hepatocyte identity and their zonation state.

title: MENDER: fast and scalable tissue structure identification in spatial omics data.
biological_context: Brain regions, whole-brain atlas, breast cancer
main_goals: The paper introduces Multi-range cEll coNtext DEciphereR (MENDER) for tissue structure identification in spatial omics data. MENDER offers substantial improvements over modern complex models while automatically aligning labels across slices and using less running time. It allows the uncovering of previously overlooked spatial domains that exhibit strong associations with brain aging and enables the differentiation of breast cancer patient subtypes.

title: Human cerebellar organoids with functional Purkinje cells.
main_goals: The study reports a human organoid model (hCerOs) capable of developing the complex cellular diversity of the fetal cerebellum. It creates functional connections between inhibitory and excitatory neurons that display coordinated network activity. Long-term culture of hCerOs allows healthy survival and maturation of Purkinje cells.

title: Breaks for Precision Medicine in Cancer: Development and Prospects of Spatiotemporal Transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper reviews the integration strategies of single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics data, summarizes recent advances in spatiotemporal transcriptomics in cancer studies, and discusses the combined application of spatial multiomics. It aims to provide new directions and strategies for the precise treatment and clinical prognosis of cancer.

title: Regulatory T cells in skin mediate immune privilege of the hair follicle stem cell niche.
biological_context: Hair follicle stem cell niche in skin
main_goals: This study investigates the role of regulatory T cells (Tregs) in maintaining immune privilege within the hair follicle stem cell niche in the skin. The authors developed a model to selectively deplete skin Tregs and observed subsequent T cell-mediated inflammation of hair follicles. Spatial transcriptomics was used to identify aberrant IL-2 signaling in a rare form of human alopecia.

title: STAligner enables the integration and alignment of multiple spatial transcriptomics datasets.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Batch Correction', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: STAligner enables the integration and alignment of multiple spatial transcriptomics datasets.

title: Integrating spatial transcriptomics data across different conditions, technologies and developmental stages.
biological_context: Human cortex slices, mouse olfactory bulb slices, mouse hippocampus tissue slices, spatiotemporal atlases of mouse organogenesis
main_goals: The paper presents a graph attention neural network called STAligner for integrating and aligning spatial transcriptomics (ST) datasets. It enables spatially aware data integration, simultaneous spatial domain identification and downstream comparative analysis. STAligner captures shared tissue structures, disease-related substructures and dynamical changes during development.

title: Author Correction: Spatial transcriptomics uncover sucrose post-phloem transport during maize kernel development.
main_goals: Uncover sucrose post-phloem transport during maize kernel development using spatial transcriptomics.

title: Space-feature measures on meshes for mapping spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper introduces algorithms for calculating geodesics in the space of diffeomorphisms, termed space-feature-measure LDDMM, extending LDDMM algorithms to accommodate a space-feature action on marked particles. It leads to the derivation of a cross-modality alignment algorithm of transcriptomic data to common coordinate systems attached to standard atlases. The shape of space-feature measure brain spaces is measured by transforming them by diffeomorphisms to find a metric between these measures.

title: Attention De-sparsification Matters: Inducing diversity in digital pathology representation learning.
main_goals: The paper proposes DiRL, a Diversity-inducing Representation Learning technique for histopathology imaging to address the problem of attention sparsity in SSL-pretrained models. It leverages cell segmentation to densely extract multiple histopathology-specific representations and then proposes a prior-guided dense pretext task. The goal is to induce adequate diversification in attention for capturing context-rich representations.

title: The spatial transcriptomic landscape of human gingiva in health and periodontitis.
main_goals: The study applied Stereo-seq to obtain a spatial transcriptome atlas of the gingiva in healthy individuals and periodontitis patients. The aim was to identify major cell types and inflammation-related signaling pathways in periodontitis.

title: SGCAST: symmetric graph convolutional auto-encoder for scalable and accurate study of spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper develops SGCAST, an efficient auto-encoder framework for spatial domain identification. SGCAST uses a symmetric graph convolutional auto-encoder to learn latent embeddings by integrating gene expression similarity and spatial proximity. The framework enables mini-batch training, making it scalable to high-resolution spatial transcriptomic data.

title: Single-cell landscape of idiopathic multicentric Castleman disease in identical twins.
biological_context: Idiopathic multicentric Castleman disease (iMCD) in identical twins
main_goals: To provide evidence of the putative cell-of-origin of IL-6 signals in iMCD and describe a distinct monocytic host immune response phenotype through a unique identical twin model, using spatial transcriptomics and single-cell sequencing.

title: Inferring super-resolution tissue architecture by integrating spatial transcriptomics with histology.
main_goals: The paper presents iStar, a method that integrates spatial transcriptomics data and high-resolution histology images. iStar predicts spatial gene expression with super-resolution. It enhances gene expression resolution to near-single-cell levels in ST and enables gene expression prediction in tissue sections where only histology images are available.

title: Presence of onco-fetal neighborhoods in hepatocellular carcinoma is associated with relapse and response to immunotherapy.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering']
main_goals: The study aims to identify cell subsets involved in HCC relapse and response to immunotherapy by employing single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and bulk RNA sequencing. It identifies POSTN<sup>+</sup> CAFs as a key onco-fetal interacting hub and explores the association between onco-fetal reprogramming, EMT, tumor cell proliferation, and T<sub>reg</sub> cell recruitment.

title: A call for spatial omics submissions.
main_goals: This is a call for submissions. It does not present a new method or application.

title: Differential developmental blueprints of organ-intrinsic nervous systems.
biological_context: organ-intrinsic nervous systems (enteric nervous system (ENS) and intrinsic cardiac nervous system (ICNS))
main_goals: The paper investigates the developmental differences between the enteric nervous system (ENS) and the intrinsic cardiac nervous system (ICNS). It aims to understand the mechanisms driving organ-specific organization of these neuronal networks. The study integrates multiple omics approaches to uncover distinct differentiation paths influenced by the host organs.

title: Bayesian Hidden Mark Interaction Model for Detecting Spatially Variable Genes in Imaging-Based Spatially Resolved Transcriptomics Data.
main_goals: The paper introduces a Bayesian Hidden Mark Interaction Model for identifying spatially variable genes in imaging-based spatially resolved transcriptomics data. The method utilizes a zero-inflated negative binomial mixture model and a geostatistical mark interaction model to analyze gene expression patterns. The effectiveness of the method is demonstrated through simulations and analysis of real datasets.

title: Image-based spatial transcriptomics identifies molecular niche dysregulation associated with distal lung remodeling in pulmonary fibrosis.
main_goals: This study uses image-based spatial transcriptomics to analyze gene expression in lungs affected by pulmonary fibrosis. The aim is to identify the localization of disease-emergent cell types, establish the cellular and molecular basis of disease features, and define distinct molecular niches. The research also uses machine-learning and trajectory analysis to understand the progression of the disease.

title: MAPS: pathologist-level cell type annotation from tissue images through machine learning.
main_goals: The paper introduces MAPS, a machine learning approach for rapid and precise cell type identification from spatial proteomics data. MAPS aims to achieve pathologist-level precision. The goal is to facilitate advances in tissue biology and disease comprehension.

title: Inferring single-cell copy number profiles through cross-cell segmentation of read counts.
main_goals: The paper introduces DeepCNA, a novel method for inferring single-cell copy number alterations (CNAs) from scDNA-seq data. It utilizes an autoencoder network for cross-cell segmentation of read count sequences and a mixture model for copy number prediction. The method aims to improve breakpoint detection and copy number estimation compared to existing approaches.

title: Unlocking the Molecular Variations of a Micron-Scale Amyloid Plaque in an Early Stage Alzheimer's Disease by a Cellular-Resolution Mass Spectrometry Imaging Platform.
main_goals: The paper introduces a modified desorption electrospray ionization (DESI) mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) method called segmented temperature-controlled DESI (STC-DESI) to achieve high-resolution and high-sensitivity spatial metabolomics observation. The method is applied to analyze the brains of transgenic AD mice and identifies molecular changes associated with individual Aβ aggregates. The study aims to improve the diagnosis and therapeutic intervention of Alzheimer's disease.

title: Improved Support Vector Machine based on CNN-SVD for vision-threatening diabetic retinopathy detection and classification.
main_goals: The paper introduces a novel methodology for detecting and classifying vision-threatening diabetic retinopathy (VTDR) using a hybrid CNN-SVD model. It also presents the Hierarchical Block Attention (HBA) and HBA-U-Net architecture to improve image segmentation. The model aims to enhance the accuracy and robustness of VTDR detection.

title: EEG-BCI-based motor imagery classification using double attention convolutional network.
main_goals: The paper introduces a Double Attention Convolutional Neural Network (DAttnConvNet) to classify EEG signals for motor imagery-based brain-computer interfaces (BCIs). It aims to improve classification accuracy and efficiency by using an attention mechanism for feature selection and optimization. The model incorporates pre-processing techniques such as M-LMS and feature extraction using CSP, PCC, and an ExAo algorithm.

title: Spatial distribution and driving factors of Chinese dragon and lion dance athletes based on GIS.
main_goals: This study analyzes the distribution characteristics, trends, types, and driving factors of dragon and lion dance athletes using GIS and geographical detectors. It aims to provide insights for cultural heritage protection and related investment.

title: Segmentation of cellular ultrastructures on sparsely labeled 3D electron microscopy images using deep learning.
main_goals: The paper introduces a deep learning approach for segmenting cells and subcellular ultrastructures in 3D FIB-SEM images of tumor biopsies. The methodology combines deep learning for detecting intracellular space, optical flow for boundary propagation, and filopodium tracking for cell segmentation. The aim is to enable quantitative measurements and analysis of cellular structures to understand cancer mechanisms and progression.

title: An exhausted-like microglial population accumulates in aged and APOE4 genotype Alzheimer's brains.
main_goals: The study investigates the role of age and APOE4 genotype in altering neuroimmune function in Alzheimer's disease using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies a specific microglial population (TIM) that contributes to AD risk and pathology. The paper suggests TIM as a potential therapeutic target for AD.

title: Correction to: Cellular heterogeneity in red and melanized focal muscle changes in farmed Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) visualized by spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This is a correction to a previously published paper. The abstract does not mention the main goals or contributions.

title: EtOH-LN cryoembedding workflow to minimize freezing artifact in frozen tissues: A pilot study in preparing tissues compatible with mass spectrometry-based spatial proteomics application.
main_goals: The paper introduces the EtOH-LN workflow as a safer and accessible alternative to existing coolants for cryoembedding of frozen tissues. It aims to minimize freezing artifacts in frozen tissues, making them compatible with mass spectrometry-based spatial proteomics applications. The study demonstrates that the EtOH-LN workflow exhibits significantly reduced freezing artifacts compared to cryoembedding in cryostat.

title: Acquisition of Drug Resistance in Basal Cell Nevus Syndrome Tumors through Basal to Squamous Cell Carcinoma Transition.
main_goals: This study investigates the mechanism of resistance to SMO inhibitors in Gorlin syndrome. Using multiomics and spatial transcriptomics, the authors identify the basal to squamous cell carcinoma transition as a key process. They also nominate potential genetic suppressors of resistance.

title: Synovial Tissue Insights into Heterogeneity of Rheumatoid Arthritis.
main_goals: This review summarizes recent studies on the cellular and molecular heterogeneity in rheumatoid arthritis synovium. It aims to provide scientific and clinical perspectives on current knowledge and future challenges, highlighting the potential of spatial transcriptomics and machine learning for precision medicine.

title: Analysis of community connectivity in spatial transcriptomics data.
biological_context: Melanoma brain metastases, invasive ductal carcinoma, human-small-cell lung cancer, mouse brain
main_goals: The paper introduces Analysis of Community Connectivity (ACC) to characterize the relative similarity of cells within and between communities. It develops a Bayesian multi-layer network model called BANYAN for integrating spatial and gene expression information to achieve ACC. The method is demonstrated on simulated and real spatial transcriptomics datasets to reveal distinct cliques of interacting cell sub-populations.

title: Human neural stem cells restore spatial memory in a transgenic Alzheimer's disease mouse model by an immunomodulating mechanism.
main_goals: The study investigated the therapeutic mechanism of human neural stem cells in an Alzheimer's disease mouse model. Spatial transcriptomics was used to analyze differentially expressed genes and pathways to elucidate the effect of stem cell transplantation on neuroinflammation.

title: ESQmodel: biologically informed evaluation of 2-D cell segmentation quality in multiplexed tissue images.
main_goals: The paper introduces ESQmodel, a Bayesian probabilistic method to evaluate single cell segmentation quality in multiplexed tissue images. It uses extracted cellular data and a prior belief of cellular composition to compute per cell entropy, assessing segmentation accuracy based on the consistency of cellular expression profiles with cell type expectations.

title: Metabolomics at the tumor microenvironment interface: Decoding cellular conversations.
main_goals: This review discusses how altered metabolic pathways contribute to cancer progression and drug resistance. It explores current spatial metabolomics technologies and how they could be integrated into clinical practice to improve patient outcomes. The paper aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the field.

title: True-T - Improving T-cell response quantification with holistic artificial intelligence based prediction in immunohistochemistry images.
main_goals: This paper introduces True-T, an AI-based method for quantifying T-cells in colorectal cancer (CRC) using IHC images. It employs a three-stage pipeline: T-cell segmentation, density estimation, and prediction of five-year survival rates. The method aims to provide valuable prognostic information for CRC, potentially aiding in clinical applications.

title: THItoGene: a deep learning method for predicting spatial transcriptomics from histological images.
biological_context: Human breast cancer and cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma
main_goals: This paper introduces THItoGene, a deep learning method, to predict spatial gene expression from histological images. The method utilizes dynamic convolutional and capsule networks to analyze histological images and explore the relationship between image phenotypes and gene expression regulation. The study demonstrates superior performance in predicting spatial gene expression within human breast cancer and cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma datasets.

title: Spatial Proteomics toward Subcellular Resolution by Coupling Deep Ultraviolet Laser Ablation with Nanodroplet Sample Preparation.
main_goals: The paper introduces a novel spatial proteomics platform using deep ultraviolet laser ablation coupled with nanoPOTS for high-throughput and high-resolution tissue sample collection. The platform aims to improve the speed and spatial resolution of spatial proteomics. The study demonstrates the platform's ability to detect a large number of proteins and profile distinct subcellular regions.

title: It takes a village to grow a tree: Most tree species benefit from dissimilar neighbors.
main_goals: The study investigates how the growth of different tree species is influenced by their neighbors and their traits. It aims to test the complementarity hypothesis, focusing on the impact of functional dissimilarity on tree growth and species interactions within forest communities. The research explores how competition and species identity affect these relationships.

title: Computational cell-cell interaction technologies drive mechanistic and biomarker discovery in the tumor microenvironment.
main_goals: This review outlines recent advances in the study of cell-cell interactions within the tumor microenvironment using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics technologies. The goal is to promote the discovery of critical cell-cell interactions and expand the repertoire of druggable tumor biomarkers.

title: Defining the boundaries: challenges and advances in identifying cells in microscopy images.
main_goals: The paper reviews challenges and advances in identifying cells in microscopy images, focusing on segmentation methods. It highlights both classical and deep learning approaches, with an emphasis on tools like Cellpose and the importance of standardization.

title: Advanced progress of spatial metabolomics in head and neck cancer research.
main_goals: This article comprehensively reviews the progress of spatial metabolomics in head and neck cancer research, encompassing insights into cancer cell metabolic reprogramming. It covers various mass spectrometry imaging techniques for in situ metabolite analysis. Finally, it emphasizes the application of presently available techniques for early diagnosis, margin assessment, and prognosis of head and neck cancer.

title: Clearance of VWF by hepatic macrophages is critical for the protective effect of ADAMTS13 in sickle cell anemia mice.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of hepatic macrophages in sickle cell anemia (SCA) using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. The researchers found that the ADAMTS13-cleaved VWF was cleared from the circulation by a specific macrophage subset. Depletion of macrophages abolished the protective effect of ADAMTS13 and promoted vaso-occlusive episodes.

title: Uncovering intestinal macrophages through the integration of single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper investigates intestinal macrophages using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. The study aims to uncover the characteristics and spatial distribution of these cells within the intestine.

title: The journey towards clinical adoption of MALDI-MS-based imaging proteomics: from current challenges to future expectations.
main_goals: This review discusses the progress and challenges of MALDI-MSI for clinical applications. It covers recent developments and promising clinical proteomics applications.

title: A Spatial Transcriptome Reveals Changes in Tumor and Tumor Microenvironment in Oral Cancer with Acquired Resistance to Immunotherapy.
main_goals: This study aimed to reveal the dynamic changes in the tumor and tumor microenvironment (TME) in oral squamous cell carcinoma with acquired resistance to immunotherapy using spatial transcriptomics. The results identified activated pathways related to epigenetic modification after immunotherapy, suggesting that it may prevent cancer immune system activation via the anti-PD-1 antibody.

title: Feasibility Study Utilizing NanoString's Digital Spatial Profiling (DSP) Technology for Characterizing the Immune Microenvironment in Barrett's Esophagus Formalin-Fixed Paraffin-Embedded Tissues.
main_goals: This study aimed to determine if highly multiplex interrogation of the microenvironment could be performed on FFPE endoscopic samples using NanoString GeoMx DSP. It also sought to identify immune cell types and pathways that might mediate the progression of Barrett's esophagus to esophageal adenocarcinoma. Spatial proteomic and transcriptomic analyses were performed to identify differences between progressors and non-progressors.

title: Streamlining spatial omics data analysis with Pysodb.
main_goals: The paper introduces Pysodb, a Python-based tool designed for efficiently loading and exploring spatial datasets from the Spatial Omics Database (SODB) within a Python environment. The tool facilitates data processing and interaction with various computational methods. The paper also presents seven case studies to demonstrate the application and reproducibility of the tool.

title: Fishing Innate Immune System Properties through the Transcriptomic Single-Cell Data of Teleostei.
main_goals: The paper summarizes single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNAseq) and spatial transcriptomics experiments related to the innate immune system (IIS) in zebrafish and other Teleostei. It highlights the potential for meta-analyses and comparison with the mammalian IIS, as well as the need for more scRNAseq data from nonmodel Teleostei.

title: ENGEP: advancing spatial transcriptomics with accurate unmeasured gene expression prediction.
main_goals: ENGEP is an ensemble learning-based tool that predicts unmeasured gene expression in spatial transcriptomics data. It uses multiple single-cell RNA sequencing datasets as references. ENGEP aims to overcome the limitation of profiling a limited number of genes in spatial transcriptomics by predicting the expression of unmeasured genes.

title: GTAD: a graph-based approach for cell spatial composition inference from integrated scRNA-seq and ST-seq data.
biological_context: mouse cerebral cortex, cerebellum, developing human heart and pancreatic ductal carcinoma
main_goals: GTAD introduces a graph-based approach for cell spatial composition inference from integrated scRNA-seq and ST-seq data. The method uses Graph Attention Networks to capture cell spatial relationships and topological structures. GTAD aims to enhance cell-type identification and improve understanding of tissue microenvironments.

title: The effects of physical activity on white matter microstructure in children with overweight or obesity: The ActiveBrains randomized clinical trial.
main_goals: This study aimed to investigate the effects of a 20-week physical activity intervention on white matter microstructure in children with overweight or obesity. It also explored whether the effect of physical activity on white matter microstructure is global or restricted to a particular set of white matter bundles. The study found that the intervention did not significantly induce changes in white matter.

title: Spatial gene expression in the adult rat patellar tendon.
main_goals: This study used spatial transcriptomics to determine the gene expression profile in the adult rat patellar tendon. It aimed to predict cell type composition based on spatial location and identify spatially variable genes and their expression patterns in the tendon.

title: Exploring distinct properties of endometrial stem cells through advanced single-cell analysis platforms.
main_goals: This review summarizes current single-cell analysis techniques for endometrial stem cells and explores their relevance to related diseases. It aims to identify and characterize distinct endometrial stem cell populations and investigate their dynamic changes during the menstrual cycle and differentiation processes.

title: Multiomic spatial landscape of innate immune cells at human central nervous system borders.
data_modalities_used: ['single-cell RNA sequencing', 'time-of-flight mass cytometry', 'single-cell spatial transcriptomics', 'immunohistochemistry']
main_goals: This paper characterizes the immune system at human CNS interfaces using multiomic and spatial analysis. It investigates the diversity of myeloid cells and examines their distribution in glioblastoma samples, revealing distinct responses to hypoxia.

title: Single-cell multi-omics analysis of human testicular germ cell tumor reveals its molecular features and microenvironment.
main_goals: This paper investigates the molecular features and tumor microenvironment (TME) of seminoma, the most common malignant solid tumor in 14 to 44 year-old men. The study identifies key gene expression programs and immune cell subtypes within the TME using single-cell multi-omics and spatial transcriptomics. The findings aim to advance understanding of seminoma tumorigenesis and identify potential therapeutic targets.

title: Cross-linking breast tumor transcriptomic states and tissue histology.
main_goals: The paper introduces a data-driven approach using a graph neural network to predict the gene expression state of breast cancer patients from whole slide images (WSIs). The method identifies gene groups with co-dependent expression and associates histological phenotypes with underlying gene expression patterns. This allows for biological insights from routine pathology imaging directly.

title: TrkA-mediated sensory innervation of injured mouse tendon supports tendon sheath progenitor cell expansion and tendon repair.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of peripheral innervation and TrkA signaling in the repair of injured tendons. It demonstrates that sensory innervation and TGFβ signaling are critical for tendon repair in mice and human tendon regeneration.

title: Revealing spatial multimodal heterogeneity in tissues with SpaTrio.
main_goals: The paper introduces SpaTrio, a computational method for integrating spatial transcriptomics and single-cell multi-omics data. SpaTrio aims to uncover spatially multimodal heterogeneity, understand gene regulation, and resolve multimodal communication among cells. The method is benchmarked and applied to real datasets to provide multimodal insights into spatial biology.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics reveal POSTN<sup>+</sup> cancer-associated fibroblasts correlated with immune suppression and tumour progression in non-small cell lung cancer.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of POSTN+ cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) using single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. The research aims to identify CAF subpopulations, their spatial relationships with immune cells, and their impact on tumor progression and prognosis. The study seeks to provide insights for potential therapeutic targets.

title: Unveiling the hidden AP-1: revealing the crucial role of AP-1 in ccRCC at single-cell resolution.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of AP-1 in clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) using single-cell multi-omics datasets. It aims to reveal the expression and regulatory mechanisms of AP-1 in ccRCC, providing insights for future research and treatment strategies. The study utilizes single-cell and spatial transcriptomics approaches.

title: Drug targeting in psychiatric disorders - how to overcome the loss in translation?
main_goals: The paper discusses challenges in psychiatric drug development and proposes using single-cell and spatial omics data to improve the translational predictivity of preclinical models. It aims to reduce failure rates in clinical trials by evaluating drug targets more accurately.

title: Tertiary lymphoid structures sustain cutaneous B cell activity in hidradenitis suppurativa.
main_goals: This paper investigates the B cell activity within hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) lesions. It aims to understand the dynamics and microenvironmental interactions of B cells using histological analysis, single-cell RNA sequencing, and spatial transcriptomics. The study identifies tertiary lymphoid structures (TLSs) in HS lesions and describes the interactions among various cell types within these structures.

title: An approach of separating the overlapped cells or nuclei based on the outer Canny edges and morphological erosion.
biological_context: Cells and nuclei from Human U2OS cells, mouse NIH3T3 cells, and synthetic cells
main_goals: The paper introduces a new algorithm for segmenting overlapped cells or nuclei in microscopy images. The approach uses outer Canny edges and morphological erosion to achieve improved segmentation accuracy. The method is evaluated on human, mouse, and synthetic cell datasets and compared with existing methods.

title: Smoother: a unified and modular framework for incorporating structural dependency in spatial omics data.
main_goals: The paper introduces Smoother, a unified framework for integrating positional information into non-spatial models using modular priors and losses. Smoother enables accurate data imputation, cell-type deconvolution, and dimensionality reduction. The framework is applied to colorectal cancer and human prostate datasets to reveal biological insights.

title: Pathway centric analysis for single-cell RNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics data with GSDensity.
main_goals: The paper introduces GSDensity, a graph-modeling approach for pathway-centric analysis of single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data. The method aims to identify biologically distinct cells, reveal novel cell-pathway associations, and map spatially relevant pathways in biological systems without clustering. GSDensity is applied to mouse brain development and human tumor data for method validation.

title: Autophagy of OTUD5 destabilizes GPX4 to confer ferroptosis-dependent kidney injury.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of autophagy of OTUD5 in ferroptosis-dependent kidney injury. The researchers used spatial transcriptomics to identify GPX4 as a key molecule at the interface of the inner cortex and outer medulla. They found that OTUD5 stabilizes GPX4 and that its degradation via autophagy exacerbates kidney injury.

title: Spatial Biology of Breast Cancer.
main_goals: This review discusses the application of spatial methods, including spatial transcriptomics and proteomics, to understand breast cancer progression and treatment. It also examines the role of emerging multiplex imaging technologies and their potential impact on future research.

title: Correction to 'Probabilistic cell/domain-type assignment of spatial transcriptomics data with SpatialAnno'.
main_goals: This paper presents a correction to a previously published method, SpatialAnno, which likely deals with probabilistic cell/domain-type assignment in spatial transcriptomics data. The main goal is to address any identified issues or errors and improve the accuracy or functionality of the original method.

title: Seminar: Scalable Preprocessing Tools for Exposomic Data Analysis.
main_goals: The seminar focuses on preprocessing techniques for exposomic data analysis. It emphasizes scalability using combinatorial techniques and traditional statistical strategies. The goal is to improve downstream analytics by mitigating noise and addressing multicollinearity.

title: On-Tissue Spatial Proteomics Integrating MALDI-MS Imaging with Shotgun Proteomics Reveals Soy Consumption-Induced Protein Changes in a Fragile X Syndrome Mouse Model.
main_goals: This paper uses spatial proteomics to map the spatial distribution and quantify proteins in the hippocampus and hypothalamus of a Fragile X Syndrome mouse model. The study aims to identify protein markers and potential therapeutic targets related to soy consumption in this context.

title: Intestinal permeability is associated with aggravated inflammation and myofibroblast accumulation in Graves' orbitopathy: the MicroGO study.
main_goals: This study investigates the association between intestinal permeability and orbital inflammation in Graves' orbitopathy (GO) patients. It aims to determine if increased intestinal permeability, indicated by elevated serum LBP levels, correlates with augmented expression of genes related to immune cell infiltration and myofibroblast activation in orbital tissue. The study seeks to link gut microbiota composition with orbital inflammation in GO.

title: Systematic benchmarking of imaging spatial transcriptomics platforms in FFPE tissues.
main_goals: This paper benchmarks the performance of three commercial imaging spatial transcriptomics (iST) platforms on serial sections from tissue microarrays (TMAs). The goal is to guide the choice of iST methods for researchers designing studies using precious samples. It assesses both technical and biological performance, including transcript counts, specificity, concordance with RNA-seq, cell typing accuracy, and false discovery rates.

title: Reconstructing Spatial Transcriptomics at the Single-cell Resolution with BayesDeep.
main_goals: The paper introduces BayesDeep, a Bayesian hierarchical model, to reconstruct single-cell resolution spatial transcriptomics data. The model leverages cellular morphological data from histology images. It aims to improve downstream analyses such as pseudotime and cell-cell communication.

title: Imputing Single-Cell Protein Abundance in Multiplex Tissue Imaging.
main_goals: The paper introduces machine learning methods to impute single-cell protein abundance in multiplex tissue imaging data. It explores the strengths and weaknesses of different machine learning approaches, including regularized linear regression, gradient-boosted regression trees, and deep learning autoencoders. The study incorporates cellular spatial information to enhance imputation performance and demonstrates the biological relevance of the imputed data.

title: Single cell spatial transcriptomics reveals distinct patterns of dysregulation in non-neuronal and neuronal cells induced by the Trem2R47H Alzheimer's risk gene mutation.
main_goals: This paper investigates cell-type-specific spatial transcriptomic changes induced by the Trem2R47H mutation in Alzheimer's Disease. The study aims to identify transcriptomic dysregulation, especially focusing on glial and neuronal alterations.

title: ATAT: Automated Tissue Alignment and Traversal in Spatial Transcriptomics with Self-Supervised Learning.
main_goals: The paper introduces ATAT, a computational framework for automated tissue alignment and traversal in spatial transcriptomics. It utilizes self-supervised contrastive learning on H&E-stained images to streamline the alignment of multiple ST samples and model gene expression transitions. The framework aims to address the challenges of manual annotation and pathologist expertise in ST analysis and enables alignment of tissue samples with complex morphologies.

title: Dysregulated Repeat Element Viral-like Immune Response in Hepatocellular Carcinoma.
main_goals: This study investigates the relationship between repeat RNA expression, immune response, and clinical outcomes in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The researchers used RNA in situ hybridization, immunohistochemistry, and spatial transcriptomics to analyze HCC specimens. The goal is to identify repeat RNAs as prognostic biomarkers and potential therapeutic targets.

title: Multi-MSIProcessor: Data Visualizing and Analysis Software for Spatial Metabolomics Research.
main_goals: The paper introduces Multi-MSIProcessor (MMP), a software designed for processing and analyzing Mass Spectrometry Imaging (MSI) data. MMP integrates data read-in, visualization, data preservation, and biomarker discovery functions. The software aims to enable complete spatially resolved metabolomics analysis and facilitate the deep mining of batch MSI datasets.

title: Optical microscopic imaging, manipulation, and analysis methods for morphogenesis research.
main_goals: This review provides an overview of microscopic techniques for multicellular imaging and image analysis software tools, focusing on cell segmentation and tracking. It also covers cutting-edge techniques for mechanical manipulation of cells and tissues and highlights recent findings on morphogenetic mechanisms. The goal is to provide a practical overview of these techniques for morphogenesis research.

title: Cellstitch: 3D cellular anisotropic image segmentation via optimal transport.
main_goals: The paper introduces CellStitch, a novel optimal transport (OT) approach for 3D cell segmentation from anisotropic microscopic images. It aims to address the challenges of inaccurate segmentations and lack of 3D training data by formulating cell correspondence across layers with an OT approach. The method is extended to interpolate internal slices from anisotropic cell images to recover isotropic cell morphology.

title: MSIpixel: a fully automated pipeline for compound annotation and quantitation in mass spectrometry imaging experiments.
main_goals: The paper introduces MSIpixel, a fully automated pipeline for compound annotation and quantitation in mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) experiments. It aims to overcome challenges in molecular identification and improve the reliability and comprehensiveness of MSI-based spatial metabolomics.

title: Challenges and opportunities to computationally deconvolve heterogeneous tissue with varying cell sizes using single-cell RNA-sequencing datasets.
main_goals: The paper addresses challenges in deconvoluting heterogeneous tissue with varying cell sizes using single-cell RNA-sequencing datasets. It aims to improve the accuracy of deconvolution methods by considering cell size, total mRNA, and transcriptional activity, and proposes standards for using cell reference atlases and integrating single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data.

title: Author Correction: Spatial proteomics reveals secretory pathway disturbances caused by neuropathy-associated TECPR2.
main_goals: This paper corrects the original publication regarding spatial proteomics and the impact of TECPR2 on the secretory pathway. It provides a correction to the findings presented in the original study.

title: Exosomal lncCRLA is predictive for the evolvement and development of lung adenocarcinoma.
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of exosomal lncCRLA as a biomarker for lung adenocarcinoma. It uses single-cell sequencing, RNA-Mutect technique, and spatial transcriptomics to characterize hybrid EMT cells and their role in the development of lung adenocarcinoma. The study aims to predict the occurrence and evolution of lung adenocarcinoma for early detection.

title: Genetic and immune determinants of E. coli liver abscess formation.
biological_context: Escherichia coli liver abscess formation in mice
main_goals: The paper characterizes E. coli liver abscesses and identifies host determinants of abscess susceptibility. It uses spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing to analyze the immune response during abscess formation. The study suggests that hyperactivation of the hepatic innate immune response drives liver abscess susceptibility.

title: Differential in vivo labeling with barcoded antibodies allows for simultaneous transcriptomic profiling of airway, lung tissue and intravascular immune cells.
main_goals: The paper introduces a method for simultaneously characterizing transcriptomic features of airway, lung parenchymal and intravascular immune cells using differential in vivo labeling with barcoded antibodies. This approach provides spatial information and allows direct comparison of cells within different anatomical compartments. It offers a time- and cost-effective alternative to classical scRNA-seq, reducing animal and reagent use.

title: Brain-wide correspondence of neuronal epigenomics and distant projections.
main_goals: The study links single-cell epigenomes and cell types to long-distance projections in the mouse brain using epi-retro-seq. It aims to interrogate principles relating projection types to transcriptomics and epigenomics and address hypotheses about cell types and connections. The data is integrated into the BRAIN Initiative Cell Census Network atlas for deeper analysis.

title: The molecular cytoarchitecture of the adult mouse brain.
main_goals: To construct a comprehensive atlas of cell types in each brain structure by integrating single-nucleus RNA sequencing and Slide-seq. This atlas allows for characterization of cell type composition, neuropeptide and neurotransmitter signalling, region-specific gene expression, and heritability enrichment of neurological and psychiatric phenotypes.

title: Single-cell DNA methylome and 3D multi-omic atlas of the adult mouse brain.
main_goals: This study generates a single-cell DNA methylome and 3D multi-omic atlas of the adult mouse brain. It aims to understand DNA methylation diversity across the entire brain in a spatial context to create a complete molecular atlas of brain cell types and their gene regulatory landscapes. The research identifies differentially methylated regions and analyzes their spatial patterns and association with transcription and chromatin conformation.

title: GNTD: reconstructing spatial transcriptomes with graph-guided neural tensor decomposition informed by spatial and functional relations.
main_goals: This paper introduces a graph-guided neural tensor decomposition (GNTD) model for reconstructing whole spatial transcriptomes in tissues. The model employs a hierarchical tensor structure and formulation to explicitly model high-order spatial gene expression data with a hierarchical nonlinear decomposition in a three-layer neural network. The aim is to improve imputation accuracy from sparse spatial profiling data.

title: Spatiotemporal transcriptome atlas reveals the regional specification of the developing human brain.
main_goals: This study uses spatial transcriptomics and scRNA-seq to build a spatiotemporal atlas of multiple human brain regions during development. It aims to understand regional specification, identifying regional heterogeneity of radial glia cells and their contribution to neuronal specification, and exploring cell-cell interactions.

title: Ursa: A Comprehensive Multiomics Toolbox for High-Throughput Single-Cell Analysis.
main_goals: Ursa is an automated single-cell multiomics R package designed to provide an easy-to-use bioinformatics package for scientists. It offers 6 automated single-cell omics and spatial transcriptomics workflows. Ursa aims to facilitate post-quantification single or multiomics analyses by providing outcomes to quality control assessments, multidimensional analyses and extended analyses.

title: Cross-Domain Identification of Multisite Major Depressive Disorder Using End-to-End Brain Dynamic Attention Network.
main_goals: The paper introduces the Brain Dynamic Attention Network (BDANet) to improve the accuracy of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) diagnosis. It aims to address clinical heterogeneity and multisite data issues by dynamically representing brain region relationships and aligning data across domains using an Ensemble Classifier.

title: Label-free spatially maintained measurements of metabolic phenotypes in cells.
biological_context: cancer cells (MCF7 breast cancer cells and HepG2 liver cancer cells) and T cells
main_goals: The paper introduces a method combining autofluorescence lifetime imaging with machine learning to predict the metabolic pathway usage of cancer cells. It aims to detect metabolic perturbations between glycolysis and oxidative metabolism at a cellular level. The method provides a label-free technology to study cellular metabolism and metabolic heterogeneity.

title: StressNet: a spatial-spectral-temporal deformable attention-based framework for water stress classification in maize.
main_goals: The paper proposes a deep learning model, StressNet, for water stress classification in maize using multispectral and multi-temporal imagery. It incorporates a deformable convolutional layer and a Bi-Directional Long Short-Term Memory network with weighted attention to extract and aggregate spatial-spectral-temporal characteristics. The goal is to improve accuracy in water stress classification compared to mono-temporal classification.

title: A comprehensive overview of graph neural network-based approaches to clustering for spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper provides a comprehensive overview of GNN-based methods for spatial clustering in spatial transcriptomics. It evaluates the performance of current methods on prevalent datasets, considering various aspects like accuracy, robustness, and computational efficiency. The survey aims to identify limitations and outline future research directions in the field.

title: Cellular heterogeneity in red and melanized focal muscle changes in farmed Atlantic salmon (Salmo salar) visualized by spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: The study investigates cellular heterogeneity in red and melanized focal muscle changes in farmed Atlantic salmon using spatial transcriptomics. It aims to understand the molecular mechanisms involved in these discolorations and identify genes associated with relevant pathways, particularly those related to hypoxia and immune responses.

title: Single-cell spatial metabolomics with cell-type specific protein profiling for tissue systems biology.
biological_context: Human lung cancer, tonsil, and endometrium tissues
main_goals: The paper introduces the scSpaMet framework for joint protein-metabolite profiling of single cells in human tissues. It aims to quantify and visualize cell-type specific and spatially resolved metabolic-protein mapping for a systems-level understanding of tissue biology. The framework integrates untargeted spatial metabolomics and targeted multiplexed protein imaging.

title: Cortical somatostatin long-range projection neurons and interneurons exhibit divergent developmental trajectories.
main_goals: This paper investigates the developmental trajectories of somatostatin-expressing (SST+) cells in the mouse cerebral cortex. The study uses single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics to characterize the emergence of neuronal diversity among SST+ cells, specifically focusing on long-range projection neurons and interneurons.

title: Transcriptomics and Spatial Proteomics for Discovery and Validation of Missing Proteins in the Human Ovary.
main_goals: This paper uses transcriptomics and spatial proteomics to identify and validate missing proteins in the human ovary. The authors used RNA-seq data and antibody-based profiling to analyze the expression patterns of protein candidates. The study aims to refine the understanding of protein roles within the human ovary and open the doors for further investigations into missing proteins and human reproduction.

title: T cell-mediated curation and restructuring of tumor tissue coordinates an effective immune response.
main_goals: This study characterizes the tumor microenvironment in melanoma using multiplexed imaging. It investigates dynamic immune cell infiltration and tumor cell neighborhoods in response to T cell therapy and checkpoint inhibitors. The study aims to identify spatial correlates of immunotherapy outcomes and inform cellular therapy evaluation and engineering.

title: A deep learning approach for automation in neurite tracing and cell size estimation from differential contrast images under healthy and hypoxic condition.
main_goals: The paper proposes a deep learning framework using U-Net, U-Net++, and FCN architectures for automated tracing of neurites and cell shape from DIC images. The goal is to quantify neurite length and cell shape under hypoxic conditions, improving upon time-consuming manual segmentation.

title: Cellsketch: Simplified Cell Representation for Label-free Cell and Nuclei Segmentation.
main_goals: The paper introduces Cellsketch, a novel technique for cell segmentation. It generates an RGB mask containing simplified representations of cells and applies the watershed algorithm to produce segmentation masks. The method achieves accurate cell and nuclei segmentation from differential interference contrast (DIC) images.

title: In vitro laser scanning confocal microscopy and unsupervised segmentation: Quantification of cytosolic calcium and RNA distribution in hypoxic neurons.
main_goals: The paper proposes a framework combining 3D tracking of RNA distribution and cell size identification using unsupervised image segmentation. It aims to quantify cytosolic calcium levels and RNA distribution in hypoxic neurons under chronic conditions. The framework is designed to study the neurodegeneration process and evaluate neuroprotective drugs through image analysis.

title: An Instance Segmentation Dataset of Yeast Cells in Microstructures.
main_goals: This paper presents a novel dataset for segmenting yeast cells in microstructures. It offers pixel-wise instance segmentation labels for both cells and trap microstructures. A standardized evaluation strategy is proposed to facilitate the development of new cell segmentation approaches.

title: Quantitative Analysis of Differentiation Activity for Mouse Embryonic Stem Cells by Deep Learning for Cell Center Detection using Three-Dimensional Confocal Fluorescence Microscopy Images.
main_goals: This study proposes a new 3D U-net to accurately detect the center of each single cell in 3D confocal images. The method aims to improve the accuracy of cell center detection. This, in turn, improves the quantification of ESC speeds and status shifts.

title: Acute ischemia induces spatially and transcriptionally distinct microglial subclusters.
main_goals: This paper investigates microglial subclusters in ischemic stroke using single-cell RNA-sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies novel marker genes, defines ischemic core-associated and penumbra-associated microglia, and explores their functional characteristics and upstream regulators. The study aims to provide a biological basis for targeting specific microglial subclusters as a potential therapeutic strategy.

title: Deciphering the role of immunoglobulin secreting malignant lineages in the invasive frontiers of small cell lung cancer by scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics analysis.
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of immunoglobulin secreting malignant lineages in the invasive frontiers of small cell lung cancer. The study uses scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics analysis to gain insights into this process.

title: LGNN: a novel linear graph neural network algorithm.
main_goals: This paper proposes a linear graph neural network framework (LGNN) for node classification. The model preprocesses the input graph, uses a high-order adjacency matrix propagation mechanism, and applies a linear mapping to obtain the final node representation. The goal is to improve graph neural network performance, especially on sparse networks.

title: Spatial architecture of high-grade glioma reveals tumor heterogeneity within distinct domains.
data_modalities_used: ['GeoMx digital spatial profiling', 'CosMx spatial molecular imaging', 'Xenium', 'Visium spatial gene expression']
main_goals: This study uses spatial technologies to map the heterogeneity in high-grade gliomas (HGGs). It aims to investigate the cellular communities composing HGG and to understand the immune landscape within spatially localized regions. The study identifies distinct tumor niches and correlates them with immune cell distributions.

title: Visium spatial transcriptomics reveals intratumor heterogeneity and profiles of Gleason score progression in prostate cancer.
main_goals: This study uses Visium spatial transcriptomics to analyze the transcriptome-wide expression patterns in prostate cancer tissues with various Gleason scores. The goal is to understand the intratumor heterogeneity and the genes associated with Gleason score progression.

title: Giotto Suite: a multi-scale and technology-agnostic spatial multi-omics analysis ecosystem.
main_goals: The paper introduces Giotto Suite, an open-source software package for spatial omics data analysis. It provides a flexible and integrated framework for representing, integrating, and analyzing various spatial omics datasets at multiple scales. The suite aims to create an ecosystem for multi-omic data analysis.

title: MetaVision3D: Automated Framework for the Generation of Spatial Metabolome Atlas in 3D.
main_goals: The paper introduces MetaVision3D, a novel pipeline for generating a 3D spatial metabolome atlas from serial 2D MALDI mass spectrometry imaging sections. It employs computer vision techniques for image registration, normalization, and interpolation to integrate the sections. The goal is to create a comprehensive 3D model of metabolites across tissues.

title: Proximal immune-epithelial progenitor interactions drive chronic tissue sequelae post COVID-19.
main_goals: The study investigates the pathophysiology of respiratory PASC, identifying dysregulated immune-epithelial progenitor interactions as key drivers of fibroproliferation and impaired alveolar regeneration. The research highlights therapeutic strategies to improve alveolar regeneration and pulmonary function by targeting immune responses after acute viral pneumonia. The findings implicate a dysregulated immune-epithelial progenitor niche in driving respiratory PASC and address the unmet need in the clinical management of PASC and post-viral disease.

title: Decoding functional hematopoietic progenitor cells in the adult human lung.
main_goals: This study identifies functional hematopoietic precursors in the extravascular spaces of the human lung. It characterizes their organ-specific gene signature, highlighting differences in immune, megakaryocyte/platelet, and erythroid-related pathways compared to bone marrow progenitors. Spatial transcriptomics maps these blood progenitors to a vascular-rich alveolar interstitium niche.

title: Simultaneous CRISPR screening and spatial transcriptomics reveals intracellular, intercellular, and functional transcriptional circuits.
biological_context: innate immune response, autism spectrum disorder
main_goals: The paper introduces Perturb-FISH, a method that combines imaging spatial transcriptomics with parallel optical detection of in situ amplified guide RNAs. It aims to study the genetic and molecular associations of spatial and functional biology at single-cell resolution. The method is applied to study the lipopolysaccharide response in cultured monocytes and autism spectrum disorder risk genes.

title: Development of a Nanoparticle-Based Tendon-Targeting Drug Delivery System to Pharmacologically Modulate Tendon Healing.
main_goals: This study developed a nanoparticle-based drug delivery system to target the healing tendon. The system delivers the S100a4 inhibitor Niclosamide to the tendon, and enhances functional and mechanical outcomes.

title: Single-Cell and Spatial Transcriptome Analysis of Dermal Fibroblast Development in Perinatal Mouse Skin: Dynamic Lineage Differentiation and Key Driver Genes.
biological_context: Dermal fibroblast development in perinatal mouse skin
main_goals: This study provides a transcriptomic reference for future research in skin development and regeneration. It used single-cell RNA sequencing and validated the findings through spatial transcriptomics to analyze dermal fibroblast development in perinatal mouse skin.

title: Shedding Light on Colorectal Cancer: An In Vivo Raman Spectroscopy Approach Combined with Deep Learning Analysis.
main_goals: The paper introduces a transfer learning model based on a one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1D-CNN) for the classification of Raman spectra in live animals. The model achieved high accuracy in discriminating between malignant and normal tissues, demonstrating the potential of Raman spectroscopy combined with deep learning for cancer diagnosis.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics Reveals Signatures of Histopathological Changes in Muscular Sarcoidosis.
main_goals: This study investigates the interaction between granulomas and skeletal muscle in muscular sarcoidosis using spatial transcriptomics. It identifies transcriptomic clusters and pathways to elucidate the pathophysiological mechanisms driving muscle tissue damage.

title: Dynamic profiling of immune microenvironment during anti-PD-1 immunotherapy for head and neck squamous cell carcinoma: the IPRICE study.
biological_context: Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC)
main_goals: The primary objective of the study is to identify predictive factors for the response to anti-PD-1 immunotherapy in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). This is achieved through a multidisciplinary approach including spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA analysis, as well as clinical data and medical images. The ultimate aim is to generate effective biomarkers and new immunomodulatory agents.

title: CellCharter reveals spatial cell niches associated with tissue remodeling and cell plasticity.
main_goals: CellCharter is an algorithmic framework designed to identify, characterize, and compare cellular niches in spatially resolved datasets. The study aims to decode the link between spatial tissue architectures and cell plasticity by analyzing data from different technologies and sample types. The method was used to identify a cancer cell niche in human lung cancer cohorts.

title: STalign: Alignment of spatial transcriptomics data using diffeomorphic metric mapping.
main_goals: The paper introduces STalign, a method for aligning spatial transcriptomics datasets, accounting for non-linear distortions. It enables comparison across sections, samples, and technologies, and alignment to a 3D common coordinate framework. STalign aims to improve gene expression and cell-type correspondence in spatial locations, improving over landmark-based alignments.

title: Mapping the transcriptome: Realizing the full potential of spatial data analysis.
main_goals: This paper reviews the challenges and opportunities associated with spatial data analysis in transcriptomics. It examines how methods from the geographical sciences can be leveraged to realize the full potential of spatial information in transcriptomic datasets.

title: Molecular cartography uncovers evolutionary and microenvironmental dynamics in sporadic colorectal tumors.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Trajectory Inference', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering']
main_goals: This paper analyzes spatial multi-omic data from colorectal tumors to map tumor evolution, identify progression trajectories, and uncover the role of the tumor microenvironment. It aims to classify tumors based on their evolutionary dynamics and identify an immune exclusion signature with prognostic value.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics Resolve an Emphysema-specific Lymphoid Follicle B Cell Signature in COPD.
main_goals: The study aimed to characterize transcriptomic signatures from lymphoid follicles (LFs) in ever-smokers and COPD patients with varying degrees of emphysema. The goal was to identify emphysema-specific B cell signatures and understand the role of B cell activation in COPD pathogenesis. The research utilized spatial profiling to analyze the LFs and their associated gene expression.

title: Dissecting the tumor microenvironment in response to immune checkpoint inhibitors via single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper reviews single-cell sequencing and spatial transcriptomic research investigating immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) response within a variety of cancer microenvironments. It aims to provide an overview of the applications of these techniques in understanding the tumor microenvironment and predicting response to immunotherapy.

title: SingleScan: a comprehensive resource for single-cell sequencing data processing and mining.
main_goals: SingleScan is an online resource that curates single-cell transcriptome and genome analyzing tools and pipelines. It aims to provide easy access to information on single-cell sequencing methods and data processing pipelines, helping researchers navigate the field and choose appropriate tools.  The resource includes tools categorized by their main tasks, workflows, and spatial transcriptomics solutions.

title: Spatial transcriptomics of B cell and T cell receptors reveals lymphocyte clonal dynamics.
main_goals: The paper introduces Spatial VDJ, a novel spatial transcriptomics method for mapping B cell and T cell receptor sequences in human tissue sections. It captures lymphocyte clones and links B cell clonal expansion to tumor-associated gene expression programs. Spatial VDJ aims to delineate B cell clonal diversity and lineage trajectories within their anatomical niche.

title: Hemorrhage-activated NRF2 in tumor-associated macrophages drives cancer growth, invasion, and immunotherapy resistance.
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of hemorrhage-activated NRF2 in tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) in driving cancer growth, invasion, and immunotherapy resistance. They use spatial transcriptomics and single-cell RNA-Seq to study the microenvironment and the effect of heme. The findings suggest that targeting this pathway could enhance cancer immunity and overcome therapy resistance.

title: A human embryonic limb cell atlas resolved in space and time.
main_goals: The study characterizes human embryonic limb development using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics. It identifies novel cell populations, two waves of muscle development, and anatomical segregation of genes. The research also performs cross-species comparison with mouse embryonic limbs.

title: Spatial omics: An innovative frontier in aging research.
main_goals: The review summarizes recent advances in spatial omics applications in multi-organ aging research. It aims to enhance the understanding of aging mechanisms and discusses challenges and opportunities in spatial omics for aging and aging-related diseases.

title: Bexmarilimab-induced macrophage activation leads to treatment benefit in solid tumors: The phase I/II first-in-human MATINS trial.
main_goals: This study investigates the safety and efficacy of bexmarilimab in patients with treatment-refractory solid tumors. It assesses anti-tumor efficacy, pharmacodynamics, and immunologic correlates, demonstrating macrophage activation and tumor control in late-stage cancer.

title: Choroid plexus mast cells drive tumor-associated hydrocephalus.
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of choroid plexus mast cells (CPMCs) in tumor-associated hydrocephalus (TAH) using single-nucleus RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics. The study identifies that CPMCs disrupt cilia of choroid plexus epithelia, increasing cerebrospinal fluid production, which contributes to TAH. Furthermore, it presents a potential therapeutic target, tryptase, for TAH.

title: Single-cell sequencing reveals Hippo signaling as a driver of fibrosis in hidradenitis suppurativa.
main_goals: This paper uses single-cell RNA sequencing, spatial transcriptomics, and immunostaining to analyze Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS). The study characterizes the main cellular players and their interactions in HS, identifies the role of the Hippo pathway in fibrosis, and provides preclinical evidence for modulating the profibrotic fibroblast response.

title: Integrative multiomics enhancer activity profiling identifies therapeutic vulnerabilities in cholangiocarcinoma of different etiologies.
main_goals: The study aimed to identify potential therapeutic targets in different subtypes of cholangiocarcinoma through enhancer profiling.
