It used integrative multiomics enhancer activity profiling to identify distinct groups associated with different etiologies and unique pathways. The study aimed to elucidate the mechanisms underlying enhancer dysregulation and deepen understanding of different tumourigenesis processes in distinct CCA subtypes.

title: Three decades of advancements in osteoarthritis research: insights from transcriptomic, proteomic, and metabolomic studies.
main_goals: The review aims to highlight advancements in understanding osteoarthritis pathogenesis achieved through omic studies over three decades. It focuses on how transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics have identified individual molecules and patterns in osteoarthritis tissues/fluids. It also explores the potential of multi-omics approaches for identifying unique patient endophenotypes and tailoring therapeutic interventions.

title: Functional and spatial proteomics profiling reveals intra- and intercellular signaling crosstalk in colorectal cancer.
main_goals: This paper investigates the signaling crosstalk in colorectal cancer using patient-derived organoids (PDOs) and imaging mass-cytometry. It aims to understand tumor cell intrinsic signaling and the impact of the tumor microenvironment (TME) to inform precision oncology.

title: Spatial transcriptomics defines injury-specific microenvironments in the adult mouse kidney and novel cellular interactions in regeneration and disease.
main_goals: This study applied spatial transcriptomics to investigate ischemia-reperfusion injury in the mouse kidney. It aimed to identify injury-specific and spatially dependent gene expression patterns, and to understand cellular interactions, particularly between proximal tubule cells and fibroblasts, and the role of immune cells in repair.

title: CellSAM: A Foundation Model for Cell Segmentation.
main_goals: The paper presents CellSAM, a universal model for cell segmentation that generalizes across diverse cellular imaging data. It builds on top of the Segment Anything Model (SAM) by developing a prompt engineering approach for mask generation. The model achieves human-level performance for segmenting images of mammalian cells, yeast, and bacteria across various imaging modalities.

title: Nephron progenitors rhythmically alternate between renewal and differentiation phases that synchronize with kidney branching morphogenesis.
main_goals: The study correlates spatial transcriptomics data with kidney branching morphogenesis to discover rhythmically alternating signatures of nephron progenitor differentiation and renewal. It investigates the role of Wnt, Hippo-Yap, and retinoic acid (RA) pathways in regulating nephron formation. The research aims to synchronize nephron formation with ureteric bud branching and inform strategies for self-sustaining nephron formation in synthetic human kidney tissues.

title: Single-cell and spatial detection of senescent cells using DeepScence.
main_goals: The paper introduces DeepScence, a deep neural network-based method, for identifying senescent cells in single-cell and spatial transcriptomics data. The method utilizes a curated senescence-associated gene set (CoreScence) and aims to outperform existing methods in accuracy.

title: Targeted spatial proteomic analysis of CD8<sup>+</sup> T- and myeloid cells in tonsillar cancer.
main_goals: The study aims to explore variations in tonsillar cancer using immunofluorescence and targeted spatial proteomics in a cohort of 105 patients. The researchers assess prognostic factors and identify molecular targets, focusing on the spatial distribution of CD8+, CD11c+, and PanCK+ cells. The findings highlight the relevance of tumor micro-architecture for prognostic markers and potential therapeutic targets.

title: Spatial transcriptomics deconvolution at single-cell resolution using Redeconve.
biological_context: Human pancreatic cancer, lymph node samples
main_goals: The paper introduces Redeconve, an algorithm for deconvoluting spatial transcriptomics data at single-cell resolution. It aims to improve the accuracy, resolution, robustness, and speed of deconvolution compared to existing methods. The application to datasets provides novel biological insights.

title: Spatial analyses: Focusing on immune-stromal interactions to understand immunity in the tissue context.
biological_context: Various human tissues, COVID-19 induced lung fibrosis, autoimmune conditions
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell Segmentation', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: The paper uses multiplex immunofluorescence histology and spatial transcriptomics to study immune-stromal interactions in various human tissues. It identifies the preferential localization of innate lymphoid cells in fibrovascular niches. The study then investigates the role of these niches in COVID-19 induced lung fibrosis.

title: Multi-omics fusion with soft labeling for enhanced prediction of distant metastasis in nasopharyngeal carcinoma patients after radiotherapy.
main_goals: The study introduces a multi-kernel late-fusion method with soft labeling for predicting distant metastasis in nasopharyngeal carcinoma patients. The approach aims to mitigate disparities in omics data and enhance the integration of multi-omics data for improved prediction accuracy. The model uses a multi-kernel-based Radial basis function (RBF) neural network.

title: Analysis on spatial difference and spillover effect of development resilience index of sports industry: A case study of 285 cities in China.
main_goals: This paper analyzes the spatial differences and spillover effects of the development resilience index of the sports industry in 285 cities in China. It uses the Topsis model and exploratory spatial data analysis to evaluate the index and constructs a spatial econometric model to explore the influencing factors.

title: Research on the spatiotemporal evolution and driving mechanism of coupling coordinating between green transition of urban land use and urban land use efficiency: a case study of the Yangtze River Delta Region in China.
main_goals: This paper investigates the spatiotemporal evolution and driving mechanisms of the coupling coordination between the Green Transition of Urban Land Use and urban land use efficiency in the Yangtze River Delta region. It uses various models, including super-efficiency slack-based model, coupling coordination degree model, and geographically and temporally weighted regression model, to analyze the relationship between the two factors. The study aims to understand the spatial and temporal dynamics of these processes and identify the factors influencing them.

title: Transformation of non-neuritic into neuritic plaques during AD progression drives cortical spread of tau pathology via regenerative failure.
main_goals: The paper investigates the transformation of non-neuritic plaques into neuritic plaques during Alzheimer's disease progression and its effect on tau pathology spread. It uses spatial transcriptomics to analyze gene expression around these plaques and identifies potential compensatory mechanisms. The study suggests regenerative failure is a driving force in this process.

title: STmut: a framework for visualizing somatic alterations in spatial transcriptomics data of cancer.
main_goals: The paper introduces STmut, a software to visualize somatic point mutations, allelic imbalance, and copy number alterations in Visium data. The tool is tested on different Visium datasets, providing solutions to add the genetic dimension to spatial transcriptomic data while discussing limitations of different data types.

title: BCG vaccination stimulates integrated organ immunity by feedback of the adaptive immune response to imprint prolonged innate antiviral resistance.
biological_context: SARS-CoV-2 and influenza infection in mice
main_goals: The paper investigates the mechanisms of BCG vaccination in providing nonspecific protection against heterologous pathogens like SARS-CoV-2 and influenza. It aims to elucidate how BCG induces integrated organ immunity through the feedback of the adaptive immune response, particularly involving CD4+ T cells, to imprint prolonged innate antiviral resistance in lung cells.

title: Spatial multimodal analysis revealed tertiary lymphoid structures as a risk stratification indicator in combined hepatocellular-cholangiocarcinoma.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of tertiary lymphoid structures (TLSs) in combined hepatocellular-cholangiocarcinoma (cHCC-CCA). It uses spatial transcriptomics to identify a TLS gene signature and assesses the prognostic value of TLS distribution and frequency (iTLS and eTLS scores) using imaging mass cytometry.

title: DTLR-CS: Deep tensor low rank channel cross fusion neural network for reproductive cell segmentation.
main_goals: The paper proposes a deep learning network, DTLR-CS, to improve reproductive cell segmentation. It replaces the simple skip connection in U-Net with a deep tensor low rank channel cross fusion network. The network aims to address the instability and semantic gaps in U-Net for global multi-scale modeling.

title: Portable BLAST-like algorithm library and its implementations for command line, Python, and R.
main_goals: The paper introduces nsearch, a command line tool and C++11 library that provides BLAST-like functionality. It also presents Blaster for R and npysearch for Python, which leverage nsearch to provide similar functionality. The primary goal is to create a portable and embeddable implementation of a BLAST-like algorithm.

title: Using Functionalized Liposomes to Harvest Extracellular Vesicles of Similar Characteristics in Dermal Interstitial Fluid.
main_goals: The paper introduces a method using antibody functionalized liposomes to capture extracellular vesicles (EVs) from tumor and healthy cell-lines and dermal interstitial fluid (ISF). The study aims to characterize EV proteins and compare differentially expressed proteins (DEPs) to understand cell communication via EVs.

title: Single-cell analysis unveils activation of mast cells in colorectal cancer microenvironment.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of mast cells in colorectal cancer using a multi-omics approach. It identifies distinct activation features of mast cells in the tumor microenvironment and links the mast cell signature to better prognosis. The study also explores the interaction of mast cells with other cell types, potentially related to tumor progression.

title: Past climate cooling and orogenesis of the Hengduan Mountains have influenced the evolution of Impatiens sect. Impatiens (Balsaminaceae) in the Northern Hemisphere.
main_goals: This study reconstructed a phylogenetic framework for Impatiens sect. Impatiens using plastome data. It then investigated the biogeographical history and diversification patterns of the plant section, focusing on the role of the Hengduan Mountains and past climatic changes.

title: Integrating spatial and single-cell transcriptomics data using deep generative models with SpatialScope.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis']
main_goals: SpatialScope integrates scRNA-seq reference data and ST data using deep generative models. It enhances seq-based ST data to single-cell resolution and infers transcriptome-wide expression levels for image-based ST data. The tool facilitates downstream analyses like detecting cellular communication, localizing cellular subtypes, and identifying spatially differentially expressed genes.

title: Untargeted and spatial-resolved metabolomics characterize serum and tissue-specific metabolic reprogramming in acute kidney injury.
biological_context: Acute kidney injury (AKI) in mice and patients
main_goals: This study investigates the metabolic profiles of serum and kidney tissue in acute kidney injury (AKI) patients and a mouse model. It uses untargeted metabolomics and spatial metabolomics to identify differentially expressed metabolites and characterize their spatial distribution. The study aims to provide insights into the molecular pathology of AKI.

title: Fusing the spatial structure of electroencephalogram channels can increase the individualization of the functional connectivity network.
main_goals: The paper proposes a novel method for constructing electroencephalogram (EEG) functional connectivity (FC) networks that incorporates spatial relationships between EEG channels using virtual nodes. The goal is to increase the individualization of the FC network and improve the performance of individual identification algorithms. The method achieves a high accuracy in identification and demonstrates robustness in reducing the number of channels.

title: Unveiling the novel immune and molecular signatures of ovarian cancer: insights and innovations from single-cell sequencing.
main_goals: This review provides a comprehensive summary of the applications of single-cell sequencing in ovarian cancer. It covers the identification of novel cell subpopulations, elucidates tumor heterogeneity, and investigates the tumor microenvironment. The paper aims to guide the development of innovative diagnostic markers, therapeutic strategies, and prognostic indicators.

title: Multi-omics analysis in developmental bone biology.
main_goals: The paper provides an overview of multi-omics approaches, particularly single-cell omics, in the context of bone biology. It highlights the use of these techniques to understand the diversity and dynamics of skeletal cells, including stem cells. The paper emphasizes the importance of integrating computational predictions with in vivo validation.

title: Core binding factor subunit β plays diverse and essential roles in the male germline.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of core-binding factor subunit-β (CBFβ) in prepubertal male germline development and spermatogenesis. The research utilizes a conditional knockout approach in mice to understand the effects of CBFβ inactivation, revealing its importance in germline maintenance and sperm production, particularly within undifferentiated spermatogonia.

title: Organotypic heterogeneity in microvascular endothelial cell responses in sepsis-a molecular treasure trove and pharmacological Gordian knot.
main_goals: This review describes the current knowledge of organ-specific microvascular endothelial cell heterogeneity at the molecular level. It elaborates on studies reporting endothelial cell responses in sepsis and discusses how this heterogeneity could be leveraged for therapeutic gain. The review also covers the use of high-throughput technologies like single-cell RNA sequencing and spatial transcriptomics.

title: A machine learning one-class logistic regression model to predict stemness for single cell transcriptomics and spatial omics.
main_goals: This paper introduces a one-class logistic regression machine learning algorithm for identifying stem-like cell populations in tumors using single-cell and spatial omics data. The method aims to extract transcriptomic features from non-transformed stem cells to identify dedifferentiated cell states, without the need for cell annotation. The model is applied across multiple spatial omics technologies to identify oncogenic stem-like cell types.

title: Revealing the role of necroptosis microenvironment: FCGBP + tumor-associated macrophages drive primary liver cancer differentiation towards cHCC-CCA or iCCA.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of the necroptosis microenvironment in primary liver cancer (PLC). It uses scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics to identify FCGBP+ TAMs as key regulators and examines the progression of premalignant cells towards iCCA or cHCC-CCA in relation to the necroptosis microenvironment.

title: Single cell and spatial transcriptomics analysis of kidney double negative T lymphocytes in normal and ischemic mouse kidneys.
main_goals: This paper investigates the molecular signature and spatial dynamics of double negative (DN) T cells in normal and ischemic mouse kidneys using single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) and spatial transcriptomics. The study aims to elucidate the distinct transcriptional profiles of DN T cells and their spatial localization within the kidney tissue, providing insights into their role during acute kidney injury.

title: Integrative multiomics analysis of neointima proliferation in human saphenous vein: implications for bypass graft disease.
biological_context: neointima proliferation in human saphenous vein
main_goals: This study investigates the transcriptomic and proteomic dynamics of neointima proliferation in human saphenous veins using multi-omics analysis. The authors aim to identify the human-specific molecular and cellular mechanisms driving this process, to provide insight into bypass graft disease.

title: Spatial proteo-transcriptomic profiling reveals the molecular landscape of borderline ovarian tumors and their invasive progression.
biological_context: borderline ovarian tumors and their invasive progression
main_goals: This paper integrates spatial proteomics and transcriptomics to study the transition from serous borderline tumors (SBT) to low-grade serous cancer (LGSC) and its corresponding metastasis. It aims to elucidate the molecular changes during tumorigenesis, identify key drivers of invasiveness, and potentially inform novel treatment strategies.

title: Temporal and spatial analysis of astrocytes following stroke identifies novel drivers of reactivity.
main_goals: This paper uses spatial transcriptomics and snRNA-seq to analyze astrocytes in mouse forebrain after ischemic injury. The study aims to understand the temporal and spatial dynamics of astrocyte reactivity, identifying distinct astrocyte subtypes and their responses to injury. The findings offer insights into the heterogeneity of reactive astrocytes and their potential roles in post-injury processes.

title: Single cell spatial transcriptomic profiling of childhood-onset lupus nephritis reveals complex interactions between kidney stroma and infiltrating immune cells.
main_goals: The study uses spatial transcriptomics to profile kidney tissue from cLN patients and controls. It aims to understand cellular interactions within the kidney, identify gene expression changes, and find modules of spatially-correlated gene expression related to inflammation and fibrosis.

title: Increased spatial coupling of integrin and collagen IV in the immunoresistant clear cell renal cell carcinoma tumor microenvironment.
biological_context: clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) tumors
main_goals: The study investigates the spatial relationship between integrin and collagen IV in the tumor microenvironment of immunoresistant clear cell renal cell carcinoma. It aims to understand the mechanisms of immunotherapy resistance by analyzing spatial gene expression and protein localization. The findings suggest integrin as a potential therapeutic target.

title: CGCom: a framework for inferring Cell-cell Communication based on Graph Neural Network.
main_goals: The paper introduces CGCom, a framework based on a Graph Neural Network (GNN) for inferring cell-cell communication patterns from spatial transcriptomics data. It aims to accurately predict cell communication between individual cell pairs and generalize its learning to predict communication between different cell types. The framework utilizes publicly available ligand-receptor and molecular regulatory information to enhance the accuracy of cell-cell communication inferences.

title: Multiplexed 3D Analysis of Immune States and Niches in Human Tissue.
biological_context: pre-invasive melanoma in situ and metastatic melanoma
main_goals: This study utilizes a high-resolution 3D imaging approach combining CyCIF imaging and confocal microscopy to characterize organelles and structures at a sub-micron scale while quantifying millimetre-scale spatial features. The approach allows for precise cell phenotyping and scoring cell proximity. The study investigates the microenvironment in pre-invasive and metastatic melanoma.

title: Imaging tumor lactate is feasible for identifying intermediate-risk prostate cancer patients with postsurgical biochemical recurrence.
main_goals: This paper investigates the use of hyperpolarized 13C MRI and spatial metabolomics to identify prostate cancer patients with postsurgical biochemical recurrence. The study aims to assess the potential of tumor metabolic imaging as an auxiliary tool for treatment decision-making in intermediate-risk prostate cancer.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals novel genes during the remodelling of the embryonic human arterial valves.
main_goals: This study utilizes Spatial Transcriptomics to investigate the transcriptome of developing human arterial valves. It identifies novel genes and pathways involved in valve development and highlights the limitations of existing databases in representing valve transcriptomes.

title: Transformer with convolution and graph-node co-embedding: An accurate and interpretable vision backbone for predicting gene expressions from local histopathological image.
main_goals: The paper introduces TCGN, a novel method combining convolutional layers, transformer encoders, and graph neural networks. It aims to accurately predict gene expressions from H&E-stained pathological images, offering interpretability and minimal computational resources. The method is validated on spatial transcriptomic datasets.

title: Identification of Niche-Specific Gene Signatures between Malignant Tumor Microenvironments by Integrating Single Cell and Spatial Transcriptomics Data.
biological_context: Breast cancer, gastrointestinal stromal tumor, liver hepatocellular carcinoma, uterine corpus endometrial carcinoma, and ovarian cancer
covered_analysis_steps: ['Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: The paper introduces a strategy to identify niche-specific gene signatures by integrating scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomic data. This approach aims to identify novel marker genes and their spatial relationships within the tumor microenvironment. The study applied this method to five different cancer types.

title: Lobular Carcinoma of the Breast: A Comprehensive Review with Translational Insights.
main_goals: This paper provides a comprehensive review of invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast, covering pathological aspects and translational features. It explores the tumor microenvironment and potential therapeutic options in the era of personalized treatment.

title: Paving the path toward multi-omics approaches in the diagnostic challenges faced in thyroid pathology.
main_goals: This review explores the application of proteomics, particularly spatial proteomics, and its integration with other omics approaches and artificial intelligence in the diagnosis of thyroid pathology. It highlights the potential of multi-omics approaches to uncover intricate molecular relationships and improve thyroid nodule diagnosis.

title: Neural stem cells persist to generate new neurons in the hippocampus of adult and aged human brain - Fiction or accurate?
biological_context: Adult and aged human brain, neurological disorders (epilepsy and Alzheimer's disease)
main_goals: This review summarizes findings related to adult neurogenesis in the human hippocampus. It highlights key milestones, methodological advancements, and controversies. The review discusses the involvement of adult neurogenesis in learning, memory, mood, and neurological conditions.

title: Matrix Selection for the Visualization of Small Molecules and Lipids in Brain Tumors Using Untargeted MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometry Imaging.
main_goals: This paper compares the performance of different matrices and polarity settings for MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry imaging in brain tumors. The study aims to identify the optimal combination for detecting metabolites and to establish a workflow for matrix selection in spatial metabolomics studies.

title: Talniflumate abrogates mucin immune suppressive barrier improving efficacy of gemcitabine and nab-paclitaxel treatment in pancreatic cancer.
main_goals: The paper investigates the role of mucins in pancreatic cancer progression and treatment resistance. It uses spatial transcriptomics to analyze Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasms (IPMN) and explores the impact of mucin downregulation on standard therapy efficacy using in vivo experiments.

title: Multi-omic analysis of human kidney tissue identified medulla-specific gene expression patterns.
main_goals: The study analyzed gene expression, chromatin accessibility, chromatin conformation, and spatial transcriptomic data from human kidney cortex and medulla to identify medulla-specific gene expression patterns. It aimed to provide insights into medulla development and function and to validate findings using spatial transcriptomics and immunohistochemistry. The datasets serve as a valuable resource for functional annotation of variants from genome-wide association studies.

title: The role of LSM1 in breast cancer: Shaping metabolism and tumor-associated macrophage infiltration.
main_goals: This study investigates the role of LSM1 in breast cancer, focusing on its impact on metabolism, tumor-associated macrophages, and the tumor microenvironment. The research aims to identify LSM1 as a potential diagnostic and prognostic marker, as well as a target for precision medicine.

title: Cholangiocytes Modulate CD100 Expression in the Liver and Facilitate Pathogenic T-Helper 17 Cell Differentiation.
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of CD100 expression and its mutation in the pathogenesis of cholangiopathies. The study uses spatial transcriptomics, immune imaging, and flow cytometry to analyze immune cell interactions in the liver and how they contribute to the disease.

title: Tumor macrophage functional heterogeneity can inform the development of novel cancer therapies.
main_goals: This review discusses the functional profiling of macrophages in the tumor microenvironment. It provides an update on novel macrophage-targeted therapies in development, aiming to control tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs). The paper leverages single-cell RNA-sequencing and spatial transcriptomics data to improve the understanding of macrophage subtypes.

title: Pregnancy-responsive pools of adult neural stem cells for transient neurogenesis in mothers.
main_goals: This paper investigates the role of adult neural stem cells (NSCs) during pregnancy in mice. It explores how these NSCs contribute to transient neurogenesis and are involved in maternal behavior. The study uses spatial transcriptomics to identify molecular markers of pregnancy-associated interneurons.

title: Single-cell epigenomics and spatiotemporal transcriptomics reveal human cerebellar development.
main_goals: This paper combines single-cell transcriptomics, spatial transcriptomics, and single-cell chromatin accessibility to study human fetal cerebellar development. It aims to reveal the roles of transcription factors and CREs in progenitor differentiation, and determine molecular signatures regulated by different signals during development. Also, it maps SNPs of disorders related to cerebellar dysfunction to determine potential cellular basis and mechanisms.

title: Cell-type brain-region specific changes in prefrontal cortex of a mouse model of alcohol dependence.
main_goals: This paper uses snRNA-seq and Visium spatial gene expression profiling to study cell-type specific changes in the medial prefrontal cortex of mice in an alcohol dependence model. The study aims to identify dysregulated gene co-expression networks and specific targets implicated in alcohol dependence. This provides a comprehensive atlas of cell-type specific gene expression changes.

title: Multi-omics data reveals aberrant gut microbiota-host glycerophospholipid metabolism in association with neuroinflammation in APP/PS1 mice.
main_goals: This study investigated the role of gut microbiota in Alzheimer's disease by integrating multi-omics data. The researchers aimed to identify the potential mechanisms linking gut microbiota, host glycerophospholipid metabolism, and neuroinflammation in APP/PS1 mice. The study also utilized fecal microbiota transplantation to explore these associations.

title: A framework for robotic excavation and dry stone construction using on-site materials.
main_goals: The paper presents a robotic construction pipeline for building freeform stone walls and landscapes from local materials. The system uses a robotic excavator with a shovel and gripper, learning from real and simulated data to detect and segment stones for grasping and 3D scanning. The work demonstrates the potential of autonomous heavy construction vehicles to build adaptively with sustainable materials.

title: Spatial transcriptomics and the anatomical pathologist: Molecular meets morphology.
main_goals: This mini review provides an overview of spatial transcriptomics methods, with an emphasis on platforms compatible with FFPE tissue, approaches to assess the data and potential applications in anatomical pathology practice.

title: SPACEL: deep learning-based characterization of spatial transcriptome architectures.
main_goals: The paper introduces SPACEL, a deep learning-based pipeline for spatial transcriptomics data analysis. SPACEL aims to address the challenges of joint analysis of multiple spatial transcriptomics slices and constructing a 3D architecture. The pipeline comprises modules for cell type deconvolution, spatial domain identification, and 3D alignment.

title: A spatial human thymus cell atlas mapped to a continuous tissue axis.
main_goals: The study maps the micro-anatomical organization of the thymus in pre- and post-natal states. It uses spatial transcriptomics and high-resolution multiplex imaging to analyze thymocyte trajectories and thymic epithelial cells, and to identify the drivers of T cell development. The authors establish the Cortico-Medullary Axis as a new framework for spatial analysis.

title: Spatial host-microbiome sequencing reveals niches in the mouse gut.
main_goals: The paper introduces spatial host-microbiome sequencing (SHM-seq), a new all-sequencing-based approach to capture tissue histology, polyadenylated RNAs, and bacterial 16S sequences directly from tissue. It aims to study native host-microbe interactions in health and disease using a deep learning approach for data mapping and detecting spatial niches.

title: Multiomic analysis of cervical squamous cell carcinoma identifies cellular ecosystems with biological and clinical relevance.
main_goals: This paper uses multiomic analysis to map intratumoral expression heterogeneity in cervical squamous cell carcinoma. It identifies three tumor states with distinct immune microenvironments and investigates their interactions. It also explores the effect of neoadjuvant chemotherapy on tumor state transition and its correlation with treatment response.

title: Tissue niches and immunopathology through the lens of spatial tissue profiling techniques.
biological_context: Health and disease, focusing on immune responses in various tissues, including those affected by COVID-19, autoimmune diseases, and cancer.
main_goals: This review discusses recent advances in spatial tissue profiling techniques, highlighting their advantages over traditional histopathology studies. The paper aims to provide a comprehensive understanding of how tissue niches direct regional immunity and their relevance in tissue immunopathology. It also acknowledges challenges and limitations while emphasizing the potential for novel therapeutic strategies and personalized medicine.

title: Crosstalk between alternative splicing and inflammatory bowel disease: Basic mechanisms, biotechnological progresses and future perspectives.
main_goals: The review summarizes the process of RNA splicing and highlights potential molecules involved in aberrant splicing events in IBD. It also discusses the use of quantitative transcriptome analyses, including microarrays and NGS, and explores the application of advanced technologies like TGS, scRNA-seq and ST. The aim is to evaluate the regulatory mechanisms of AS events in IBD and explore AS events for future treatment.

title: Spatially Resolved Co-Imaging of Polyhalogenated Xenobiotics and Endogenous Metabolites Reveals Xenobiotic-Induced Metabolic Alterations.
main_goals: This paper applies mass spectrometry imaging to assess the spatial distributions of polyhalogenated xenobiotics and endogenous metabolites in zebrafish to understand their toxic effects. The study aims to clarify the reproductive toxicity of HBCD and the accumulation of CPs in specific organs and their subsequent effects on metabolites.

title: An overview of the detection of bovine respiratory disease complex pathogens using immunohistochemistry: emerging trends and opportunities.
main_goals: The paper provides an overview of immunohistochemistry (IHC) techniques and protocols for detecting pathogens in bovine respiratory disease complex (BRDC). It highlights emerging trends like multiplex IHC, digital imaging, and integration with spatial transcriptomics and opportunities to improve IHC accuracy and applicability.

title: How single-cell transcriptomics provides insight on hepatic responses to TCDD.
main_goals: This review explores the application of single-cell transcriptomic technologies (snRNAseq and spatial transcriptomics) and highlights their contributions towards unraveling the cell-specific mechanisms mediating the hepatic responses to TCDD.

title: On-tissue dataset-dependent MALDI-TIMS-MS<sup>2</sup> bioimaging.
main_goals: The paper introduces SIMSEF, a dataset-dependent acquisition strategy that augments TIMS-MS imaging datasets with MS2 spectra. It enables on-tissue compound annotation through spectral library matching and rule-based lipid annotation, as well as mapping the chemical space by molecular networking. The algorithm and data analysis pipelines are open source and modular.

title: Exploring the single-cell immune landscape of kidney allograft inflammation using imaging mass cytometry.
main_goals: The study explores the single-cell immune landscape of kidney allograft inflammation using imaging mass cytometry. It identifies immune and non-immune clusters and aims to discriminate between different allograft inflammatory phenotypes using machine learning.

title: Spatiotemporal characteristics and driving mechanisms of household energy transition in rural China: Micro-evidence from 2005 to 2017.
main_goals: This paper analyzes the spatiotemporal characteristics and driving mechanisms of household energy transition in rural China. It aims to evaluate the effectiveness of energy transition, analyze its temporal and spatial characteristics, and reveal the driving forces behind it.

title: An attention 3DUNET and visual geometry group-19 based deep neural network for brain tumor segmentation and classification from MRI.
main_goals: This paper proposes a novel deep learning system, SC3DUNet, for segmenting and classifying brain tumors from 3D brain MR images. It introduces preprocessing steps like noise removal and utilizes dilated convolution-based VGG-19 for feature extraction, followed by feature selection and classification using a deep neural network. The goal is to improve accuracy in tumor segmentation and classification compared to existing methods.

title: Spatially distinct molecular patterns of gene expression in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.
main_goals: The study investigates the heterogeneous regions of the IPF lung using spatial transcriptomics to understand the distribution and extent of fibrotic lung disease. It identifies differentially expressed genes and dysregulated pathways within normal-appearing lung parenchyma, transition zones, and areas of dense fibrosis. The findings demonstrate transcriptional distinctions in histologically normal-appearing regions and pathway dysregulation in fibrotic areas.

title: Protocol for dissecting cascade computational components in neural networks of a visual system.
main_goals: This paper presents a protocol for dissecting cascade computational components in neural networks of a visual system. It uses spike-triggered nonnegative matrix factorization to obtain the complete circuit of recorded neurons. The approach identifies computational components of the feedforward network of retinal ganglion cells.

title: SpaceWalker enables interactive gradient exploration for spatial transcriptomics data.
main_goals: SpaceWalker is a visual analytics tool for exploring the local gradient structure of 2D and 3D spatial transcriptomics data. It enables interactive exploration of gene expression gradients and highlights tissue architectural features. The tool generalizes to different spatial transcriptomics protocols and scales well to large, multi-slice, 3D whole-brain data.

title: Spatial transcriptomics identifies candidate stromal drivers of benign prostatic hyperplasia.
main_goals: The paper uses spatial transcriptomics to identify stromal factors driving benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). It aims to identify molecular targets for therapies by investigating the interaction between stromal cells and epithelial cells in the prostate.

title: A single-cell atlas depicting the cellular and molecular features in human anterior cruciate ligamental degeneration: A single cell combined spatial transcriptomics study.
main_goals: The study aims to identify cell types in the human ligament and investigate their roles and interactions in ligamental degeneration using single-cell and spatial RNA sequencing. The research explores changes in the ligamental microenvironment during disease progression and seeks to uncover the molecular foundation of the degeneration process.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals a low extent of transcriptionally active hepatitis B virus integration in patients with HBsAg loss.
main_goals: This study aimed to explore the transcriptionally active HBV integration events in the liver tissue of patients with chronic HBV infection, especially in patients with HBsAg loss. The research constructed high-resolution spatial transcriptomes of liver biopsies to analyze the viral integration events. The study also evaluated the expression of HBsAg and HBV core antigen, and quantified intrahepatic cccDNA levels.

title: ConSpaS: a contrastive learning framework for identifying spatial domains by integrating local and global similarities.
main_goals: The paper introduces ConSpaS, a novel node representation learning framework for spatial domain identification by integrating local and global similarities using graph autoencoder and contrastive learning. It aims to improve the accuracy of spatial domain identification and denoise gene expression data while preserving spatial expression patterns. The method integrates spatial information and gene expression data to improve characterization of the global similarity of gene expression data.

title: Measurement and characteristics of the temporal-spatial evolution of China's healthcare services efficiency.
main_goals: This paper analyzes the spatiotemporal evolution of healthcare services efficiency (HSE) in China using the stochastic frontier approach (SFA)-Malmquist model and spatial analysis techniques. It aims to understand the spatial distribution and dynamics of HSE across different regions, providing insights for policy recommendations to improve healthcare efficiency.

title: Dimension-agnostic and granularity-based spatially variable gene identification using BSP.
biological_context: Cancer, neural science, rheumatoid arthritis, and kidney studies
main_goals: This paper introduces BSP (big-small patch), a non-parametric model for identifying spatially variable genes from two or three-dimensional spatial transcriptomics data. The method compares gene expression patterns at two spatial granularities. BSP is tested in simulations and validated with biological discoveries.

title: Instant processing of large-scale image data with FACT, a real-time cell segmentation and tracking algorithm.
main_goals: To present FACT, a fast and accurate real-time cell tracking algorithm for processing large-scale image data.  FACT segments approximately 20,000 cells in 2.5 seconds on average and exports quantifiable features within minutes. The algorithm is applied to identify directionally migrating glioblastoma cells and irregular cell lineages.

title: Rapid and signal crowdedness-robust in situ sequencing through hybrid block coding.
main_goals: To overcome limitations in resolution, sensitivity, and speed of existing spatial transcriptomics methods, the authors introduce SPRINTseq, a new in situ sequencing strategy combining hybrid block coding and molecular dilution.  SPRINTseq enables fast and sensitive high-resolution data acquisition, demonstrated by recovering over 142 million transcripts from mouse brain slices. The technology is used to uncover the cellular and subcellular molecular architecture of Alzheimer's disease.

title: Cervical Cancer Classification From Pap Smear Images Using Deep Convolutional Neural Network Models.
main_goals: To develop deep learning models for automated cervical cancer detection that do not rely on segmentation methods or custom features.  The study compared 13 pre-trained deep CNN models using the Herlev dataset to identify the best-performing model for cervical cancer classification.  DenseNet-201 was found to be the best-performing model.

title: Integrated single-nuclei and spatial transcriptomic analysis reveals propagation of early acute vein harvest and distension injury signaling pathways following arterial implantation.
biological_context: Vein graft failure following cardiovascular bypass surgery
main_goals: To elucidate the response of the vein conduit wall during harvest and following implantation using single-nuclei RNA-sequencing and spatial transcriptomics; to identify key maladaptive pathways driving graft failure; to identify potential therapeutic targets for biologic intervention.

title: FICTURE: Scalable segmentation-free analysis of submicron resolution spatial transcriptomics.
main_goals: To present FICTURE, a segmentation-free spatial factorization method for analyzing transcriptome-wide data with billions of submicron resolution spatial coordinates.  FICTURE aims to overcome limitations of existing methods that struggle with complex tissues and scale poorly.  The method is designed to be efficient and compatible with both sequencing- and imaging-based spatial transcriptomics data.

title: cellPLATO: an unsupervised method for identifying cell behaviour in heterogeneous cell trajectory data.
main_goals: To introduce cellPLATO, a Python-based software for measuring and classifying diverse cell behaviours based on clustering of parameters of cell morphology and motility.  The tool analyzes live cell microscopy data to identify behavioral subtypes and trajectories.  It was used to investigate the role of IL-15 in modulating NK cell migration.

title: A multidimensional analysis reveals distinct immune phenotypes and the composition of immune aggregates in pediatric acute myeloid leukemia.
main_goals: To conduct a multidimensional analysis of the tumor immune microenvironment in pediatric AML and non-leukemic controls; to characterize the composition, phenotype, and spatial organization of immune cells in the pediatric AML bone marrow; to identify potential targetable immune-evasion mechanisms specific to pediatric AML.

title: Programs, Origins, and Niches of Immunomodulatory Myeloid Cells in Gliomas.
data_modalities_used: ['scRNA-seq', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'mitochondrial DNA-based lineage tracing', 'organoid explant systems']
main_goals: To understand the immunomodulatory properties of glioma-associated myeloid cells using scRNA-seq, spatial transcriptomics, and lineage tracing.  To determine the factors driving the expression of these immunomodulatory programs. To provide a framework for developing more effective immunotherapies.

title: Differential chromatin accessibility and transcriptional dynamics define breast cancer subtypes and their lineages.
main_goals: To characterize the links between gene expression and chromatin accessibility in different breast cancer subtypes and their cells of origin using multi-omic techniques. To identify key genes and regulatory networks defining basal-like and luminal breast cancer lineages. To provide spatial detail for key markers of benign and malignant cell types and immune cell colocation.

title: Machine learning links T cell function and spatial localization to neoadjuvant immunotherapy and clinical outcome in pancreatic cancer.
main_goals: To investigate the impact of neoadjuvant αCD40 therapy on T cells in the tumor microenvironment (TME) of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) using machine learning to analyze single-cell, spatial, and highly multiplexed proteomic data.  To identify potential biomarkers of disease-free survival (DFS) for αCD40-treated patients. To demonstrate the utility of machine learning in molecular cancer immunology applications.

title: Human neural stem cells restore spatial memory in a transgenic Alzheimer's disease mouse model by an immunomodulating mechanism.
main_goals: To elucidate the therapeutic mechanisms of human neural stem cells (hNSCs) in an Alzheimer's disease mouse model using spatial transcriptomics.  The study aimed to determine if hNSC transplantation restored spatial memory and to identify the underlying mechanisms, specifically investigating the role of microglia-mediated neuroinflammation.

title: Quality Control for Single Cell Analysis of High-plex Tissue Profiles using CyLinter.
main_goals: To address the impact of imaging artifacts on single-cell data analysis from high-plex spatial profiling of tissues.  The authors introduce CyLinter, an interactive quality control software tool, to identify and remove data associated with these artefacts.  This improves single-cell analysis, particularly for archival specimens.

title: Breast Cancer Macrophage Heterogeneity and Self-renewal are Determined by Spatial Localization.
main_goals: To map the determinants of functional heterogeneity of tumor microenvironment (TME) macrophages in breast cancer using an ex vivo organotypic TME model, in vivo murine models, and human samples.  To identify the signals regulating macrophage heterogeneity and accumulation, focusing on a self-renewing macrophage subset.  To explore the therapeutic potential of disrupting macrophage self-renewal in breast cancer.

title: Comprehensive single cell aging atlas of mammary tissues reveals shared epigenomic and transcriptomic signatures of aging and cancer.
biological_context: Mouse mammary glands, human breast tumors
main_goals: To investigate how aging affects the transcriptomic and epigenomic programs of mouse mammary glands at single-cell resolution; to identify age-related changes in epithelial, stromal, and immune cells; to determine if transcriptional signatures of aging mammary cells are found in human breast tumors.

title: Spatial transcriptomics and neurofilament light chain reveal changes in lesion patterns in murine autoimmune neuroinflammation.
biological_context: Experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) and Multiple Sclerosis
main_goals: To investigate the spatio-temporal patterns of neuroaxonal damage in EAE, using spatial transcriptomics and other techniques to understand the role of CNS myeloid cells in neurodegeneration and the relationship between lesion patterns and serum neurofilament light (sNfL) levels.

title: Spatial spillover of local general higher education expenditures on sustainable regional economic growth: A spatial econometric analysis.
main_goals: To explore the impact of local general higher education expenditures on sustainable regional economic growth in China. The study used spatial econometric analysis, specifically the spatial Durbin model, to investigate the direct and spillover effects of education expenditures on regional economic growth from 2000 to 2021.

title: Treatment with tumor-treating fields (TTFields) suppresses intercellular tunneling nanotube formation in vitro and upregulates immuno-oncologic biomarkers in vivo in malignant mesothelioma.
main_goals: To determine whether tunneling nanotubes (TNTs) are a therapeutic target for Tumor-Treating Fields (TTFields) therapy in malignant pleural mesothelioma (MPM).  To characterize TTFields-induced changes to molecular profiles in vivo using spatial transcriptomics. To develop a new method, SPOTT (Spatial Profiling of Tunneling nanoTubes), for visualizing TNTs in intact tissue and superimposing them over spatial genomic data.

title: Exploring myometrial microenvironment changes at the single-cell level from nonpregnant to term pregnant states.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Clustering']
main_goals: To characterize the changes in the myometrial microenvironment at the single-cell level between nonpregnant and term pregnant states using scRNA-Seq and spatial transcriptomics.  To identify spatially distinct cell populations and alterations in cell proportions, particularly smooth muscle cells and macrophages.  To provide insights into myometrial remodeling and the anti-inflammatory response during pregnancy.

title: Advances in cellular and tissue-based imaging techniques for sarcoid granulomas.
main_goals: This review summarizes existing cellular and tissue-based imaging methods used to visualize sarcoid granulomas.  It also explores the potential of spatial transcriptomics and MALDI-MSI for advancing sarcoidosis research. The overarching goal is to illuminate the trajectory of sarcoidosis research.

title: In Situ Spatial Reconstruction of Distinct Normal and Pathological Cell Populations Within the Human Adrenal Gland.
main_goals: To investigate the centripetal differentiation model in the human adrenal cortex using spatially resolved in situ transcriptomics, characterize aldosterone-producing micronodules (APMs), and better understand adrenal diseases such as primary aldosteronism.  The study aimed to identify distinct cell populations and their positional relationships within the human adrenal gland.  Results supported the centripetal differentiation model and characterized APM heterogeneity.

title: STOmicsDB: a comprehensive database for spatial transcriptomics data sharing, analysis and visualization.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Visualization', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Data archiving']
main_goals: The main goal of this paper is to present STOmicsDB, a comprehensive database for spatial transcriptomics data sharing, analysis, and visualization.  It integrates 218 manually curated datasets and offers a user-friendly interface.  The database also includes standards for data archiving and allows researchers to create customized sub-databases.

title: Reduced-complexity Convolutional Neural Network in the compressed domain.
main_goals: This paper proposes a method to perform CNN learning and inference in the compressed domain to reduce computational complexity and improve speed.  A graph-based frequency channel selection method identifies important frequency channels, reducing complexity by discarding insignificant ones and eliminating unnecessary layers.  The method improves speed by up to 70% with similar classification accuracy compared to traditional methods.

title: Spiny projection neurons exhibit transcriptional signatures within subregions of the dorsal striatum.
main_goals: To identify cell-type-specific spatiomolecular signatures of direct and indirect SPNs within subregions of the dorsal striatum using RNA profiling in situ hybridization.  The study aimed to reveal the molecular identity of SPNs mediated by differentially expressed genes across striatal territories. This provides a foundation for understanding normal striatal function and region-specific dysfunction in striatal disorders.

title: Comparative spatial proteomics of Plasmodium-infected erythrocytes.
main_goals: To determine the steady-state subcellular location of more than 12,000 parasite proteins across five different Plasmodium species by subcellular fractionation of infected erythrocytes. To compare the pan-species spatial proteomes and their expression patterns to understand species-specific host adaptation processes.

title: Artificial intelligence-based pathology as a biomarker of sensitivity to atezolizumab-bevacizumab in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma: a multicentre retrospective study.
main_goals: To develop an AI model (ABRS-P) to predict atezolizumab-bevacizumab response signature (ABRS) expression from histological slides of hepatocellular carcinoma; to evaluate the association of ABRS-P predictions with progression-free survival; and to integrate spatial transcriptomics with the model predictions.

title: Investigation of the active ingredients of Shuangshen Ningxin Fomula and the mechanism underlying their protective effects against myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury by mass spectrometric imaging.
main_goals: To investigate the active ingredients of Shuangshen Ningxin Formula and their protective effects against myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury in rats.  To elucidate the mechanism of this protection using spatial metabolomics and MALDI-TOF MS imaging.  To demonstrate the utility of MALDI-TOF MS in detecting the spatial distribution of small molecule metabolites in the myocardium during pharmacological research.

title: Maternal nutritional programming shapes the cerebral landscape.
main_goals: This review paper examines the impact of maternal obesity on offspring neurodevelopment.  It explores the concept of nutritional programming as a potential intervention strategy.  The authors highlight the use of techniques such as fluorescence in situ hybridization, spatial transcriptomics, and tissue clearing in studying these effects.

title: The effect of El Niño and La Niña episodes on the existing niche and potential distribution of vector and host species of American Cutaneous Leishmaniasis.
main_goals: To model the potential distribution of five host species and four vector species associated with cutaneous leishmaniasis, comparing their distributions under different El Niño, La Niña, and neutral climate conditions.  To identify host-vector pairs based on niche overlap. To understand the impact of climate variability on the transmission dynamics of cutaneous leishmaniasis.

title: Functional Proteomics Characterization of the Role of SPRYD7 in Colorectal Cancer Progression and Metastasis.
main_goals: To analyze the role of SPRYD7 in colorectal cancer progression and metastasis using functional proteomics.  The study aimed to elucidate the dysregulated SPRYD7-associated proteome and its interactors.  The results demonstrate that SPRYD7 is a novel protein associated with CRC progression and metastasis, potentially representing a novel therapeutic target.

title: Spatial Mechano-Signaling Regulation of GTPases through Non-Degradative Ubiquitination.
main_goals: To investigate the spatial regulation of GTPase ubiquitination in endothelial cells under shear stress.  To identify WWP2 as a novel regulator of RAP1 ubiquitination and its role in maintaining endothelial barrier integrity. To demonstrate the consequences of WWP2 deficiency on ROS production, lipid oxidation, and inflammation.

title: Spatial and single-cell profiling of the metabolome, transcriptome and epigenome of the aging mouse liver.
main_goals: To investigate how spatial location within the liver affects cellular aging trajectories.  The study integrated spatial transcriptomics with single-cell multi-omics data to reveal zonation-specific age-related changes in metabolism, epigenome, and transcriptome.  The findings highlight the influence of microenvironment changes on cellular epigenetic, metabolic, and phenotypic outputs during liver aging.

title: An integrated study to decipher immunosuppressive cellular communication in the PDAC environment.
main_goals: To decipher cellular communication in the pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma tumor microenvironment using spatial transcriptomics, scRNA-seq, and bulk RNA-seq.  To identify key cell types and genes involved in immunosuppression. To highlight the role of TAMs and the LGALS9 gene in PDAC immunosuppression as potential therapeutic targets.

title: Preinterventional Third-Molar Assessment Using Robust Machine Learning.
main_goals: To develop an AI system to aid dental decision-making for mandibular third molar removal using 2D orthopantograms.  The system uses a U-Net for region detection and a ResNet-101 for classification of M3M superimposition and root development.  The goal is to improve efficiency and reduce risk in clinical practice.

title: Hidden Markov random field models for cell-type assignment of spatially resolved transcriptomics.
main_goals: The paper introduces SPAN, a statistical spatial transcriptomics cell assignment model, to annotate cells or spots in SRT data using predefined marker genes and spatial information.  SPAN combines a mixture model with a hidden Markov random field to model spatial dependency. The effectiveness of SPAN is demonstrated through simulations and real data experiments compared to other spatial and non-spatial clustering algorithms.

title: Multiscale modeling of drug resistance in glioblastoma with gene mutations and angiogenesis.
main_goals: To develop a multiscale agent-based model of glioblastoma that integrates cellular dynamics, signaling pathways, gene mutations, angiogenesis, and therapeutic interventions to explore the interplay between genetic mutations and the vascular microenvironment in shaping tumor evolution during treatment with tyrosine kinase inhibitors.  The model aims to unveil the impact of these factors on drug resistance and guide the development of potential therapeutic strategies.  Model predictions are validated by integrating single-cell RNA-seq, spatial transcriptomics, bulk RNA-seq, and clinical data from GBM patients.

title: Probabilistic cell/domain-type assignment of spatial transcriptomics data with SpatialAnno.
main_goals: SpatialAnno is an efficient and accurate annotation method for spatial transcriptomics datasets. It leverages a large number of non-marker genes and qualitative information about marker genes without a reference dataset. The method estimates low-dimensional embeddings for non-marker genes while promoting spatial smoothness.

title: Unraveling temporal and spatial biomarkers of epithelial-mesenchymal transition in colorectal cancer: insights into the crucial role of immunosuppressive cells.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Trajectory Inference', 'Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: To characterize the spatiotemporal relationship between EMT-invasive malignant tumors and immune cells in colorectal cancer using scRNA-seq and spatial transcriptomics.  To identify key genes involved in CRC progression and the role of immunosuppressive cells in tumor formation. To provide a framework for delineating the spatiotemporal invasive niche in CRC.

title: Single cell spatial analysis reveals inflammatory foci of immature neutrophil and CD8 T cells in COVID-19 lungs.
main_goals: Develop a suite of mathematical tools (SpOOx pipeline and MDV software) for statistically significant co-location analysis of immune and structural cells in COVID-19 lungs using 37-plex imaging mass cytometry.  Reveal a cellular map of inflammatory network and identify spatial and temporal links between specific immune cells and alveolar progenitor cells during diffuse alveolar damage. Provide the pipeline and visual-analytical tool as a resource for spatial analysis.

title: MIGGRI: A multi-instance graph neural network model for inferring gene regulatory networks for Drosophila from spatial expression images.
biological_context: Drosophila embryonic development (eye and mesoderm development)
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Gene Regulatory Networks inference']
main_goals: The main goal is to introduce MIGGRI, a multi-instance graph neural network model for inferring gene regulatory networks from Drosophila spatial expression images.  It addresses the challenges of GRN inference from large, complex spatial image collections by using contrastive learning to extract features and a multi-instance GNN for semi-supervised learning.  The method achieves strong performance in inferring GRNs for early eye and mesoderm development, exhibiting robustness to missing data and enabling interpretable analysis.

title: Spatial transcriptomics uncover sucrose post-phloem transport during maize kernel development.
main_goals: To visualize gene expression patterns in maize kernels during grain filling using spatial transcriptomics, identify cell populations and molecular markers, and elucidate spatial storage mechanisms of starch, protein, and oil. The study aimed to provide insights into functional genes controlling agronomic traits in maize kernels.

title: Inhibition of ATR opposes glioblastoma invasion through disruption of cytoskeletal networks and integrin internalization via macropinocytosis.
data_modalities_used: ['histology images', 'protein expression', 'spatial transcriptomics', 'intravital imaging', 'time-lapse microscopy', 'super-resolution imaging']
main_goals: To investigate the role of ATR kinase in glioblastoma invasion.  To determine if ATR inhibition could be a therapeutic target for reducing glioblastoma invasion. To elucidate the mechanism by which ATR inhibition reduces glioblastoma invasion.

title: Spatial Transcriptomics Resolve an Emphysema-Specific Lymphoid Follicle B Cell Signature in Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease.
biological_context: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) and Emphysema
covered_analysis_steps: ['Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Differential gene expression analysis']
main_goals: To characterize the transcriptomic signatures from lymphoid follicles (LFs) in smokers with and without COPD and varying degrees of emphysema.  To identify emphysema-induced transcriptional networks and determine the association between centrilobular emphysema and genes involved in B cell maturation and antibody production.  To resolve the role of off-targeted B cell activation within LFs in autoimmune-mediated emphysema pathogenesis.

title: Single-Cell RNA Sequencing Technology Landscape in 2023.
main_goals: This review paper provides an overview of single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) technologies in 2023, including droplet-based, plate-based, and hydrogel-based methods, as well as spatial transcriptomics.  It highlights the advantages and disadvantages of scRNA-seq and single-nucleus RNA sequencing (snRNA-seq) and discusses the technical challenges that need to be addressed in the future. The paper emphasizes the significance of scRNA-seq in understanding cellular heterogeneity and gene expression dynamics.

title: Imaging in Type 1 Diabetes, Current Perspectives and Directions.
data_modalities_used: ['Positron-Emission Tomography', 'Magnetic resonance imaging', 'electron paramagnetic resonance imaging', 'spatial omics']
main_goals: This commentary piece outlines the role of molecular imaging in T1D research and highlights the need for further applications of such methodologies in T1D.  The paper discusses the use of several imaging techniques to quantify beta cell mass and function in Type 1 Diabetes.  It emphasizes the need for better monitoring technologies to improve therapies for the disease.

title: Spatiotemporal single-cell transcriptomic profiling reveals inflammatory cell states in a mouse model of diffuse alveolar damage.
main_goals: To analyze inflammatory cell states in a mouse model of diffuse alveolar damage (DAD) using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics.  To identify the role of fibroblasts in neutrophil recruitment during DAD-induced neutrophilic inflammation. To characterize the spatial organization of the inflamed niche in the lung.

title: An adaptively multi-correlations aggregation network for skeleton-based motion recognition.
main_goals: The main goal is to propose an Adaptively Multi-correlations Aggregation Network (AMANet) for 3D skeleton-based motion recognition.  This network aims to capture dynamic joint dependencies in skeleton graphs using three key modules: Spatial Feature Extraction Module (SFEM), Temporal Feature Extraction Module (TFEM), and Spatio-Temporal Feature Extraction Module (STFEM). The method also utilizes relative joint coordinates via moving frames of Differential Geometry and a Data Preprocessing Module (DP) to enhance the original skeleton data.

title: Preneoplastic liver colonization by 11p15.5 altered mosaic cells in young children with hepatoblastoma.
main_goals: To identify mosaic genetic alterations of the 11p15.5 locus in the liver of hepatoblastoma patients, characterize their functional consequences (IGF2 overexpression, H19 downregulation, alteration of liver zonation, enriched extracellular matrix and angiogenesis), and identify a 60-gene signature in 11p15.5 altered hepatocytes using spatial transcriptomics and single-nucleus RNAseq.

title: Hexagonal image segmentation on spatially resolved transcriptomics.
main_goals: This paper proposes hexCNN, a novel hexagonal Convolutional Neural Network for hexagonal image segmentation on spatially resolved transcriptomics data.  It addresses noise and dropout in spatial transcriptomics data by extending an unsupervised algorithm to a supervised learning method and using a regular hexagonal convolution. The main contribution is improved accuracy and ARI compared to existing GNNs, demonstrating the effectiveness of hexCNN in noise removal and preservation of biological signal.

title: SCAN: Spatiotemporal Cloud Atlas for Neural cells.
covered_analysis_steps: ['Visualization', 'Integration with other omics', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis']
main_goals: To create a database called SCAN that integrates and analyzes massive multiomic data from the nervous system, covering over 10 million cells and data from over 900 species.  The database provides interactive interfaces and integrated functions for efficient data exploration. SCAN aims to benefit neuroscience research and promote the development of diagnostic strategies for neurological disorders.

title: Spatial transcriptomic interrogation of the murine bone marrow signaling landscape.
main_goals: To apply spatial transcriptomics to fully mineralized tissue (mouse femurs), to combine spatial transcriptomics and scRNAseq to define the cellular components of the stem cell niche, identify cell-cell communication, and gain a comprehensive understanding of local and global SSPC regulatory networks.

title: Spatial transcriptomics reveals unique gene expression changes in different brain regions after sleep deprivation.
main_goals: To define the impact of brief sleep deprivation across the mouse brain using spatial transcriptomics.  To identify differentially expressed genes and their regional variations after sleep deprivation.  To develop bioinformatic tools for registering tissue sections and gene expression data for brain-wide comparison.

title: WEST is an ensemble method for spatial transcriptomics analysis.
main_goals: Propose WEST, a weighted ensemble method utilizing ensemble techniques to improve performance and robustness in spatial transcriptomics data analytics. Compare WEST's performance against existing methods on synthetic and real datasets. Demonstrate that WEST is a significant advance in detecting spatial domains, offering improved accuracy and flexibility.

title: Single-cell and spatial transcriptomics: Discovery of human placental development and disease.
biological_context: Human placental development and disease (preeclampsia, gestational diabetes mellitus, advanced maternal age, recurrent pregnancy loss, placenta accreta spectrum disorders)
main_goals: Review and summarize current literature on using single-cell and spatial transcriptomics to reveal cell heterogeneity and cell-cell communication in normal and diseased human placentas. Discuss findings in specific placenta-related diseases and outline future directions.

title: Deciphering normal and cancer stem cell niches by spatial transcriptomics: opportunities and challenges.
biological_context: Normal and cancer stem cell niches
covered_analysis_steps: ['Cell-Cell Interaction Analysis', 'Spatial Domain Identification', 'Spatial Gene Expression Analysis', 'Deconvolution']
main_goals: This paper reviews how different spatial technologies are used to identify normal and cancer stem cells and their niches. It discusses the opportunities and challenges in characterizing these niches, often hindered by technological limitations, and highlights computational solutions used to address them. The focus is on understanding the interplay between stem cells and their microenvironment across normal development and tumorigenesis.

title: Spatially resolved gene expression profiles of fibrosing interstitial lung diseases.
main_goals: The study aims to dissect gene expression profiles between lung microenvironments (LMEs) within and across different types of fibrosing interstitial lung diseases (ILDs) using digital spatial profiling. It identifies differentially expressed genes between LMEs within each condition and across histologically similar regions between conditions. The study also aims to classify previously unclassified ILD cases based on gene expression profiles and unsupervised clustering.

title: Spatial proteomics of Onchocerca volvulus with pleomorphic neoplasms shows local and systemic dysregulation of protein expression.
main_goals: The study aims to assess the protein inventory of Onchocerca volvulus neoplasms and identify proteins associated with tumor development using laser capture microdissection and mass spectrometry. The protein expression in neoplasms was compared to normal tissues to identify proteins linked to the development of PN and systemic dysregulation of protein expression contributing to worm mortality.

title: Spatial, transcriptomic, and epigenomic analyses link dorsal horn neurons to chronic pain genetic predisposition.
main_goals: This study investigates the genetic basis of chronic pain by analyzing dorsal horn neurons. It utilizes a multi-species approach integrating rhesus macaque snRNA-seq data with human and mouse datasets to create a species-conserved atlas of neuron subtypes. The research then links chronic pain genetic variants to regulatory elements in these neurons using single-nucleus open chromatin analysis.

title: Targeting immune-fibroblast cell communication in heart failure.
main_goals: The study investigates the molecular mechanisms driving immune-fibroblast cell communication in human cardiac disease. It identifies a disease-associated fibroblast trajectory and the role of IL-1β signaling in the emergence of specific fibroblast populations. The findings highlight the potential of targeting inflammation to treat tissue fibrosis.

title: The Microscope and Beyond: Current Trends in the Characterization of Kidney Allograft Rejection From Tissue Samples.
main_goals: This review discusses current and emerging tools for characterizing kidney allograft rejection from tissue samples.  It highlights digital pathology, multiplex immunohistochemistry, transcriptomics, and single-cell/spatial transcriptomics as key areas of advancement. The aim is to improve the reproducibility and granularity of rejection characterization, moving beyond the limitations of the Banff classification.
